I'll admit, I was quite skeptical of this game. I thought it looked really good since the trailers, but didn't want to pay full price. It was 25% off and paid for it and don't regret it at all. Seeing as I don't feel like doing a NG+ in elden ring with the DLC right around the corner, I'm satisfied playing through this game for the time being. Really great game so far.

TLDR: After beating the game (Pre-patch) and (Post-patch) I think I start to understand the errors of my ways. But I'm happy with the small balance change so keep it up devs. No the game is still difficult so don't worry souls elitists. Also managed to get all achivements. So overall I can recommend the game. It's the best souls like out there, which is not from FS.

After two playthroughs, I understood, why I struggled in some parts. You have to be patience and don't buttom smash like ZUG ZUG ME SMASH. I'm now enjoying the game far more after some small changes of my playstyle. The machanically part of the game is not perfect but you get used to once you understand it.
I had some improvements I wanted to see in the game and I felt like the devs heard me with the respec system being locked away after CV. Now you can respec after BRBH. Thank you so much for this devs. You going the right direction with the update. Now I have complained about the blocking and parry system alot, but I felt the window for it was very small. I was too impatient to time it right. But some weapons counter fable attack is def to small with the current parry window. The glaive is exception.

Mechanics:
It's very unique in some ways. Perfect blocking and parrying can be rewarded and come in to save your puppet strings. Sorry I had to lol. It's not a perfect mechanic, but you will end up getting used to it. Just be patient about.
If you are struggling with surviving, I will recommend take a look at your p-organ. You can make a good defensive build while remaining heavy hitting as well.
Dodging is not totally useless, you just have to time it right, since you have less i-frams compared to FS games. So don't panic roll, blocking is your friend.
Rally system is also part of the game, when you miss the perfect block but normal block instead. You will take small damage, which you can regain if you hit the enemies as long you don't get hit while regaining back the HP.

Enemy design:
Let me start of with.. Why does so many enemies have so many delay attacks? Elite / unique mobs have either sluggish delay attacks or just insta attacks. It is hard to read and it feels kinda unpredictable. But yeah they are tanky and merciless. On a short note some of them have been nerfed a little so they shouldn't be to harsh to deal with. You just have to be little more patient when to attack and not.
The grab attacks looks pretty similar to other attacks. Again is it gonna be a grab or normal attack? Looking at you SWM.
Fury attack is kinda not my favorite design. These red delay attacks makes it really annyoing to try and perfect block. Delay attacks are the worst kinds of attack, you can put into these type of games. You can't change my mind on that. If it is to prevent dodge spamming, I'm sure there is other ways to deal with it.
Since the enemies are little taller, you can end up with terrible camera angles. Without spoling too much, but there is one boss, which can make the camera angle pretty damn awful. Since I don't wanna spoil his name, here is a little nickname for him: Aldrich the odd looking beast.
Overall enemies could have been designed little better, but if you fight them enough, you will shred them without thinking about it.
Enemy design is ehh 6/10.

Bosses:
The bosses sufferes from the same awful thing. Can you guess what it is? Delay attacks that is correct .So yet again you gotta be patient and watch out for the window to block or parry the attack. But don't be to passive, mix in both defensive and offensive combat style.
Normally I didn't mind second phases, except for BFF and her 3 phases. Multiple phases in this game was used little too many times. No all bosses needs 2 FULL hp bar. Look at FS souls games again, and count how many of them has 2 phases in BASE game.
Gank bosses are still not fun. I dunno why game companies keep adding gank bosses. Stop it. Looking at you BRBH. Update the BRBH is not too terrible of a gank boss fight, but just very annoying. Looking at you bunny with the puppet string.
Now from time to time it really do feels like I'm playing DS2 with ''enemies having perfect tracking'' Like bruh what is this tracking? I still stand by this.
Update Archbishop, King of Puppets (first phase) and Simon got a HP nerf. Not only did Simon get his HP nerfed same did his damage. I'm okay with these changes. Good job devs.
GMOTS is prob the worst designed boss ever created in the souls world. How the heck did that abomination get to be in the game. I'm not happy about that thing avoided the nerf hammer, but I guess I will continue cheesing it lol.
NP fight is cool and all, BUT for the love of videogames. NEVER EVER have a NPC who keep talking during a boss fight. It is so freaking annoying to listen to and it makes it hard to focus atleast for me. Yeah yeah I can just mute it, but still bad design choice.
CV and KoP are prob my favorite fights.
Overall I will give boss design a 6/10.

I will admit, it's kinda cool you can dismantle weapons and then put the parts on other handles and such. Update since the stagger got buffed, it might make heavy weapons little better than before.

Last thing I really dislike about this game is the camera. I had some issues with it, some fights makes it even hard to see what is going on. Little more zoomed out wouldn't hurt.

Well I have some pros
- Music is pretty good.
- Game really looks amazing.
- Game runs pretty smooth, I was kinda shocked by that.
- Storytelling is pretty good, you kinda grow into the all NPCS, atleast I did. Also few ncps that made me want to punch them so hard in the face. So yeah the character development is well done.

Since I have beaten the game two times now. I have to admit, I sucked and got my butt clapped by the bosses. But soon after I learned how to get good, I have been the one bullying the bosses, minibosses and elite mobs. But I still hope we see more changes in the future. But let's wait and see. I do wanna thank you devs for the glaive, it's now my go to weapon of all time lol.
Let me finish saying it's a very good game. It's has to be played as Lies of P and not like FS souls games.
With this said, let's not deny this game has some flaws still. But I can def recommend it. It's tough, but not impossible to beat.

[quote][h1]THE GOOD[/h1]
+Cool concept for a game in general. The story is a dark twist on the tale of Pinocchio, during an evil puppet uprising. It's packed with heart, interesting characters, and thought-provoking ideas.
+Awesome weapon building system. Aside from boss weapons, every weapon you find comes with 2 parts: its blade and its handle. The blade determines a weapon's speed, range, and damage types, while the handle determines its moveset and damage scaling. On top of all that, each part comes with a special ability, meaning every weapon will end up with 2 abilities. Tinkering with wacky combinations is highly addictive, and it doesn't cost any resources, so you're free to experiment as much as you want.
+Amazing art direction. Enemy designs are especially well done, featuring some of the scariest robot designs I've ever seen.
+Many quality of life improvements to the Soulslike genre. Quests are easy to keep track of, the respec system is very generous, running back to the boss arena is always painless, and the armor system isn't tied to your appearance.
+Many layers of build customization.
+Good incentives for multiple playthroughs.
+Great level design and atmosphere.
+Great bosses overall.
+Great soundtrack.[/quote]
[quote][h1]THE BAD[/h1]
-Much of the difficulty comes from an abundance of delayed attacks that make no logical sense.
-Borrows an excessive amount of ideas from other Soulslike games. Blurs the line between homage and ripoff frequently.
-Lack of precise numbers in your skill tree choices. Something might seem good, only for it to suck when you actually try it out. I had to do a lot of respecs because of this.
-Other than a few different endings and some more open areas, the game is very linear.[/quote]
[quote][h1]SCORE: 95%[/h1]
Assembled with care.[/quote]

It's a souls clone, so you know what you're getting.  I liked this  when I first started playing, and it's also grown on me as I've played it more.  This is a solid game.  I do wish that these sorts of games would figure out how to have sprint and dodge be separate buttons, though.

Pretty good game, 7.5 / 10

It's clearly a copy of FromSoft games (mostly feels like DS3 + bloodborne with a tiny dash of Sekiro) all mashed into one package but it manages to have some amount of identity nonetheless. It doesn't quite measure up to the source material but it comes closer than most. Sometimes it feels like they tried too hard to be similar. A strong DLC with less linearity could round up this game's quality.

Pros:

- Some mechanics are actually improved: stagger + critical attacks, weapon durability being actually fun to manage.
- I feel all 3 damage stats in NG are balanced and work well.
- The P-organ update system adds a bit of RPG/build decision making in NG, which is cool.
- Good sound design
- Weather and day/night system was a nice touch

Neutral:

- Weapons are Ok but nothing too crazy or well executed. In practice, the vast majority of handle + blade combinations are not worth using at all even if the idea was nice. Most boss weapons are not great and the scarcity of update materials make that even worse as you won't even try them. In the end I had more fun playing with different weapons in DS3; in Lies of P, I find myself always coming back to the same 1-2 weapons that work way better than the rest. The movesets are bit boring and samey.

- Boss design is Ok with some highlights (Scrapped watchman) and some very bad bosses (e.g the swamp monster who can spam his tentacles at you then link this into 2 red attacks with no windup) 
In general, long combos and very fast startup/windup are used a bit too often to catch the player by surprise, which doesn't feel as good a nice dance like Gundyr or Nameless King)

- Story/universe is OK. Can't say the item descriptions which are supposed to cover the lore are very well executed. Perhaps a translation issue?

- Combat is OK and better than most souls like but still can be a bit janky when you least expect it (like terrible tracking, stagger working in mysterious ways, etc)

- The legion arms are OK; some (1) are waaay more useful than others. I don't think it adds enough to the gameplay to remove the customizations that are 1 handed vs 2 handed, ranged weapons, dual wielding, etc.

Cons:

- The game is extremely linear and as much as I prefer a linear game over a crappy open world one, I feel like this is going too far. DS3 is way more linear than DS1 and it still has sequence breaks (e.g, Dancer), and path choices (e.g swamp vs cathedral) This make NG+ quite boring and even NG could be spiced up if you could go get your favorite weapon early on instead of having to wait 9 chapters. Almost all chapters have the same rythm which goes like 3-4 elites, 1 boss, go back to hotel for NPC talks; rinse and repeat.

- Level design is a bit boring, with mostly horizontal town-ish environments and very predictable layouts and shortcuts. Sometimes there's a shortcut one minute after another for zero reason.

- Zero fashion. You find a complete clothe uniform you like and use it for the entire game, most are ugly. Hats look even worse.

- How many 2 phases bosses do you possibly need? Less is more. Keep it a surprise. Also you can tell one boss has a second phase because the first phase is pretty tame and the hp bar melts rather quickly.

- Some very strange choices like providing a respec statue that is unlocked later than another, more convenient option.

- The trash mobs are really, really trash and just an inconvenience. I feel they struggled to nail the stagger/hyper armor balance of these vs elites.

People were recommending this game saying it was as good as a FromSoftware title and that fooled me into buying this game, this games falls short of the level design of FromSoftware every fight in this game is a gank, dogs will be literally jumping through windows to eat you, almost every thin bridge in the start of the game has a guy to shove you from it and make you die of fall damage, I died more times to fall damage in this 5 hours than I did in my entire life playing DarkSouls 1 and 3. Most big enemies are damage sponges that have so much life and do so much damage that I'm forced to kite them for minutes (and apparently they heal life when not being attacked, same with bosses), the game wants you to perfect parry enemy to the point of most of them having some sort of hyper armor during their attacks, and some of their attacks (red attacks) are literally immune to normal parries, but not like in Sekiro that you can still dodge the unblockable attacks because the game ignores your dodge invincibility frames during those attacks, they literally state that "you cannot guard nor dodge you can only perfect parry them", anything bellow a perfect parry in this game will still damage you, and as someone who has perfect parried Genichiro, for some reason I cannot grasp the timing in this game, this game is very unpolished and if you are coming from a FromSoftware title expecting to have the same feeling when you do a backstab or a parry, you will be feeling very uncomfortable. If you wish build variety, like to play as a caster build or ranged, there isn't any, this game is limited only to melee weapons, the "builds" in this game consist in choosing the weapon you want to use and the four amulets you want to use with it, and since the "armor" of the game has no visual difference (since the costumes are the things that changes your appearances and they have no stats tied to it) you will just be choosing the bigger numbers to a more and more abstract progression were every piece have literally no other value than the spreadsheet being bigger, most of the game has this aspect were you never feel immersed in it, it's not like darksouls were everything is so subtle and full of intention, in this game you will interact with a pile of debris and it will have a pristine paper telling you all you need to know about the lore of the facility, everything just feels like a game and it breaks my immersion. So to end this rant I will say, this game can be good for you if what you want is to feel that you started a newgameplus with a level zero character in some sort of sick masochistic challenge run, and I can respect that, I intent to keep playing and to change this review if something new comes up,  but if you want to just have fun with a good souls like, this game is the same price as Elden ring, and that game will be way more repayable and fun and will not punish you harshly for every failure. Now if you want BloodBorne for PC, this isn't, I'm very sorry to say that, but it isn't, that's all.
It's simply the best soulslike game not made by Fromsoft. Nothing else comes close.

Let's start the review with this: this game has several Malenias💀

I just finished the game. I loved the art, the style, the combat, the narrative (except not being able to tell Eugenie something if you don't speak to NPCs in a VERY specific order :( ). I loved the parry system and I do not find it too strict unlike many people, and this is my first parry heavy soulslike. Somehow found this game to be easier than Elden Ring. I do recommmend this game for anyone who likes soulslikes and aesthetics, as there were several instances where i was like "omg so prettyyyy AAAAAAAAAAAAA". It just feels solid and complete (haha pun intended). So yes, VERY VERY MUCH recommend this game. It just feels like the developers love from's games and just wanted to make a game with a slighgtly different take on the narrative and combat. And this game runs at 60 fps on Steam Deck which is *U N H E A R D* of for modern AAA. 

There's one major thing I do not like about this game though: SOME bosses that comprise of 2 separate FULL POWER bosses, which make the entire boss fight last about up to 10 minutes, which is too much. There are several issues with this:
1. The first phase feels like a giant very difficult runback.
2. You are unable to properly learn the boss's moveset.
3. Makes the second phase 50% luck based 50% skill based (or at least that's my experience).
4. Fatigue because the fight is very very long.

By far the worst example of the above is the big swamp thingie (I made up the name but those who have beat him know who I'm talking about). That's the only boss who I, after several hours, had to use specters on. Literally the only one. AAAND I wanted to give up on the opera house boss when i found out about the second phase, but I was lucky there, which I don't feel like should be the case in a souls-like game.

And theres one minor thing that i found distracting: some layouts in the cities dont make sense and feel like an afterthought.
looks hella cool1

This is a difficult one:
I tried really hard to like this game. And I'm sure many people love it.
But since the question is: Do **you** recommend this game?
My answer is no.
I guess waiting for a bigger sale is best if you want to try this. 60 Bucks is definitely too much though.

Now I think the whole "Bloodborne for PC" thing, is nothing that anyone thinks is 100% a fact.
But just in case, this is of course not 1:1 Bloodborne, but I'll talk about gameplay in a bit.

First a few points that I really like:
The art style/setting is really cool and the game is pretty, on top of that it runs really well, and no weird fps cap, so that's a big plus.
The weapon mixing mechanic is definitely cool and worth experimenting with. Even if I ended up using BOSS WEAPONS for the majority of my play-through.
Getting your last flask back for attacking is also a cool Idea, as you can limit the maximum flasks, but still give the player a chance to keep fighting on, it really rewards playing well.
The shortcuts and fewer stargazers (bonfires) are something that I like, it's a good way of designing levels for souls likes, however this doesn't mean the world is interconnected much.

But now I have quite a few points that cripple the experience, and hence make me dislike this game overall.

Combat: The combat is probably the most important or at least one of the more important aspects in souls-like games.
I've heard that the combat leans on Bloodborne, to which I must honestly wonder if those people actually played Bloodborne. This game has rallying, but it's a bad deal. In BB you can rally damage that you take, which encourages to keep close and keep fighting, if you get hit, you retaliate. Here, you can only rally from a block, which means you trade stamina for the chance to get health back. Alternatively you could trade stamina for not getting hit, by dodging. People like to complain that DS3 made dodges too good, too universal. However this games rally mechanic isn't really an answer to that. Also on that note: It works off of blocking, a mechanic that BB threw out the window altogether, again I don't see how this is like BB. 
What's also vastly different from BB is the parry mechanic, which doesn't rely on shooting someone in the face as they start to swing, but rather leans on Sekiro. This leads to one of my main complaints:

This game feels like it has an identity crisis.

Parries work like in Sekiro, you do a timed block to deflect, however the attack patterns do not have that same level of Rhythm they had in Sekiro. I think that it is incredibly hard to recreate that type of combat, and it didn't really work here.
On top of the off feeling, you do not have a posture bar. Instead of breaking your enemies posture to deathblow them, we get our typical critical attack. So instead of parrying and doing a visceral/critical, we get to fill an invisible posture bar with quite a few deflects, to then crit.  This doesn't feel rewarding, not at all.
I was constantly stuck between trying to play DS3 and Sekiro.

Fake-out bosses: This is also pretty annoying to me. I don't mind if there is a boss or two, that has a hidden second phase. In fact, I love fighting Sister Friede for instance. However this game does it too much, and more often than not it's obvious from the get go. You hit that boss once or twice, and you know: wait a minute, there will be another health bar. After several bosses in a row that flop over, put me in a cut-scene and then go into phase 2, it's tiresome.
Transitions mid combat are so much cooler, and add to a fight. Instead I get put to a fixed place after a cut-scene...

Tracking and Range:
A lot of attacks have insane tracking and movement. Often enough an attack looks and feels like it would be easy to zone out of, only for the boss to zip over and track your ass. I have no problem with getting chased or a game dictating a Rhythm where you can't zone, or kite. But this game doesn't really do that. You get a slow, heavy, overhead attack from a pretty stationary enemy only for said enemy to zip closer once they actually swing.

With a fully realized world, interesting characters, great voice acting, great pacing, interesting lore, tons of weapon options, loads of variety topped off with an amazing soundtrack, memorable bosses and satisfying addicting gameplay, this game truly has it all. The gameplay is a satisfying blend of Bloodborne, Sekiro and takes a lot of inspiration from the Dark Souls formula. As a passionate fan of the genre, I cannot recommend it enough. Please support this dev and do yourself a favor and get this game. You won't regret it.

So far the game is good. One element I like is that the story is properly explained. This is a nice addition to the Souls-Like style if you are tired of games being obscure just to copy Fromsoft. No need to go watch a video just to figure out what is happening. No need to feel like you've missed a dozen NPCs.

Edit:
After more than 40 hours, I want to add that this is a very good game. The second half of the game is very hard as well. You do need to "git gud" to stand a chance. In my experience, 3 or 4 of the bosses will take 20+ tries. With one more boss to go for me, it might be  a lot more than that. It can be frustrating because I do feel like these devs (as well as Fromsoft) still add way too many spastic moves for second phase bosses. I'd rather have one long and rational boss rather than one that devolves into insanity. All that said, the game is great and I recommend it to anyone that actively enjoys the official Souls series. The quality is that good.

TL;DR: If you're a Soulsborne fan, the developers have made great strides in recent updates to make this game a much better experience. If you were put off originally like me, a big Soulsborne fan, consider giving it another try.

As a big fan of the FromSoft Soulsborne games, having gotten all trophies for all of them bare Sekiro, I was eagerly waiting for this on it's initial release but was left  disappointed. Originally this game lacked the balance you'd see in a FromSoft games, it didn't have that "fairness" of knowing something you did wrong that led to your downfall, meaning you could do better next time. I got all the way to the end of Lies of P originally, but was so sick of it that by the last boss I simply opted for the "bad" ending and sold my first PS5 copy.

Now, I'm happy to say that the game is in a much better place than it was when it first released. There's still some "total BS" moments (one boss inflicting a status debuff, which you then cure, only for it to immediately be re-applied simply shouldn't be a thing) but they're much fewer and further between than before. The games' mechanics seem to actually serve their function rather than being barely noticeable - purposefully guarding attacks to reduce damage and following up with attacks to regain some of that lost HP is actually meaningful now, whereas previously it didn't seem to do anything. "Perfect Guards" where you guard at the right moment seem achievable and I'm able to actually do so reliably in a way that feels good, whereas before the window to pull them off seemed much too narrow. There are even some noticeable mechanics in the game originally that I didn't even know existed, like breaking weapons from Perfect Guards because of the efforts the team have made to bring more balance to the game's difficulty.

Definitely consider picking this up if you're a fan of the genre. I've thoroughly enjoyed my more recent playthrough compared to what the game was like on it's initial release.

This game is a little bit shit.  I love fromsoftware games and i've played a lot of souls likes.  The problem lies of P has is that the gameplay feels like any other poor souls like.  

it wants to force the player into using it's cumbersome perfect block system.  Even though i has all the basic souls like mechanics.  Players are punished for attempting to avoid damage and dodge attempts don't provide real i-frames.  

I hoped the story at least would be interesting enough to incentivize pushing through but after 9 hours playing the story feels stale.  it also feels like they're afraid to make any reference to pinnochio (lost opportunity really).  For reference i'm at the church and Andreus.

Speaking of the story this game is linear.  There's some decisions around the 'lying' mechanic and there are times where you backtrack to complete a side quest of sorts.  But aside from backtracking i have yet to find any branching directions that didn't dead end.

There's also a poor guide for learning mechanics in game.  I can't find anything in the game that explains which of the two stats associated with most weapons is Strength.  I figured it out myself but it's not made clear.

I appreciated the story in this game FAR more than how Fromsoft typically handles theirs
Namely in that this game isn't drenched in pure Nihilism. 
There are a lot of sad things that happen, but simultaneously there is always hope.
The things that you are doing make a genuine difference, and people show appreciation for your actions throughout the experience.
I actually wanted to hear every word of dialogue and read every note because of how much better the game overall handles storytelling
And making you feel invested in the world, rather than punishing you for showing interest.

I had a blast playing the game and here are some of my points both positive and negative: 
Aesthetic of the game is great, the steam-punk theme fits great and NeoWiz did a great job with the art and level design, weapon design, all in all props to them.

The weapon abomination system as I like to call it where you combine a handle and blade of a weapon is a refreshing really cool system and props to the developers for creating it. 

Boss design is really great and enemy variety is plentiful, each area that you visit feels fresh even tough there are some re-used models or enemies. 

My only complaint is that this game was designed to be played with fast weapons, in my experience I beat the game as a strength (Motivity) build with the sword from the Parade Master, found it looking the coolest, but man, some of the other motivity weapons are really slow (as they should be), but the enemies and bosses in the later half of the game become really fast for those weapons to even be viable. 
Another issue is that enemies have incredible poise, while you cannot even swing without getting staggered from a light attack, which sometimes can be frustrating. 

The legion arms are another great addition to your arsenal and blast huge damage even without you speccing into intelligence (Advance). 

The game didn't feel unfair at any point of my playthrough, which is a huge mistake that other souls-like games face, where the artificially increase the difficulty with really anti-player monster placement or bloating enemies with stats. Every problem had a solution, you just had to be creative or look around. 

Overall, I had a great experience with the game and strongly reccomend it if you are having that soulsborne hunger but want something fresh, the gameplay will feel familliar, yet really different.

Lies of P is a good souls-like game with the familiar gameplay loop. Go from checkpoint A to B. Kill all monsters to get resources for levelling up & upgrading gear. Unlock shortcuts & checkpoints. Kill bosses. If you’ve played a souls-like game before you will be familiar with the gameplay loop.

Lies of P is more story focused, or atleast tells a story so it’s easier to follow. Unlike Dark Soul games that tells the story heavily with the environment & item descriptions. Lies of Ps’ story is good but can be confusing at first. Characters talking about something that will happen. For example, “We have seen more X in this area”, but when you travel there nothing has changed yet. Very small things that don’t really take away from the story.

The game is also very linear with very little exploration. The game is also relatively short, I think I finished it in 40 hours & I can see people finishing it much faster than that. It’s not necessarily a bad thing, I prefer shorter games with higher quality content than big games like Starfield & Skyrim, where most of it is low quality content just so they can market it as “there’s a lot of things to do”.

For some people, understandably, 40 hours is not worth 59,99€. I however think it was worth the cost. The game is incredibly optimised, even the demo was optimised when it came out. It’s, sadly, very refreshing to buy a product that feels finished. It also has replay value with New Game+ if you enjoy the gameplay & are interested in more of the lore. You need to play the game at least two times to unlock everything. You also understand the story much better & therefore see the world with new eyes. I hope that makes sense.

The combat is good but enemies have a lot of delayed attacks so if you really dislike that I don’t think this game is for you. The combat feels very rewarding if you master perfect blocking. The weapon arsenal is decent & you can even take weapons apart. Mixing handles & blades to make a weapon that better suits you. You can't disassemble boss weapons.

Don't mind my low play time, I played the hell out of this on a Playstation before I picked it up on Steam. 

This game is un-fucking-believable. 

From the day it was announced, I'd been waiting for this to come out. At the time, I really wanted to play Bloodborne, but I didn't have a way to play it thanks to the lack of a port. The game reminded me of Bloodborne because of some of the architecture in the game trailers, as well as... y'know, tailcoats and stylish weaponry. 

Fast forward a good long while, and Lies of P is out. I preordered it on Playstation (and at this point, I'd already played fully through Bloodborne numerous times), and got to play this a few days early. 

And let me just say -- if you've heard anyone say "ohh, it's just a Bloodborne clone lol"? They're either seriously stupid or haven't played Lies of P. Maybe they just weren't paying attention. Lies of P is *inspired* by Bloodborne, but by no means is it a clone. 

-It has its own art aesthetic. It'll remind you of Bloodborne, but it won't just *feel* like it.

-A unique style of souls combat with a pretty equal focus on guarding/whittling enemy posture and dodging/going full-offensive.
 
-The game *looks* incredible, and it's super well-optimized to boot. Seriously. I'm using a GTX 1660 TI with 16 GB of RAM, and I'm getting a solid sixty frames with maximum settings (except for volumetric fog quality, which is set to high. ONE setting is lowered.)

-There's a good weapon variety, and you can even mix-and-match movesets and certain abilities between weapons. 

-The story is presented in a way that's easy for people who don't like reading a million pieces of external lore content to understand what the hell is going on. It's mysterious in places, as per the soulslike usual, but you won't be totally clueless about what's going on in the game's world.

-As far as I know, the game is still looking to receive a good handful of updates. Some new weapons and outfits here and there, and any bug or gameplay fixes that might be necessary. 

-The enemies? Great. The bosses? Great. Enemy placement, how about? It's all great. Tons of enemy variety, and they're all perfectly creepy for the settings they're in.

-The Riddler? Uh...

-The music? Gorgeous. The boss themes are pretty good, but the collectible vinyl records are something else. 

-The characters? I found myself getting more attached to the likes of Venigni and Eugenie than *most* people in, say, Elden Ring or DS3. 

I could go on for a lot longer, but I'll wrap it up with one last statement -- if the geniuses at NEOWIZ continue to make these games, then FromSoft is finally gonna have REAL competition in the soulslike genre. Lies Of P is NOT fucking around when it comes to fun, and it's REALLY not fucking around when it comes to challenging. Eager for more from Neowiz, because they've displayed nigh mastery of their craft here. 

And they removed Denuvo. :3

Genuinely the best Souls-Like game I have ever played. The combat and movement fixes a lot of problems that games like Dark Souls and Sekiro have. It has an easy to pick up control scheme and memorable characters and areas. Even all of the bosses are pretty memorable. The game itself has quite a bit of replayability and it was completely worth it trying to 100% the game. Lies of P nails the "beautiful environment" that many souls-likes have. There are so many chances to stand in the middle of a bridge or on a cliff-side and just observe the beauty of the broken world. It's sad to see that this game didn't get as much recognition as I feel it deserved. As one of the games I paid full price for (which I haven't done in a LONG time), I feel like the cost was worth it.

P.S. if you get the chance to, PLEASE listen to the music from this game. Either the full OST or just the collectible records will do. [spoiler]"Feel" actually made me tear up.[/spoiler]

Mechanically, this game doesn't feel like a Soulslike. It feels like an extremely safe clone of Dark Souls 3.  There are a handful of unique flourishes, but they're all minor. If Elden Ring hadn't come out, that might have been enough. The problem is that Elden Ring pushed the envelope a lot; not just by switching to an open world design, but by increasing player mobility. Pinocchio can't jump vertically, move faster than a jog, or run longer than his stamina bar says so. It makes combat and exploration feel very dated.

The setting suffers from having come out a year after Steelrising, another Soulslike with a virtually identical plot and setting: Revolutionary France/Victorian England has achieved a Golden Age on the backs of magitek robots, but they've rebelled and slaughtered the citizenry; the most human-like of the robots must now save mankind from its hubris. The Pinocchio angle feels like a subtraction from Steelrising's take, replacing a unique aspect of the story with a retread of a classic story. The Gepetto character being named....Gepetto reinforces the feeling of cold, corporate regurgitation that isn't helped by the CEO stating that they chose Pinocchio specifically because it's a story that's well known in the West.

The whole package just winds up feeling boring, like it's going through the motions. What unique quirks exist wind up sidelined before a game that looks and plays exactly like games I've played before. At least games like Code Vein made me feel like there was *something* going on, even if I didn't understand it. There's no art here, no feeling. 

With the year we just had, there's not a lot of reasons to try out a game that is so determined to be competent and nothing more. Lies of P isn't a bad game, but it isn't a good one, either.

Perfect guarding is so much fun, and I love a lot of the mechanics that this game has that make it different from other souls games. Guard regain is like Bloodborne's Rally mechanic that lets you regain health, but it's not as simple as take a hit and then hit them back. Fable is basically what replaces a mana bar, and it lets you do really awesome attacks or give yourself buffs, depending on the weapon you are using. Legion arms are kinda like a second mana bar that you use for even more unique attacks, from shooting flames to firing a grappling hook at enemies to throwing a small puddle of acid on the ground that does literally nothing because that one arm sucks. I also really love that your "armor" in this game doesn't change your appearance and lets you customize purely for cosmetic reasons, it's just a shame that this is used in a game that has very limited cosmetics and no character creator. However, the narrative and art design of this game is so amazing that it makes up for that pretty quickly. 

Also there is a kitty at the hotel that you get to be friends with :)

Bloodborne is a 2015 action role-playing game developed by FromSoftware and published by Sony Computer Entertainment for the PlayStation 4. Bloodborne follows the player's character, a Hunter, through the decrepit Gothic, Victorian-era–inspired city of Yharnam, whose inhabitants are afflicted with a blood-borne disease which transforms the residents, called Yharnamites, into horrific beasts. Attempting to find the source of the plague, the player's character unravels the city's mysteries while fighting beasts and cosmic beings.

I am a bit frustrated with how ill-conceived a modern souls-like game can be. I understand that there are some special "rules" for a game to be considered soul-like, but damn... Does ANYBODY really like this horrible way of switching between consumables with the help of the mouse wheel IN THE MIDDLE OF THE FREAKING FIGHT? Why couldn't they just implement a simple panel with 1-9 bindings at the bottom of the screen? You can literally run out of some consumables you took to a boss, and then they become an empty item slots that you have to scroll through simultaneously tracking the boss's movement to avoid getting killed.

The weapon system is bad. At the beginning, I was very passionate about finding a new weapon since it seemed to be a really rare occasion and their appearances were pretty varied. After a few hours, I still couldn't figure out a suitable way of fighting or the best weapon for my style until I found the dagger. Since finding the dagger, I realized there is no sense in having anything else. You literally lose the opportunity to move fast and waste your stamina with 2 VERY LONG attacks with a minor increase in damage.

The timings of actions are somehow ridiculous. I often find myself pressing the buttons related to specific actions (like drinking HP potions) just to realize it was a little bit too soon for it to work after a dash/jump, etc.

Some UI decisions are really bad and not well thought out. Why in god's name place three health bars of the bosses you are fighting with in the bottom middle of the screen? Multiply it by 5 characters (3 bosses, me + specter), and you have a freaking firework of pixels lighting up the screen. Now let's try to figure out what's going on to avoid getting killed. 

At the beginning, P's robotic hand seemed to be an interesting way to diversify fights, but later I found myself feeling bored with Legion crafting options as well as their usages.

A lot of useless medallions. 

Although you can equip only 4 pieces of "armor," the first one is completely straightforward, with just one stat for physical damage reduction. On the other hand, the other 3 pieces consistently confuse you whenever the location changes. They have a variety of stats, starting with physical damage reduction and finishing with defense against specific types of attacks (slash, pierce, etc.) or elemental resistance, which constantly varies depending on the location you are in and the monsters/bosses you are fighting, so you need to go over and over to achieve maximum resistance for a certain case.

Overall, the game feels interesting, the graphic is very good, and you really want to walk across Krat city learning its history, but I think that the complexity of the gameplay comes mainly from the very poor fighting system rather than the actual complexity of the monsters and bosses.

Lies of P is not a perfect game, but, in my opinion, it is the single greatest soulslike ever made. It stays true to what a Souls game is, while taking it in a new direction. Simultaneously, it not only understands why souls combat is so addictive and what makes From Software's level design so immaculate, but it also executes these flawlessly (for the most part). What's more, is the developers have been sure to innovate and make this game their own. And to top it all off, Lies of P runs flawlessly both on steam deck and my PC.

I highly recommend Lies of P at full price, but if you can get it on a sale, that's even better.

Amazing.
Besides the Timothée Chalamet simulator this game is excellent.  Really enjoyed it will revist.

I was enjoying this game until the second half.

Having playing both Sekiro and Elden Ring prior to this title I have to say the boss balancing is unreal. Fights go from halfway enjoyable to absolute cancer by the later half of the game.

Literally every single boss has 5-10 hit constant combos on repeat with a parry mechanic that isn't frame perfect and has an absolutely ridiculous delay. If you want a game where i have to parry 15 times in a row just to get an attack window, you better have a parry mechanic that is both intuitive and responsive. Bosses have almost no decent telegraphing either which makes it more of a rote memorization rather than any kind of intuitive response to game cues. This isn't fun at all.

Honestly the lore and feel of the game are great but the bosses are just about the worst I've experienced in any soul like title. They aren't fun to learn, they are irritating, and I have almost no desire to finish this game after wondrous fights like the door guardian and walker of illusions.

Amazing game. If you like FromSoftware games, especially Bloodborne, and are a fan of Souls-Like, this is probably the best Non-FromSoftware Souls-Like there is. Fun weapons, fun features, fun gameplay. Enemy design is awesome and so is the level design. Not to mention the nice soundtrack. Awesome game, give it a shot!

Having finished the game, the story, both are amazing, would be my top 3 souls like if this game obviously wasn't budget restricted in terms of mob variety, their moves and art in the environment. 

Bosses: - most are hard, only 2 or 3 i killed in 1-3 tries, what's amazing about them is how u learn through the game to use every mechanic making it easier to play against them but they naturally get harder and harder as you get better keeping the battles interesting and not that frustrating through the whole game.  What I didn't like about only some of the bosses was the artistic design. But it wasn't that bad since they all fitted the story and the lore of the world very well.

Mobs: - Bcs some of them were to easy and way to plentiful of the same kind and u would run through some of the lvls (bonfire checkpoints) for an hour just 1 shoting mobs and finding collectibless until you got to the next boss. 

Mini bosses (mob bosses)  - they have good moves and are challenging just the right amount, but there's very little of them in variety.

Story is 10/10 unlike in other souls games u'll understand what's happening here, it's simple, might be unsatisfying at the begging, but at the final act it all made perfect sense.

Music: It's almost always there, every boss has it's own and you can collect a dozen to chose from and listen at the hotel where u speak to ur friends and upgrade everythn.

the game is basically a 10/10 for a AA game, it's a double a game that almost feels like a triple a one. Obviously it's not as epic and vast as elden ring, but in my opinion it's close enough to be worth the 60 bucks.

TL;DR: Found several annoying issues that would be easily fixable within half a year of release, yet they are still present for several months. Not worth the money when they can't even get the basics right.
Refunded after 2h!

Long Version:
Started the game and hit the first major bug after 2min when I noticed the Y-Axis inversion does not work correctly.
Fixed that with a little google search (by inverting the Steam Controller Input Option, game still has the unresolved bug!)

Picking up new items gives you a short description but the text goes away so fast that nobody can really read it.
After a short google I found out that this was not only an issue for me but lots of people.
Ignored this (extremely annoying) design issue and noticed that other hints/help text, which are like half as long or shorter than the item pickup text, stays on for three times as long....feels like devs/designer did not really care with such basic things that can honestly make or break a first time experience like mine.

And finally, the grand finale: I almost immediately started trying to understand the damage system by carefully hitting easy enemies with a single hit and repeating multiple times after dmg number disappears.
To my surprise I got very different numbers each time. First I figured it might have to do with some hidden hit boxes on the weapon or counter damage or something.
Turns out: The base damage in this game has a built in RNG roll of about 20%!!!
Putting aside the fact that I think Souls Like games should try and keep their damage systems as consistent as possible to reward player skill instead of RNG I could maybe understand rolling for 5, maybe even 10%. But a fifth of your possible max damage is just stupid. Makes trying/comparing builds, weapons and items a nightmare, not to mention hitting enemies just feels inconsistent in general (duh!)

With these kind of problems in the first 2h of a game that has been out for almost half a year I am thoroughly disappointed considering the price of 45€ (not to mention the outragous 60€ for this mess when its not on sale)

Lies of P is the best souslike, rather than simply copying the formula like some do, the game uses the formula as a template and crafts it's own identity around it. The game is incredibly fun and deeply engrossing, I found myself deeply concerned for it's characters and heavily invested in it's story. Honestly one of the best games I have ever played. 120hrs, max level 561 at NG+7, because I didn't want to farm for Ergo so I just decided to play through it 7 times. All achievements in 73 hours. The game is a hecking masterpiece. The game definitely has more pros and cons in my opinion.

The one thing I enjoyed most about this game is the direct approach to the story. There in no confusion to where you need to go, you are guided throughout the story. Side quests aren't as direct but they are side quests for a reason. Also, main NPCs in Krat Hotel also have character side stories as well. Lastly, there are 3 total endings in the game, so while you don't have to do all 3, to get the most out of the game I would recommend getting the endings, especially the True Ending. 

All in all, it's a beautiful game. It is quite challenging but for those that have played Sekiro, you may find the guard system to be very familiar and the overall difficulty to be similar in comparison as well.

I would highly recommend the game. Enjoy the story, be patient and yeah, enjoy!

The status of this review will not change until the issue of boss ergo not being distinct enough is resolved. When players get boss ergo it is grouped in with all other ergo. Unlike other souls-likes which have similar uses for boss souls, such as demons souls, dark souls 1, Dark Souls 2, Dark Souls 3, and Elden Ring, boss soul items in Lies of P are similar in appearance to standard soul items, and don't ask players if they are sure that they want to use them. I collected dozens of standard ergo along with multiple boss ergo, which I eventually used at one time to increase my level. I had not realized that I had used the boss ergo until I discovered that they may be used to create boss weapons at Alidoro's shop. From my understanding, there is no way to acquire this ergo again until the next new game cycle. Due to the inability to acquire previously used boss ergo, and thus, attain a weapon that I was highly anticipating, I was without any alternative other than to create a new save in order to attain this weapon. Though one is able to discover that boss ergo is unique and may infer that boss ergo possibly has an alternate use from reading the item description, those who are not paying close attention to the item(s) description will be likely to use it without realizing. Adding an additional prompt which asks if the player wishes to use an item that will have alternative use later verifies that this item has use beyond ergo gain, and prevents players from unknowingly using a unique ergo item. I have enjoyed many aspects of Lies of P, but find the aforementioned issue too glaring to ignore.

Having just finished Bloodborne and picking this up almost immediately afterwards, I have some serious gripes with people saying it fulfills a BB itch. The game lacks all the inspiration and polish that any Miyazaki game does. 
-Running looks like you're on ice, you just spin around with no weight to your movement. 
-The voice acting it atrocious. Inconsistent mixing, tone, and bizarre intonation.
-Parrying is unrewarding and requires knowing the enemy's attack pattern before you get hit. You have to predict the attack, not react to it. 
-Oh yeah, the dialogue is horseshit. Every character you meet is like "tee hee I know something important you don't know but I'm not gonna tell you, aren't I so important?" Instead of adding to the intrigue, it just grates on you.
-Uninspired bosses. R1 to victory when they spaz out and miss you. R2 when you finally break their, uhhh, poise(?) to do a not so critical attack
-Speaking of poise, there is no poise in this game for bigger enemies. You can only get an attack or two in because as soon as they miss you, they wind up for another one and you can't interrupt it. Good luck parrying that! Have I mentioned that the parrying sucks?
-Level design sucks. "Hey here's 5 enemies you can face one at a time down a pretty wide street. Btw, when you're done, here's a shortcut so you can skip them next time." I have yet to die in the game, but instead of taking the shortcuts after spending my souls, I would just kill the enemies again because it was so dang boring otherwise. 
I am attempting to refund this steaming pile of garbage as it ultimately boils down to being pedo bait with the 14 yr old looking MC. Maybe they should have spent more time making the game play better than on his hair effects.

The game is so good that I straight away jumped into NG+ right after finishing NG, which is something I have never done with any game before, not even Elden Ring or DS3. 

The music has absolutely no right to go this hard, Quixotic and Memory of Beach will give you a rush that Einaudi compositions do. 

This is easily the best souls like I have ever played, and I have played quite a few. It even surpasses FromSoft games in some aspects, like how none of the bosses are just HP sponges. The fights are tough but fair, and the game has a great parry system that is almost as good as Sekiro's. 

And the best part? The game runs flawless, like no stutters or random crashes or random bugs, absolutely nothing. This is how modern AAA games should be made, cant wait for the next game!

Easy 10/10.

One of the rare Souls-like that equal and in some ways exceeds FromSoft. Did 2 playthroughs on Game Pass but had to buy it and finish my 100% run on Steam. 

I was skeptical of Lies of P when I played the demo and the blocking and dodging felt off but after playing it after release it was clear the developers took people's feedback because they really locked it down to being damn near perfect.

While it is "harder" than other Souls-likes, it demands your engagement with the parrying and dodging mechanics unlike FromSoft games where you can just block your way to most victories. I find it also a little more forgiving too because levels are not that far apart so you could grind a couple more levels to help if you do get stuck.
absolute banger

It's quite commendable how a studio that's not affiliated with From Software can pull off the formula so well as they did.

The mechanics, the world and the general feeling is similar to Bloodborne but nothing ever feels copied or directly taken from it as Lies of P has its own story, setting and mechanics, and executes all of it very well.

It's not perfect and has some jank in its movement and writing, or rather translation, but for a first try in the genre it's shining a light on the studio that's beyond promising.

Ahhhhhh YES, this was such a good game...it scratched that itch that Sekiro left behind so long ago for me. Some brutal, punishing moments for sure but an overall very satisfying experience from beginning to end.

Amazing story, fantastic combat, outstanding world design...the game does hold your hand a little though unlike other souls-likes where you have to figure things out yourself or unravel a cryptic mystery...its actually harder to miss things simply because there's a marker that appears when there's something to do or someone to interact with, but that's all entirely subjective as to how you feel about that type of stuff. I didn't mind personally, just something to mention I suppose.

Loved the "build your own weapon" system where you can dismantle weapons you find or buy (excluding special weapons) and mix'n'match handles and blades. The handle determines the style of attacks while the blade determines things like damage and a number of other variables...I have to admit though, having jumped into this just after the Wo Long Collab, you start off with Guan Yu's Glaive that's classed as a special weapon and feels EXTREMELY nice to use, though it isn't overpowered and you can't really upgrade it until way later in the game.

There's no armour in the typical sense of like helmets, chest pieces, etc...you get parts that determine armour, weight, resistances and so forth, whilst your visual appearance is entirely cosmetic and you'll unlock a few different outfits as you go. They are unfortunately limited to full body outfit, hat and glasses so no real deep "fashion souls" thing going here if that's what you're all about.

An all in all very interesting experience, not at all what I had initially expected and a great addition to anyone's souls-like collection!

Now...about that post-credits scene...

Maybe the best FromSoft inspired game? Tons of quality of life improvements (like, when NPCs have new info for you, their portrait appears on the fast travel screen), tons of customizability, total build freedom, fun weapons, fun creature design, bosses are tough but fair, boss runbacks are super chill, summoning an NPC helper is smooth, and the whole thing is challenging without being bloated with ten billion trash mobs like Lords of the Fallen. To top it off, the story is engaging even if it's not ~deepest lore mysteries~. Just a totally polished experience top to bottom
If you like bloodborne, you will love this game.

THE GOOD

There are a lot of good things like the visuals and music, but they're all stolen.

THE BAD

PLAGIARISM

I have played many Soulslikes. I have played many games that took some of From Softs elements and mechanics and made it work.
I played good and bad versions of those. I played Mortal Shell, I played Lords of the Fallen, I played Nioh, 
I played the Surge.
Never have I seen a game that steals literally everything, down to the fonts.
This game is not a Soulslike. This game is blatant plagiarism.

First, I was enamored with the game. "Hey this reminds me of Bloodborne". "Hey this is also like Bloodborne, but worse".
And all of those "Hey this is just like Bloodborne, but worse" quickly started adding up.
The game is "very heavily" inspired by Bloodborne. You have a poorly implemented Rally mechanic,
you have status buildups that work exactly like in bloodborne, the atmosphere and aesthetic played a "heavy influence", the dark symphonic music, the dark victorian theme, some assets are direct copies, the story is a direct copy of Bloodborne ("puppets gave gone mad, except you" vs. "hunters have gone mad, except you").
Then there are giant rolling balls you have to avoid, the gestures (the shrug animation is literally identical), 
the quest NPCs behind windows, the cube being basically the Elden Ring teardrop flask, the entire Ergo system being literally Souls, the corpse run to pick back up your Souls, boss Ergo being boss Souls you trade for a choice between a weapon and an accessory, moonstones are titanite shards, the healing pulse (Estus) replenishing after killing a bunch of enemies existed in DS3, the prosthetic arm is from Sekiro.
Hell, even the bad camera when fighting large monsters and EVEN THE FONTS are copied from Bloodborne.

Even the basic mobs are a 1-1 copy of bloodborne's torch huntsman. Every time I fought one I expected it shout "Away! Away!"

COMBAT

- The game is basically Bloodborne but clunkier
- No animation canceling
- Input action delay
- Action queue / animation stacking
- Slow MC animations, especially in comparison to the opponent, meaning you get stunlocked
- excessive amount of delayed attacks ruin the cadence and rhythm of the combat for me
- basic movement abilities are locked behind the P Guard, like rolling twice with reduced delay (and even then the delay is still there)
- The rally system, directly copies from Bloodborne. It worked in Bloodborne, because you were discouraged from blocking,
there was not even a functional shield to find, you were encouraged to be aggressive and to attack, you could stagger
by being hyperaggressive. In Lies of P, the enemies will be much more aggressive, start long combos you will have to
perfect parry 8-10 times or dodge, meaning you can not really make use of this mechanic that is supposedly there to
encourage you to attack to regain HP. It's just copied without understanding why it worked in BB.
- Stagger is technically a good system, rewarding you for being aggressive. However, in order to actually stagger
once the bar is full, you have to use a (slow) charged R2, meaning you're most likely to eat an attack or possibly 
an entire chain of attacks. The enemies are hyper aggressive, so you are not very likely to find a window to do so.
And once you stagger, the window to position yourself on the red circle and do a visceral attack is tiny, and you will
often miss it if you use heavier weapons. This combined makes this yet another useless mechanic that was copied from
Soulsborne without understanding why it worked in Soulsborne.

Something odd I also found:

- The stargazers are copies of the DS bonfires where you can level up, 
the first stargazer lets you level there, yet from then on, 
you can not level up at stargazers anymore and have to go to the hub


CONCLUSION

Many games keep copying and layering Soulsborne mechanics on top of each other without understanding what made them work, and often those mechanics just clash with each other.
This is another one of those. 
However, this is the most excessive, blatant, shameless, soulless and cynical example of it I've ever seen. 
At the same time, they managed to make the combat much, much worse.
The combat is slow, unresponsive and clunky, your animations are slow, your animations are queued, 
there is no animation cancel, and you will get stunlocked. 
Not even the story has any signs of originality, being a direct retelling of Pinocchio.
It's a shameless ripoff. If I want to play Bloodborne, I'll go play Bloodborne, instead of bad plagiarism of it.
This game is what you get if you tell ChatGPT to make Bloodborne with a Pinocchio story.
There is 0 originality and creativity in this game.
The story is not their own, their graphics, mechanics, artwork, music is not their own, so how am I even supposed to rate it?
I hope From Soft sues for plagiarism.

BY FAR the best souls-like that exists right now, dare I even say it surpasses some FromSoft games. This game was made by a studio which never even attempted a souls-like before, and this is their second game ever, and in 26 hours I had zero bugs. That rarely happens in any game, let alone something of this scope from a small studio.

The game also runs amazingly, very well optimized even for low end PCs (which I have), constant 60 FPS with no drops, everything on high.

I can't think of a single major complaint I have with the game, sure it's more linear than your average FromSoft game but that doesn't make a difference if you love the combat here.

Level design is great, visuals are fantastic, the atmosphere is also top notch, along with sound design and honestly pretty much everything. Took me 25 hours to beat so you could argue it's not that long, but imo quality > quantity.

Eagerly awaiting the DLC.

Do not play this game if you're expecting quality combat.  The combat system is lazily implemented with parts stolen from other souls like games with zero thought or care to how those parts interact.  What you end up with is a slow as dirt playable character who can't react and enemies and bosses who are fast enough you need to react.  This turns the game into a slog where the only option is to throw yourself at something ad nausea until you learn the fight inside and out.  

The game also forces you to utilize the parry mechanic that derives difficulty from unnatural animations that have randomly placed pauses in an effort to "trick" the player.  Additionally, some animation are simply not visible to the player due to the size of the boss.  This is on top of a parry system that drops inputs and often times just doesn't work.  Many times where I am pressing and holding the guard button and nothing happens as you get hit for the full amount.  

This game's setting and story would have had it sitting at the top of the genre but instead it will be known for its lazily implemented combat system.

Edit: List of things I've noticed since this review... more dropped inputs, often time the block just doesnt register.  Enemies can spin on a dime to face you mid attack motion making the dodge mechanic useless.  Seen my weapon pass right though enemies with no damage registered numerous times.  Just lazy, lazy development which is a shame given the story is interesting.

edit edit: just asked for a refund for this game.  The glaring and persistent issues with the combat system make the story not worth seeing such a shame.

Before playing Lies of P, I was very skeptical on whether or not it would be worth it. The instant I fought against the first mini-boss, that all changed. Lies of P is GOLDEN if you like the older-styled souls games (Bloodborne, Dark Souls 3, etc). It implements multiple systems that were used in previous souls game and so much more! The level design so far is genuinely amazing and feels very similar to the shortcut-system used in DS1. The combat feels great and though it's not as flashy as Elden Ring, it is still very VERY exciting. The bosses feel genuinely fun to fight and, in my opinion, fighting them feels like a complete mixture between the parries of Sekiro and the rally-style fighting of Bloodborne. Lies of P is an amazing game and I highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys the Soulsborne games.

lies of p

I've played twice through it, which is now a first (save for leveling up in MMOs), so that's something. And even though I now have all achievements, thanks to saving & reloading, I would still play another time through it. It's just - an absolutely great game. And a great game on its own, even despite any comparison to siblings in its genre.

Performance is just great too: runs very well, very easy, no hiccups whatsoever. Graphics are not amazing by current standards, but animations and models are, and nothing looks off. The faster moving bosses are incredible on screen, and even more incredible when you can react to them.

I love the level design, with its such pure linearity that makes it difficult to miss all items in a run. I like that it's varied enough, and pretty coherent about where it takes you. There's plenty of variety in monsters and environments, and not abusively reused; even the last level brings about a couple of new ones. 

The story is coherent, not overly obscure at it is often the case in the genre, and pretty decent on its own. But it's neither too dull or straightforward to be boring, and playing though it the 2nd time in NG+ still pays off from new perspectives. 

The influence and elements from the Pinocchio book and other stories are such an amazing and tasteful addition. They took the inspiration and made it their own thing, and really in a great way. It's not a rip-off, it's not a cheap shoe-in of some public domain work, it's really a layer of polish and a finishing touch over something that works on its own.

Lastly, there are so many small quality of life improvements to be appreciated throughout, it really makes playing so much more enjoyable. Sure, there are still a couple of quests that can strangely fail when you don't follow a specific sequence, but nothing on the scale of absurdity delivered in other games. And you can wear costumes without any regard to armour, which is great.

Lies of P is the first souls-like game that I've ever attempted to play. Safe to say I was in for a fun, but rude awakening as I booted the game up. With that being said however, I absolutely love this game, and can't wait to finish it.

This has to be one of the better games I have played, amazing and breathtaking graphics as well as a dark take on the Pinnochio story. The combat is fluid and stunning, it feels so good to finally beat a boss that I worked on getting past for hours sometimes even a day or so, just to find out that you need a different Amulet or some other combo of Amulet - P-Organ - Weapon to get past the next one, it's just really fun stuff to have to figure out how all those things will work to make the game bend to one's will. If I didn't have the right setup for a lot of the fights or I didn't find most if not all of the item's in a certain area then I found myself feeling really weak against the different late game bosses and some of the earlier ones too, but I think this was by design because if I was to play and not delve into the game I wouldn't of found out all the crazy plot developments and different enemies to kill and awesome weapons, granted I didn't switch it up a whole lot in regards to different weapons but what I did use were epic. This game is worth my time for sure I am glad I played it.

This game is an absolute masterpiece! I have played and beaten nearly every Souls game that exists up to this point, and this one is easily my favorite so far, even though it's not made by FromSoftware. It's fantastic to see this genre of game receiving love from new developers!

Lies of P has a very Bloodborne vibe to it, so if you enjoyed Bloodborne, you will probably enjoy this game too. Typically, there are always a few bosses in these types of games that I don't like, but in this one, there was only one boss I absolutely hated. Every other boss provided a solid sense of learning how to handle their move sets and progressing further through the fight, which is exactly what I love about these games. The environment is incredibly immersive as well, the dark Pinocchio vibe felt incredibly satisfying to explore, and I continued to find new areas I never knew existed in subsequent playthroughs. 

My first blind playthrough took around 30-35 hours without the use of phantoms. I ended up playing through the game three more times with various weapons, experimenting with phantoms, and each playthrough was a blast! I will likely play through the full game again once the DLC releases.

I highly recommend this game to any Souls fans! It's 100% worth buying!

25 hours of playing, wanting to get the final boss's weapon for ng+. Decided to do the other option given to me thinking it'd do an ending but i'd still be able to fight the boss. Turns out it skips the boss and you can't fight it till the next new game cycle. I feel sick because that means the past 25 hours i've been playing it has become null and void. I feel sick because of that. Why make it so you can't fight the boss if u get that ending? Why do it like that? I hope the developers make it so that boss becomes optional no matter what your choice.

The first 10 hours are a blast, everything after that is obnoxious difficulty porn. It took all the wrong lessons from the newer fromsoft games. Nearly every boss has two full healthbars which is just so obnoxious, and unlike in a souls game there are no alternative routes to explore so you can come back when more competent/powerful, the whole game is a straight line. Your options are either ram your head into a brick wall or mindlessly grind the same area over and over. They almost had something with this game, almost, until they decided that making your game frustrating is synonymous with fun. Overcoming a fair challenge is one thing, mindlessly bashing your head into a wall until either you or the wall breaks is quite another.

Mum, can I have *any FromSoft souls game*?  - No, we have Elden RIng at home.

This game is what mum has at home.

There is pretty scenery, but the world feels empty. Each zone has 2 or 3 mobs pasted about the place, followed by a zone boss that is not difficult. The beauty of soulslikes is the precision with which the mobs do their attacks, and learning to counter them. In Lies of P, I play with one weapon the whole game, and brute force everything with a strong attack. Mobs don't learn, or counter, they just get wacked. Mobs get stuck on the terrain, hitboxes are janky in parts, block timing is weird. The AI is bad, the trash mobs only have a couple of attacks which they seem to do in order. The game provides no challenge, the weapon upgrades aren't rewarding, the Legion Arm can just be ignored. The mechanics of the wishing box seem cool, but it never gets used, along with any item collected (except status cure on spam). No ranged attacks, but that doesn't matter because there's so few enemies to deal with and few novel situations.

The sound effects are awful, the music is great. The scenery lovely, but the filling is sparse and uninteresting. The scene ratio is odd in places, it feels like I'm running around a dollhouse. at times it looks and feels like a 3rd person game from 20 years ago with visual mods and a texture pack.

The story is interesting, delivered by occasional narrative dump. The levels are linear and uninteresting. I reach a new destination, it looks cool, then follow the rails to the next boss, kill it first time ** NB the last act had a couple of challenging bosses.

I keep waiting for the game to 'get good'. but it didn't. The last few acts were definitely an improvement, but it's just not for me. It's a Dark Souls clone, without the sense of wonder and exploration, repetitive mobs, limited weapons and movesets, boring mobs, and a half-arsed story with characters I have zero emotional investment in. 

I really want to like this game, but it isn't holding my attention. I think I'll slog on to complete it and amend this review later if my view improves.

Many familiar mechanics, that I imagine will be heavily compared to that of FromSoftware's games are here, but not without reason, because they are all expanded in a very deliberate way to benefit the distinct experience "Lies of P" wants to be, rather than a replication of what's come before, which many might dismiss it as at first glance. also P organ funny

Sekiro and Bloodborne mixed together with So much originality and passion. This game is absolutely the best souls like ever. It wears its inspiration proudly while also making a totally unique game. It does everything it sets out to do Perfectly. The world and atmosphere is beautiful with incredible enemy designs and bosses. The gameplay is very reminiscent of bloodborne but with a sekiro-style parry. You will need to parry a lot but can't rely on it 100% because you do have stamina. The parry window is Very small, punishingly so as someone who loves sekiro, which is either a plus if you're great at these games or a minus if you can't learn to parry. Overall this game is absolutely phenomenal and i recommend it to just about anyone!

One of the cleanest Souls-Likes I've ever played. To be honest, I was struggling halfway through, I found some bosses to be stupidly hard, but as always in Souls-likes, I just had to git gud. As soon as I broke through that plateau I loved the rest of the game. The movement is okay, can be a struggle at the few "parcour" passages, but in fights it was super nice.
The weapon system is interesting, could've used more of its uniqueness to stand out from other but I did like how you could change the handle for different moveset and the blade for different damage output.
Boss fights swayed a lot for me, I really loved the "human" fights, with the monster fights I found that the parrying was a bit weird and dodging could sometimes feel inconsistent. 

SPOILER:
Unfortunately, I missed the final optional boss fight, to do this you must choose the option to stay a puppet and you will be able to fight it. I will need to catch this one up some time in the future.
Holy sh1t, it's so good.

A souls like that you could practically convince me was made by From Software when it comes to the gameplay's quality. The level design of areas is well thought of and improves as you progress through the game. Great usage of well-made shortcuts over falling in the trap of abusing bonfires which FROM themselves do fall a bit into since DS3. 

Enemies tend to have well telegraphed attacks. I do think between regular enemies not dealing that much damage, stamina costs being a lil lenient and high amount of healing later on regular levels become not enough stress-inducing to my liking of braving the odds. However, the bosses stay relatively balanced until the end of the game, they've offered a good challenge from start to finish with practically no frustration. I do wish the final bosses had beaten me harder especially with an earlier boss destroying me so bad right before them. 

The arsenal of weapons is surprisingly good with a variety of different movesets for similar types of weapons. Boss weapons slap! The weapon mixing system is fun to experiment with as well.

While I don't remember that well boss tracks on top of mind, there are exceptional tracks hidden that you can unlock as you progress through the game! Lots of french lyrics though that not many will be able to appreciate as much as I did.

The world is interesting and the story is good. I'd say some characters are more interesting than the overarching narrative. Just like souls games, you can learn a ton about the story through item descriptions, though you won't be piecing the narrative together in an eureka moment like Elden Ring. Investing time in reading all items didn't bring gigantic satisfaction like some souls games did. Also, for about half of the game the story felt comically similar to Bloodborne for me to the point I had a hard time seeing it as its own. The last quarter of the game did resolve that and showed off far better its own themes and brought its own fair share of poignant moments.

Overall, Lies of P was a great experience with clear flaws that make it fall short of the better From Software games. Howveer, It is a VERY impressive first souls like from Neowiz that I must applaud and just great experience on its own.

So close to not recommending this game, but I feel that the first 70% of it shouldn't be discounted by the remaining 30% just because the latter left an awful taste in my mouth.

So many issues throughout this game that I was willing to overlook because I liked what it was doing in total, but those issues turned out to be the things that ruined it for me. The fact that you need to make crucial decisions within 5 seconds, not being able to fully consider what you're being asked, does not work at all and many people have posted about having panic selected and picked the wrong answer because they weren't sure which gave them the outcome they were looking for. The entire ending of this game is dependent upon you realising that not giving Geppetto your heart is the good ending (giving you access to the final boss), and not doing so not only gives you the bad ending but leads to you slaughtering every friendly npc in the hub world and replacing them with puppets, which is such an absurd tonal shift in the game, painting Geppetto as some cartoonishly evil villain. 

I'm obviously incredibly bitter about this because it has meant that a nearly 30 hour play through, where I tried my best to pick the high-honour option in every dialogue choice, has gone to waste and I'll have to replay the entire game again in order to have another shot at not messing up. I understand that Geppetto is painted as somewhat untrustworthy in latter parts of the game, and some have pointed to that you following his instructions at the end may make you less of a human, which is fine, if I had time to consider this, instead I'm forced into making a decision on a quick timer to force drama but actually leading to such a disappointing conclusion.

Not to mention, as I say, that you miss out on the final boss if you choose this, and the last boss you will have faced becomes Simon Manus, Elden Beast 2.0. He has infinite poise, constantly casts spells (some literally the same ones as Elden Beast), has huge-range attack strings that he'll constantly spam as you run away from spells, has little punishment windows, near impossible to posture break, constantly jumps away across the massive arena, has a huge health pool, need I go on? Such a disappointing boss, that I have to consider my final boss.

On top of all this, the last location is some elaborately huge castle that has no business being so large, I was so tired as I was nearing the top, always hoping I'd be going into the last bit, but there'd always be more. For context, most areas have on average 3/4 bonfires, but the final location has 10, with the distance between each one being substantial. 

Honestly, the majority of this game is really good, though I'm not rushing to replay it like I was with other souls games, but the latter section is just such a huge letdown that I cannot help but feel angry that I wasted all that time to have some terrible ending/final fight thrust onto me because I didn't choose the right decision quick enough.
