Excellent Soulslike that might be the first to justify the genre tag. It starts off aping Fromsoft's design principles faithfully but expands into its own niche with a ton of room for player expression, and a story you might actually parse.

This game is my favorite souls-like not made by From Software, even better than Nioh. It deserves a lot more attention and I hope more people play this over the years.

It really captured everything I love about the genre. How you discover the little bits of lore, the few key choices, how you can miss paths and items, the difficulty, variety of weapons, enemy design, everything.

I will say this though, this is the most familiar souls-like by far, not trying to mess with the formula at all. I played this game *EXACTLY* like dark souls, which for me is not a problem. Another point is that there are a few difficulty spikes and some bosses were made with the player using the shadow summon in mind, so if you try to do everything solo like me, some bosses feel very unfair. Beating them is very rewarding nonetheless. 

Great game and I wish for more games from this studio.

Very close to a good game, and probably the best soulslike not developed by FromSoft, but it's unfortunately ruined by garbage boss design in the second half. Constant use of 2nd health bars, ridiculous delayed attacks that require you to memorise timings rather than react intuitively, never ending combos followed by red attacks that require perfect guards - only for the perfect guard system to be too high risk low reward. Has serious balancing issues between fast and slow weapons too, even worse than the souls games.

Fun game overall, especially the first 60-70% or so, but the final 30% ultimately soured my feelings towards it.

It's a hard game to describe.

Back in the day, there were mods called "Total Conversions", which meant they changed almost every aspect of the game to the point where it felt like a new game using the same foundations. Lies of P feels like a Total Conversion mod of Dark Souls. It would take a giant paragraph to list all of the identical features stolen from Dark Souls, but suffice to say it really does just feel like a super fancy mod.

But a victorian/steampunk re-skin of Dark Souls is pretty fun! The story is well told and interesting. It feels much more like a cinematic journey than Dark Souls where you have to dig to learn the lore. Lies of P has cutscenes and dialog explaining what's going on. The gameplay is good, and I genuinely prefer some of the features over Souls games. For example parrying being just blocking at the right moment rather than being a separate button, and I enjoyed playing with the "Organ" skill tree system. I always wished Dark Souls had slightly more RPG mechanics. The lying/humanity system was interesting as well.

The weapon system in Lies of P really stands out though. I don't think its better or worse than the Souls weapons system, but it's new and fun. Boss weapons that you trade their "soul" for (exactly like Souls games) are static, but all other weapons come in 2 parts that you can mix and match to your hearts content: a blade and a handle. The blade determines the damage type and critical strike animation, while the handle determines the overall weapon animation. Total weight determines the animation's speed. So for example you can take a giant wrench hammer head and slap it on a baton's handle, making a very bulky strange club. Or you can pull a big spear head off a spear and put a knife blade on instead, making a rapid-attack poke stick. Some combos aren't as good as others, for example putting the giant wrench head onto the spear shaft means you poke with a blunt object and it's not as effective--but it's not a big penalty if you have an idea you love. My personal favorite was this giant bone-saw-blade (normally a huge two hander) stuck onto a butcher knife handle, making a fast and deadly serrated machete with good reach.

Visuals are pretty, no issues with performance.

I don't have much in the way of criticisms but here are my main 3:
- Personally I felt no desire to play through it again with another character or even NG+. I just felt like I had experienced everything the game had to offer after 40hrs--which is a great amount of playtime don't get me wrong, it's just that I have hundreds of hours put into each Souls game from making bunches of new characters and doing NG+ runs and still wanting to go back and play more. Lies of P didn't have that appeal to me. I think partially because you are a defined character (P) going through his story.
- The levels are beautiful, though often not well laid out like Souls games are famous for. It just kinda feels like amateurs trying to copy the Souls level design to be honest. The attempt is there, but it's just not pulled off with the level of skill that From Soft delivers.
- Derivative gameplay, it doesn't really bring much originality to the table besides the weapon system and dark-fairytale story/setting.

Overall a solid "B" rating from me. I'm glad I played it, I had a good time. And now I'm uninstalling it and going back to playing old Souls games for the 10th time.

Excellent game all-around and I am eager for the DLC and the sequel.

+ Very well executed take on Pinocchio with engaging lore/story throughout.
+ The several combat systems between the 2-part weapon configuration, the grinder, and the legion make it plenty of fun to try different things to handle a boss or just a tricky path.
+ Generous enough with unlockable shortcuts that you can retry bosses fairly quickly, if not immediately, and without risking using too many resources getting back to the arena.

Flaws that have work-arounds:
- I got locked out of the conclusion of a subplot just because I talked to NPCs in the hub in the wrong order (and at that point, you're just notified that they have stuff to say). It definitely feels like a design oversight that the devs should fix.
- Respeccing the level is unlocked a couple bosses too late (I think). I'm sure speccing is more intuitive for Souls buffs, but people like me coming from action games where the character is configured one particular way probably could just end up with a bad build.
- Related to the respeccing issue: The skill tree is very confusing at first, and the way you fill in slots to access additional tiers (phases) is counter-intuitive. Definitely watch one of those video tutorials fans made on how to get the most out of it. Basically you can access the later tiers much sooner with the same number of points by just allocating them a certain way.
Fantastic game. Lies of P took the Soulslike genre and made it their own. From level design, to NPC interactions, you can tell the developers put a lot of thought into everything. Try it out :)

The initial and the mid part of the game (I would say until chapter 7) are pretty fun. Then it changes radically. I wanted to like this game, but I can't. It's like walking on a staircase where all the steps are fairly balanced, and then at chapter 8 you suddenly hit a wall of 50 steps melted together. At that point it wasn't fun any longer.

The core problem of the game is that it tries desperately to emulate the souls formula, but it misses the mark: there is barely any sense of progress; the bosses appear just huge hit sponges and take mostly no damage at all to your hits; and some of them are just broken, with no possibility to parry or dodge any of their hits. 
The last boss fight I managed to tolerate (the swamp monster. don't give a sh*t about spoilers) gives you no opportunity to dodge, to block or (even less) parry. If the game decides you must get a hit, you must take it and not complain.

I understood that the developers wanted to give a brutal experience because they believe souls players like it, but that's not actually what makes a Souls game good: it's the sense of progress and growth, which I haven't seen at all in their attempt to emulate their formula. 

Another example is the level design. A beautiful and famously well designed level in the From games is the Cathedral of the Deep, in Dark Souls III. The level is famous because it has just one bonefire where all the routes converge, and you unlock all the routes one by one by progressing in the level. This game is heavily inspired by that formula, which the developer put straight on chapter 3. And then on chapter 4, and then on chapter 5, and so on. 

I'm very sorry as I really wanted to like this game, but it has been a very long waste of time. I would consider twice if I'll take anything from this software house in the future.

EDIT:

I know that a common argument against my review would be "git gud". I'm very sorry but I refuse it: gitting gud should be fun, and not a chore. It was fun in Sekiro (best game ever on the genre), it was fun in Elden Ring, it was fun in the Dark Souls series, but not here. If gitting gud for the game becomes a chore, then I'm sorry but I can quit.

Yes I know weapons can scale, and weapon scaling per  characteristic is completely negligible. Good? Bad? I don't care. The important thing is to give players fair methods to defeat hit sponges bosses. And on a certain point onwards, the game does become unfair.

Concerning the specific boss, you enter the arena, and the boss welcomes you with either popping from the ground, or an unparriable charge, and no, you can't avoid either of them. Afterwards, it stands up and hits, and you can block, parry or dodge, but none of them wouldn't work, and you must take the hit. In the end, the only way for sorting it out is to get to their back and stab repeatedly with your fire blade. Then it comes the second phase, where (in addition to the previous behaviour) the boss now can hit you from every side and doesn't stay put. Again: good? Bad? I don't care. It wasn't fun any longer.

MINIMAL SPOILERS WITHIN THIS REVIEW..... I played the demo and despite its few issues it was absolutely AMAZING. Then after a bit of waiting the full game dropped (naturally i preordered it) when i started it was quite difficult and i had a hard time while playing and sadly didn't have time to finish it. After months i came back and finally completed this masterpiece of a game, the final boss was decently challenging but actually felt easier than some of the starter bosses, naturally this was because i had finally grasped the mechanics... I love the weapons in this game most feel unique and purposeful and there is a weapon for any and every playstyle. I would EXTREMELY recommend this game to anyone who enjoyed any Fromsoft game especially Bloodborne for the aesthetic and Sekiro for the gameplay mechanics... Bosses feel genuinely good to fight and it never ever felt unfair well except Luxasia (i hate this boss with a passion), my favourite boss fight was White Lady she was super fun even though i struggled for a few attempts... The world was genuinely so fun and interesting to explore and i always tried to find and see everything before moving on to the next region, i really love the hidden lore details around the place... I feel the endings are satisfying and fit extremely well depending on what actions you chose during gameplay... All in all i'm hoping for more from this beautiful universe especially after that ending cutscene.

I've completed the game:

+ Cool aesthetics

+No Weapon Stat requirements

+ the weapon system is cool, but needs to be unlocked several hours in.

+- The game requires you to go through a skill tree system in order to get abilities you have from the start in most Souls games. But the ability upgrades it can offer are actually pretty neat.

- The endgame has super flail-y enemies and bosses with ridiculous long combo strings and no stamina limit.

- The game starts you with the ability to level up at any checkpoint, then takes it away after the first hour. You only have it back in the endgame.

- Bloodborne except if it had Dark Souls 2 level design and an enemy is going to sneak attack you around every corner in the very first level.

-Tthe game is somewhat poorly optimized. It cranks my 2070 into overdrive even on medium settings.

- The translation is pretty awkward as well.

- Gemini is annoying and I can't shut him up.

First thing to ask yourself: do you like the recent catalog of From Software? (Dark souls, Elden Ring, Sekiro, etc) If so, then you will almost certainly like this game. However, I must stress just HOW GOOD this game is as a souls-like.

This is, bar none, the best souls like experience I have played not developed by From Software. The combat is weighty and feels excellent, there are a variety of weapons and other combat options to choose from, and how you approach various encounters has the proper elements of tension, but with tools to do the job. 

Furthermore, the map design in this game is amazing. It felt like every time I made a decent amount of progress, just when I was starting to worry about the possible trek back through if I died, there would be a shortcut back to a previous checkpoint, or a new one. And in keeping with this, the pacing of the game is almost perfect. It never felt like I had a great deal of downtime between major events, and I was always hyper-focused while playing.

It is a more linear experience than most of from-soft's catalog, but in so doing is a shorter and more focused experience. I was able to beat the entire game in about 30 hours, but that was going back to previous areas and covering every square inch of this title for secrets. You could probably beat it in 20 or less if you didn't necessarily want to find everything.

For anyone with even a passing interest in souls-likes, I cannot recommend this game highly enough. Please play it.

it "feels" very good to play, and the difficulty is needed in order to "make you play" the correct way. I'm only six hours in, but I like it a lot. I love the word-play with the names and the looks of certain characters and I particularly like that the first thing you see in this game is "in honor of the great writer Carlo Collodi" so true, btw.

It seems like a good game[strike]with an annoying problem: key press doesn't register sometimes. Especially during a boss fight with lots of animation. It seems the character is stuck in animation somehow, just standing there doing nothing even when the key is pressed repeatedly. It's not like the character is in the middle of an action, but he would just stand there not responding to key presses, usually for a second or two before actually doing it.

Other than the problem mentioned above, it seems to be a good game.[/strike]Graphics is great, music is very nice and characters are beautifully modeled. Not so sure about the so called 'souls-like' but I like playing the game so far.

I [strike]still[/strike] definitely recommend this game[strike] even with the input not registered issue[/strike].

EDIT: Turns out, what I thought was a problem is actually me being dumb, didn't realize the stamina bar was empty. Since then, I have been having a blast with this game! What a gem!

Graphics is beautiful. Level design to me is great. Story is captivating and narrated well. Plenty of options for weapons as well. The best thing for me is the fighting mechanics! Even though the character can dodge and guard, I feel like the game is leaning much more toward (perfect) guarding. The perfect guard window is very tight which I think is intentional (a good decision by the developers in my opinion) since that encourages players to also adopt dodging into their fighting style, not just 100% guarding. Dodging in this game I think is meant to be used strategically in a sense that you dodge not just to avoid being hit but to also set it up for your next counter attack. Once I got a hang of perfect guarding and dodging, the game started becoming more fluid, somewhat easier and greatly more enjoyable. Very well done!
I guess it is an OK game if you already got bored with elden ring. Plus it runs on mac really well.

Great souls-like game that keeps all the good stuff and removes almost every annoying thing from previous Dark Souls series. The dark twist on Pinocchio tales is captivating and fresh, since it's not that explored in other games despite the big potential of the fairy tales. The plot is given clearly and "normal", comparing to Dark Souls where you have to fish for every bit of information to be able to piece it together. Combat is a great combo between DS' "rolls" and Sekiro's "parry" where you can't do only one, but have to constantly swap in-between them to properly defeat the enemies.
For me bosses are harder then in DS, especially the last 3, while the road between bosses is quite linear and doesn't give any trouble.
There is also a skill tree present where you can adjust your build by getting different passive and active abilities, as well as a special tool with different options to select from for your every need. This all feels more like an RPG and promotes exploring to get all the hidden items for progression.

This is the best soulslike ever made, but tells a unique and interesting story. Combat is incredible, music is great, game is lengthy. It's kind of wild some random developer came out with this thing because it is so well done. However, I WILL point that this game is wholly and entirely derivative to its core. This isn't really even a "soulslike", they have ripped off From Softwares game design beat for beat, at some points it literally had me laughing. Level design, gameplay tropes, combat, npcs, level up waifu, it's all here. So i don't think it's particularly cool to just steal From Softwares game, but alas, moving on. If you like those games, Lies of P is a no brainer recommend. Besides a very annoying last level this game delivers. I got it on sale but it's worth it at full price.

Feels like a game made by someone that played bloodborne once and didn't understand what made it good. Dialog feels like it's written by someone that has never had a conversation with a human being before. 
edit 1:
It's shocking seeing people say this is as good as the average dark souls game when this doesn't even clear dark souls 2. Struggle to solve the basic dark souls enemy design problem of circle strafing and slapping their cheeks being the end all be all solution to fighting anything. Has the classic problem of a boss that's reasonably difficult solo being less than trivial when summoning a single person. You can't pause this game for some reason despite it being single player. Rips off the perilous attack warning system from Sekiro but rather than this being excusable by being improved upon it's somehow worse. Attacks and rolling don't feel as though they have as much weight as they should, the biggest miss being the sound design around rolling.
Takes the health recovery mechanic from bloodborne where lost health can be recovered by attacking enemies shortly after taking damage. However you can only do this with health lost from guarding for some reason. While this does support the decision to not have shields it also slows down combat by incentivizing hard guarding more. The inclusion of a mechanic to regenerate an estus flask charge by dealing damage to enemies is a good inclusion to help solve the problem of pacing being slowed down by having to retreat to a campfire too often. They cripple their own design decision by making this making only function when you have no estus charges left. This means that the only time it will be useful in practice is in boss fights.
The decision to include a weapon durability mechanic is just awful. I've yet to run out of weapon durability from a single encounter and just repair in between fights. This means the mechanic is just a time wasting nothing in practice.

edit 2:
They use the iphone alarm clock sound as an alarm in this game which immediately downgrades it to a 5/10 before considering anything else in the game.
Fine Sony, keep your Bloodborne stuck on PS4. I'll play this instead.

7.5/10 This is hands down the best non FromSoftware souls-like I have ever played. It has similar elements of story telling albeit still having direct story telling, the gameplay is some of the most polished I've played in the genre, it has a great artistic style, and it feels satisfying. 

Its not without its flaws though. My main complaints are the way perfect guards work, the p organ tree, and gear balancing.

Perfect guard has one flaw that games like sekiro didn't: its too precise for the way its implemented. The timing for a perfect guard changes based upon where you and the enemy are standing. Due to how precise the timing is, you need to stand still unless you want it to be super inconsistent. Combine this with things that cannot be guarded and things that are way too risky to try to guard and you can get a frustrating experience.

The p organ (aka your skill tree) feels padded out: The main issue is invaluable things like dodge improvements are in the tree and if you skip them you will make your time worse. The tree is also counter intuitive wherein you actually want to fill out the first 2 phases in their entirety before moving onto the later phases because of how the minor nodes scale with completed full nodes and not the phase itself.

Every defensive piece of gear will only get heavier and there are no lightweight sets unless you go for basically naked or starting gear which in this game is a major downside. HP scaling is similar to Elden Ring but defensive scaling of gear is almost the same way in terms of carry weight. Pretty much every build is going to want to dump a ton of points into carry capacity because otherwise you'll be getting 1 shot with 40+ points into health.  20 points of health and 20 points of carry weight is vastly superior to 40 points of health. I'd even argue that 20 health and 40 carry is more valuable than the inverse.

Really fun and rewarding combat in a great, moody setting. Feels good to finally beat a boss after figuring out how they work from fight after fight. Even if I don't end up using a new weapon, finding it and then trying it out is super exciting. Incredible action game.

This best soulslike game was not develop bye Fromsoftware!

Lies of P not only takes elements from the Soulsborne games it even improves on them. Even exceeding Fromsoftware in some regards like weapon durability. The game has the most mechanically similarities with Sekiro and Bloodborne, but is a clone of neither. You can't play it as you would Sekiro because the Parry mechanic works differently and you can't play it just like Bloodborne either because you have to mix up the Parries/perfect Guards with Dodges. 
Major bosses give you a Spector you can summon to help you in the fight and they balanced better than the NPC summons in the dark souls games in my opinion because they do not make the boss an easy win but they are also not useless either. They come at cost of a star fragment and considering how the star fragment aren't hard to come by means that the cost of a Spector is rather cheap. 
The only real critic I have is that I feel like that the difficulty at said major bosses can spike a bit to much from the difficulty of their area. What gave me the feeling that sometimes the intended you to use the sectors. 
I would recommend everyone that likes the Soulsborne games to give this game a shot as it can defiantly compete with Fromsoftwares games. However, I couldn't promise you that you will like it because Lies of P is different enough from Froms games to be its own thing.
I am definitely looking forward to what Neowiz Games and Round 8 studios develops next!

Do not miss out on this game. It is a Souls game through and through, and one might argue it has the most polished and satisfying Souls combat of them all. Taking the best parts of Sekiro, Bloodborne and Dark Souls combat, and *actually* managing to surpass them - it's an incredible achievement by the developers.

Souls comparisons aside, this game also has a beautiful melancholic atmosphere. The story is extremely dark, depicting a disaster where puppets and zombies rampage through what used to be a thriving human city on Earth. To preface, I really did love a lot of this game. I think there's a lot here for the right kind of player, but I also feel that so much of the game is made worse by very strange decisions that only serve to make the game more annoying. I was not able to finish the game, and I was very reluctant to post a review without doing so, but after putting 50 hours into it, I think I have enough experience to form an opinion. 

This is a fairly standard souls-like game. At the beginning, it's extremely fast-paced, and resembles Bloodborne more than anything, including the plot. At first I was worried the game was *too* similar, but it built up its own world as the game went on and introduced enough unique mechanics to separate it as its own game. That being said, I had a lot of fun playing. Unfortunately, the further along I got, the more the game seemed to focus on a plot that is inconsistent with the gameplay, and gameplay that demanded I use certain abilities over others, rather than allow me to focus on the abilities I found most fun, as it did at the beginning. 

[b]Gameplay[/b]
Like I mentioned before, the game feels extremely similar to Bloodborne at first, but slowly defines itself as the game goes on. Walking through city streets and neighborhoods, the map design felt both fun and realistic, and the enemy placement made sense, and was dense enough to pose a challenge. I found myself just walking around areas after I cleared them just to imagine what they were like before the frenzy.

As the game went on however, closer to the final third or so, it's clear how you're intended to play the game: You either need to dish out damage so fast the enemy can't get an attack in, or perfectly parry everything. By the point in the game I stopped at, the boss Laxasia the Complete, there is no in-between. I felt like most bosses I beat in the late-game were only because they missed me on accident, or they just got stuck in a corner long enough that I was finally able to land a hit. 

I'm very aware that I'm probably just not that good at the game, and that if I tried harder, for longer, I could probably beat it. I've beaten DS1, 2, 3 Bloodborne, and Elden Ring, so I felt rather confident I could *eventually* get good enough. But like I said, it got to a point where I was just hoping to get lucky rather than making any actual improvement. Even a game like Sekiro, which I honestly couldn't beat, took more skill than blind luck. 

There were some very strange map decisions too. One of the side-missions I did had me look across a district for a specific house number. Except only five buildings in the entire district had house numbers, four of them had the same number, and the one I was looking for was on a second-story balcony. I guess the city-planners of Krat had some difficulty with deciding what would go where or something.

[b]Plot[/b]
I don't want to spoil too much plot-wise, and I will say it stays interesting the whole way through, but there are certain aspects that don't make very much sense if you think about them for very long. There's a heavy emphasis on a Puppet King that's apparently mobilizing frenzied puppets to a common goal, but that's not at all how it seems in-world, they just act like their frenzied. Then, after killing the King, there's frequent reference to the puppets losing a sense of direction and aggression, then you go to the next area to find literally nothing has changed. Further along, you can find an audio recording coming from the Puppet King that makes a baseless claim about the instigator of the puppet frenzy, without providing any evidence. Then you have an option to tell someone you "know" who's the instigator, or to hide it. But I have no reason to believe the recording, there is no evidence to support the claim, and the claim was made by someone who apparently sought the genocide of the city. 

There's also a character named Gemini who's more or less attached to you throughout the game. Not once, and I mean *never* does this character provide anything at all to the story. He constantly asks questions the player already necessarily asks themself, and restates the blatantly obvious after any plot development is made. I found myself muting the game anytime this guy started talking, because it really was completely useless.

It's a shame, because a vast majority of the characters were quite interesting, many of them very likeable! I really wanted to see it to the end. I came up with a few theories about what was going on, and enjoyed the dialogue and voice acting very much, but the constant "tell-don't-show" approach to the story made it very difficult to care later on.

--
[b]In conclusion,[/b] I absolutely loved the environment, the graphics, and really the whole first two-thirds of the game. It was fast-paced, with a spooky, interesting plot, and challenging gameplay that demanded variety from the player. As it drew towards the climax though, it started demanding perfection, and the plot felt confused about what story it was even trying to tell. 

I imagine a great deal of my opinion was formed by my lack of skill, and that my annoyance with the plot could be due to my misunderstanding of it. Most people seem to love this game, and I did really like a lot of it. It just seems like significantly less effort was put into the final parts than the beginning.

[h3]tl;dr:[/h3]
This game is really interesting and fun, and gets more so until about the halfway point. Then it just gets harder and more confusing until it demands perfection, and the plot just feels lost. I might just be bad at the game, or maybe the story would've made sense at the very end, but its just not fun to beat a boss and feel like it was almost pure luck that did it.

PREFACE: This is not a "bad" game, but the review is binary yes/no and it is not for everyone, even Soulsborne fans.
In short: If you want a challenge with the feel of the Souls games, this game is for you. If you want a challenge that is also an enjoyable and fair experience, this is not. DON'T get this as your first soulslike either, as even in the genre I'd call it one of the most difficult ones.

The Good: The art style and character/enemy design are interesting and fresh. The lore and setting as a twisted take on the fairytale of Pinocchio is a cool idea with all the references and characters. Recombining weapons is a fun feature that makes combat fairly customizable (although it can feel overwhelming), with different elemental damage, physical damage types, move sets and special attacks. Another welcome aspect is how clothing choices are separate from the "armor" that gives your character their defensive stats. Legion arms remind me of the shinobi prosthetics in Sekiro and give you more gameplay and combat options. You can further upgrade your character stats, skill-tree (unlocking more heals, item slots, etc.), weapons (both blades and handles), legion arms, ... In general, more customization is probably welcome for most players (recommended to check out what the stat upgrades do!) and luckily you can reset all your stats from a certain point in the game. The general areas give you a good amount of room to explore but not too much and are challenging enough with some tougher enemies sprinkled into the lot of cannon-fodder.

The Not-So-Good: While I get that this is a soulslike, it seems like it's trying to copy FromSoft's homework a bit too closely sometimes. How the story is told, the very bleak and desaturated atmosphere, and also the types of areas don't really stray away too far from what you'd expect from the genre and I wish they could have made it less straight-up Bloodborne-meets-Bioshock in setting. The fairytale theme could have provided something more saturated and psychedelic elements with e.g. a narrator voice giving you more information about the world and events when discovering books (or basically anything that isn't just reading text in a menu). Level design, while well-executed with the various shortcuts, can feel a bit uninspired, especially when knee-high suitcases or other objects are the invisible walls that block your way. I am split about the weapons wearing and breaking, as they are mostly just a thing to worry about but it's also fair as enemy weapons will also break eventually. Also not sure why we can't get a proper pause button.

The Bad: Mixing core combat elements from Bloodborne (rally) and Sekiro (deflect) sounds good on paper, but it opens up various issues. In Bloodborne, you take damage even when blcoking but can you get back health by dealing damage to enemies regardless of whether you were blocking or not. In Sekiro you don't take blocking damage (unless you're playing one of the "optional hard modes") and there is no stamina bar, but your posture can break, leaving you open for attacks. While the former is more dodge heavy and the latter wants you to take on your enemies head-on and deflect, they both have mechanics in place that support the play-styles. In Lies of P, you take damage while blocking, your posture can break if you're blocking hits while out of stamina, you don't get the chance to regain health from taking hits that you didn't block and dodging does not feel that useful in most boss fights. "Unblockable" attacks only leave you with the option to deflect perfectly or go out of the way, if at all possible. Adding to that is the very unintuitive-feeling parrying as it needs to be pressed very close to but not quite on the hit and, unlike Sekiro, having no attack-canceling mid swing. Which brings us to...

The Ugly: How the combat comes together with mini-bosses and especially in the true boss-fights is the most frustrated I have been in a long time. The game demands crazy precision and speed with your deflects, which wouldn't be so bad if the boss-design and gameplay mechanics would play into that. Main issues here being 1) how hard it is to read moves with the camera and bodies of large bosses concealing their hits, 2) windup and hit-times being ridiculously inconsistent from crazy long windups with lightning-fast hits to unblockable attacks coming almost instantaneously, 3) the crazy onslaught of hits with precise tracking that some of the bosses put out, especially 2 late-game ones, which also suffer from particle effects blurring a lot of their telegraphs. If blocking was a safer option, if deflecting was more lenient in timing, if attack-canceling existed, if the camera showed the huge fists of enemies coming down instead of leaving them off-screen, if you had different ways to interact with unblockables, the move-sets wouldn't feel so cheap and frustrating.

Overall: Good visual design, lore and music. If you like the atmosphere of games like BioShock, the Souls series and Dishonored, this will appeal to you in terms of atmosphere. If you want challenge, it's an obvious recommendation, but it often verges into the "hard for the sake of being hard" category and the difficulty is in part due to the implementation of gameplay mechanics. Definitely a great first attempt by the developer in this genre. However, there is definite room for improvement and also innovation on the genre.

A combat-focused masterpiece, [i]Lies of P[/i] has some of the most satisfying melee fights of any game I've played in years.  Clean timing and hitboxes, fluidly animated attacks which are readable while remaining challenging, and visual and audio design on-point that will have you savouring every blow landed and feeling the visceral vibration of every strike parried... it's got it all.

I played this right off the back of [i]Lords of the Fallen[/i], a game which I feel is so similar to [i]Elden Ring[/i] (particularly in terms of combat) that it must deserve a far better reception than it gets, simply by virtue of being so similar to the latter game so widely hailed as a masterpiece.  Playing [i]Lies of P[/i] strengthened my belief in the kinship of those two games in another way: [b]to me, [i]Lies of P[/i] is the S-Tier combat game which puts these other two Souls-likes firmly in the A or even B-tier by comparison.[/b]  At least for combat - which is the main draw of the genre, I think - these other games, though great in their own right, feel flimsy compared to the crispness of [i]Lies of P[/i].  I also think it's a more difficult game, but since the immaculate combat also makes it more [i]fair[/i], it's less frustrating despite the added challenge.  I never suffered a death in this game that left me uncertain of what I could've done differently to prevent it; even if there are a few "gotcha" moments, they're always clearly understandable so that they can be avoided with the proper approach on subsequent attempts.

The developers have also done away with some (though not all) of the genre's unfortunate tropes, and gone their own way, often to great effect.  Even just the small touches are refreshing, like icons on waypoints to indicate new opportunities for dialogue or quests, and placing dropped XP outside the entrance to the boss room instead of inside.  The weapon customization system is interesting, though I didn't find myself experimenting with it too much on my first playthrough.  Overall, though we still have some issues like a few long-ish walks back to boss fights and a bit of obscurity to the mechanics at first (maybe I missed a tutorial popup, but I had no clue of the benefits of "Motivity" vs. "Advance" at first, and decided to look it up), it feels like the developers understood and improved upon the genre's formula in making this game.

In conclusion, while I spent a portion of this review lauding the greatness of [i]Lies of P[/i] at the expense of other games, the game is so good that what it has actually done is make me develop a new passion for the entire genre, a more complete understanding of it for having experienced the best it can offer.  I feel as though it has heightened my senses, and I want to return to those aforementioned games to see what I might have been missing, as well as try new and old ones which I haven't yet played.  But more than that, I think I might just go straight back into [i]Lies of P[/i] for an immediate second run - something I almost never do - and delight again in experiencing the pinnacle of a genre I've come to love.

Welcome to the city of Krat where you are either a perfect parry God or you are dead. There is no in between.

Are you a souls veteran like myself? Do you pride yourself on thinking you know everything souls related? Well I got news for you my brothers and sisters; you know nothing. This game will break you down and build you back up, into the true warrior that you were meant to be.

You are P, and you are about to embark into a world steeped in lore and mystery. Should you lie? Should you tell the truth? Who is your Papi and why does this girl have blue hair? All of these questions will be answered, assuming you don't have a stroke from trying to read what the bosses are saying to you; as they beat your freaking @$$.

The world building and story progression here is fantastic and I loved every second of it. The bosses and enemies evolved perfectly and I was genuinely surprised by how well crafted this game was. You will laugh, you will cry and you will revel in your own personal growth as you go from rags to riches in this tale.

I started out as absolute dog sh!t and ended as a white haired, jet black alchemist, wielding the acid legion and critical trident; while flaunting my dominion as the parry God. 

Try Lies of P out today and you too can become the legend that staggers bosses and then falcon punches them in the face.
In my opinion holds its own against Bloodborne and the other Fromsoft games. Not perfect, but definitely fun.

If I had to summarize this game in a sentence, it would be:
Like Bloodborne and Sekiro had a child, with "child" being the operative word. I feel this game does everything Bloodborne does, but in a less-polished way. To be specific, levels feel extremely linear and the combat itself is nothing to write home about. Also, a lot of the "show don't tell" story-telling also just feels sub-par, particularly when comparing to From Soft games.

The theme of this review is clearly "comparison is the thief of joy", and I acknowledge I would likely find much more enjoyment were this my first souls-like. As it stands, however, I feel that the sum of the game's parts don't equate to a satisfying experience for me.

There's a lot to like here, but for me personally I find everything about this game to be lacking.

There's no grey area for recommending games here, so I had to go with the no-recommend. That said, I would recommend this game to someone looking for a souls-like to scratch that itch, but would certainly be including my reservations

I feel like this game has an identity crisis sometimes... One minute you're fighting through a dismal, dark, depressing world; the next, you're fighting a beefcake boss with a WWE intro as his opening cutscene. Or you're listening to your partner cricket role play as a tour guide. I personally didn't find the cricket's dialogue annoying, but I can see why others might. I liked the idea of including a bit of humor despite the mood, but it makes it hard sometimes to fully understand the tone the game is trying to set. There's just such large gaps of rogue machines, death, dismemberment, and disease between the lighthearted bits that it kinda throws you off guard when it happens.

There is a lack of enemy variety and the game is so riddled with ambush encounters and traps that it just got painfully predictable after a while. Nearly every single pickup item had an ambush waiting next to it; and nearly every single enemy wandering around alone was bait for a second enemy to sneak up on you. A good chunk of the first half of the game was spent fighting the same enemy that opened with the same easily counterable attack every time. While the enemy variety got slightly better as I progressed, it wasn't enough to offset the bad taste from earlier areas.

The combat feels a bit too stiff and slow and lacks that extra layer of polish that's supposed to bring all of its components together. There is almost no poise, so there's less of an incentive to opt in for the heavy stuff. You may be unfairly knocked out of charge attacks or certain abilities because of this, which is very important if you want to land visceral attacks.

Contrary to popular opinion, the bosses were a highlight for me. While the overuse of the "second phase boss" was pretty annoying, overall they were a nice throwback to older trial-and-error boss design. Most bosses were a healthy mix of learning the boss' pattern, and general skill.

This game was very close to being a masterpiece, but a lack of polish in areas where it mattered kept it from shining. I'm ultimately torn on whether or not to give a positive or negative review so I'll just consider the current steam rating and decide whether or not I think it should be higher or lower.

A great contribution to the "soulslike" gameplay genre. Absolute blast with it so far. Story is fun, gameplay is responsive, and combat is a fun combo of attack, defense, and evade.

It has stunning art, out of this world music, beautiful story, and lovable characters. It's not too deep when it comes to theme, yet not shallow either. Tbh it's quite coherent comparing to a lot of other indie souls-likes.
Gameplay wise it's a nice mix of Bloodborne+Sekiro+Eldenring. It can be a bit off-putting at first because the combat logic has some unique ideas that souls veterans need to learn and not just play it like *insert souls game here*. The weapons and combining system are extremely varied and a excellent innovation.

The progression of this game is very linear, and that comes with 1 problem.

Limited weapon materials that only come in at absolute end game already.

You can't get unlimited special weapon leveling material even after NG+, ending in discouraging trying different weapons. Despite this oddity, the game is worthy of the new indie souls-like darling reputation it has, and swiftly joining one of my favorites.

Its got good parts, but I honestly mostly did not enjoy my time with this game. The level design is very boring (outside of the amazing visuals) and progressing through levels after the first couple just became a slog of doing the same charged strong attack to bring down simple mooks in a single hit. Then to cap that off every boss felt like I was fighting two back to back which wasn't a lot of fun since I quite enjoyed getting good at phase 1, but then having to redo phase 1 again and again and again just to get to practice phase 2? Add to that the fact that I never really got a hang of the dodging because it was just easier to throw on defense and get perfect blocks, so I never really mastered the combat other than that annoyingly small perfect block window.

There is a good game in there if you want more of this sort of combat, and what is does well it does exceptionally well, but for me the bad parts dragged more than the good justified. If it has a sequel I will probably play it, but I am not doing new game+ on this one.

This game brings a lot to the table. A unique gritting setting,A lot of upgrade materials to upgrade weapons with "unlike Elden Ring" A easy to follow story and still complex story. And a really fun/satisfying parry mechanic.

One of the best souls clones. Great level of challenge, really interesting mechanics, and of course fantastic bosses. I enjoyed the world building and story of the game, although it is a shame that almost nothing from the game feels original. Pretty much everything feels like it’s riffing off of something that already exists, to the point where there is even a joker/Batman character dynamic between two characters, including an eccentric billionaire whose parents were murdered after going to the movies. A well thought out souls like that's a bit too linear for my taste but long, otherwise very mature, which even dared (like The Surge) to take up a completely new setting and its own story, which was also implemented very coolly. The block and groggy mechanics, which were certainly inspired by Sekiro, are well implemented and fun to master. Combined with the ability to regain life lost through imperfect blocks, this mechanic is more than fair and should be able to be mastered by everyone. If you're looking for a real challenge, you can limit yourself, and that's not a problem here.

Hands down, a masterclass in souls-like games storytelling - I dare say even surpassing FROMsoft, and I'm an avid fan of that type of nitpicky easter-egg based stories. Less is more, and just a litte bit of structure goes a long way - all games in this genre, including FROM, should take notes, because this is currently the pinnacle of souls-based games stories. 

Difficulty can be a bit jarring, especially towards the end, but trudging through it really payed off. I don't say this lightly, but this game can easily be called a masterpiece and not many games can reach this praise, at least not in my book. 

Congrats to the devs for taking souls-games to the next level and proving that there's more to the genre than just haphazardly throwing bits of lore here and there and calling it a story. Soundtrack is out of this world, artstyle is on point, ambience and atmosphere are AMAZING, enemies have variety, bosses are not rehashes, combat and weapons are ingenious, scope is just right and I absolutely adore the setting - very much looking forward to the DLCs, sequels and what other fairy tales we'll get to explore.

Towards all the negativity aimed at the difficullty, especially by the self-proclaimed "veterans" around: even though I've finished all Dark Souls, Elden Ring, Bloodborne and other souls-likes - I can safely say that I do not consider myself a great souls player by any means - I'm a sword and board scrub and could never get consecutive perfect parries in these type of games (reason why I never even started playing Sekiro in the first place), thus aiming towards dodge builds mostly. But the difficulty here felt just right and even finished this on NG+ which is a first because of time restraints -  but what worked for me is taking a different approach where i got stuck - what worked a lot of times was going full on aggro with a very fast technique scaled weapon (usually Etiquette), Aegis equipped for easy parries and less than 30% weight for quick recovery and dodging, with a bit of physical resistances on (lose some of the equipment to reach the weight threshold if needed). And just pushing through...again...and again...and again. In the end it all payed off.

 Thanks for an amazing  experience. Truly.

PS: Also has the best damn weapon in any soulslike so far: a freaking umbrella. [spoiler]Nameless Puppet[/spoiler] didn't stand a chance.

Soulsborne at home except that, this time around, it is not a demeaning joke. Believe all the people saying that the guys at Neowiz have cracked the code to FromSoft's iconic formula, an incredible feat from the developers behind the debacle that was Bless Online.

The combat is tight and offers many options to approach battles. The weapon crafting system is expansive and deep, allowing for a reasonable amount of builds, and the level of customization is impressive despite the main character being the same for everyone.

A caveat though: while sticking close to the source material, the game is quite linear, going from chapters to chapters with few reasons to revisit previous areas. The level design is also a little lacking -the first few areas in particular- and it only picks up starting with the factory.

Tonally, LoP also borrows from its inspiration, but is distinct enough as to carve its own identity. It is as dark as it gets but it leans more towards a macabre fable than the gruesome dark fantasy or cosmic horror themes from its peers. 
The story, while endearing, is also much less cryptic than your usual FromSoft game, what may be a good or a bad thing depending on whom you ask. But when it lands, it lands hard and by the time you see the credits rolling, you'll be most certainly left wanting for more.

And I definitely hope that there will be more, as this Lies of P has all the qualities to be the start a new promising franchise, on par with the all-time greats that made the punishing Souls genre so successful.

I lied

EDIT: I regret to change my previously positive review of the game, but I feel an ethical obligation to do so. I believe Shigeru Miyamoto once said that you should never be prevented from completing a game because of a prior mistake, and while LoP does not formally make completion impossible, I am certain many players will find a certain point in the plot insurmountable.

At the point I mentioned, the game removes your ability to fast travel, to fully respec, and to buy most consumable items. This is before a boss, and there is no warning whatsoever. I anticipate fan rejection of what I've said, so please check my achievements: I beat the boss. It  took a few tries, but I did so. I am also a veteran player of this genre, and I do not expect every player to be able to match that. 'Git gud' is not a response to a flawed game. Asking $50 for a game you may have to hard reset 2/3rds of the way through is not acceptable. The developers made a catastrophically bad design choice, and I will remain a negative review on LoP, regardless of its many other high points.

Original review follows:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

So Lies of P is a good game. I want to stress that, and I'm going to highlight the highs first.

1) The records are some of the greatest music ever encountered in a game. They are just perfect, that sweet, melancholy, aching sort of composition. I invite anyone to hear Feel and not think about the people they've cared about most, and yet lost. I invite anyone to hear Fascination and not just feel the pain of life drawn up and exposed, like someone expertly massaging a knot in the back muscles.

2) The bosses are good! They're quite good, they're nice.

3) The opening levels are great, just fantastic design.

Okay. I really like this game. I wanted it to succeed, and it's a miracle it did. These are the things that don't work:

1) The level design past the first third is awful. If the designers didn't want you to simply run past every encounter, I have no idea what they were doing. If they *did* want you to run past every encounter, that's awful. That's just bad. The frustration of every level will ramp and ramp and ramp for artificial, stupid reasons, and you just have to roll with it if you like the game.

2) The bosses aren't amazing. I required no more than three tries on any boss so far, and I'm near the end game. Most bosses I one shot. This ties back into complaint #1: the difficulty of this game is bad design, not legitimately interesting design. You won't find Friede or Orphan or Malenia (so far, in my experience). You'll get a *ton* of Abyss Watchers-esque fights. Just so many. None of them are as good as Abyss Watchers, or Nameless King, or any other 2HB From boss you want to name, but lord will you have to fight them anyway.

3) The story ain't great. It's fine, but it won't scratch that weird itch. I started finding holes and just, like, 'why is this this way' things early on and it never gets better from what I can tell.

4) This is stupid, but Hotel Krat is obviously a modern-ish situation, the walls don't look Belle Epoch at all. Also, where are all the bathrooms? Does Geppetto pee out the window?

This is one of those reviews where the writer laments that Steam only allows a binary "yes" or "no" recommendation.

Lies of P is a great entry in the Souls-like genre, but ultimately, I just felt like putting it down before finishing because each major combat encounter pretty quickly became the song-and-dance of learning perfect guard timings and perfecting them. Once I got to my third phase-two fake-out boss in a row ([spoiler]Green Monster of the Swamp[/spoiler]), I realized I just wasn't really enjoying it like I was at the start of the game.

Beyond combat the game is great. The story and characters are intriguing, the art and graphics are beautiful, and the music and sound design are excellent (I started listening to the collectible gramophone tracks because [spoiler]they increase your humanity[/spoiler], but found myself genuine enjoying the songs for their own sake, for example).

But, in this genre, combat is the meat of the experience, and when the core of the game becomes too samey and, ultimately boring, I just have to put it down.

I'm marking myself as a "no" for a recommendation mostly because Steam demands a yes or no, and also because I just didn't think the combat was worth chewing through to finish the story, as good as the story is on its own. If you're a fan of big parries being the defining arc of combat then you'll probably get along better with this title than I did, and will likely enjoy it a lot, but it just wasn't for me in the end.

TLDR: Lies of P is incredible.

Lies of P is a game that I never expected to be as good as it is. The quick synopsis for this game would be pretty-boy
Pinocchio beats up monstrosities and robots in a Bloodborne meets Sekiro style souls-like. Initially this concept 
sounds silly as hell, but when you start seeing what this game has to offer with the engaging combat and amount
of polish only seen in the likes of games by From Software as well as the incredible respect and attention to detail it has
for the source material it really is impressive.

Narrative:
• The narrative is actually rather captivating. Something that most Souls-like games lack is a clear narrative, which I can understand since the vagueness of most souls games is what can be intriguing to most people that play these games. BUT this game proves you can provide a compelling narrative that's ALSO full of mysteries and subtle details to discover while not being completely obfuscated. 
• The NPC's throughout the game are all rather charming and unique from one another, they provide a lot of different dialogue depending on you're point of progression in the game and they really start to grow on you. Also if you're curious enough you can find out more about their backgrounds by interacting with them.
• In terms of progression through levels the game can feel pretty linear and to some people who really like exploring alternative paths or fighting optional bosses this may leave more to be desired in that regard. Honestly though I don't consider this much of a con anyway since this game wasn't setting out to do this, they wanted to convey a tightly designed story with engaging combat and they delivered.

Graphics:
• The graphical fidelity and level design on this game is incredible. Seriously these guys understand what makes Souls environments so compelling when take things into consideration like atmosphere, shortcuts throughout levels, being able to see how the world interconnects or looking over places you previously passed through.
• Not only does this game look pretty, but the animations for each enemy is functionally very well done. Attacks are all telegraphed extremely well and things move in ways that make sense.
• Effects look pretty and again very polished, everything is conveyed so clearly that it's not something you even consciously think about which to me shows how well it's designed. You know exactly when a perfect guard is pulled off by the bright orange-yellow flashes, exactly when an enemy is suffering from a status effect both from their appearance such as flames licking off their body and coloured damage numbers by their healthbar to indicate their status effect, as well as the healthbar glowing white when ready to be staggered. You just start to feel these things and it doesn't distract you from the battle.

Combat:
• Combat in this game is the most engaged I've ever felt playing a souls-like. I'm sure if you've heard anything about this game
you've heard my previously mentioned statement of "Bloodborne meets Sekiro", and while it might seem like everyone's just repeating the same opinion without thought this statement really is a good way to describe it, BUT this is only the best way to describe it for people who haven't play this game yet. Lies of P does its own thing and you have to play it in its own unique way.
• Previously mentioned under my graphics bullet points is that the animations are all done extremely well, and this lends itself to
combat perfectly. In this game you quickly learn that you can time a guard to perfectly deflect enemy attacks, this not only
prevents you from taking damage but can also wear down the enemy's weapon and make them stagger. Fear not though, if you mess up a perfect deflect you will still block some damage and some of your health can be restored by attacking similar to Bloodborne. Once their healthbar glows white that means they can be staggered, so once you see that you can wait for an opening and smash 'em with a fully charged heavy attack or fable art to get a chance for a visceral attack-- but this isn't the only thing to combat. Bosses mix up their movement and attacks in ways that sometimes using your positioning or dodging can be a good tactic to avoid damage and create openings. 
• Expanding on my previous bullet point when fighting bosses you switch between parrying, moving, dodging, and attacking in a way that makes it feel you're not just trying to kill a big strong enemy but that you are PART OF the boss fight. The tools and tactics you're given never make you feel like you're outmatched or that a fight is unfair, once this game clicks you can take time to feel out the bosses movesets and then develop your own moveset and rhythms to counter and outplay them, like its an fair dual.
• One more point about the bosses is that each boss is memorable in terms of design, their moveset, and their arenas. Everything is hand crafted so well that each boss fight will remain in your head. Each boss being designed so specifically is why I believe the linear progression in this game isn't a bad thing, the experience is so tightly optimized.
• Even normal enemies throughout levels have this cadence in combat to a lesser extent so you don't get too fatigued but still 
actually feel engaged. To me this made fighting normal enemies less of a nuisance like some other souls-likes and more of something I actually enjoyed doing. 

Gameplay:
• Movement in this game feels as you'd expect, responsive and quick all with animations that reflect this. Quicker attacks feel fast and fluid, heavy attacks feel weighty and deliberate, dodging/sidestepping feels responsive.
• Weapon customization is the most fun they've ever been. In this game you can switch out different weapon handles
with different blades. The blade is the part of the weapon you upgrade and the handle is what determines the scaling and moveset, on top of that each handle and blade has a different "Fable Art" that's similar to Weapon Arts from Dark Souls so you can mix and match combos you like. You can also use a tool the game offers called Weapon Cranks to alter their scaling to better fit your build.
• Boss weapons are all unique in terms of design, appearance, and capabilities. I seriously wanted to try them all out to see how they'd change my playstyle. These weapons can't be disassembled like normal weapons but they make up for that by having incredibly unique capabilities.
• This game has a skill tree of sorts called the P-Organ(yes this is what it's actually called lol) that can be invested in using a 
resource in the game called Quartz. Each major upgrade such as increasing your amount of healing items requires a certain amount of Quartz socketed to it to be activated, and with each piece of Quartz you socket there are a multitude of minor upgrades to choose from which really makes you able to customize your abilities to best suit your playstyle.
• Throughout this game there's the theme of lying or telling the truth and these decisions shape things and people as your progress. These decisions aren't black and white either leaving you to decide what you feel is right to do.


Conclusion:
Lies of P is a tightly designed souls-like with incredibly engaging and rewarding combat along with a narrative that is captivating enough to keep you entertained until the very end. Seeing what this game has accomplished has easily made this one of my favourite souls-like, I'd even go as far as to place this above some From Software games. I'd recommend this game to anyone who's a fan of the genre.

The weapons and move sets are cool but the movement is weightless, the enemies are boring, both design wise and their mechanical execution. They are easy to forget and lack character.
Bosses are either a cake walk or difficult in a not fun way, fast big bosses with weird timing, so far they have no story, background or a narrative reason to be there and beat them. It's a generic placement of elements.
The sound is bad, it's missing juice when enemies are idle/move/windup attacks, same with bosses and there is no good ambient or boss music either. 
The game is kind of dead when it comes to the soundscape and it's a big part of experience that's missing.
The level design and environment art are mediocre and look very appropriate for a mid level dev, everything is kind of flat, on a grid and it's just not fun to explore, every part in an area looks the same and there is no environmental story telling to the sell world as lived in, even let's say the bodies on the streets don't stand out and they don't sell the story well.
There is no reason to have bonefires in this game, it's just a generic linear action game and not compelling to go back to.

The only game not made by From that has ever nailed souls-like formula this perfectly.  This game pulls its entire blueprint from Bloodborne but when it's this well done and does so while flipping the story of Pinocchio, they have my future purchases safely locked up.  

Easily one of the more beautiful games I've played in the last year too, the art direction is magnificent.  It adds a few quality of life fixes to From's games as well, like finally being able to warp to a spawn point or HQ without sacrificing any upgrade currency.  That one is long overdue.  I know ER had it but Bloodborne didn't and that's just silly.  Still the best game ever though.  

If you're a carbon based life form that loves that 'eyes dilated with a BPM of 155 when the boss hits the final 15% of their hp and can murder me at any split second' moment in your gaming, you will love everything about LoP.  And that post-credits [spoiler]Wizard of Oz[/spoiler] reference has me eager to shove more $$ into Neowiz's hands as soon as possible.  Well done, shareholders!

And [spoiler]The Nameless Puppet[/spoiler] was my favorite final boss since Isshin the Sword Saint.  Also bonus points for the fact that it is the [spoiler]reanimated human corpse of Gepetto's 'actual' dead son[/spoiler].  This game is not afraid to get bonkers dark.

If you're skeptical of this but you like other souls likes I highly recommend this, absolutely great game. Includes some new interesting mechanics like it's weapon crafting system, as well as a much better system than other souls games for doing side quest content. Visuals, sound, story telling, gameplay is fantastic.

Absolute masterpiece of a Souls-Like, almost thought I was playing an actual FromSoft game for most of it. Answers the question if "sekiro" style combat allowed for unique builds with different attack speeds (strength/dex/etc). Makes me excited that FromSoft will implement more customization into their next "sekiro-like". 

The game is set in a beautiful yet creepy world and and touches on a lot of the bloodborne atmosphere. I was worried that the game would have a lot of repetitive "puppet" bosses, but I was pleasantly surprised at some of the bosses and enemies that were introduced!

I will warn new players that this game more or less REQUIRES memorization of attack patterns (especially in the late game).  A lot of attacks are well telegraphed, but many enemy attacks are timed weird and require a lot of practice to get down. Once you know them though it feels fair and is extremely satisfying to pull off a string of perfect parries. If that isn't your thing than this game probably isn't for you.

Lies of P on the surface is "Bloodborne at home" but  its more like the inbetween of Sekiro and Jedi: Fallen Order, with the game feel of Bloodborne.  Difficulty isnt Bloodborne - Sekiro ball bustingly hard, but it falls in a good middle ground thats just above Fallen Order. It's accessible enough for new players of the genre, while not dumbing down mechanics.

the biggest highlight for me is the amount of customization when it comes to building Pino.  All weapons aside from boss weapons are modular, the game encourages you to experiment.  It's also nice to be able to reset your stats and skill builds really easily from a resource that regenerates itself over time.

The "Lie" system is the game's answer to Humanity in the Soulsborne games.  Ultimately It only affects the story's ending, and small details on Pino if you pay attention enough.  It's not that you "ALWAYS" need to lie, its more so "It's better to lie in this situation, and don't be a dick".   

The pacing of the later half of the game feels off as many bosses suddenly like to have 2nd phases, which can be frustrating for some.  And of course you do not restart from the end of the first phase. This does force the player to learn and perfect the first phase to have enough resources for the next but I can understand many do not like this. I'm somewhat in the middle on this issue.  I would rather have fully developed bosses rather than artificially stretching it out.

All in all, the devs also listen to the community which I appreciate. My initial impression from the demo was mixed because of the weapon durability system, and dodging feels terrible.  Fortunately those fears were addressed.  I will hope they learn from the feedback they received and apply it to the upcoming DLC and possible sequel

One of the best souls games ever. I can only fairly compare it to Dark Souls 3 (But it feels more like Bloodborne, though I have only seen gameplay and haven't actually played Bloodborne yet). I would say if you enjoyed the DS series you should try it, if you particularly liked Elden Ring for its open world, there isn't really "open world" as this game is linear in its path to bosses with minor explorative routes like DS3 had. The most interesting parts of the game for me was #1 - The Story. #2 - The combat. #3 - The Bosses. #4 The environment/asthetics #5 - The characters # 6 - The unique weapons/items. There is probably more I enjoyed and hard to articulate everything really. There are many surprises in this game, not just in the enemies and unexpected combat stuff, but in the story too which I found so interesting. Most DS games I really don't understand the story even though when I play it I'm like "yeah I guess I get it" but if you were to quiz me I would probably fail that quiz. With this game, I feel like I at least understand 60-70% of the story, if not higher. I cannot recommend this game enough. It's solo only, no co-op as far as I understand. And the replayability due to the choice of making a "lie" / "truth" decision run, really feels good to play the 2nd time around in NG+. JUST BUY THE GAME!!! And if you want to wait for a sale, that's fine too.

[h1]Transhumanist Tropes[/h1]
Deceits of Urine is hands down my game of the year. Thanks too the implementation of personalized end of year stats that companies like to implement, too let you know everything you do is tracked, and that you can never escape; I know that I wrote 176 reviews this year. That also means I 100% that many games, as all of my reviews dedicate as much effort before the review can be written. This being the 177th review of the year. Without a doubt, this is the my game of the year. Much of Transhumanist (trans?) media, whether books, movies, shows or games, have a tendency to follow certain predictive, yet still interesting political, socioeconomic, and social story tropes. Many of them portray a bleak and dystopian view of the future. Especially from a technocratic, corporatist, or anarcho-capitalist framework. Many consider a nihilistic approach to the outlook of the future where certain long lasting race, gender and sex based social issues still exist. Usually the framework of said issues simply shifts to encompass a new subject for conservatives to call woke. Typically with regard to genetic and/or mechanical modifications. As if we, as a society, will never be free of very basic bigotted societal views. What does this have to do with Deceptions of Wee? It certainly doesn't feature a futuristic setting, however that does not stop the fact that this retelling of the Pinocchio story not only has transhumanist talking points, it discusses the singularity, political corruption, eugenics, and technophobia. Although the political atmosphere of Dishonesties of Piss is never fully discussed, it can be assumed that (based on the notes you find) the political atmosphere is a mixture of an oligarchy (from the flat out political power and influence the upper class has), and a democracy (again due to notes that encompass talks about judges, politicians, courts, police, and unions). Not unlike most of the world. Much of the story pulls influence from Isaac Asimov's "Three Laws of Robotics," Astro-Boy/Pluto, Kill-la-Kill, Batman, Pinocchio (obviously), Frank R Stockton's "The Lady, or the Tiger?," and possibly others. The remainder of this review will contain [b] Spoilers[/b] which I will not be censoring,[u] so read at your own risk.[/u]

[h1] Fun Flattery [/h1]
Before I get into the story, let me appease the people who are looking for the gameplay notes. That way they don't have to see the expansive madness of my reviews. This is for you Harrison, yes you, who else would I be talking to besides you, Harrison Temple. I know you, I know you only want to know about the gameplay. First of all, I want to get this out of the way: [b]If you have not played, beaten, or liked any of the mainline Soulsbourne games (Dark Souls 1-3, Demons Souls, Bloodbourne, or Sekiro) [u]I do not recommend this game[/u][/b]. This game demands more from you than a normal Soulsbourne game. It requires more patients, and more practice than I believe the mainline Soulsbourne game has ever asked for. The controls work mostly the same and can be picked up rather quickly, especially if you have played other Soulsbourne games. Everything is polished and the animations are very fun to watch. Besides the main mechanics of the controls, much of the game is built around the blocking mechanic. Blocking reduces the damage you take, and allows you to recover some of your lost health for a limited amount of time by dealing damage. If you perfect block, you take no damage, and the enemy loses points from their poise. Dealing damage and perfect blocking allow you to break an enemy poise. This is indicated by a white highlight over the enemy health. Dealing a charged heavy attack will allow you to stagger the enemy and follow up with a critical (fatal) attack. Enemies can also do Fury attacks, this is indicated by the enemy glowing red. If this occurs you can either run away, or perfect block. Those are your only options. Dodging or normal blocking will still allow the enemy to damage you. That is until later on in the game/in new game +. Later in the game you can get an equipment that allows you to dodge Fury attacks, and in new game + you can unlock the ability to normal block fury attacks. Plagerism is the talk of the town right now. Although this is a soulslike, I think this is more a form of flattery than a rip off of the series. It is definitely it's own beast. Flattering the games that started the genre with their own unique twists to the Fromsoft original. I've heard this game compared to Bloodborne, but with it's emphasis on perfect blocking, fatal attacks, and poise, it's definitely closer to Sekiro than Bloodborne.  

[h1]Retrospective Retelling[/h1]
Disinformations of Tinkle is, simply put, a retelling of Carlo Collodi's "Pinocchio." The main difference in this retelling, is the assertion that telling the truth is the robotic thing to do. That telling a lie is the thing that actually makes Pinocchio human. Or at least more human. Although called puppets, this game plays off puppets more like automatons. Geppetto creates Pinocchio as a stand in for his dead son named "Carlo." After the author. Thusly you are called Carlo and never called Pinocchio. As if that is a title for what you are rather than who you are. The blue fairy awakens you and seems to only be able to be seen and/or heard by other puppets such as yourself and Gemini. Gepetto is portrayed as the final villain of the game. Notably it could be determined from the beginning as he urges you to always be truthful posing antagonistically to your search for humanity. As if that's what makes you good, but also more robotic. Gepetto, throughout the game, shows disdain for showing any sort of personality or humanity. Calling you a bad child, explaining you need to be punished for disobeying, and notably having anger for showing any lack of Filial piety (the idea that you owe your parents for simply bringing you to life). Throughout the game your character is forced to make choices between telling the truth and telling a lie. Lying increases your humanity, but both options have their own set of choices or consequences. The game throws interesting results and interesting scenarios at you. Not everything is black and white, many of the scenarios seem harmless to lie in, providing an opportunity for a white lie or golden lie. Shortly before you awaken, Gepetto starts an uprising of the puppets by adding an extra rule to the Grand Covenant. Long before the events of Distortions of Piddle a character by the name of Lorenzini Venigni (who is basically a Batman stand-in) lost his parents as they were coming home from a theater play. Venigni's parents were very well off, and Venigni blames himself for their death due to going back to the theater late at night for a toy. His parents were killed by a puppet that had gained an ego (becoming self aware). However the officials of Krat cover up this fact. Venigni inherits his families wealth and their butler (another self aware puppet). Venigni invents the idea of the Grand Covenant (a reference to Isaac Asimov's "Three Laws of Robotics") a set of rules that all puppets are encoded with and must obey. Rule 1: Puppets cannot harm humans. Rule 2: Puppets must obey orders given to them. Rule 3: Puppets cannot lie. The puppet who killed Venigni's parents is a reference to Astroboy/Pluto. Specifically Brau 1589, a mysterious character throughout the game, the King of Riddles, Arlecchino, contacts you via phone to provide you with riddles you solve for rewards. However, as these questions continue, eventually he reveals a sadistic nature forcing you to admit to being a murderer, justified by your bodycount throughout the game. When you finally meet Arlecchino, he's broken already, pinned to a wall with a spear in his chest. Yet taunts you and Venigni while claiming that the very fact that he loves to kill humans is what makes him human, that murder is the thing that makes him alive.
