Before I played this, I had really high hopes, but I was told down by some people that before I even start it, I should beat Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice. I tried beating Sekiro, however I wasn't too good at it, and so that put my hopes down for this game, but I pressed on and got it anyways. This game completely BLEW me away. The art, the versatility, the weapons, and the characters. The entire thing, overall was much better than what I wanted from the game people kept relating to Bloodborne and Sekiro. Probably the second favorite game in my library.

I'm going to say right now, if this game had From Software's name on it, it would be hailed as one of the best games of all time. If this game had From Software on the box, not a person would question it. It is THAT good. A lot of the common criticisms of this game are miner nitpicks that would be entirely overlooked if it was coming from well From. 

Let me go over some of the improvements over the typical souls formula. Some are big, some are small, all feel nice.
- Separation of costumes and defense equipment.
- A durability system that doesn't feel unfair but also doesn't feel pointless.
- Showing you the number of souls you could get from popping soul items in your inventory in the level up screen
- An overall improvement on the weapon art systems called "Fable Arts"
- Good thrown items with proper scaling
- A way to recover charges of the main healing item. (ie Estus)
- Customizable weapons
- UI indication of status effects on enemies
- A way in the ui to see what type of dodge roll / stam recovery speed you are getting.
- A display of which Stargazer (Bonfire) is closest to side quest objectives on the teleport screen
- The use of multiple systems for progression

Then we have some things that are less objectively improvements and more just things that in my subjective opinions improve on the souls formula.
- Binding of parry to the same button as block and effecting based on timing.
- A twist on Bloodborn's "Rally" mechanic wherein you can recover health depleted while you are blocking by quickly attacking again.
- Parrying to do enemy stagger damage in addition to regular attacks.
- Dodges are still useful
- More limited weapon types augmented by the ability to mix and match handles with blades making for a lot of interesting weapons.
- A combination of linear progression with DS1esque shortcuts to allow for interesting level design that loops back on itself but usually within one specific area at a time. 
- A good combination of exploration without being overwhelming.
- Quality of life things in the level design such as removing some of the railing in the hotel making it easier to get back to the first floor stargazer from Gepetto's room. If you play it look at this, it's impossible to not notice it once you have it pointed out, these developers playtested this game enough to know that removing this one section of railing would prevent you from having to run all the way around and did that. I love shit like this.
- A more narrative focused story.
- Very consistent boss fights. In From games there's always a poopoo fight or two. Godskin Duo almost ruining Elden Ring, Bed of Chaos etc. Lies has amazing consistency, not every boss fight is perfect but there isn't one that I absolutely hate.
- Builds are more consistent, there are more powerful builds than others but none feel quite as busted as some of the builds possible in other games in the genre. Nothing on the levels of Rivers of Blood or Moonveil. Pipewrench head on Baton handle is very powerful but not gamebreakingly so. The game can't be trivialized by just picking the right weapon and the right build. 

Some other points of note
- The animations are AAA tier, this isn't an overstatement the animations are near perfection. In fact I'd argue they're better than most AAA games out there.
- The soundtrack is amazing. 
- The UI is good, and very functional. 
- The combat feel is best in class. Not another non-Fromsoft game even comes close, hell, Fromsoft themselves are given a run for their money (if not outright beaten)
- Nothing feels unfair, everything is doable, even the poison swamp areas feel very fair in their design. You never actually are forced into getting a status affliction if you play your cards right.
- Excellent character designs.
- Top notch Voice Acting

To address some criticisms I've seen:
- Two healthbar bosses. Every criticism I've seen is basically you have to get through phase one to try phase two again. And well, that's actually pretty dumb. They could give 1 really big ass health bar and split the phases right in the middle and you'd still have to fight phase 1 to get to phase 2. Every two healthbar boss felt nicely balanced for that fact. I haven't seen one complaint about this that really makes any sense. And yes these fights can be difficult, but there is not one boss runback in this game (even the door guardian) that is that bad, A lot of the time there just isn't a runback.
- Difficulty. A lot of the difficulty complaints are basically trying to play it entirely like Darksouls, entirely like Bloodborne or entirely like Sekiro, this is none of those learn to play THIS game and you should be fine. And if a boss feels two hard drop swallow your pride and summon the damned spectre, he makes things easier without making them feel trivial in most cases.
- This game is a ripoff/plagerism. This barely merits a response, it's a soulslike fallowing souls-like tropes, of course it feels similar but it really does its own thing.
- The game is too linear. This might be a legit problem IDK, it's clearly what they were going for but you know I think it's just an opinion thing. I felt less overwhelmed on a blind playthrough. This is partly because I like to explore every square inch of the game and in this game it's actually possible to do that in one run. 

Some legitimate areas where other games, especially from From might be better.
- Overall level design. And this really only counts for the first half of DS1, but if you like these truly go your own route maps that let you tackle things how you see fit in the order you see fit then yeah DS1 might be better. I will add though that Lies is good start to finish. The height of DS1 level design is better yes, but the low isn't. Lies has very consistently good level design so I'd argue that while it might only be 75% as good at its best compared to DS1's best it stays at that 75% consistently, where the worst of DS1 might be 25% as good as it's own best if that makes sense. Still I'd rank it below DS1 and DS3 overall but above say DS2 or Sekiro even.
- The ambience. This game is more colorful than Bloodborn but it doesn't quite ooze the atmosphere that some of the From games do. It;s still VERY strong on atmosphere but not quite as good as From at their best.
- The mystery and intrigue. With linear level design and a narrative story it does less to make you wonder what pieces you are missing or what you might find that say DS1 or DS3, still it's good and only really falls short of these masterpieces. 

So if you're on the fence about Lies of P, I would say give it a go. If you like other Souls-like games at all this is a fantastic buy worth full price. It's got a lot of content and has an upcoming expansion. Even if you don't think it's as good as the best From has to offer it's definitely closer to a From game than say Steelrising or Thymesia. As I said from the beginning, if this had From branding no one would think it was made by the B team.

When everyone was praising this game at launch I shy-ed away from it out of a sense of being burned too bad by other soulslikes in the past. This game, however, blows pretty much any non-From competitor out of the water. The music is phenomenal, the fights feel fair and suitably epic, and the mechanics fit like glove. While I think the exploration and characters could use a bit more work, the rest of the game easily makes up for it in spades. If you like souls, you will like this.

The most fun experience in a game ive ever had, even after 3 playthroughs, i just have an itch to do another one. I just cant get enough of the combat, i pray that Round 8 studios adds a "reflection of strength" boss rush type of thing where i can just infinitely refight the bosses. the 4th official boss and the 3rd last boss are two of my favorite bosses, but theyre so far apart in the story. If you've played bloodborne, or sekiro, then this game is definitely for you. It has the themes of bloodborne, creepy, horror type of aesthetic and a combat like sekiro. One of the main criticisms of Sekiro was that there was no weapon variety, and while it was called a soulsgame, it didnt have the combat of one. Lies of P bridged that gap, while it focuses on parries, you can both block and regain your health, kinda like a rally system from bloodborne, and you can dodge. Dodging has I-frames in this game, so that is an option, unlike in sekiro.  Its also one of the first games, atleast as far as ive seen, where you can literally build your own weapon to fit your playstyle, and all weapons have the ability to parry. The game also took more inspiration from Sekiro by implimenting a Shinobi prosthetic, in this game its called a "Legion Arm" and its extremely fun to use.  This was the perfect game for me, as a person who played 4 playthroughs of Sekiro which was 166 hours in total. Now granted, a lot of that time was spent trying to get the platinum, and constant farming. Point is, i love that game, and if you do to, then Lies of P is a game for you.

While this game can be pretty dang hard and at times it makes you wanna scream your lungs trust when I say there are enough resources to fight off the difficulty like leveling up with ergo, upgrading your weapons, finding the weapons that best suit your fighting style and even summon one spectre which for me personally was enough to easy up a bit and give me a chance to fight back, it was really hard but in the end i actually enjoyed it a lot since the more i died the more learned how to play this game better and polish myself to a better player in lies of P. Graphics are BEAUTIFUL and i would say way better than fromsoftware, really recommed this game if you are a tough cookie to crack in hellish mechanics

the good:
- looks nice and performs great, event on modest hardware

the bad:

- most choices don't matter (beyond increasing lie/truth counters)
- that platforming section in cathedral is a total bullshit

the other:

Just finished NG+ and this game is incredible. It's like they looked at FromSoft's combat systems and went "we can do better than that" and then they did. They give you the Sekiro parry, the Bloodborne dodge and then put you up against bosses that are closer to Dark Souls 3 in terms of clearly legible attacks and distinct openings where it's safe for you to attack and still managed to make he game VERY difficult in a way that rarely frustrated me, because I always knew there was an ideal way to deal with each attack.

Yeah, in terms of visual artistry I think it's a bit tame, the level design plays it very safe, but the plot really worked for me and the bosses were consistently so good that it rarely impacted my enjoyment.

Easy recommend for people who've started to get frustrated with FromSoft's approach to combat and boss design, while still looking for a very challenging game.

This game is like if Elden Ring and Devil May Cry had a steampunk baby. It has the combat, difficulty, and progression of Elden ring with the linear exploration and crazy arm gadgets of DMC. Lies of P sill has many aspects and mechanics that make it totally unique. The combat is much more punishing and requires you to use the parry method (which was always optional in elden ring). This game leans on it HEAVY, almost to the point where you won't make it past the first couple bosses unless you use the summon, get lucky, or grind levels to get your damage up. Even though parry is basically required to have a smooth run, it feels more forgiving than ER and even without a perfect parry it gives you the chance to get the health back you lose while blocking. This is also the only Souls like I have played where the normal enemies are genuinely more of a threat than bosses are so don't underestimate basically anyone that can hit you. It doesn't matter if its a wiggling robot torso with no arms or legs it will absolutely delete half your health bar if you aren't careful. Overall, amazing game, lots of rage, super satisfying.

Didn't expect this game to be this good. happy to know that I didn't waste any money on this. Infact, this game inspired me to improve my own game. Ironically this game turned out to be similar thematically of what I was developing so Luckily, now I have a reference game, plus I can improve upon some concepts.

The replay value may be this game's biggest highlight. I've beaten it 5 times over and there is still a craving in me for more. So far, I've done an all-lie playthrough, an all-truth + one weapon only playthrough (the starter broadsword), 2 runs just messing around in NG+, and most recently a no-consumable run. I've also max upgraded every weapon and the P(ee) Organ/ skill tree, and actively avoided one achievement required for 100% just so I could justify doing a no-heal. All 5 runs were done without the cube and summons, which feel disconnected from what [b]wood[/b] otherwise be a near-flawless, tightly knit combat system. The rest of said system fortunately remains quite engaging and multi-faceted. Something that greatly contributes to its replayability is how it incentivises experimentation in combat. Sticking to one strategy throughout will not work, I learned that the hard way. The weapon crafting and robot arms lead to possibly hundreds of fun builds and synergies, and a lot of mechanics like durability and status ailments that seem annoying and padded on at first, [b]liar[/b] and interact very well later on as fights get more complex. Dodging, rolling and strafing are all viable, and switching between them is always better than sticking to only one, it just looks and feels awesome to pull off.

The lack of any real exploration and extreme level linearity is a little disappointing, but most semi-open world type games get tiring anyway at a certain point if not done properly, so more of a focus on fight encounters is appreciated. Speaking of which, the roster of bosses and trash mobs is nearly spotless. They spared no expense when it came to the creature designs, that's for sure. I love how there are such wacky enemy types that show up for one level and never again, it's a measured and context-driven nature to the encounters that lead to an impressive variety when it comes to enemy designs and the scenarios; it keeps the levels fresh and carries the immersion when the level layout isn’t quite there. Bosses, mini and major, are consistently excellent, disappointing Door Guardian aside. Some of my favorite character designs in recent memory, as well as immaculate animation work. Very readable attacks and [b]strings[/b] have unique but intuitive rhythms that are super satisfying to master, plus how moves flow into each other is almost seamless. Nameless Puppet, Laxasia, and Victor are standout favorites. I am tempted to name more, but I won't for brevity. Scrapped Watchman.

To end on by far the biggest surprise, the music is fantastic. While the soundtrack in-game is nothing too special as most of them are standard orchestral tracks that feel too imitative of you-know-who (they shall go unnamed because I am sick of the constant comparisons), the hub jukebox selection is astoundingly good, so much better than it had to be. Truthfully, I can say the same for the game as a whole. Fantastic.

This is not only one of the best non FS soulslikes ever, this is one of the best soulslikes ever, including that of FromSoftware. In my eyes, this is better than that of Elden Ring. 
The many new mechanics introduced in this game make it feel to familiar, yet fresh. The ability to break enemies' weapons, the ability to craft new weapons and the different endings that come with the decisions to Lie/tell the truth. This game is so polished it's bursting at the seams. Combining these new mechanics with the good old ones make this game a pleasure to play, even if it requires a slight learning curve. The game is hard, very hard. And if I had any way to improve this game, it would be that I'd increase the perfect block window by a couple frames, that way some boss attacks wouldnt be so frustrating. That said, this game will be remembered as one that perfected a genre, and if you havent done so already, play it now.
Definitely worth it. More Sekiro than Bloodborne, still missing some From Software magic, but a very good souls-like.

General Combat 

* Combat Preparation mechanics is very grounded as part of story, Still in the end its souls like game.

* Encounters have variety, I pushed strength so it was easy for me to deal with trash mobs, some hidden elements as expected in genre to add some juice to parkour.

* Dodging is super limited, you have to master it. Its a bit tricky so you generally want to avoid dodging cause the game tells you to. It is limited and recovery wise not also in favor of player, and really depends on the enemy range and reach. Sometimes it gives you advantage to abuse the mechanics like in AOE damages so its interesting in that terms.

*Combats are slow, exaggerated moves so player can learn avoid. Good variety of different types from the beginning of game. Elden ring type of feeling can be expected in some encounters that you are tiny which is kinda I am looking for in games in boss combat.

* Rare mobs are not re spawned like in the other games though it didn't notice that till I die to another trash mob and that time didn't see one of the npc spawned. So its not super distinguishable maybe sometimes their difficulty difference.

*Performance wise it is very good and expected results.

Level Design

* There is generally Souls like parkour mechanics. It is too linear however in its level design, there was a sense of effort to have multiple paths. Sense of exploration somewhat exist in some places , in the dark corners of an alley with some dead end paths etc, still not open world of course.

* Game looking great aesthetically in many terms. Dark Victorian era Fantasy elements with some steampunk elements kinda great. This influences the mechanics of the game a lot of-course and sets in a different corner than its rivals. It is possible in many terms there is also catholic elements.

* There are some traps that can be utilized I saw 1 or 2 so far, maybe there is more aspects to it but I didn't feel that its part of game-play maybe a bit can be an helper to player if you  kite npc.

Game Design / UX

* Controls are good generally even I felt they are more responsive than the dark souls, god of war. It feels good, however there is a sense of punishment for unnecessary elements, like if your ammo is finished checking that put you into a controls blocked state which is OK, you can do that but why that long animation hard to guess.

* UX Feedback Systems wise its generally expected mechanics in this genre. Clear whistles and bells. Playing on PC quite easy too, not blatant so pushes player a bit to think.

* Steampunk setting really unlocks and influences the utility design in many terms, both in level design but especially in combat which opens the room for one of the most important parts which is Legion Arms which is great. It fits the game very well and its fun to play with. I didn't use in couple of hours of gameplay but even knowing they exist its quite exciting.

* Core mechanics wise, I am always feeling a bit bad when I can not jump. It is ok to let player a little bit jump, don't worry about this much breaking the level , we can break it anyway, just don't let go the forward button in these games you will eventually speed-run.  Blocking was well balanced, I felt very good control over my weapon. Felt quite powerful while using it.

* I made in depth analysis of its features when it comes to its usability yet but there is somewhat attention to accessibility, there is a bit player comfort attention to it but definitely way beyond where it can be.
This game absolutely rules, on par with Fromsoft's caliber

Unquestionably an excellent game! From start to finish. It provides a unique spin on the Soulslike genre but still remains in its roots. It challenges you in new ways never before seen in Souls. The story is well written and is clear and easy to follow while also having depths.

Gone are the days of hoping that Bloodborne comes to PC or that Bloodborne 2 gets made. Lies of P is here to fill that void and it fills it well.

Seriously This game took me by surprise. SOUL LIKE GAME WAS NEVER A GAME FOR ME. NEVER EVER PLAYED GAMEs like soul type at all before except remnant 1 and 2 if u consider them soul like and just because of co op with friends.  Other than that I skipped games as soon as I see soul like. 

But man was I wrong about this game. This game is SUPERB. I bought this game never thinking I will be hooked on this and thinking I will be refunding this game before 2 hours of play time just like i did on other soul like games.  But it hook me and I literally all niter as soon as i started playing, went thru 4 chapter at once learning to dodge shit and stuff lol didnt even realize the time gone by and cant drop my controller down. The story is captivating. The environment feel like post apocalyptic neo industrialized with i-robot style went wrong. Kinda like other dimension of i robot with steampunk nature.  This game may be soul like but man I dunno I dun feel soul like at all which is a good thing.  I felt more like playing Metro exodus or something of that nature gameplay wise without guns of course. 

Trust me this game is freaking superb. FOR ONCE I AM IN LOVE WITH THIS KIND OF SOUL LIKE GAME.

CON:
This game is hard for me to recommend because of all the issues regarding the flow of combat. Bosses are really unfun to fight because of janky animation and over use of delayed attacks. Some big bosses attack you from off camera and they also have awful hitboxes. Parrying an enemy pushes you back a lot creating distance between you and the enemy which makes no sense as perfect parrying should reward you by creating openings for an attack. Also weapon durability mechanic is quite annoying while fighting a boss, I just don't understand how it adds anything to the game.

PRO:
The game has great atmosphere and story. The weapons assembly system is great. The game is well designed as all the mechanics in game complement each other in general. The level design although linear is quite good. Some humanoid mini bosses are good.

Verdict:
Lies of P is let down by its combat which is the bread and butter of any souls like game. If they had nailed the combat this game would be a masterpiece.

Lovely souls-like that improves the formula in several areas. While not perfect, definitely worth your time.

And finally, he is literally me.

For Better and For Worse, this is probably the welcoming Souls-Like I've ever played.

For Better; the art design, atmosphere, music, writing, questing, characters, and the way the game plays with expectations a coziness and love that seeps into everything you do and feel throughout the game. There's so many moments that demanded me to sit down, listen, and eat up the scenery with the production value to more than match From Software.

For Worse; this is more subjective but this is probably one of the least punishing Souls-likes I've played though its still really engaging. Having access to Specters on bosses, lenient parry windows, and not even losing all your ergo on dying definitely subtracts from the thrill but does mean this is a great introduction to the genre and, ultimately, still a good time for veterans.

I have completed new game plus once to try several builds and here is my conclusions.
It is easier than people say. Yes, parry (prefect guard) is quite hard to do, but blocking and donging are good enough to handle everything. 
Story is quite interesting. 
Some advices:
You need to have the best body parts in any type of build. Just keep the weight below 60% and never aim for lightwigth bonus (< 30% weight) because it gives you no viable bonuses. 
As for weapons - I used greatswords in first playthrough and daggers in second. Swords/blunts are not very different from greatswords, just a bit faster. But in NG+ you need faster attacks to survive. So I recommend you to use daggers. I used acidic dagger - it is very good for any type of enemies and you can get it quite early (chapter 3 if I remember correctly, maybe chapter 4). Don't bother with second weapon - it will be useless. 
Stats - health, weight and acid damage. With daggers you don't need too much stamina so don't invest much there.
Arms - Fulminis (electric damage) is the best. Shield is good too. Sometimes you will want to use long range arm. 
Amultes - anything you like actually. I prefer damaging amulets and life regeneration for common enemies or physical resistance for bosses. 
Perks (heart improvements) - focus on healing charges and defence first, then attack, and utility at last.

TLDR: Incredible game that you should definitely play. The combat, story, and world building is superb, but 2 warnings: always talk to the character named Venigni before talking to the character named Eugenie or you will regret it near the end of the game. Second, big enemies and bosses have a tendency to trap you in a corner making it impossible to see.

This game is the best non Fromsoft souls game I have played. Although I would put it below all the other Fromsoft souls games, I would still say it is of equitable quality to Fromsoft souls games. There is a large variety of weapons and tools and to my surprise they all feel unique which I find is a problem that nearly every souls like game suffers from including the originals.

BUT! I have 2 complaints: first, the blacksmith of this game is called Eugenie who's quest line resolves after another npc's quest line is resolved. if you speak another npc named Venigni he reveals a MAJOR PLOT TWIST that is significant to the resolution of Eugenie's story, HOWEVER! if you decide to speak to Eugenie first BECAUSE SHE IS THE BLACKSMITH you are automatically forced into resolving the quest line WITHOUT ACCESS TO ONE OF THE PROPER ENDINGS. I am being vague about the details to avoid spoilers but I feel the need to say this so that whoever sees this and reads it will hopefully be able to avoid my own cruel fate. 

The other issue with this game is that big enemies and especially bosses will trap you in corners completely blocking your camera and preventing you from moving as they barrage you with an endless amount of attacks that you can't react to. Someone might argue that it is my fault that I ended in the corner due to my lack of awareness and this is true, but I am a souls veteran and think that I am pretty good at these games, so if I am seriously struggling with this consistently throughout the whole game I imagine many other people also have the same problem. I feel that this issue could be easily resolved if the code was changed so that bosses backed up just a little bit after finishing their attack if they detect the player is in a corner.

Overall this game is amazing and although it has flaws, what game doesn't? I bought this at full price and don't regret it, although I would never judge someone for buying even a game this good on sale.
P.S. motivity is strength and technique is dexterity... you know what to do don't you Pinocchio?

Combining Souls-like mechanics with Pinocchio and some of the best Victorian/steampunk aesthetics I have seen in a while was extremely attention-grabbing. I knew I wanted to give this game a shot the second I saw its promotional material and it absolutely does not disappoint. Lies of P not only far outshines non-Fromsoft Souls-likes, it even manages to reach the stars above some of Fromsoft's own works.

Neowiz have a firm grasp on what makes the souls games tick. While bosses should be in the game, it should never become a priority for the devs of a souls-like to cram in as many bosses as possible, Lies of P boasts a whopping 25 bosses (13 of which being optional), and while the bosses may vary a bit in quality (we'll get to that later) it never feels like the bosses are a large focal point for the developers.

The combat is extremely rewarding. While learning to counter is highly recommended, it isn't mandatory. The sheer customisation options for equipment is staggering.  Trading shields or other purely defensive weaponry for Legion Arms pushes the player into a more aggressive playstyle (with the exception for Aegis but even that arm allows for more aggressive counter attacks). It, Guard Regain (Basically the Rally system from BloodBorne), and enemies' generally quick fighting pushes the player towards tackling enemies head-on. And mastering a boss, countering every attack while destroying their health bar is the most rewarding aspects of this games combat.

Let's talk about the bosses shall we..
While some of the latter bosses in this game are really well designed for the most part, there are a few stinkers and unfortunately, some of the really good bosses suffer from issues prevalent in other souls-likes.

Starting with the two worst boss fights in the game, The Black Rabbit Brotherhood fights. Both of these fights hearken back to many terrible bosses from Dark Souls 2, opting for having multiple enemies instead of one really good one. Neowiz were kind enough to design the boss fights so that you don't have to fight all brothers at once, however this doesn't stop the first fight from dragging on due to every enemy being very aggressive and quick, lacking in the kind of duality that made O&S from Dark Souls 1 such a great fight. Ideally you'd want to make the eldest brother slower but perhaps with harder hitting attacks, similar to Ornstein, slowly rumbling towards you as your focus is on one of his faster younger siblings. While he does that when one of his siblings are on the field, only occasionally lunging towards you, when his siblings leave the field, he suddenly becomes much faster. Another factor that just lead to the fights both dragging on is that the siblings all have a bit too much health. It's a similar issue to Simon Manus, where his second phase has too much health, making the fight drag on.

Were I to design this fight, I'd have the eldest brother be similar to Ornstein, slowly walking towards you with lumbering steps, with slower attacks that hit like a truck. Meanwhile his siblings enter the fray one at a time, They'd have varying degrees of speed (much like they do in the game). As a possible trade off for having four enemies you have to defeat is giving the three youngest siblings much less health than the eldest so the fight doesn't turn into a battle of attrition. Also no Rematch. Even my version would have a risk of dragging on for too long so fighting the boss twice would just be frustrating.

There are also a couple issues that plague even the best of bosses in the game, there are two big ones that come to mind...
Firstly, if you do enough damage to an enemy's "poise" for lack of a better word, their health bar glows white signalling they are "staggered", hitting the enemy with a heavy attack, a Fable ability or a fucking Shot Put renders the enemy helpless for a few seconds, allowing the player a chance to land a critical strike, dealing massive amounts of damage. Issue is, some bosses (and even some regular enemies) will unleash a last, quick attack (usually a quick flurry of attacks or an A.O.E) before you are allowed to do the critical hit. This only really feels like a "haha gotcha" from the devs, managing to land a heavy attack or a Fable ability while the enemy is staggered can be really difficult with some bosses, especially some of the later ones, so managing to get them to this state shouldn't make them do a quick "gotcha", it just feels unnecessarily cruel towards the player.

The other huge issue being attack wind-ups. It's become more and more common for souls-like bosses to do an attack where they lift their arm, stand still for a few seconds only to then lock onto the players exact ip adress and slash down before you can even react to it happening. This issue becomes most prevalent on mid-late game bosses and is unfortunate since some of these late-game bosses are really good fights. Simon Manus is otherwise an amazing display of spectacle but some of his moves are really poorly telegraphed and giving some of his magic attacks disruption (especially the quick one) was a mistake, Laxasia constantly keeps you on edge, but some of her attacks feel just a bit shitty to avoid or parry. One way you could do this kind of attack is if you clearly indicate before the attack is about to slash down. The Scrapped Watchman has one such attack where he lifts his arm up for a few seconds, and while the slashing down is pretty fast, there is a very noticeable twitch in his arm before he's about to actually make the attack.

While there are definitely areas of improvement with some of the bosses, thankfully, I get the impression Neowiz never made it a focal point to cram in as many bosses as possible because bosses sell copies. The game has a good blend of exploration and boss encounters. Speaking of which, While I can miss the interconnected design in DS1, Lies of P's linear level design doesn't detract from the game's quality. And I can certainly appreciate that Lies of P's story is told to you in a more direct way.

I already briefly touched on the aesthetic in the opening lines but to expand on it a bit. This game looks amazing. The designs of everything from the smallest puppet, to the city of Krat to the Nameless Puppet scream care (Fucking incredible boss in terms of mechanics and design by the way (again with one or two issues though)). A lot of care was put into the design of this game and it is obvious. Krat's atmosphere is one I just want to sink deep into. The music is also stellar! I adore the music in the records you get throughout the game. "Feel" has been and will be listened to often.

Finally, while I may have been harsh on some of this game's shortcomings, I truly believe Lies of P stands shoulder to shoulder with some of Fromsoft's best works, I'm very much looking forward to the sequel and I sincerely hope it improves on the foundations built by Lies of P. This game is truly a great display of what a truly great Souls-like game can look like.
100% recommend!

I really wanted to like this game but am honestly just tired of waiting for it to get better... can we stop pretending its anything more than a shameless copy of Fromsoft titles. Various mechanics and systems from Dark Souls, Sekiro, and Bloodborne all Frankenstein-ed together into what ends up being a very shallow linear game with none of the depth, lore, or exploration that makes Souls games good. A tiny version of Cathedral of the Deep, a trap pulled directly from the Catacombs of Carthus, Ballistae that fire at you while you clear a swamp area of enemies, puppet dogs - they even copied the f*****g dogs? Seriously? You can call it an homage to Fromsoft, at the end of the day it plays like a low budget ripoff of Dark Souls. “Imitation is the sincerest form of flattery that mediocrity can pay to greatness”. I genuinely don't know what people are getting out of this that I'm missing but some people seem to love it. 4/10 did not awaken my P organ.

TLDR; Great game. Easily the best soulslike game, including fromsoft's own titles as an overall package.

Excellent performance. Smooth as butter, well optimized, and little to no stutters or bugs. DLSS support, no 60fps lock, borderless fullscreen support, etc, it meets all the qualities of a great modern triple A game.  

Many great design decisions and QoL that elevate the game significantly. The crit indicator, infinite resets with coin fruit, ergo outside the boss arena, defensive stats not tied to costume, etc, a lot of minor but excellent improvements. All the systems in the game are well designed and worth engaging with (P organ, legion arm, fable arts, etc). For example, no stat reqs on weapons & the assembly system allows you to experiment with every weapon and customize for a lot of player expression in a way that's harder in other souls games.

The game is not as difficult as a lot of people say. I personally didn't take over 5 attempts on any boss except Laxasia even without spectres, you just need to utilise the full range of your defensive arsenal well and learn the movesets which aren't too extensive and are well telegraphed. Felt perfectly balanced in terms of difficulty and probably the least frustrated I've ever been with a soulslike. I always felt like I was learning and I never felt like I was losing to BS, which was amazing and sadly rare in soulslikes. 

Level design, mob placements, and elite mob design is a massive contributor to the game feeling better than fromsoft titles. Lack of gank fights, annoying encounters, and overall less enemies that aren't as annoying made the levels feel much better. Rarely did I ever die in the actual levels or feel punished for exploring unless I played bad. There was no 'bad' level, hell even the obligatory poison swamp level was done well and fun.

Bosses were all very good for the most part with excellent telegraphs and fun movesets that are hard but never unfair. In terms of fun, best were Laxasia & Scrap Watchman with Laxasia being in my souls boss hall of fame. I found the Human/Stalker encounters were fairly weak overall though.

Story was not bad, not mindblowing by any means but there were some good character moments that caught me by pleasant surprise with their depth and perspective. Vegnini, Arlecchino, and Antonia were great standouts, rest of NPCs were alright. It's much more direct than fromsoft storytelling which I found more fitting for the kind of story Lies of P is trying to tell. The soundtrack is solid and the records are fantastic.

Overall, the best way to describe the game would be consistently excellent. No other soulslike that I've played has ever had such a high degree of consistent quality. I'm a pretty critical and picky, and even I was having trouble finding major flaws. The entire game never dips below the incredibly high bar it sets for itself and remains very consistent quality wise throughout. Worth the full price easily.

Suffers horribly from the tropes of souls-like games. Basic enemies that have one shot combos? Check. NPCS that inexplicably die if you don't talk to them before a boss? Check. Enemies that appear from behind you because, just get better? Check. Not gonna lie it was good up until the half way point when I realized it's uninspired and sort of a bland souls game. Not even that many weapons either.
Possibly best souls-like ever made, must have for every fan of the genera .

Lies of PP is a game that is for anyone who has ever lied about the size of their PP. Also its dark souls. With Timothee Chalamet. I had to google his name.

In terms of level/enemy design and music, it is basically Dark Souls 2 with better visuals. And since I like Dark Souls 2, Lies of P came to my liking too.

It has a compelling story on top of the usual lore type storytelling. Consumables are actually usable here. I like that you can recharge your healing flask if it is empty by killing enemies. Even combining handles and blades might be helpful.

The only problem I have with this game is its parry mechanic. It allows you to regain your health if you block the enemy attack. But your character is too slow and some enemies are too aggressive and because of that, you have two issues:
1. You don't have any room for mistakes. If you block too soon, you will receive some damage that you might regain, but if you block too late, you will lose your health and the opportunity to regain the blocked amount of health. Whereas in Sekiro blocks consume your stamina instead of health, so you have more possibilities for mistakes. So the only option here is either the perfect block, which fully negates damage but is not easy to master, or dodging, which is very slugish.
2. Too little window for counterattack. You are just too slow and there are only a few weapons with a longer reach. So even if you perfect block the enemy attack, you have to get to the enemy and attack them, which takes a lot of time and by the time you get to them, the enemy will start attacking you again. Whereas in Bloodborne you don't have additional steps. If you receive damage, you can take it back almost immediately.

So yeah, it is basically a less fun version of Sekiro and Bloodborne combat. It does not really make the game harder, just more frustrating. Not to the point of dropping the game, but it sure wants to take your time to teach you how to block. It also may be a skill issue because I tried not to use phantoms even on the group bosses.
Don't get me wrong, I still like this game, but I think it would have been better if the developers just stole From's mechanics instead of weirdly mixing them. But despite all that, it baffles me that this is the only souls like game that gets the From's formula on the first try, where every other developer, in my opinion, can't figure it out to this day. So I hope this game will succeed and their next game will be a lot more polished and could actually compete with From Software.

Compared to most games that claim they're Soulsborne. Lies of P takes the torch and runs way out ahead. Given how successful the game has been, it slipped my radar until a month ago. Having my doubts in the first couple of sections,  this was completely unfounded. Taking it's time to really build out the mechanics and explain them in detail. Halfway through, most mechanics become well-rounded and distinguished. NEOWIZ had some vastly unique elements that seamlessly blended together. Some of these are more heavily weighted than others, but you may not realize it until you hit a difficulty spike. One such game fundamental P-Organs are far more heavily weighted than I expected. This one element nearly derailed my run of the game. However, you can reset these attributes and readjust them as needed. The level design was creative and engaging the entire time. Harkening back to Dark Souls and Bloodborne each level twisting back on itself with shortcuts in between. Joined together with a surprising amount of detail. You'll start to realize how masterfully this game is put together. Boss fights are genuinely engaging, satisfying, and innovative with attack patterns. However, as a souls veteran of these games. A handful of bosses are extremely tough and will take multiple hours of attempts to complete. With the exception of one which I consider unfair I.E. "Git Gud". Adjusting my attributes, weapons, throwables, legion arms, handles, and play styles I could not overcome. Original review around 12 hours:
Gameplay is maddeningly hard-fun but Progression is somewhere between bad and and infuriating. 

I love how difficult the combat is - want to smash controller through TV and then come back later and absolutely NAIL a boss fight and it feels so good - then you're lost and there's nothing AT ALL to do or progress, until you finally accidentally talk to X who you swear you've tried talking to 10x, and he says "I've already instructed Y to talk to you so you should have no trouble" when until that interaction Y has been saying the current gen game equivalent of "..." to you. 
Apologies to the creators for a negative but I must. Purely linear you must A-B-C-D game with no open world options for stumbling your way interestingly back to the plot, but it won't help you recover if you get off track. In fact it punishes you for getting off track in some meaningful and frustrating ways. That's just not fun.
I think at this point I'll finish it, but I might not, and if I don't it won't be because it was too hard, it will be because I decided some of the design choices just made me feel like I was truly wasting my time, and not in the way you intend to when you fire up a video game.

Fantastic game. Surprisingly good in so many ways:
- I really enjoyed world, artwork and characters - a violent steampunk fairytale with really great atmosphere.
- Combat feels very fluid, engaging and fun. 
- Many challenging and well designed bosses.
- You have a great learning curve for boss encounters etc.
- Weapon variety and the ability to swap handles and blades is great.
- Good variety of different enemy types. That thematically fit the area where you encounter them.
- I really liked the level design. 
- Character progression very well done.
- Secrets, story choices and different ending. (Also good ng+)

And yes, it is a comparatively hard game. You wil need to master it's mechanics in order to beat it. So if you are easily frustrated and  just want a casual, easy experience, this game might not be right for you. But learning the mechanics and mastering them feels very rewarding.

It is a good game. Nowhere near as good as Sekiro but better than Dark Souls 3. It is a souls game where you don't need to watch a lore youtuber explain you the story. I heard claims that this is a "parry focused souls game" and I can see why some may think that as successful parrying is tied to many perks and amulets, where it becomes a necessity for almost all boss fights to learn to parry, but there are some moments where dodging is the far superior tactic. For example, there was this one boss that kept melting my stamina and then my health with a long combo that I could never fully parry, but then that combo was trivialized by simply dodging to the side repeatedly. What I am saying is, you need to know when to dodge and when to parry. If it gets overwhelming, just block and respond with some counter attacks, you regain health you lost from guarding by attacking.

Now some negatives, levels were too long in my opinion. Too often I simply wished for them to end already and let me fight another boss, but the same humanoid monsters in the same long sets of corridors and rooms just kept going. On my New Game+ playthrough I just ran past all enemies and it still felt too long.
Finally the specter system. Right before boss rooms you can summon an AI controlled specter to fight with you. I am not all that against this as if you simply don't wish to bother with a boss fight on your 2nd or 3rd playthrough you can utilize the specter to skip past it faster. But the bosses focus the specter way too much, making you more of a spectator to the fight until the incredibly tanky specter or the boss dies. So if you want, you can trivialize lot of bosses with the specter and then be left with a feeling of being ignored in the fight.

Still this was overall a good game. Well worth the price I paid in the steam sale.

I made sure to beat all the bosses before posting this.

This game is hot garbage 

Outside of the obviously fantastic QOL features and overall aesthetic there aren't many things this game has going for it. Movement and rolling feel sluggish and clunky the whole way through and levels are packed with enough ambushes to make Ds2 blush. Enemies also have such jacked up attack tracking I'd just burst out laughing after seeing bosses constantly pull off 180 degree turns and lightning-fast gap closers from way too far away while they were halfway through their attack animation. Shit just looks really goofy

Besides that the bosses range from mid at best to needlessly annoying at worst. Most of the time it just feels like I'm playing scuffed Sekiro with how sporadic a lot of the parry timings are due to janky looking animations for some attacks. A lot of the bosses also have Elden Ring type combo extensions where you never know if the boss is done attacking or just waiting for you to get closer so it can continue its combo. Never really struggled with any bosses but after beating them my thoughts were either "Oh that's it?" or "Damn glad that's over". I'd say the only good bosses were Laxasia and Nameless Puppet which funnily enough feel like Sekiro bosses that wandered into the wrong game. Bosses having additional attacks after landing a stagger on them is also a terribly cheap mechanic. Hope the next game avoids that.

Loot and weapons feel extremely underwhelming too. Most of the time you just end up with useless crap or ergo fragments and since this game doesn't have spells or something similar to spells there's little gameplay incentive to actually explore unless you're trying to find quartz (which is usually just in chests or on mini-bosses anyway). Among the loot are weapons which are also boring since none of them feel like they have any identity due to every weapon essentially being two pieces of lego with some fable abilities attached to it. Even the Fable Arts aren't anything to write home about. I just stopped bothering with weapons entirely midway through the game since it was too much hassle to keep testing out new weapon combinations to see if I'd wanna switch up my playstyle. A lot of boss weapons also just look silly and don't line up with the boss they're dropped from at all (Victor gives a greatsword, Green Monster gives a katana, Laxasia gives a pizza cutter like wtf???). Compare them to Bloodborne's trick weapons or even some of Ds3's boss weapons and you can clearly see the difference. 

Going in I thought the weapon durability mechanic would be terrible and it turns out I was mostly right. Durability just feels like needless busy work during boss fights and in between enemy packs. You could remove it completely and the core game loop would only improve. There's a reason why Elden Ring and Sekiro removed weapon durability completely.

Overall the devs have a lot to improve. I use so many Soulsborne comparisons because it really just feels like this game is trying to ape the Souls games (mainly BB and Sekiro) rather than try and do its own thing. There are decent enough new ideas in here but they're dragged down by the issues I mentioned. It's probably the best non-FromSoft souls-like out there but it's still a far cry from competing with FromSoft's level of quality. Great first attempt for the studio, they can only go up from here.

so, after beating the game, whilst my review has changed to be generally positive, the mismatched combat system, the multiple infuriating enemy and area designs (in places where continuity is lost) and the games in ability to focus on any one play style (it feels like it's trying to be every from game and in turn is incredibly mediocre on that regard) it overall (IN MY OPINION) barely scrapes past being an incredibly average souls like, which, to be fair, and average souls like is still a 6/10. i give this game a 7/10 on this arbitrary scale

edit: on track to get 100%, everything is going swimmingly, but belles quest is fucking bullshit. how was i supposed to know not to kill that guy. that's some stupid joke by one of the devs just to go "haha got em", what a fucking awfully designed quest

Holy moly I loved this game.  I got turned on to Lies of P from a video by Joseph Anderson and decided from that critique that this game was worth a try.  Best decision of 2023.

The combat is a shining jewel where clearly NEOWIZ put a lot of thought and lessons from From Software's games (and developers inspired by From Soft) to create a system that is engaging, fun, and challenging from the first minute to the final boss of the game.  And NEOWIZ decided an exemplary combat system was not enough- Lies of P story is nothing to ignore either.  Originally I thought "dark Pinocchio, really?" but holy dang I LOVE IT.  Some characters are hit and miss with people, but overall I cared about these characters and I needed to see what happened to them... and the treat is that finding out what happens, see more of the game world, is all executed through that excellent combat system.

Have you enjoyed From Software's recent games?  Then this is an easy recommendation for an experience you are probably going to thoroughly enjoy!  Heck, even if you're new to this style of game, I still recommend it as a fun and challenging game on its own right.

The best part?  They announced a sequel and a DLC expansion!  More of a great thing?  YES PLEASE!

I wanted to wait until I actually finished the game to put a real review out (It usually takes me a couple false starts to get through a game like this completely) but now that I have, this is -- as a lot of people have said -- almost assuredly the best non-From entry into the Soulsborne genre, and more than that, I'd actually put it higher than a couple of From's games. I had such an incredible time with this one, and the developer really seems to understand the formula beyond simply trying to copy it.

One aspect of the genre that often gets overlooked or lacks focus is the pacing and encounter design, and Lies of P -- for me -- absolutely nailed both. The playthrough where I finally beat the game took about 25 hours, and at ALMOST no point was I bored or exhausted or just wanting to get to the next thing. I think for Souls veterans the bosses MIGHT be tweaked a little on the easy-side? But that's honestly hard for me to judge because I am Poo-Poo Garbage at videogames. I never got stuck or had a ton of trouble with any bosses (save maybe a couple towards the end of the game). Your own results may vary, but I found most of the bosses very, very interesting to fight, and there's just enough of them without being TOO many.

Another area I think this game excels that I will touch on without spoilers but that I don't see a lot of people mention is NPC side quests. There are a handful of them and I found them all extremely compelling. Good characters with good stories that are doled out in a satisfying slow-drip over the length of the whole run. It's just really well-executed.

Bloodborne is my favorite game of all time, so I don't say this lightly when I say that Lies of P isn't just 'The Bloodborne We Have At Home.' Though derivative in its basic structure and function, Lies of P is its own thing and one of the best games I've played in recent memory.

I will offer one piece of spoiler-free advice though for anyone thinking about playing it who hasn't yet, and it has to do with what I said a couple paragraphs ago about ALMOST never being exhausted: Holy MOLY the last area of the game is LONG. Like, way longer than you think it's going to be. You'll think you're nearing the climax and it'll just KEEP GOING. It's all still really good, but bring some Gatorade and take breaks after bosses. Trust me.

This game has a lot of good things about it. If you're looking for a souls-like game, this is a great one to pick up. The story is fine, nothing to write home about. Very cool aesthetics, very cool world to be in. *This is a parry game.* If you hated Sekiro, you will hate this less, as it's a much simpler parry system. But you still have to parry. And even though you have to parry, the game does not keep things straight across the board when it comes to weapons. So if you want to use a giant sword, get ready for much slower parry reaction times. 

There are some cool boss fights and cool areas to explore. The in-game systems are easy to understand and there are a couple of interesting tools you get to help you in your battles that give the player a lot of options. There are your standard dex and strength builds, but then a few other options as well. 

Cons: 
Weapon range. I cannot tell you how many times, even with my giant sword, that I swung at things that are very close to me, I missed, and then was smacked by the same mob I was trying to kill. I don't know why, but they really hate the idea of weapon range being any where near realistic. My giant sword will go through mobs' bodies and do nothing. It's infuriating, but you do kinda get used to just being right next to every single thing you fight.

Run back times. The run back times, especially to bosses, are brutal. I'm talking 1min+, through mobs, through obstacles, just to get back to a boss, or if you're trying to get back to the place where you died, it can be even longer. Some elites respawn, some don't, so it can be just the worst grind trying to get through certain areas or just back to the boss.

The end of the game. The end of the game is 95% bosses and 5% mobs, and it's f&%$ing awful. Just grind after grind of these awful boss designs with no break. I think I'm on the last boss of the game at the moment, and I can't even bring myself to play. I'm just so burned out on endless boss reps and endless bad boss design. And I'm serious; the vast majority of the bosses in the last parts of the game are just absolute garbage piles of design. Remember all of the things that you hated in other souls games? Get ready to beat your head against a wall, because they don't give a sh!t and did all of the same awful designs for bosses. I've spent more time repeating boss attempts in the last parts of the game then I have spent playing the entire rest of the game; it's that bad. If you're amazing at parrying, you'll probably think it's easy, but if you're like me and are use to rolling, you're in for a world of hurt. 

Armor. The armor, or cosmetics, or a combination of the two, is seriously lacking. I don't want to spoil anything, but let me just say that it is very basic, and very boring. 

I want to reiterate, this is a good game. There's a lot about it that is good and intriguing to play through again. I just don't know that I would be able to stomach playing through the last part of the game again, considering I can't even make myself do it on my first play-through.

Everything in this game is either a slavish copy of an element of a successful game, or just bad. The only good parts are the graphics, and how well the game runs. 

The lore is shallow - I don't know how can people even compare it to the genius of From Software's world-building (perhaps they are shallow themselves?), the combat does not really work, because it's based on convoluted mechanics - like reclaiming health with attacking, and woefully unreliable, gimmicky defense. Inventory, buff and upgrade system, everything else is a meticulous, and absolutely unimaginative rip-off.

And attempt to ride the popular wave, no doubt, but ultimately, a mediocre one. The more you play, the more disappointed you become, and the very end of the game is just a boring chore of a three very badly designed boss fights.

I played the demo before it released and hated it, but I saw it was on sale a few weeks ago and picked it up anyway, I figured if everyone else loved it so much I must be doing something wrong.  I loaded it up promptly, prepared to keep an eye on my playtime so I could return it if necessary.

And then it clicked.  On my first try, I wiped the floor with a boss that stopped me dead in the demo.

This is the best soulslike I have played in years.  It's consumed my life for the last few weeks, I've played through it with feverish intensity, and now that I've rolled credits, I'm not exaggerating when I say I enjoyed it more than Elden Ring.  Its combat is tight and responsive, its bosses are (almost) universally masterfully designed, the world is moody and atmospheric, the music is spectacular, and the story is, to my surprise given the UI's slightly absurd obsession with the word 'lie', thematically tight and well-executed.

It really is that good.  If you're a fan of soulslikes, particularly the parry-heavy bloodborne style, you owe it to yourself to give Lies of P an honest try.

[h1]"People have no idea so many secrets are buried in Krat."[/h1]

[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Lies of P is a dark fantasy parody souls-like of the beloved children's tale "Pinocchio". By utilising stunning graphics, beautifully rendered audio, and a familiar formula, Lies of P seeks to join the higher echelons of the genre. But does it succeed at breaking free from its strings, or is it bound to be a puppet forever?

[table]
[tr]
	[th][b]🟩 Positives[/b][/th]
	[th][b]🟥 Negatives[/b][/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td]🟩 A wondrous story that stokes curiosity with every step and pushes you to uncover just one more secret.

🟩 The combat is the formula foundation in this game. It feels familiar and yet fresh enough that there is a learning curve. And with an array of weapons and items to choose and customise, you can make P your own.

🟩 Graphically, one of the most impressive games I've ever played.

🟩 The audio is exceptionally high quality and envelopes you in the experience as you explore the world. [/td]
	[td]🟥 Enemy variety is pretty slim, and in the latter portion of the game, you will only really find reskinned enemies from the early stages, who utilise scare and corner tactics to get a free hit in.[/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

[h1]Story[/h1]
You play as a puppet named P, awakened into a world of lies torn asunder by a catastrophe relating to the puppets. The voice that beckons you begs that you travel through dishevelled and blood-soaked streets to reach Hotel Krat, where she promises you answers, and your story will begin in earnest.

Without wanting to spoil anything, as the story becomes quite involved and intricate beyond the point of reaching the Hotel itself, I will leave the basic synopsis there. I will say that amongst all the games I have played in 2023, this is probably one of the best-written experiences I've had, and while it's far from perfect, it falls into the familiar traps of the soul-like genre. It achieves where many of its ilk fail by captivating its audience with an engaging setting, world and a story that unravels as you progress through it. I would highly recommend reading up some information as you go, as the story does become particularly intricate in the latter stages, and I wish I understood it more intimately before I advanced.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3123881898

[h1]Gameplay Analysis[/h1]
[h3]Bad children get the stick.[/h3]
As with most soul-likes, combat is a foundational part of the experience and becoming familiar with it is crucial to your success. Lies of P is no different and probably requires you more than most to learn the mechanics quickly or spend much of your time stuck on bosses who are often relentless in their onslaughts.

The main tools at your disposal are your weapon of choice and the innate ability to either dodge or parry enemy attacks, which can take a bit of practice to adjust to timings. As you progress through the story, more options for fights become available, such as the ability to heal, use wish stones that can buff you during fights and grindstones that add effects to your weapons to boost your damage output.

Your reward for killing almost anything in the world is Ergo, which acts as your currency and experience in this game. You can use it to buy items or level up your character's attributes to increase their effectiveness in a number of different ways.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3123886439

Thankfully, dying in this game isn't a brutal experience, as checkpoints usually aren't that far away, you can unlock shortcuts to make the run back quicker, and even if you were to die again on the way back to your Ergo deposit, you only lose a portion of the total, instead of it all.

Lies of P does an exceptional job explaining the mechanics as they open up, so you shouldn't have any problems unboxing them as you progress through the campaign.

[h3]Your lies are a rare ability. You are able to choose your own path.[/h3]
One of the most iconic mechanics of this title is your ability to guide your own story in an impactful way through the truth or lie implementation. At several intervals throughout the story, you will have the chance to tell the truth or to lie to progress, and both impact what will happen in the short and long term.

To complete the game, you will need to do roughly 2 or 3 playthroughs, so don't feel too pressured to go down a particular path for completion until you have to later.

[h3]"Another fine day in the city of Krat, but I wonder my friend, just where have you been...at"[/h3]
Exploration is pivotal in this game, as many of the best weapons and items are in dark alleys and rundown buildings off the beaten track. There is no practical way to tell what you've missed, so the best method is to be thorough on your travels and explore every inch of the world before you move on.

But items aren't the only reason to explore, as many of the quests during the game require you to delve deep into the world to complete them. Completing these quests will assist you greatly in your adventure by providing you with rare resources you couldn't have obtained otherwise.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3123885971

[h1]Audio and Visual[/h1]
The graphical quality of this game is above the standard I've experienced to date. It is a stunning experience that captivates the heart and mind of the person playing it from start to finish. The world is rich with colour and dynamic effects to keep you enamoured as you explore its many dark pathways and puppet-ridden avenues.

The audio is of the same exceptional quality. From the enthralling soundtrack that perfectly couples with the unravelling storyline and marvellously detailed world to the atmospheric detail as you walk the cobbled streets of Krat and beyond.

It is a truly captivating experience all-round.

[h1]PC Performance and Specifications[/h1]
With the game set to ultra quality and 2560 x 1440 resolution, I never saw the framerate drop below 60 FPS and didn't experience any visual discrepancies during the campaign.
🟨 As with all souls-like games, I played Lies of P with a controller.
RAM: 32GB (Under Load Usage: 43%)
CPU: i9 10900KA 3.70GHz (Under Load Usage: 27.3%)
GPU: MSI Ventus RTX 3080 (Under Load Usage: 43.5%)

[h1]Final Thoughts - Excellent[/h1]
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2529084785]Review chart here.[/url]
Probably amongst the best soul-likes I've ever played and rivalled even my beloved Dark Souls in terms of quality and experience. Lies of P is an exceptional experience for veterans and new players of the genre and will provide you with a solid experience regardless. With familiar enough mechanics and a familiar yet redesigned story that many of us would have read or watched at some point in our lives, weighed down only by its limited enemy roster, this is an unmissable experience worth every penny.

[quote]Krat has been torn apart by puppets and people lay dead in the street, but if you head to[url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/hellpurgatoryandparadise] Hell, Purgatory and Paradise[/url], you will receive the sanctuary and salvation you require to survive.[/quote]

[i]Review written in both french and english.[/i]

[h1]Français :[/h1]
Ce jeu est un chef-d'oeuvre ! Pour les fans des soulsborne et des souls-like, il vaut vraiment le détour !

[h3]Points positifs :[/h3]
- Les graphismes sont sa plus grande qualité. Le jeu est incroyablement joli, même en lowest.
- Très bien optimisé, pas besoin d'une machine de guerre pour le faire tourner.
- Certaines mécaniques ne sont pas simples à prendre en main, mais ça reste un point positif car c'est ce dont on pourrait s'attendre venant d'un jeu qui se décrit comme un souls-like.
- Le jeu se joue aussi bien à la manette qu'au clavier / souris, même s'il est fortement recommandé d'utiliser une manette.
- La difficulté est plutôt facile pour un souls-like, c'est un excellent jeu pour s'initier à ce genre.
- Les designs des personnages et des ennemis sont tout simplement bluffants. Le protagoniste dégage à la fois une aura de mystère et d'innocence et ça le rend bizarrement très attachant.
- L'ambiance générale du jeu est très réussie ; les décors sont sinistres et les cadavres d'humains, ajoutés au comportement des marionnettes et des pétrifiés qui font un peu penser à des zombies, ajoutent une sombre atmosphère post-apocalyptique au jeu.
- Il y a plein de mécaniques intéressantes qui font que, même si le jeu est évidemment inspiré des soulsborne, il ajoute sa petite touche qui le rend unique. Par exemple, les armes sont divisées en deux parties (lame et poignée) et le bras gauche du personnage peut être utilisé de diverses façons.
- Pour l'histoire, je n'ai rien à redire. C'est une histoire typique des souls-like : quelque chose a fait qu'une partie de la population est devenue dangereuse, on joue jusqu'à affronter le boss final et on débloque une des fins disponibles en fonction de nos actions tout le long du jeu.

[h3]Points négatifs :[/h3]
- Le système d'esquive ne sert pas à grand chose et est même parfois inutile contre certaines attaques ennemies, puisque ce sont les parades qui font bénéficier de bonus et d'avantages. Ça aurait été bien de voir un souls-like se baser sur l'esquive plutôt que la parade, pour une fois, surtout que les parades sont assez compliquées à caler et que c'est limite du frame-perfect la plupart du temps.
- Pareil, la durabilité de l'arme ne sert à rien, puisqu'on peut l'aiguiser à n'importe quel moment. La seule chose qui se produit si la durabilité atteint 0, c'est que l'arme se brise. On peut la réparer soi-même en se rendant à un stargazer ou utilisant un item assez rare mais rien de très punitif en soit. Il n'y a même pas de système qui fait que le personnage inflige moins de dégâts si la jauge de durabilité est basse, donc les malus sont pratiquement inexistants. Pour un souls-like, je pense que ça aurait été mieux d'avoir un aiguisoir à usage limité, ça permettrait de rajouter une difficulté supplémentaire.
- On peut changer de tenue et de coupe de cheveux, mais ça reste purement esthétique, étant donné que, de ce que j'ai constaté, ça n'apporte aucun changement aux stats.
- Ceux qui ont un PC gaming bas de gamme devront s'attendre à quelques lags, notamment pendant les combats de boss ou le chargement des zones.

Si vous aimez les soulsborne, ce jeu est ce qui se rapproche le plus d'un Bloodborne sur PC. Beaucoup de mécaniques sont similaires aux Dark Souls et les fans de la saga pourront sûrement apprécier Lies of P, que ce soit pour le gameplay, l'ambiance générale ou même l'histoire.

[hr][/hr]
[h1]English:[/h1]
This game is a masterpiece! For soulsborne and souls-like fans, it's definitely worth a try!

[h3]Positive points:[/h3]
- The graphics are its greatest quality. The game looks incredibly pretty, even on lowest.
- Very well optimized, no need to have a war machine to run it.
- Some mechanics are not easy to learn, but that remains a positive point because it's what one would expect from a game that describes itself as a souls-like.
- The game can be played with both controller and keyboard/mouse, although it is strongly recommended to use a controller.
- The difficulty is rather easy for a souls-like, it's an excellent game to get started with this genre.
- The characters' and enemies' designs are simply stunning. The protagonist exudes an aura of both mystery and innocence and that makes him oddly very endearing.
- The general atmosphere of the game is very successful; the settings are sinister and the human corpses, added to the behavior of the puppets and the petrified, which are a bit reminiscent of zombies, add a grim post-apocalyptic atmosphere to the game.
- There are lots of interesting mechanics which mean that, even if the game is obviously inspired by soulsborne games, it adds its own little touch which makes it unique. For example, weapons are divided into two parts (blade and handle) and the character's left arm can be used in various ways.
- As for the story, I have nothing to complain about. It's a typical souls-like story: something has caused a part of the population to become dangerous, we play until we face the final boss and we unlock one of the available endings based on our actions throughout the game.

[h3]Negative points:[/h3]
- The dodging system is not of much use and is sometimes even useless against certain enemy attacks, since the parries are what provide bonuses and advantages. It would have been nice to see a souls-like based on dodging rather than parrying, for once, especially since the parries are quite complicated to do and it's almost frame-perfect most of the time.
- Same goes for the weapon durability, since you can sharpen it at any time. The only thing that happens if the durability reaches 0 is that the weapon breaks. You can repair it yourself by going to a stargazer or using a fairly rare item but nothing very punitive in itself. There isn't even a system that causes the character to inflict less damage if the durability gauge is low, so the consequences are practically non-existent. For a souls-like, I think it would have been better to have a limited-use sharpener, that would add an additional difficulty.
- You can change your outfit and haircut, but it remains purely aesthetic since, from what I have observed, it does not bring any change to the stats.
- Those with a low-end gaming PC should expect some lag, especially during boss fights or when zones are loading.

If you like soulsborne, this game is the closest thing to Bloodborne on PC. Many of the mechanics are similar to Dark Souls and fans of the saga will surely enjoy Lies of P, whether it is for the gameplay, the general atmosphere or even the story.

Would recommend.

Although it is very derivative of several previous games such as Sekiro and Bloodborne, Lies of P is a game that manages to have its own personality and in my opinion turns out to be the most valid non-Fromsoftware soulslike game ever created so far.
Among its strong points we have the very detailed settings and in general an excellent attention to detail, the very well characterized and particular enemies (although they suffer from a bit of repetition), a combat system a bit "trial and error" but fun and somewhat clean and finally a story studied down to the smallest detail and conveyed very well to the user.
It remains a somewhat rough game but for being the first one created by this new gaming company it is certainly impressive, if they understand the mistakes made in this first game they are on the right path to a masterpiece
