I really enjoyed Lies of P a lot more than I thought I would. If you like souls-likes, I think this game is worth your time and money. But I'll list my pros and cons if you're on the fence:

Pros: 

The weapons and animations look and feel amazing. Getting a perfect parry into fable art into heavy attack stagger into heavy attack and then a quick light attack to finish the scripted "fatal blow" looks and feels amazing to pull off. I didn't know I needed combos like that, but now I do - they're really cool.

The weapons themselves are really cool. Bloodborne and Elden Ring are two of my favorite games of all time, but in both of those I struggled to find the weapon that really spoke to me. In Lies of P, the weapons were all fighting for my favorite and I regularly switched weapons just because there are so many cool weapons to choose from, not even to get into weapon crafting (which was awesome). 

I really enjoyed the story and characters - I don't want to spoil anything, but I will say that I was very skeptical, and the fact that this game mirrored the Pinocchio story was initially a turn off for me. The game changed my mind for sure. I'll be thinking about this story for a while. 

I enjoyed the enemy placement and encounter design. Traps and ambushes were fair and predictable, and almost always avoidable if you pay attention to environmental hints. 

The bosses in this game are sick. I really enjoyed all of them. I kept thinking I would be disappointing by the quality of them, but Lies of P keeps a high bar from beginning to end here. I didn't think any of them were a shocking difficulty spike either, but your mileage may vary here. 

I think they did an amazing job of tying gameplay elements into the narrative. 

Music also slaps.

Runs amazingly on steam deck. I got 60-90 fps right out of the box with no tweaking (I do use tools like cryoutilities).


Cons:

I think the level design was a little too linear for me. The upside of this is that I didn't have any fomo, since all the little secrets are pretty easy to find. In Elden Ring, if you want to complete a story line on your first play-through chances are you'll need a guide, in this game I was able to complete 80% of all the quests and stories in my first blind play-through (and could have done more if not all if I had payed more attention) to helpful hints such as the character icons in the fast travel menu indicating that a character has new dialogue. Regardless - the level design had more of an FPS feel to it where you're basically charging through a level with a straight line to the boss, unlocking shortcuts back to the starting spawn as you go. For reference, my favorite world design of all time is DS1 - I am not looking for open world, but this was really really a line in one direction. 

I don't like the "grab" telegraphs. A lot of them look like normal stabs and bait you to parry them, and it can be kind of annoying. I actually think that Sekiro solved this pretty well by providing you with a big "grab" icon when a boss was about to go for a grab, allowing you to react. 

Enemy variety felt a bit lacking, but the quality of the enemies felt good. It may be more of an aesthetic variety that I was missing as opposed to a mechanical variety. 

I don't like sprint being tied to the dodge button. Dodging with "B" is fine, but trying to sprint around the levels holding "B" and not being able to control your camera is annoying. For me this made exploration way more comfortable on steam deck where I could bind a back button to "B" and use that to sprint while keeping control of my camera. When playing on controller I had to curl my pointer finger around to rest it on the "b" button, which was not as comfortable. Ideally, I could have clicked in the left stick to toggle sprinting, but whatever.


Undecided:

I would say that several bosses have moves that you're supposed to die from on your first attempt or until you memorize the pattern. I really enjoyed figuring out each fight, and going from getting slammed to basically taking no damage the entire fight. That feeling when the tables start to turn on a hard boss is great. However, it doesn't always feel fair I guess? Compared to Dark Souls, Elden Ring, and even Sekiro, there were relatively few bosses I managed to take down on my first blind attempt because of the nature of their moves and attack patterns. I think there were a few main bosses I killed on my first try [spoiler](Parade Master, Mad Donkey, Fallen Archbishop, Corrupted Parade Master, and all of the lone stalkers+white lady)[/spoiler] and two that I killed on my second try [spoiler](Manus and Nameless Puppet)[/spoiler]. To me that felt like a fair enough balance. But there were definitely times where I was like "oh yeah you're supposed to die on that until you've seen it".

I like that costumes are not tied to defensive stats, but I wish you got more costumes early. My three favorite costumes didn't come until the final two stages of the game (at roughly the 85% mark), so I didn't feel like I really got to enjoy them until NG+. I also wish that there were more costumes and less re-skins of existing costumes, but at least the costumes that are available all look pretty cool. 

Not sure where I sit on boss runs (running all the way from a bonfire back to a boss room as opposed to reviving at the boss door). Not really a problem unique to this game, but when you're supposed to die until you've learned the boss the runs can get tedious. 

Some of the P Organ upgrades felt like they should have been base abilities (looking at you double dodge). However, it was probably good to be forced into learning the perfect parry, as it is pretty core to combat in this game. Having the improved dodge from the start would have left many players trapped in the midgame crutching on the dodge when they need to have already learned how to parry. So fair enough I guess. 

I loved this game. Highly recommend and looking forward to the DLC.

What a *great* game!
Either you enjoyed Dark Souls - and other souls-like games - or you didn't, you owe it to yourself to at least try Lies of P.
It's like if Bloodborne and Dark Souls (and a bit of Sekiro) had a magnificent baby with it's own character and personality.

From a great combat system, stellar Music, amazing graphics, amazing boss fights, - actual - story, gameplay and game feel, this is one of the best soul-like games out there, I would dare to say, even better that many of the games from FromSoftware (Ultrawide support, unlocked FPS, amazing hit detection boxes, again, an actual story delivery).

Around 20-35 hours to complete, more if you go for multiple runs, and *huge* replayability if you want - only parry run, only dodge run, heavy build run, ninja run, the list goes on -.

If this is the quality of souls-like that NEOWIZ puts out, I can't wait for they next game on the "Lies of" IP.

The best game I've played since Elden Ring. I have played all of Fromsoft's souls games (except for DS2 which I still have not completed), and in my opinion, Lies of P is not just the best souls-like out there, but it is one of the best souls games PERIOD. Great fun with elements on a souls like experience!
masterpiece

+ There is nothing truly innovative here, but the game manages to mix so many elements of FromSoft games into a combat system that is genuinely unique and, above all, incredibly fun. The perfect guard system works beautifully with the timings being just right as long as you learn the combos and animations of the enemies and bosses you're fighting. It's not quite Sekiro, since you need to hold the guard and figuring it how long to do that for, especially for fast combos, is part of what you'll have to learn. Short of a perfect guard, you take some damage but can regain it, a slightly tweaked borrow from Bloodborne that encourages an aggressive play-style and hints that you may need to try guarding for certain attacks or enemies. The secret lies in a balance of both dodges and guards, as you quickstep when locked on just like in Bloodborne, and finding that balance for each encounter was really fun for me. However, dodging is made a lot more easier if you can fast roll and fast rolling is enabled at < 30% equip load which makes Capacity, if you want to fast roll, the single most important stat in the entire game. A pretty important quirk to keep in mind.

* I do think the feedback for when you hit a perfect guard could have been better. It's there, through VFX and SFX, but it doesn't have enough oomph and I found myself often looking for the health bar to see if I lost any health or not. I did manage to get a better feel for them as the game progressed, but they're definitely not as impactful as Sekiro's "clang" of swords when you parry. That particular feedback is unmatched.

+ Being able to recharge one Pulse Charge when you've run out by either dealing damage or guarding perfectly was a stroke of genius. It is such a small consideration, but it affects game-play in a tremendous way, allowing for some breathtaking, nerve-wracking wins where I've managed to pull victory from the jaws of defeat against all odds, so close to dying. It is immensely satisfying when it happens.

+ The weapon system is the only thing bordering on innovation and it's really inspired. You can combine blades and handles of the various weapons you find to create some Frankenstein monsters of destruction. In my play-through I didn't really experiment much, but I've seen enough of other people playing with the system to know that it truly works and can reward you with some really powerful weapons that might be just right for your play-style. Boss-weapons can not be dismantled and reassembled, but they all have their own fun gimmick. I committed to the Two Dragons sword upon finding it and the parry on the charged R2 is so fun. Very difficult to time, but supremely satisfying and useful when successful.

+ Pretty much the entire boss line-up was great, all the fights consistently fun and, most of all, fair. Their animation work was both beautiful and clean, with attacks and moves being easy to read and thus timings fun to learn. Sure, some unnaturally delayed attack animations here and there, something I wish stayed with FromSoft's games, but nothing absurd or truly infuriating. Some mini-bosses also stand out, some truly tough fights peppered along the way to impede your exploration.

+ Visually, the game is an accomplished use of UE4 with great looking materials and direct lighting, a clean image and really stable and strong performance. No dips in frame-rate and no stutters across the entire play-through. There is some geometry lacking in detail here and there and the solution used for indirect lighting is very limited with some interiors showing extremely flat lighting, but overall the game is really easy on the eyes.

+ The story presentation was a step up from FromSoft's entries bar Sekiro with which it is pretty comparable. Even though P doesn't speak, there is a limited dialogue system which also allows you to choose between lying and telling the truth in various instances, a choice which has an effect on your character as well as the ending. That, coupled with some simple side-quests here and there, adds a level of interaction to the world that's usually missing in these games.

- In spite of the better presentation, I found that I couldn't care for the story, or the world, at all. The writing and voice acting are uneven and in many instances downright bad. Because of that, the world itself suffers as well; there is a magic missing that's present in FromSoft's entries, something that makes the world believable and lived-in even when it's desolate. That feeling I got when exploring Lordran and Yharnam is sadly missing here. Then again, FromSoft hasn't managed to recapture that in a while either (for me), so yeah >.>

- The level design is very linear as well, with very few side-paths and very straightforward shortcuts, just a funnel towards the next boss most often. Krat sadly did not employ Yharnam's urban planners. However, the variety of enemies is large enough that it compensates for the linearity and manages to save exploration from total boredom.

[h1]Where ER combat failed to adapt, Lies of P succeeds[/h1]
This game does such a brilliant job of integrating the sekiro deflect mechanics with traditional souls combat; something promised in Elden Ring but not fully delivered beyond a generic stance break ability.
Out of any souls game, this one allows me to approach fights absolutely however I'm most comfortable with. The entire game is playable with dodge rolling for example, although certain bosses will encourage certain combat styles, making it especially rewarding to master each system and recognise when to apply it. 

Better multi enemy fights than other Souls games, with good use of audio cues to help you understand what is going on off screen. Some super derivative bosses and movesets, but the aforementioned combat improvements make this less noticeable.

Lots of world building is delivered in order to flesh out the world; and ensure the endings have impact. Throughout the game it is clear that your choices are going to make a difference at the end, although the ambiguity creates a lot of tension. I ended up not liking my ending very much but that was because my choices had backed me into a corner decision wise.

The game feels very familiar, although progression is somewhat dated in comparison to combat - playing out more like DS2 with linear areas that don't necessarily transition smoothly, although lots of shortcuts and looping back in on yourself to enjoy. This isn't really a problem for me as the souls market is a little starved for linear level design at the moment. Areas are still for the most part memorable and distinct, although I would have liked the boss designs to be more representative of their arenas and the local enemies you fight before them.

[b]19 hours to beat[/b], although I am still missing one boss. Planning to complete the achievements for this as I'm loving the experience.

[h2]Completion Edit[/h2]

Now I have collected all the achievements for this game I'd like to slightly append my review.
I got to experience the rise of P ending for one of them, which requires lots of thought surrounding the humanity system. I think this was a great choice and gets the player to interact with things they otherwise might not, like the piano. 
My final run took me just short of 5 hours which is a great tell of the quality of a souls game. Once you master all of the mechanics and routes this game can be ran very fast which I think is excellent.

The story of this game is quite deep and am looking forward to it being expanded in the future. 

Certainly overall has to be a top 3 souls game for me, really just engaging mechanics used throughout that I will deeply miss when Elden Ring DLC finally releases. The parry, legion arm, fable art meter, health recovery system are all elements that just elevate the gameplay in this game well beyond almost every other game in the genre. It is of course beautiful and very thematic, while also being a solid length with a quality standalone story.

[b]42 hours to complete[/b]

ADVICE FOR NEW PLAYERS/THOSE NEW TO THE GENRE:

- START WITH THE "BALANCED" loadout, first. ALWAYS EXPLORE and take your time in battles. Practice the perfect parry with 1 enemy at a time, next to a Stargazer (Campfire). Make it a habit to do this and you'll SMOKE enemies. I don't want to give you a loadout to copy, as you wouldnt have your own journey, then.

HOWEVER, I will say:

- As one of your weapons, just to deal with electronic/robotic puppets better, use the ELECTRIC COIL HEAD and HANDLE as one of your 2 weapons. It'll help A LOT. If you want even more range on it and find a wrench weapon later (assuming you find it), use the wrench handle as a base and the coil head as the blade.

Oh and one more thing! Sometimes there's an easier solution to taking down a Mini boss! Such as the Puppet of The Future in the factory! have a good look around the area! (No spoilers~)

Completed my first playthrough and I have to say... what a gem of a game. The short review is that Lies of P does a great job of reimagining a classic tale through the lense of a contemporary genre.

I'll start the longer review by stating that knowing a bit about Souls games will make P a lot more enjoyable, but the story is a clear, obvious difference between P and typical Souls games. The classic Souls experience has an immensely fragmented story that takes significant additional research time to put together, if you even wish to do that. Given that the sell for Lies of P is that it's a Pinocchio story, it shouldn't be surprising that they took a different route and placed the story front-and-center. That said, it's wonderful how they asked "what would this story look like in a Bloodborne universe?" and then nailed it perfectly. It's actually not just BB, either: As I was playing, I got vibes from a mix of other games, be it Bioshock, Silent Hill, or Resident Evil, among many other influences I'm sure you can find. It perfectly demonstrates how "derivative" isn't always a bad thing. 

Similarly, you can expect a far more straight-forward level experience. Although it did at times feel like I was literally playing a copy/paste of a BB or DS area, the game is more-or-less linear. Area A leads to Area B and so on. There is exploration to be had within each area (and I highly recommend doing that), but unlike classic Souls designs, you're always going to be heading in a direction of clear progress that also advances the story. Souls games are almost defined by the exact opposite with hidden areas, hidden bosses (or "out-of-order" bosses), etc., and the ability to get easily lost. It's actually quite refreshing for someone like myself that has kids and can't necessarily sit and play for hours on end; I can come back to P and know exactly where I left off. Moreover, the game is good at providing clear indicators when something can be done to progress a side story/quest, which again helps a forgetful person like myself remember what I could be doing. It's a good design in my eyes.

Next, gameplay. P is a mix between BB and classic DS. Your movement is going to feel a lot like BB, but perhaps a bit slower, which is a characteristic the enemies share. Unlike BB, you have a guard, so that's more classic DS. The twist with P is that all enemy attacks do guard damage, which you can regain by landing attacks; however, you can negate this by guarding right as an attack lands, so it acts much like a parry. It's an important mechanic since there are large wind-up attacks that cannot be blocked and thus require this (or a dodge). I personally took a BB approach and went all-in on dodge, and it didn't seem to be an issue. Either way, the result is that you end up moving and fighting in a classic DS style, waiting for those big punish windows, but all with the look and flair of Bloodborne. 

This leads me to my only two real gripes with the game: The sluggish controls and often buggy interactions. Although combat will feel like a mix between BB and DS, it's kind of the worst of both worlds. Your dodge is not nearly as good as it is in BB and your build possibilities aren't nearly as extensive as DS. And then, very weirdly, I found myself getting stuck on walls a lot, even a couple times getting stuck on enemies and dragged about. Or, the occasional disappearing act when an enemy would clip into the environment and be stuck there (or worse, somehow get unclipped and surprise attack; that was fun).

The good news is that neither of those things is a gamebreaker. For one, they happen only enough to make you chuckle and shake your head. For another, the game gives you a ton of offensive mechanics to make up for weak defense. You have your typical DS variety of items to buff yourself or throw at enemies. There's no magic but you do have two separate meters that offer powerful special attacks. There's a durability aspect to your weapon, which I bring up only because you repair your weapon yourself as needed and the item you use to do so can be bolstered to offer temporary buffs as well. On top of that, you have a more traditional RPG skill tree that provides various boosts, be it offensive, defensive, or even utility (by expanding your inventory/etc.). So yeah, there's a lot you have to boost your power.

This actually leads me to the topic of difficulty. Even without all these tools, the game feels rather easy. I actually kept forgetting I even had meter attacks and it certainly didn't seem to make the game any harder. The LONE exception to this rule is the very, very final boss, which was really funny to experience a mostly stress-free playthrough and then have what was one of the harder bosses I can recall in a Souls game lol. Now, this could be viewed as a pro or a con, but like every soulslike, the game can be as hard as you want by simply not using whatever tools you think will make things easy or vice versa.

So, given that we don't (and maybe won't ever) have a Bloodborne 2, it was incredibly pleasant to play this game. BB is my favorite Souls game and it was nice experiencing that vibe again with a sincere spiritual successor. I hope they make more.

This game has an incredible combat system. You're able to combine blocking, parrying and dodging, but you aren't obligated to stick with any of them: Play however you want! Your weapons have light, heavy and charge attacks, as well as some special moves. You can stun enemies, riposte them, backstab them, throw some sawblades at them, break their weapons by parrying and blow them up with rockets even. And it all feels so damn fluid and satisfying.

The weapon variety is stunning as well. Your arsenal will have more than 40 weapons, each with its own moveset, special 'fable-arts' and sometimes even a gimmick.

But that's not all there is! You can separate all the normal weapons (29 to be exact) into a blade and a handle. After that it's time to create your own abominations of weapons, and there are literally no restrictions. Wanna slap the edge of a greatsword on the handle of a tiny knife? Do it. The handle decides your moveset and the edge dictates your swing speed. This system has lead me and my friend to sit in the hub area experimenting with different blades and handles for hours!

You're also equipped with a 'Legion arm', which allows for even further experimentation with builds. With these, you can hook enemies, electrify them, place landmines and more! You can also upgrade your 'Legion arms' to obtain new sick moves which add to your playstyle.

Speaking of level design, it seems as if the little bastard Miyazaki himself was involved here. The game is constantly trying to trick and kill you, makes the game feel fresh even after 20 hours of gameplay and keeps you on guard constantly (By the end of the game my friend was so paranoid he was walking through the corridors slowly never releasing his block button lol). The atmosphere and the gothic architecture are fabulous and remind of Bloodborne.

If you are curious about the bosses, you won't be disappointed. I don't remember a single boss fight where there wasn't a second phase. The designs are both awesome and scary. The fights themselves... Gorgeous! The attack patterns are very fluid and diverse. The 10-hit combos are reminiscent of Sekiro, and it feels so good to parry each blow. My friend says some bosses are too tanky, but I think everyone is granted a fair amount of health.

There is also a cute cat you can pet in the hub area. ^^

The only complaint I have is that the game is very, very linear. There are no optional areas, thus you're likely not going to miss on much content throughout your first playthrough. There are a few optional bosses though, but the 'optional' aspect is decided by how you will act in certain dialogues.

Definitely a must-play if you like the souls genre.

Lies of P is an amazing souls-like and is definitely on-par with the FromSoftware titles.

Lies of p review:

i just completed my first playthrough, and i gotta say i'm impressed.
The music hits different and the boss/combat themes are masterpieces.

The areas are beautiful and well crafted. However there arent really any hidden areas/bosses, Fortunately that isnt really a problem for me atleast. There is also alot of different enemies making every new area engaging (i just played LOTF)

The weapon system is unique and fun, making the weapon that best suits your playstyle.
The fable moves are fun and provide some different utility, i didnt play with them that much though. One thing about them is they can be used without stamina, which can be useful in certain situations. The same can be said for the legion arm, not too powerful but useful in its own way.

The parry/ guard is an excellent addition to the souls genre, giving the player more options to counter and attack makes it more engaging. An example would be laxasias first phase double horizontal swing or rapid slash combo, you cant dodge it if you're too close, but parrying works like a charm. the opposite can be said for victor where dodging is your best friend. Sometimes the optimal thing to do is just run around/away from a certain attack to either punish or simply be safe. This makes learning the bosses so much fun.

The bosses were very good, and i can say that laxasia has landed within my top 5 souls bosses. The only bad thing i can say about them is that some of them (Manus especially, since he's the second last boss) need more moves, but I think all souls bosses need more attacks. I guess it doesn't really count as critique then, more a personal wish. 

If wish fable attacks and legion arm played a bigger role / were more powerful to incentivise their use, but they do get stronger from scaling so idk. There isn't really anything I would add/change to make this game better. It has good music and feels incredibly fun to play. I have to give the game a 10/10

Completely rewriting this after playing through 2 more times in NG+/+1 and 100%-ing the game.

Great Soulslike with more replayability than FromSoft titles for me. Lies of P is a lot shorter than DS3/ER and is linear and quicker paced. This, combined with the additional progression systems of Legion Arms / P-Organ which are kept and expanded in NG+/+1 are an incentive to replay it multiple times to completion. The game is definitely more fun in NG+ than NG, in this way it's similar to Nioh 1/2.

Game controls great, basically the same scheme as ER/DS3. Looks very nice and runs well. The in-game records you can find and listen to are well-made and are way more memorable than the general soundtrack, which didn't really stick with me. The additional progressions (Legion Arms / P-Organ) are a very good addition that let you customize an alternative attack/tool and various stats. You can't obtain every Legion Arm upgrade in a single playthrough, but by NG++ you can have them all maxed out. New P-Organ tiers and bonuses are unlocked in NG+ and NG++. Unfortunately no new tiers are unlocked beyond NG++ apparently, which I'm hoping gets expanded on in the future. Resetting your Level, P-Organ, and Legion Arms is possible, though it costs a resource obtained just by waiting. I'm also delighted that only about 3 bosses have a grab attack, thank God.

Parrying feels more useful on NG+ runs, as on a first run you'd never really spend long enough on a boss to learn the timings for perfect parries. It's also more punishing than just dodging, especially when it comes to Fury attacks. On my NG run I almost never bothered with parrying, relying almost exclusively on the dodge and quick attacks of the Rapier. The lack of parrying and blocking also meant I usually never had to repair my weapons mid-fight (except bosses who use a status effect to break your weapon). The game features a lot of two-phase boss fights which feel like (or are) completely different fights between the phases, so I hope you like those. There also multiple-boss fights which are probably the most annoying ones. Thankfully there is only one single gimmick fight.

Overall, just play it. And hope they add more stuff for NG+++.

***9/10***

If someone told me FromSoft made this game, I would have believed them. This is the only soulslike I've ever played that met the quality of the actual Souls games, feeling like a true successor to Bloodborne. While most boss fights don't feel as difficult as From's, that's not necessarily a bad thing. Each boss is a spectacle in its own right, and the more gimmicky ones are incredibly fun to fight. The OST is so much better than it needed to be, you can feel the amount of time and effort that went into each track, especially in the collectible records. The weapon assembling mechanic is great, increasing your available weapons exponentially each time you find a new one, granting an insane amount of build variety. It's super easy to respec your character whenever you want, so you never feel locked into one build, and there's no need to worry if you level up an unnecessary stat by mistake. The game has Sekiro's parry, Bloodborne's rally, and a connected world akin to Dark Souls 1, among other things from From's games, making it feel like a celebration of the genre in the best way possible.
If you're a fan of Bloodborne, or any Souls game, this game is a necessity.

Now it's time for me to grind out the rest of the achievements while I wait for DLC or a sequel.

Worst "souls-like" game i've ever played - in comparison to Elden Ring and even Lords of the Fallen this game is a clunky, trial of misery with lack of fun. 
1. All of your usual "souls-like" mechanics are locked behind items and unlocks you don't get till after you beat the game. So the regular dodge, block, counter, iFrames, that are core to the Souls-Like genre are missing until then. NG+ ends up being what the first play through should have felt like.

2. The balancing is backwards in the most un-fun way. This means mini-bosses and story bosses move lightening fast, with massive string combos and instant teleport/lunge strikes. The rest of the enemies in between move like slugs, with slow attacks that are just "free kills" with no fun - because the game is so short they NEED you to grind for it to last more than 5 hours.

3. Your character moves rediculously slow in comparison to other souls-likes. You will be wishing you were in Elden Ring, Lords of the fallen, or Monster Hunter instead. This makes most boss fights seem super annoying and spammy, without any cool boss moments in the fights other than all bosses being multi-phase transformers.

4. Almost all of the "items" you pick up are throw-aways. Not worth using. Why? low damage, and with your "summon" for all the fights that matter, the summon will do most of the fighting for you. Your character just spams attacks while not targeted.

5. The Skill point system (P-ORGAN) Most of the skills you unlock are just basic skills you get from the very START of souls-like games, with the exception of healing items. I didn't feel like I was getting more powerful when I was leveling up, I just felt like I was trying to get closer to the starting character of Elden Ring or Lords of the fallen. Really felt bad for skill progression.

6. The weapons are mostly bad, with the exception of 6 weapons, not counting the end boss weapon. Additionally, even though you can "craft different weapons" most weapons only had stats for 1 of 3 types of gameplay and were poorly optimized. This meant only one third of the weapons found would be useable, and of those only 2 would be keepers. 

7. The story - oof. I bought this game for the concept of a Pinnochio souls-like story. There is almost no story. The razor thin veneer of the story just has Geppeeto & the cricket with maybe 15 lines the entire story, which are just casual observations of what is already going on. No character development, no attachment to characters, no feeling that this is a Pinnochio story at all. Just a throw away gimmick.

终于通关了，我发现我之前的评论大错特错。
这个游戏的机制并不是鼓励弹反，而且鼓励进攻，尤其是能打出硬直的多段攻击。
它给了4种攻击方式，普通（轻攻击及重攻击）、虚构攻击、义手攻击以及道具攻击。
4种攻击攻击如果安排得当、相互衔接，并对敌人弱点进行针对，那么整个战斗就会舒服无比，而且这种优势是游玩时可以明显感受到的。
另外，武器组装系统的加入，使得普通（轻攻击及重攻击）更加多样性。后期我用的是人偶斧头+匕首柄，其轻攻击相对较慢但威力充足，而重攻击反而攻速较快、可形成多段攻击，使得战斗中不仅攻击力足够，也容易打出硬直。
不过上面这些，都需要在后期升级完成的情况下才能感受到，前期的进攻手段确实非常受限。而且有些地图也非常恶心。另外，谜语之王以及冻结盛宴的支线任务奖励很丰富，但是太容易断了。

Easily the best Soulslike I've ever played. Imo when it comes to combat and weapon mechanics, this game triumphs virtually every single Fromsoft game - and that's not an exaggeration.

It's got the movement-heavy dodging and customization / stat distribution of Dark Souls / Elden Ring. It's got the deflection / blocking / stamina system from Sekiro (with a twist to up the skill required and to make it align better with the more traditional souls-esque mechanics). It's got a similar health regain mechanic to Bloodborne that emphasizes constant aggression, and similar weapon functionality (with more customization).

Its story and art direction, imo, is absolutely fantastic, and the music you find on vinyls throughout is nice too. I think where this game really falls off, though, is area variety. Though the combat, enemy variety and level design is on par with, if not better than, Fromsoft's games, I think the actual visuals are a little lacking. Though it's very graphically impressive - certainly moreso than Elden Ring - it struggles to make full use of that graphical fidelity to its full potential. Most areas feel very similar. Some areas seem like they're going to have potential only to end up being the same drab, desaturated tunnel / city street / wooden-plank-platform area. Its areas also don't feel lived-in or real in any way, making the whole experience somewhat video-gamey, turning what could be very cool areas into somewhat boring paths that lead from boss to boss. 

That being said, the bosses are excellent, as are the enemies. If you're willing to live with areas that are about as colorful as half of Dark Souls III, you'll have a great time.
Takes a little to get used to coming fresh off of Sekiro/Elden Ring but about halfway through I really started to enjoy it!

All this game does is show that the FromSoft formula is near perfection. The game itself is good, but not worth the hype. It's a 7/10 at best. I really don't like the parry mechanic being the main point. I hated Sekiro as well because of the "perfect parry" mechanic. I think it really takes away from what makes these games good. It wants you to be aggressive like Bloodborne, but then also play slow and just parry until you get a stagger off. It doesn't really work well in my opinion. 
My personal build is Motivity, so my attacks are very slow. I will parry and barely get 1 attack in after the enemy's chain of attacks. The heavy charge attacks are also so slow, that it makes it really hard to get it off before getting hit. 
The world is linear, which isn't a bad thing, but the areas feel really small and have no real substance besides enemies. I think the areas with "zombie" like creatures in the woods is also pretty random.
Lastly, I feel like the enemies are either too easy or too hard. Minibosses are everywhere and even sometimes right before a checkpoint. I will choose to run to the checkpoint door and open it before fighting them, which I never felt I had to do in other souls games. Bosses are extremely hard, as it's all just about parrying all the attacks. Bringing in a summon almost hinders you in certain fights, because it makes it harder to get a stagger off when they take the aggro.
All in all, it's an okay game with many similarities to FromSoft games. I just think the world, story, fighting, and enemies could use work.

After putting off playing this game, I'm so glad i finally did.
The absolute best souls-like I've played that is not from FromSoftware.
The aggressive combat, fantastic level design and great bosses all from a developers first shot at this type of game make me excited to see how the genre will develop more in the future.
Easy recommendation for anyone still waiting for that Bloodborne PC port.

Overall:

I wouldn't really recommend unless you're a Soulsbourne player. I did my first playthrough with specters (summons) because of the difficulty and it made the game hard to appreciate. I did my second playthrough by fighting all the bosses alone and that made the game actually click and feel fun and empowering.

Gameplay & difficulty:

I'm not a huge souls person, but LoP is really good and kind of worth it. It's not perfect, and some of the challenge is just made messy by certain architectural decisions of the fights. The main complaint is that every attack has this obnoxious arbitrary pause window that makes the flow of enemies feel unnatural and you thus can't intuit when to perfect block, you can only learn the timings via memorization.

Story & world:

Absolutely fantastic world building and characters. Still has the NPC conversation story telling mechanics like other soulsbourne games... but I think this does it better, and it also has cutscenes that both tell a story and are artistically brilliant. Specifically the animations & music in the boss entry cut scenes are absolutely superb. I did 3 runs of the game to get all trophies and I skipped most cutscenes where the weight of them was learning the story, but there's a few where I watched at every opportunity because they're just that good.

Trophy collecting:

If you're only doing a single play-through, you can ignore this.

The fact that you have to do NG+ (or at at least most of it) to get all the trophies kind of blows because NG+ makes the game kind of frustrating as all basic enemies do 10x damage, so exploring the world becomes annoying as there's so many enemy traps that assume you're going to get ganged up on and surrounded... which basically means you die. I ended up just running straight through a lot of the last level which is full of this, whereas I actually really liked that level in the base game.

You also have to do a lot of playthroughs to get all the trophies. Though if you have multiple devices there's ways to get multiple endings in a single playthrough.

Performance:

This thing could run on a potato. I get nearly 60 FPS consistently on the Steam Deck at low settings. On my 3080 PC at 4K, I get around 105-120 FPS depending on how busy the current environment is (e.g. boss fights run consistently at 120 but areas loaded with enemies run a little closer to that 105).

Best non-FromSoftware souls game.
This is a combo of Bloodborne & Sekiro for a fainted heart. 
A 9/10 souls experiment.

⁃ The levels are too linear.
⁃ No poise mechanics at all.
⁃ All side quests are very flat and simple.

Why it’s so great then?
 +  Weapons combination is a new fun tool for players.
 +  Beautiful story with multiple endings.
 +  All characters are created and polished so fine.
 +  Move-sets of enemies are so well matched with their identities.
 +  Souls retrieval upon death concept is good.
 +  Perfect deflections lead to weapon break down.
 +  Soundtracks and graphics are stunning.

Pros:
+ Gorgeous art style and visuals, the game captures the magnificence of the belle epoque down to the smallest detail, from buildings to clothing it is a masterpiece to look at from start to finish.

+ Varied and versatile combat system, between the dozens of weapons, legion arms, items and passives you can build your personal P to face the horrors of Krat, making this game the first one to really challenge From Software in the combat quality department.

+ A gripping story that reinvents the Claudio Collodi characters into a spectacular dystopian tale about the nature of one self, from our protagonist P to all the supporting casts and bosses, every character has a place in the story being told.

+ Top Notch level design, the streets of Krat and surroundings are filled to the brim with stuff to find, secrets to uncover and vistas to enjoy, exploration in this game is a pleasure.

Cons:

- Some players might find the maps to be slightly too linear but its really a minor nuisance.

Lies of P is a masterpiece in the Soulslike genre, reaching From Software level of polish, quality of combat, level of character costumization and fairness and brutality of bosses. No player that has even the slightest passion for the genre should skip on having Lies of P in their collection of games, especially with an expansion and sequel on its way.

Just buy it and you wont regret it.  9.5/10

A great Souls-like, one of the best even. It beats Dark Souls 2 thats for sure. 

It's a very tight experience, with linear levels and a more straightforward story (Which isn't bad). 

The combat has to *click* to be enjoyable. If you approach it exclusively like Dark Souls, Sekiro or Bloodborne you probably will have a hard time, and even if you mesh with the combat bosses can be a true challenge and pain in the ass depending on your build and willingness to adapt. 

Overall it's a great time. Tight combat, an enjoyable story based on pinocchio, and a fun and interesting upgrade curve/weapon upgrade system make this worth the 60 Euros, and it becomes a steal when on sale. Any fan of Souls-likes should at least give it a try.

This game's movement and combat feels directly in line with Bloodborne, Dark Souls 3, and Elden Ring, despite having significant mechanical differences. If you enjoy how those games feel, compared to Demon's Souls, Dark Souls 1, and Dark Souls 2, you will have a good time.

The game's parry system is sort of a hybridization of Bloodborne's rally system and Sekiro's parry system. It works very well. For the vast majority of the game you can just dodge, but there are advantages to mastering parrying.

Atmosphere is very similar to Bloodborne, but not identical. This is not just Bloodborne at home.

Performance is perfect. I'm on a Ryzen 5800X and Radeon RX6600. Buttery smooth. Graphics are excellent.

The thing that this game actually does better than FromSoft's Soulsborne catalog is telling a story. With the exception of Elden Ring (and Sekiro if you believe that Sekiro is a Soulsborne game), Soulsborne games are exceedingly light on NPC interaction outside of the player hub, and the lore usually requires extensive item reading and YouTube video watching to understand. Elden Ring, IMO, is a partial improvement in this regard. Lies of P has a clear and straightforward narrative, not dumbed down per se but definitely not requiring the mental gymnastics and item description consumption that the Soulsborne titles do. There is nothing wrong with how FromSoft does things, but it is refreshing to play something in this genre that mixes this gameplay style with more traditional storytelling.

Soundtrack is top tier. I bought this game on sale but went back and picked up the soundtrack as well.

If you are a Soulsborne veteran, most of this game will not challenge you. All the lessons that you picked up from those titles will make large portions of this game a breeze. Moreover, there is so much quality of life upfront that it blunts the difficulty: You can easy teleport between "Bonfires" and after the first boss you get an item that lets you teleport to "Bonfires" and the player hub without losing "Souls". Pocket "Souls" tell you how many "Souls" you get from using them. Mid-to-late game gives you respec options. You don't have boss runs once you unlock level shortcuts. There are items that let you adjust weapon scaling depending on preferred stats, and non-special weapons can have their blades and handles be mixed and matched to let you craft weapons that match your preferred stats and weapon abilities. The game has an extensive perk tree that you can upgrade your character with, allowing for very extensive customization that lets you make your character very strong in your preferred way. There is probably more, but these all standout. If you are a Soulsborne noob and want something to ease you into the genre, I can't think of a better game (Code Vein is also good but even easier yet). If you are a veteran, you may have a bad time if all you care about is difficulty. If you are a veteran and want something that will punish you for lack of effort but won't push you to your limits, this is the game.

There is only one reason why I don't rate this a full 10/10. Two of three endings of this game require you to fight an optional final boss after the main final boss. This optional final boss is a huge difficulty leap over every single other boss in this game. Unlike before, I had to farm for throwable items, respec into a parry build, and master the parry system, which I had managed to otherwise skip purely due to my mastery of previous Soulsborne titles carrying me through. I subtract 0.1 from my score not because of any resentment over having to get good, but because this explosive leap in difficulty crashed into my immersion from the prior portions of the game's emotional ending. This nitpick is barely worth talking about compared to the immense amount of fun I had otherwise, but I feel that I would be dishonest if I left it out of this review.

Despite not being able to give this a full 10/10, I do consider this to be a masterpiece. It's worth the full price, though I always recommend people buy on sale when they can. This game deserves all the love it's getting. There is a small sequel hook at the end, though based on what I could see it's not a direct sequel to this game's story so much as another story set in the same world. When it comes to sequel hooks, you know that the game you are playing or movie you are watching is excellent if you have no problem with said hook. I had no problem. I hope these developers get a chance to make the game they hinted at and I will gladly buy it when it releases.

Liked:
- Unique world and setting, with references to classic tales but a unique story
- Satisfying combat against challenging but fair enemies
- Lots of mechanics to encourage a variety of playstyles, such as guards, parries, special attacks, and utility attacks
- Satisfying levels with secrets to uncover and new challenges in combat and exploration
- Unique, varied bosses which present new challenges without being unfair
- Lots of customization in stats, weapons, skills, and abilities for various unique playstyles

Disliked:
- Some minor performance issues, such as one boss getting stuck and enemies occasionally not loading
- Levels are a bit too linear, with exploration being limited to finding some items
- A lot of progression mechanics, making remembering how they all work a bit tedious

[b]Lies of P[/b] is fantastic.

After Sekiro, I have been feeling discomfort around From Software’s releases; on one hand, I enjoyed Elden Ring and Armored Core 6, but on another hand, I didn’t get that overwhelming satisfaction I had, completing them in the vein I felt when completing Demon’s Souls, Dark Souls 1-3, Bloodborne, and Sekiro. Since I haven’t found a 3D Soulslike that clicked the way those did, I felt like I needed to resign my hopes for another experience like what I had in 2019.

Then P showed up out of nowhere for me and blew me away in its execution. I will now refrain from referencing From’s catalogue and focus on P and only P. It’s easy to compare it to those other games, but I believe P deserves to stand proud without references. There are three strengths to P: [u]Combat Mechanics, Encounter Variety, & Atmosphere.[/u]

Mechanically, the way you engage with combat seems, at first, like a standard-fair experience, but there are a lot of little nuances that create its own identity. Let’s talk about what you’re going to be doing a lot in the beginning of any new Soulslike: Getting hit, something you’re inevitably going to endure before you can git gud. P offers a twist in how you mitigate damage by taking blocking and turning it into a temporary punishment. You lose temporary health when you block, requiring you to quickly attack in between blocks to restore that health, or perfect-time block to take no damage. This is in addition to dodges w/ standard I-frames. Where this becomes engaging is how you need to find a sweet-spot between dodging difficult hits and then taking gambles to perfect-block more predictable hits. Your encouragement to perfect-block is two-fold: One, you can only perfect-block fury (red) attacks unless you can physically out-run the attack. Two, successful perfect-blocks cause posture damage more rapidly than hitting, allowing you to swiftly guard break foes for massive damage. A fun detail about this is you’re not necessarily required to always perfect block, as a later-perk allows you to restore temporary-health from perfect guards, meaning that if an enemy is flurrying you with several hits, getting a mix of perfects and non-perfects can still result you taking no damage, so long as you are landing those perfects in the end of that flurry.

In my opinion, this is very engaging. On top of that, you have a healing and weapon-degradation system that brings new twists on these played-out aspects of the genre. Healing are basic, replenishing on resting, but the real show-stealer is the unique comeback mechanic, where dealing damage and perfect-guarding after your last charge is spent allows you to slowly refill 1 charge (and only your last). This means even when a fight is not going well, there is always a chance to turn your pending failure into a last-minute success. Weapon-degradation is also built-in perfectly by creating a tension you need to be wary of, specifically during long-engagements with boss-fights. You’re always able to replenish your durability, but it costs you seconds of exposure, meaning you need to find gaps in your opponent’s aggression to repair, which is exciting and intense during specific encounters.

Finally, regarding combat mechanics, weapon-equipping has no restrictions apart from weight (an easily avoided problem with well-considered loadouts), which means you are free to equip any weapon and experiment to your heart’s content; upgrade resources aren’t too hard to acquire apart from cap-stone resources, which means it doesn’t feel like a grind-chore to boost up a new weapon you’re interested in. Best of all is the weapon-crafting, itself, where you’re able to mix blades with move-sets. Another way to think of this is mixing damage-type and current-level enhancement with move-set and scaling. Found a greatsword you boosted early-on but want to try out this spear you just found? Stick that sword onto that shaft and now you have a spear-sword. Or maybe you’re a mad-lad and want to stick it onto a rapier-hilt so you can pretend that big hunk of steel is an estoc. You’re never really punished for making these decisions, and it’s just fun to find combinations that suit your current needs. There’s no spell-casting, which in a way keeps you focused on honing the aforementioned combat, but there is Legion for limited-used special moves, and Fable attacks, which are unique to your weapon and hilt, which are replenished from hits and perfect blocks. Customizing your puppet and seeing the combinations you can land with these tools keeps the whole package rewardingly fresh.

Enemy variety comes with its own discovery, as the roster is as perfect as one can expect from this genre. Without spoiling a fun twist that happens past the half-way point of the game, you can be sure to expect new enemies and new ways the enemies engage with you from beginning to end. Up to the very end of the game, you are being introduced to either new enemies or new twists in previously-encountered enemies; even the final non-boss enemy you fight is unexpected. As for boss-variety, it’s solid and comes with all different flavors: Slow moving, Fast-moving, passive and dangerous, aggressive and flurrying, you name it. Even on a third playthrough on NG++, I was always excited to revisit each boss, because I knew I was going to have the opportunity to enjoy the dance each of them provides with new loadout perspectives. Challenging yourself to perfect-block the majority of their moves is some of the most enjoyable game-play I’ve had recently.

Last detail I want to highlight is the atmosphere, and it doesn’t disappoint. In addition to being moody and thick with excellent music, I found this to be one of the rare Soulslikes to make me feel engaged with its world in a way many do not. I’ve never been a fan of the ‘items tell the story’ approach, and I found that because there was an active narrative being told, it made me want to learn more about the world. A question I like to ask myself when playing any game is “What would life be like in this setting?” And when it comes to a lot of soulslikes, unfortunately, I always find myself unable to really imagine existing in those settings. They are, for the most part, worlds to explore and destroy bosses in. In P, however, you’re given a bleak depiction of what the setting of Krat was, and what it has become, which means I’m not just motivated to enjoy fun combat, I also feel like more attuned to what my character is and his goal. As annoying as Gemini sometimes can be, I enjoy having exposition and world-building to help me care more about the world I’m exploring.

Did I say the soundtrack is excellent? I did. I’ll say it again. It’s excellent!

Shortcomings are focused primarily in one section for me, which is that the exploration is only satisfactory. It’s not awful, but it’s also not amazing. If everything else I described is between B+ and A+, this is a C+. It’s engaging and has visual variety, but it is ultimately linear, with only few deviations from course to find fun treasures. The combat and weapon-variety do some [i]intense[/i] heavy-lifting to compensate for this shortcoming, so I believe if a future sequel addresses this problem, I’d call it a perfect package. One plus-side is that the rest-points are well-placed, so I never feel like I’m running into them too-frequently. That adds good tension, especially on that first play through where you’re still learning to stop getting hit.

Overall, Lies of P is a wonderful time, and if you are someone who found From’s latest games to be a bit on the disappointing side, you deserve to check this out.

My only major nitpick would be that the areas towards the end of the game are essentially just back-to-back elite enemy encounters that go on for far too long, to the point of tedium. It's a slog and it made me wonder whether the devs actually wanted anyone to reach the end of the game. But overall, if you like Souls-like games in the style of FromSoft titles, then definitely don't skip this one. It is ridiculous how detailed and polished this game is considering the team behind it.

I really recommend checking out Iron Pineapple's video on this, but there are many others who have amazing videos on the pros and cons, in detail, why this game is so good. This game has high praise and it's well deserved. It's extremely polished, extremely fun, and extremely difficult. I have flawless performance, the game looks gorgeous, and it even supports ultrawide displays, too.

A written review can't do justice imo. Check out some of those creators, and see if this game is a good fit for you. This is an extremely high quality game. Beautiful work from Round 8 Studio and Neowiz and I'm excited to see what they cook up next.
Great souls-like game. A bit easier than elden ring but combat is a bit similar to sekiro, especially the parry system. The world building is very interesting and the graphics are insane.

What can I say that already hasn't been said about this game. It's awesome, fun combat, cool enemies and bosses and a story/lore that was actually more interesting than I was expecting. As far as wearing your inspiration on your sleeve I feel like this game does it about as well as you can. The inspirations are clear but they've definitely used it to their advantage to make a really solid game. Personally I'd say this team has done a surprising amount of innovating on the formula as well as bringing new things unique to this game to the souls-like genre. If I had to make some critiques the biggest would probably be the levels/world. While it isn't completely linear they could've done more with exploration and the layout of level progression. But the actual issue is more related to the architecture, many textures used are pretty copy and pasted and a bit uninspired at times. Additionally many buildings or other structures in the world often don't fit together well, in a literal sense, like building parts overlapping and feeling out of place or not thought through. The only other genuine complaint I'd have is that a lot more could've been done in regards to legion arms and p organs skills. The arms that are there are interesting and useful but there is a lack of variety overall and quality use cases for utilizing every legion can sometimes be infrequent. For the p organ skills it did feel like too many of them were uninspired behind the scenes incremental stat increases, and while those have their place and are good to have more interesting/fun skills are definitely needed. Overall legion and p organ are both solid systems but they have a lot of potential that wasn't utilized, hopefully the dlc will expand on this.
 
Lies of P is a great game, its highs are very high and its shortcomings are all reasonable and can be improved upon with more budget/time this team will hopefully have with future entries or other IP's they'll work on. If a 9 is a masterpiece and a 10 is an industry defining masterpiece then lies of p is a very solid 8/10.

The Tinman awoke confused and dazed, the blue fairy spoke, he nodded in reply... 

The springs and cogs that made up his body sparked with life, as the Tinman succumbs to gaslit truths...

Deep within, he knew he cannot die, arriving at a hotel, he chooses to lie...

By following whispers the Tinman found his secret, inside held the key, to knowing his youth...

The heart of a puppet beats loudly, for the fairy begs forgiveness...

The clock strikes, for the strings began to wither, Geppetto's Puppet became ever darer...

The arm binds what was thought lost, a father's sacrifice, he gives us...

The Tinman grows angry, ending this error, but there was still something he had to give her...

Finally he rests a sorrow head, for the fairy thanks this Tinman...

Ruby slippers tap 3 times, we as the viewer, know there is something bigger...

One of the best souls-like I've played 9/10.
-Beautiful design: Seriously, the world artstyle is amazing and depending where you are on the game the hotel will start changing , like your nose on the wall painting , really good details . 

-Combat: Perfect blocks feel SO GOOD. Unlike most Souls games, hits feel powerful and slow, but landing that perfect parry is euphoric. Especially the fatal attacks, they feel incredible.

-Weapons and builds: Mixing blades and handles to change scalings is awesome , Literally any weapon can be viable, which is super fun. Plus, the Fable Arts add another layer of customization. And resetting Paragon with gold coin fruits just lets you experiment builds all you want. The Legion arms are cool too, this game just nails build variety.

-Rich story: Your choices, your lies, your humanity, all shape the story and lead to different endings. It's dark, sad, and depressing, but in a good way. The cinematics are great and you get attached to the characters, so the ending hits hard.

Bad stuff
-Camera: It NEEDS more options. Stop rotations, adjustable FOV, especially for big bosses. Not seeing their attacks because they're off-screen is annoying.

-Level design: 70% is amazing, but the other 30%… ugh. Annoying enemy placement that blocks paths or pushes you off edges. Not cool nor fun.

-Body blocks: This is the WORST. Jumping enemies cornering you and getting stuck with no movement or visibility? Died to this SO many times. It happens everywhere, stairs, corners, even under bosses! Getting stuck under a boss after a perfect block is just unfair specially with the swamp boss.

-Artificial difficulty : Some bosses are super annoying with faking attack animations , NG+ you literally get 1/2 shot by almost everything , grabs are super annoying on some bosses , the game has a lot of artificial difficulty implemented but if you get used to it you'll clear the game with no problems.

Things to keep in mind

-Difficulty: It's HARD. If you're new to Souls games or a casual, get ready to learn about perfect blocks, if you don't learn you're not going anywhere.

-Linear: No Elden Ring freedom here. Stuck on a boss? You're stuck until you beat it , no cheeses , no get OP early , no ergo (xp/runes) farms , no going around the world for different bosses that are easier.

good game

Finally finished the game.  I got my money's worth, but the final 25% was a slog. FromSoft is still quite a bit ahead in game design in my opinion. Story crescendo'd in a good way, but the latter half of the game just felt off. Made more sense just to run through everything than risk dying to a collapsing floor or getting two-shot by some random shitter mob because you didn't perfect parry their micro window.

The game is quite a lot harder than FromSoft games in my opinion, maybe I just had a shit build, but it never felt hard like "wow this is a complex boss with interesting move sets".  More like "wow this boss hits like 16 times in a row and you need to perfect parry every single one otherwise you lose half your health, and there's no opportunity to chug a heal and get it back because you're in a tiny 4x4 attic and the boss which already doesn't take a break just summoned a second version of itself".

There's a difference between tasteful, complex challenge and just a soulless click timing fest like some souls-like equivalent of OSU or something. The typical neckbeard response is 'skill issue'. But a lot of solid souls players with no hit runs, have shared the same sentiments on YouTube, even FightingCowboy mentioned the parry window was kinda BS in his playthrough.
A must play for any soulsborne fan.

Pros: satisfying soulslike combat, incredibly good boss designs and enemy variety, art and animation quality occasionally surpasses fromsoft. The P organ upgrade tree is cool and actually gives interesting gameplay perks. The weapon mixing system is cool even though I didn't really use it much. The game is also really long, almost excessively so. Enemy and boss variety keeps it fresh to the end, and there are only a couple boss rematches.

Cons: weird writing and confused story and themes. A lot of the dialog feels very amateurish. The comic relief does not hit. The story is a tired "search for immortality creates a zombie disease," but with puppets mixed in. I know some people like that it tells more of a real story than most souls games, but it just did not do it for me. 
Some hitboxes and parry windows are a little questionable but most are ok.
The naming conventions for all the different resources and consumables are dumb. Even 40 hours in I was still mixing up Legion and Fable.

Still overall a great dark souls clone! Easy recommend if you like soulsbornering games.

Very likely the first and currently only good non-fromsoft souls-like. Enemy attack animations are pretty rough to figure out for the most part, and the last level is at least twice as long and tedious as it should have been, but those are probably my only complaints.

The plot is great. Derivative, but it uses its influences to tell its own unique story. The characters are all fun, there are a TON of different weapon and combat options. If you're a souls fan, you absolutely owe it to yourself to give Lies of P a serious try.
Great game, excited for dlc and a sequel

Probably the single best souls game that isn't made by fromsoft. Unfortunately, it seems they made the game a lot easier post-patches to appeal to the people complaining, but it's still a great time. 

Combat is incredibly fluid combining elements from both bloodborne and sekiro creating a unique vibe. Neither parrying nor dodging is the best you have to use both in tandem. 
Boss design is great and challenging, but it's pretty easy to get very strong in this game i'm shredding boss health bars so if you want to power through stuff you can. 
Game is pretty linear but I'm not going to complain about something intentional. Enemy variety is also fantastic you keep seeing new enemies up to the endgame.

In many ways this is better than some of fromsoft's own games and if you're a fan of bloodborne or sekiro you should check it out. It's on par with DS3 (which I consider near the top of souls) and unlike that game, the bosses don't start terribly and get better they're all good (with one very annoying exception).

It's not a perfect game by any means, but if you're looking for a pure souls experience that isn't marred by stuff like an open world. This is an incredibly competent polished experience. On top of that, the PC port is very well done which you can't take for granted these days.

This is because I had already finished playing Steelrising, which takes place in a highly similar gothic setting, with a steam punk styled mechanical protagonist and enemies. While my experience with Steelrising was overall positive, its novelty quickly wore off and thus I did not feel like giving Lies of P a shot. 

Luckily, all the positive buzz surrounding this game made me reconsider my position, because, dear God, this game is good. It is no joke when people say that it rivals FromSoftwares lineup in pure quality. If you are a fan of the genre, Lies of P is a must play.

What you may have heard before and is true: This is probably the best and/or most standalone Soulslike / Bloodbourne experience I've played yet, and actually has a story!

What you may have heard before and is NOT true: This game is very difficult! / This game is too easy! It's just right baby.

What you may not have heard before or may not know: This game does the whole "flashing red attack" differently than the previously few Soulsbournes so you might want to read the tutorial closely or look it up specifically online, but we're talking "cannot guard or iframe" not "cannot perfect parry or dodge out of the way if you do it properly"

What you may not have seen or may not experience: I also had a number of weird glitchy moments, achievements not popping for items received, achievements popping before gathering all the required items, quests not being able to complete because you did something slightly out of order - you know, traditional FromSoft experiences.

Great game with a lot of new tweaks to ideas or just new ones entirely, though sadly a lot of those could have been implemented better along with some really irksome pet peeve issues for me. Still would highly recommend for just the fact that it was able to competently make a souls game while trying a lot of new things which I do appreciate. While it is challenging, with specters and throw items, you can make the game a lot less challenging to suit your taste. Personally, summoned a phantom once to try it out and rarely used consumables cause I was enjoying the parry system. But that's just me, play a game for your enjoyment; and I definitely think there is plenty of enjoyment to be had in this game (first run is probably around 30 hours, mines more cause I really enjoyed the hotel music records). 

Speaking from a first run through mindset after doing just about everything (I'll do NG+ when the DLC drops) some pros would definitely be the guard hp rally and parry system. They elicit a more aggressive play-style which I found fun (wish I could have played Bloodborne). And while I'm not good on parrying, I'll say the timing issues are largely down to just me not fully meshing with it for awhile, and still having skill issues even now. However, I do think the guard animation your forced into after a perfect block is far to long leading to some frustration when I just want to get my attack in (I'm a strength or well, motivity build, so I need some actual time to swing). In fact a lot of animations feel like they could have been sped up a bit. But I'd only call those mild frustrations. A pet peeve would be the weapons bouncing off walls, that has never and will never feel good. 

The world itself with interesting with minor side tracks that give you a good but more linear experience, granted that's what I was looking for so that was a plus to me. The voice acting as well was so good I actually feel like mentioning, far from just serviceable, it was honestly a stand out (Red Fox voice still gives me shivers). Though again small, actually I wouldn't call this a annoyance; but honestly the amount of shortcuts and/or new save points in the early game was almost overbearing. 

Now for combat... it's good, don't let what I'm about to say overwrite that. It was genuinely a fun and challenging experience, however some of the annoyances stuck out so much I have to now rant a bit about them. Starting off with probably the most minor, the jumps and the platforming in general. The whole walk across the beams bit got old quickly, and with how the jump is, honestly would have been better without it. Feels more like a animation is being played of you jumping while your still very much grounded to the floor; that probably doesn't make sense but it's the best way I can explain my feelings on the jump. Second, the whole enemies jumping out at you bit was a bit overused too. Thirdly, kind of wished some of the save points were closer to boss. They aren't a jaunt through the level, but it's just enough leg work to be noticeable but not challenging; so just felt like a waste of time. The Laxasia was a good one, which I'm thankful for cause I wanted to try the break weapon to win phase 1 strat. 

Now these while they annoyed me I wouldn't exactly call them negatives. The telegraphs on some of the attacks is a bit, well, just feels spiteful. Manus was a pain because his resting animation and a attack animation were similar, the slow down to bait out parries is darn near criminal sometimes, and those last ditch attacks after a stagger on the bosses (while I get what they were going for) is all just a bit much. The rope arm specifically I pray it got some hyper armor, came out faster, or had tighter hitboxes. Cause seeing a opening and hitting the rope the second it was safe to do so but still having the enemy get a hit out before you (especially when its like a horizontal swipe that isn't even close to you) and knocking you out of the animation was just depressing. They could have leaned a bit more into the rule of cool for rope arm, the fact it's just slightly to short to grab a enemy across a gap or the fact you move back a little so you cannot use it to yank a enemy into the abyss while on a beam were disheartening. On that note, kind of wish fables were a bit weaker but charged quicker so I could weave them into combat more though that issue is reduced in the later game and NG+s.

Great art direction and gameplay is great (but not stellar). The game is the closest to a FromSoft game you can get, except the structure is pretty much linear (which I did not find to be a bad thing). All in all a great game if you are a From fan. I would not recommend to people who have not played a FromSoft game first as this is noticeably harder and more complex. 

The main issues I found are--
Gameplay: there's too much going on in terms of combat options, and there's too little reward for parrying. Not a complaint about difficult, as I beat it with mostly focusing on parrying; but it does not have the satisfying immediate staggers of Bloodborne, nor the build up to Sekiro-style actual executions. It's both very cumbersome to build up parry stagger, then fiddly to trigger the stagger once it is built up. and then often little damage is done, and late game bosses also get a counterattack to your coup-de-grace.
Story: scenario and storyboarding are excellent, but the lie/truth options are often basically just being normal vs. being asinine rather than hard choices about whether to lie. 
Graphics: (I played on a Steam Deck OLED on Best graphics setting for most of it) while the environments were great, the character faces were all a little out of focus around the hairline, which was distracting.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead– murdered by my brother-in-law, Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now, and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, he asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded. I... I always thought Hank was a very moral man, and I was particularly vulnerable at the time – something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me in on a ride-along and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin, so I agreed. Hank had a partner, a businessman named Gustavo Fring. Hank sold me into servitude to this man. And when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling-out. Things escalated. Fring was able to arrange – uh, I guess... I guess you call it a "hit" – on Hank, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured. And I wound up paying his medical bills, which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge. Working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring. The bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA. To keep me in line, he took my children. For three months, he kept them. My wife had no idea of my criminal activities, and was horrified to learn what I had done. I was in hell. I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, and in response, he gave me this. [Walt points to the bruise on his face left by Hank in "Blood Money."] I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. All I could think to do was to make this video and hope that the world will finally see this man for what he really is.

Um souls-like que agrega, mas um souls-like ainda longe do ideal. Um jogo que se mostra mais eficiente em contar histórias e em progressão de quests que os jogos que se inspira mas que ainda não entendeu completamente a fórmula. 

Muitos cenários que inspiram a exploração mas que são extremamente straightforward e vazios (poucos inimigos e desafios num geral). Problemas com boss design e telegrafação dos ataques são consistentes durante o game.

Seus méritos são muitos também, a sacada das armas terem handles e blades é genial. Mas isso não seria o suficiente sozinho. Então eles também trazem mecanismos para respec e mudança de scalling das armas desde muito cedo o que te incentiva a testar e mudar as builds, o que é fantástico. Outro ponto muito forte é o storytelling somado a questão da verdade e mentira, que em suma é positivo mas deveria ter mais peso para gameplay. Para um primeiro jogo da desenvolvedora nesse estilo é muito promissor, no aguardo de uma sequência.

At the time of writing this, I have achieved the true ending and completed most NPC questlines in a single playthrough. The world is intuitive and the systems are so incredibly user-friendly! I did not need to look up anything outside of very hyper-specific instances unique to my playthrough. There is a system in place that shows you what areas of the map an NPC you have already met is in, or wants to talk to you at. No more "This NPC travels to a really hidden area at a hyper-specific, easily missable moment, good luck finding them lol" moments like in the actual From Soft titles sometimes! Things like that, and many more things I want you as the reader to find out for yourself as you play the game, are why I am recommending the game.

However, I want to adress the Bloodborne comparison. Sadly, I haven't been able to play that game yet, but from all I have seen and heard of it, this game is not very much like it outside of a first glance and a bit of setting and theme. It plays a lot more like something in between Sekiro and the mainline Souls games, yet it still has a unique feel and the enemy design allows them to get really creative with attack patterns. Perfect Parrying is a MASSIVE mechanic that I wish they went into more detail on during the tutorial section. Don't try to play this game without it!

The only major downside I can think of is that while the weapon variety is excellent even if you weren't able to swap out the weapon blades and handles, it also didn't feel like I needed to experiment with the arsenal much. I quickly settled on putting the highest-damaging blade on the handle with the highest Technical scaling, and then switched to my final weapon, which was a "Special" uncustomizable one, and it worked solidly throughout the entire game. That being said, my gear never felt under or overpowered, though the mid-point of the game felt a bit easy, especially the bosses. I fist-tried many of the rather impressive roster!

Still had fun the whole way, and a lot of it at that, and that doesn't even speak about the phenomenal story! It is definitely the best non-From-Soft Soulslike I have played... ever, and I couldn't recommend it more. Honestly? You could've told me this was made by the OGs of the genre, and I might only get thrown off by a lack of references to their IPs.
