Sekiro was so good that it ruined many other games for me, that is, until Lies of P came around. Lies of P recaptured that 'Sekiro/Bloodborne' magic that I'd been missing for so long. The combat in this game is absolutely sublime, but only if you're willing to meet it on its own terms.

Don't be surprised if you spend 1-2 hours on a boss fight. A lot of the enjoyment in this game comes from trusting the designers: It's really easy to get beaten down a few times and assume "this boss is unfair". Instead, I recommend that you trust the design, learn when to parry, when to dodge, and when to run away, and you'll find that every challenge in this game is actually very approachable.

Every boss is fun in its own way. Every level has tons of interconnected paths, with only a handful of checkpoints per chapter that get re-used a ton. There aren't many secrets, and outside of the many shortcuts, the levels are mostly linear. This is okay to me: The combat is the real focus of this game.

Every aspect of this game's design is yelling "don't give up".  You can always rally back some health if you mistime a parry. You can always recharge 1 health flask if you're out of charges, meaning you can always make a comeback. Boss attacks are consistently telegraphed so you can always learn the mechanics of a fight if you're willing to put in the time. As a result, this game is much more forgiving than you'd expect.

I don't want to hyper-fixate on the insanely high-but-satisfying difficulty though: This game is also absurdly polished. The music, the visuals, the performance, the controls, everything is executed amazingly well. Soulslikes often die by their least-polished or most-clunky aspect, so to have a non-FromSoft soulslike execute everything so well is really something special.

In the end, I think non-FromSoft soulslikes are, ironically, often held to a higher standard than their FromSoft counterparts. Think about all the nonsense you've excused in games like Elden Ring or Dark Souls 2 and ask yourself: are you willing to give Lies of P the same clemency? To that end, I think Lies of P is an excellent game that gets nitpicked to shreds by soulslike fans who've forgotten how tough a soulslike is supposed to be. After years of playing souls games, I think we've all gotten a little too comfortable. Lies of P is a great wake-up call.

Remember how hard Bloodborne and Sekiro felt when you first played them? Lies of P is tough, but if you accept that it's NOT dark souls, and learn the correct way to play, I really think this game will recapture that magical feeling you've probably been missing since you first started playing soulslikes.

This game is a confused, ambitious, mess of a wonderful game. Trying to combine the game design philosophies of Bloodborne and Sekiro is quite the undertaking, and the developers were partially successful in making a unique souls-like experience. Lies of P is punishing, but for the wrong reasons regarding specific aspects of the game. 
-
Certain game design decision when it comes to combat and the scaling system for weapons had me very confused. Not being able to fan deflect and cancel attacks into parries like Sekiro, and the game being much slower than Bloodborne, made combat feel very awkward at times. I had reached the midway point of "King of Puppets" at the 8 hour mark, defeated the rematch with the Rabbit Brotherhood at 13.5 hours, stuck on Laxasia from hours 15-23, then beat the final two bosses in ~2-2.5 hours, mainly being stuck on Nameless for a bit..Manus was a second try. Despite my relative fast completion of the game, I felt like I never mastered the combat mechanics by the end. Instead, I felt like my progression was gated by behind damage walls and trying to *push* beyond them. By the end, my Twin Dragon Katana was doing ~150 damage (35 technique) to Laxasia per light attack. The Acidic Crystal Spear, which I had since after the cathedral that I avoided since it had split damage, did ~400 (40 advance) damage and applied a DOT debuff that made an enemies weapon break faster. Flat numbers are king in Lies of P and it really seems scaling is secondary to initial numbers. Obviously, I re-allocated to make the S scaling Acidic Crystal Spear be functional, but much of my damage was from the high-base elemental damage. I felt as if the "weights were off" and after allocating my stats to Advance, I first tried Laxasia (my personal wall). So I don't know if it's a skill issue, or if it's more the fact that I never truly understood the systems of the game by the end and was unintentionally limiting my damage since around the four hour mark. 
-
I recommend this game for it's unique experience. I'm glad some competent and ambitious developers decided to take a crack at the souls formula. I hope that their next release refines the combat systems presented in Lies of P to something truly special, rather than the confusing Sekiro-Bloodborne hodge-podge the game is stuck in. Great atmosphere and general design, soundtrack is pretty good as well.

This game is like a well balanced mix between Bloodborn and Sekiro, with a shadowy story and a rhythm-based combat system. So it gives you this good old experience at it's finest. But it's biggest surprise is that it fixes a lot of user interface flaws which From software games usually delivers. You only suffer for pleasure in this game if you know what I mean.

This game is very heavily front loaded. First half of the game is fun, then the horrible boss design kicks in and it becomes a complete mess. If you're a veteran of the Soulsborne games, you will not like the 2nd half and will most likely put it down after you realize each boss gets worse and worse with hp bloat and horrible design after the puppet king. Also, bosses SCALE with you so it doesn't matter if you have 10 str/dex or 40 str/dex or a +1/+10 weapon, you will always deal a set % of damage to bosses and mobs. IDK who thought of this, but it's the dumbest thing I've ever encountered in a Soulsborne. It's like the developers didn't know how to make the game difficult so they just set a slider on bosses/enemies and cranked it all the way up the 2nd half.

I wish I could refund this game but I'm past the 2 hr mark, it  takes about 10 hours to reach the puppet king and it's been all downhill from there. I went from loving the game the first 10 hours then hating it literally 2 hours after (2 bosses after puppet king).

I really really like this game. Hell I might even love it. I mean, I am nominating it for game of the year and have 60+ hours on it. BUT, and this might be a wild take or something, I disagree with everyone who says this game is on the same line that fromsoft games are and I HIGHLY, whole heartily,  disagree with people saying that it's even better than some fromsoft games. Now, I'm not saying fromsoft games are perfect but even with their problems, they're still amazing. With this game however, I noticed a lot wrong and also somethings that just aren't great about it in general. First off, gameplay. After almost 3 full playthroughs, I think that the timing for a perfect block is absolutely abysmal. I wouldn't say im anywhere near great at parrying but I wouldn't say I'm that bad at it either. I mean, sekiro was pretty much a breeze for me. I think the window of opportunity is just too short which is the main reason why I almost completely rely on dodging. Now this isn't a horrible thing because I actually do prefer the dodging/quickstep more than parrying (one of the reasons I love bloodborne) but its still a big problem. The second part is level design. People who say the level design in this game is fromsoft quality CLEARLY havent played a fromsoft game fully or really even appreciated it because the level design is also abysmal. It is SO linear. I know people say that ds3 has linear level design (which I agree with but I still love it) but this is like triple the linearity. When you're greeted with branching paths, they usually end INSANELY quickly and only give you like the lamest throwable or consumable that you probably aren't gonna use. I'm not saying that this game doesn't have its good moments. The last "level" of the game is BY FAR its best. It has pretty great level design and this is why I feel that people say the level design is great, because their judgement is clouded by the last level that they played. It's just nowhere near as good as fromsoft in this category and I genuinely don't understand why people say it is. The third thing isn't really a "problem" like the last 2 and more so just, something I don't like. The soundtrack. Now when I say the soundtrack, I mostly mean the boss themes. I love the record music this game has, I think its really creative and just overall unique, but the boss themes are the complete opposite. They are so bland and boring. It feels like they put all of their creativity into the record music and none into the actual themes that most people will listen to. Lastly, this is kinda gameplayish I guess but idc. The new game plus scaling. It's awful. Bosses last up to 4+ minutes per fight. They demolish your health instantly and they have SO MUCH health which you can really not do anything about since you cant upgrade your weapon any further than +10. Anyways, that's it. I love this game but I don't think its anywhere near the quality that fromsoft delivers. I really hope the dlc addresses some of these problems and I have really high hopes for whatever their next game is considering they've probably learned many things throughout the development of this game. 7/10 for me.

EDIT: About a month and a half later now and I can safely say that this game is like, an 8.5 to 9 out of 10. It's not like I've really played a lot of it or have forgotten the cons that this game has but man, I just really really enjoy the game. The gameplay is incredibly fun albeit sometimes irritating. The atmosphere and visual designs are great. The bosses are really fun. I can't help but feel that it's almost a ds2 situation (I havent played ds2 but still) in which it may not be the best souls/soulslike game but it is still an absolutely incredible game.

I saw the trailer, got a good feeling about the gameplay and the visual looks nice so I walked into this world expecting the gameplay to captivate me. And it did, I love the combat, but what I did not expect was how good the lore and the story are. I'm actually intrigued and wanting to find out what's gonna happen. There are a lot of weapons to collect from weapons you pick up from chests around the world, from bosses and a secret weapon as well. There are a lot of creative mechanic in this game that will definitely surprised you by how good and creative it is. There are quite a few collectibles to find in the world and the rewards for finding those are very satisfying. This is no doubt, the best souls like game out there, I dare say it can even rival the real DS or ER, or BB. Even the visual reminds me of DS, ER and BB, it's nothing cutting edge but it's very well done. The voice acting is good and the character designs look fantastic ( I mean it's a Korean game). 

The only downsides I can think of about the gameplay is that some bosses are very lackluster in the design. All of the "big" boss only has 2 phases. The game is relatively short if you're decent at souls like game, around 30 hours, could be a lot longer if you really suck. But the game is designed for multiple playthrough with more skills to unlock and multiple endings. But with all of that I don't think this game should worth 60 dollars, it's a very good game with a delusional price tag, with the amount of playtime and the quality this game should be at max 50 dollars. I mean Elden Ring is 40 bucks in my country, and it has 3 times the amount of content.
Definitely recommend but get it on sale or on gamepass.

I did not play any Souls-Games and actively disliked Elden Ring for it's unfocused open-world approach and the necessity to play with a guide at hand. I’m mentioning this to state the fact that I have had no love for the genre at all. 

This game, however, may have changed that. It is easily my favorite single player game of the last decade or two. I just started my second play through, and I’d say that the game lost nothing of its appeal yet. I’d say it’s even more fun than the first time around. 

There's nothing good that hasn't been said about Lies of P already. What I’d like to highlight is the fact that I could play the game “blind” (as in, not following guides on the internet) and have a fantastic time. I looked up some boss strategies after failing many times, but that's the extent of it. 

The game can be tough and frustrating at times, but the difficulty feels well-balanced over all. 

I can't wait for what these guys cook up next. It also made me want to re-visit Elden Ring, maybe when the DLC comes around.

Lies of P is the first souls-like game that actually gets it right.

It's honestly indistinguishable from FromSofts' souls games. If you told me it was a FromSoft game, I would believe you and tell you that it's their best one yet. I think one of the most impressive things about this game is how interconnected each level is. 

There are tons of shortcuts back to the initial bonfire in each area. Often, the first or second bonfire has a shortcut to the region boss. There isn't much cross-region connection, a la Dark Souls 1, but the inter-region connection is after all the more important part. 

There are plenty of weapons to utilize and a wide range of movement sets, amplified by the ability to interchange the hilt and blade of each weapon. I.E. you can put a greatsword blade on a dagger hilt.

There is a parry system similar to Sekiro. However, if you are coming from Sekiro, it is going to feel off until you get used to it. The primary difference is that the parry window increases based on how long the block is held. Releasing the block too soon significantly reduces your parry window, a stark contrast to what is seen in Sekiro. While I do prefer the Skeiro system, this approach is entirely serviceable once you adjust to it.

Barring the true final boss, overall, the combat encounters are what I would describe as incredibly fair. Probably the most fair in the mainline souls games or otherwise. There are zero bullshit encounters, which is actually a really impressive accomplishment. 

The true final boss being a bit overtuned is the only criticism I can really come up with. Even then, it only took me 15-20 attempts and some googling about status effect weakness and general strategies for phase 2.

Good game but also makes you hate yourself, cannot wait for more!! Solid 8.5/10 and as a first game from this team it is well made! There are a few things in the game that could have been done a little better like the dodge and parry mechanic but at the same time they did try to not make it so you don't just play it like a dark souls game. Worth a try if you are a fan of the souls like genre. Well done guys!

I was pleasantly surprised both by how good this game feels, and how it's distinct enough from the From Software games to be its own thing. The setting is well fleshed out and fun to explore, and the combat feels very satisfying to master. If you're a Souls veteran, you'll likely not encounter too many difficulties, and if you're new to the genre, Lies of P has plenty of ways to make the Explore, Die, Repeat loop a little less punishing than the From Software paragons.

Play this game if you like dark souls 8/10

Excellent combat. Excellent weapons. Great areas. Good bosses. Long game.
Animation quality in this game is unmatched. Weapon customization will make me replay this game several times for sure.

[h3] Expectations [/h3]
I've spent many long nights as a person who thinks that titles marketed under the "souls-like" genre often underwhelm me compared to the projects released by From Software themselves. Often times, the more a studio tries to copy directly from souls (and, in this case, Bloodborne and Sekiro) the less likely the game is to live up to that standard. This game breaks that cycle. I waited until this game was on sale to give it a shot because I was worried it would disappoint. I almost wish I hadn't waited. For reference, I finished my first play through after approximately 30 hours.
[b](TL;DR-> If you have any interest or experience with the souls-like genre, this game is worth the your time and consideration.)[/b]

[h3] Comparisons to From Software [/h3]
Full disclosure, Bloodborne is my favorite game. This game is not only inspired by Bloodborne (and the other From Soft titles) but it almost seeks to recreate many of the major aspects of these games. The combat is quite close to the soulsborne-kiro games, if only a little bit less quick than bloodborne. It has a sekiro-like parrying system and stagger bar. It has the item progression of Souls. It has a health regain (rally) system similar to Bloodborne. It has bosses and level design that are clearly inspired by all of the From Soft games. It even has a safe hub area that evolves and changes as the characters and story does. 

[h3] Differences from From Soft Titles [/h3]
This game is more linear than the Souls games, but it also provides a few solid improvements on the formula. For example, if you are expected to return to a previous area to develop an NPC questline then you will see a little icon on your map leading you to which stargazer (bonfire, lantern, site of grace) with a picture of the NPC waiting to speak with you. There is a lovely hub location music mechanic where you find records in the world and come back and can play them in the hub area (and doing so has some minor story implications). This game allows you to customize the scaling and move-set of your weapon to a fantastic degree by allowing you to swap the blade of some weapons to other handles. This is the case for all weapons aside from the special weapons (primarily boss soul weapons). There is no summoning or invasion system in this game, but you can enlist the help of AI specters to fight with you for some of the main story bosses. There are no chalice dungeons (some of us liked them).

[h3] Verdict [/h3]
If you are a fan of souls-like games, this one is a contender for the best non-From Soft title ever;
- Buy it.

If you are a fan of only the From Soft titles, this game may be the first to come close to that feeling;  
- Give it a shot.

If you are interested in the souls-like genre but haven't tried them out, this is a more linear game that can act as a good introduction to the genre;
- Wish list it and try it when it goes on sale.

[h3] Final Thoughts [/h3]
Lies of P is a relatively solid substitute for 60FPS Bloodborne on PC for now :/

I feel like most people have already said enough about how great of a game this is, so I wanted to talk about my biggest surprise of the game: the records.

When I got my first one I thought to myself "oh just a shitty music player gimmick" but holy shit. The music it plays is magnificent. Quixotic being my absolute favourite. Great score.

In a sea of games in the souls-like genre, Lies of P is the rare occasion in which the game is clearly inspired  but was able to transcend just being a shallow clone.


[h1] Combat [/h1] 

The combat in this game is immaculate. The developers clearly understood the foundations of a souls-like game and were able to implement this with their own spin on it. There are a lot of tools the game presents to you in order to find a fun build to engage the game with. The incredible diverse weapon assembly system, the addition of various legion arms that supplement your build with a cool ability, the adequately named "P-Organ" system that gives you upgrades. 

But what use would all these cool additions be if the core gameplay was no good?

Thankfully, the creators of Lies of P really do understand what makes combat feel fun in this genre. Combat-wise, you have two main responses to enemy attacks, either blocking and parrying or dodging away and iframing with the more advanced applications of the two responses being the latter options. In terms of execution versus reward, all the options are viable and depending on the situation, you will have to weigh which one to go for. The game presents these build options to you in order to encourage you to engage with their core combat systems in a fun way. You are not limited to one type of response and are able to freely mix and use both types of responses through combat. You can also use one type of response exclusively if that is how you wish to play. Having multiple viable responses to enemy attacks allows for a more enjoyable experience in learning enemy and boss movesets. It does not matter if you pick the easier responses of blocking and dodging or the harder, but more rewarding responses of parrying and iframing, it is this freedom of experimentation of how to approach fights in this game that allows for the player to easily reach a flow state and enjoy the combat no matter what approach they use. 

Some other additions to the combat that help elevate the game include; 
1. Weapon durability for both you and the enemy, you will need to repair your weapon periodically so it does not break, conversely parrying the enemies weapon consistently can break their weapon, lowering their damage and range for whole fight. This adds one more small factor to keep track of in boss fights.
2. When you have no healing charges left, you will slowly recharge 1 healing charge by hitting the enemy. This keeps you flipping between the safety of 1 more heal versus needing to be aggressive to regain the heal back once you use it.
3. An enemy's health bar will glow white upon accumulating enough stagger damage through parrying or hitting the enemy. While the health bar is glowing, enemies will be staggered upon taking a heavy hit (charged heavy attack, a throwable, fable art attack, or a legion arm attack). This encourages you to make a risky attack in hopes of staggering the enemy and turning the fight or just getting hit and dying. 

In terms of accessibility, the game does lock you into melee builds for the most part and the game expects you to engage with its core combat mechanics of dodging and/or parrying. There are some additional methods that could make the game easier such as some pure ranged options available in the legion arm add-on and throwables(which are surprisingly strong in this game). There is also a standard AI summon you can use for the main bosses that takes the boss aggro from the player. However it comes attached to a clunky system in which you need to wait for in game resources to replenish the summoning material and buffs/pots for the summon.

[h1] Enemies [/h1] 

The bosses in this game are all quite unique and well designed outside of maybe 1-2 misses. Each boss is a unique, eventful encounter that concludes an area and comes with a unique moveset and tons of variety (there is a boss you can beat by only parrying, how cool is that?). Bosses are all quite aggressive but fair in that a lot of the moveset is very readable and reactable even on your first fight. There are many amazing fights in this game, and I was expecting a drop in quality at some point, but thankfully until the end, the quality of the boss fights never dipped or felt unfair. 
The enemy variety in this game is quite solid, usually you would see a solid amount of reuse of both general enemies and bosses in these types of games, however, I found that outside of a couple instances, the game generally was still able to keep introducing at least 1-2 new enemy types for each new area all the way until the last area of the game. This kept the areas feeling unique and instead focuses on giving the player more of these gameplay moments as they run into new enemies or minibosses throughout the game. 

[h1] Level design [/h1] 

Lies of P is quite a linear game, there is usually only 1 optional side path in an area so for the most part the game follows the same structure of new area into boss, then next area into next boss. Each area does have some exploration to do for finding loot and mini bosses but even then, its quite contained and linear. The levels themselves are designed simply as a big circle with a shortcut back to the save point. Depending on how you play these games this might not even be a negative as the linearity means that you would not need to look up guides or be too scared of missing anything important within an area as you can easily explore the whole area. There seems to be only one optional side area in the game and even that is on the shorter side.  While the level design was predictable at times, I was still able to enjoy the games atmosphere and environments in each new area. 

[h1] Story [/h1] 

Narrative-wise, I was quite surprised at how enjoyable the Pinocchio theme was. The game nudges you in the direction of lying to present its main themes of humanity vs being a puppet and it culminates in quite a solid ending which is uncommon among games in this genre. 
The game has a clear narrative structure and explains its story really well. The game still has some hidden lore that you can discover but this is just to supplement the story it already tells so you wont have to go digging into lore as the game just shows you all the important bits. The various NPCs in the game all have their own charm and you are given enough interactions with them so that when their part in the narrative comes to a close, you could actually care about them since the game gives you enough to chew on. 

[h1] Soundtrack [/h1] 

The soundtrack is quite solid for the most part but I felt as though the general OSTs were forgettable for the most part. The songs that really stood out to me were the songs that you could collect in game as vinyl records which the game does encourage you to play while you are running around the main hub upgrading and experimenting with your character.

[h1] Final thoughts [/h1] 

In a fantastic year of gaming, Lies of P might have flown under the radar for some, but it is one of the best in the genre and has shown itself to be an amazing inspiration rather than a pale impersonation of the original souls-like games.

While I enjoyed the music and atmosphere of this game, the combat is not it. Unlike the soulsborne games where bosses have movesets you need to memorize, Lies of P bosses will randomly string attacks together making it  impossible to properly dodge/block their attacks. Enemy Charge attacks have a tendency to be slow windup and impossible to react to when they go off (worse than Margit, The Fell Omen in Elden Ring). This happens a lot more often when you get in to the later stages in the game. Enemy placement in this game is very similar to Dark Souls 2 where they will try to surprise attack you every 3 seconds which gets annoying after awhile.
Closest thing to a Fromsoftware title there is. It even surpasses the model in some respects. Highly recommend.

All I can say is that I don't know why I kept stalling on playing this game, first I tried lords of the fallen, which was a performance disaster, got a refund and bought this. Then I saw Jedi Survivor was on sale so I got that, after playing for 20 hours and mostly just getting pissed about the terrible frame rates I decided to switch over to Lies of P. 

After only 3 hours in this game, I can already tell you it's much more fun than either of those games. It runs at a perfect, frame locked 60 fps, has amazing combat mechanics, an intriguing story and unbelievable art design. On top of that it makes a lot of quality of life adjustments in terms of quest design that other souls likes should adopt, including a bit more hinting for NPC questlines, without handholding. 

I'm very excited to play the rest of this game, but I can already say it's a certified banger

Honestly, I'm more impressed with how well this turned out than anything else. Very nice variety of weapons and enemies even to the very end, and most importantly it all feels excellent to play. This is a level of polish on par with a Fromsoft title, which is why I wish I loved it more but a lot of it just felt like going through the motions to me. Despite how strong its combat is a lot of the bosses were hit-or-miss to me, not too many of the game's levels felt like they went beyond 'solid souls level', and the soundtrack is mostly forgettable as it tries too hard to replicate the sounds of its inspiration. I feel that Lies of P's greatest strength and weakness is how closely it homages the likes of Bloodborne and Sekiro, and maybe it's because I'm too strong of a fangirl for those, but it never quite surpasses the fun I have with them. Still excited to see what Neowiz does next because while I'm largely underwhelmed by how safe Lies of P is at times, it is the only non-Fromsoft souls-like that I have beaten and not dropped to go replay whatever Fromsoft game it reminded me the most of, so they certainly have that going for them!

[i][b]Lies of P[/b][/i] is... magnificent. It was my first Soulslike experience, and was an absolute blast to play from start to finish. A few design quirks with its morality system led to a few headaches when attempting to earn all achievements, but that's the only negative thing I can say about this game.

[h1][b]Gameplay[/b][/h1]
If you've played a game in the Soulslike genre, you'll be very familiar with this game. If you haven't, allow me to break it down very simply.

Everybody wants to kill you, you have very little health and take a lot of damage, and your options are to dodge, guard or hope your attack lands first with enough force to get you out of harm's way for the moment. If you do get hurt, you can heal, but you only have a finite number of heal charges between checkpoints. You'll need to use these sparingly and hope you avoid taking too many hits.

The game itself plays in third-person, and the progression is very linear, tasking you with progressing from one map to the next in a very straightforward fashion. Each map will have a minimum of one mini boss and one major boss, with a sprinkling of lower-tier enemies throughout.

As you slay enemies, you earn Ergo, which can be used to purchase new items like equipment, consumables and others, or to level up your stats. You can level up your HP, Stamina, Weight Capacity (heavier gear will weigh you down and slow your moments without this), Heavy Attacks, Light Attacks and Elemental Damage. You can choose to build your character based on your playstyle. If you wish to experiment, there is a respeccing system in the game as well.

Lastly, the P-Organ is a passive skill tree that you upgrade with Quartz, a currency you acquire from quests and mini bosses/bosses as you play. You can increase your damage, resistances, improve the effectiveness of abilities, etc.

The game primarily plays out of the hub area, Hotel Krat, where you'll fit your character before pushing on.

[h1][b]Story[/b][/h1]
The story of Lies of P is best left discovered as you play, but the basic principle is that you play as Pinocchio and are awoken to help save the world from the madness known as Puppet Frenzy, which is driving all of the puppets in the world mad. The narrative is far more nuanced, but is worth experiencing with no spoilers.

[h1][b]Performance[/b][/h1]
The game runs like a dream. On my RTX 3090, I'm able to play at a locked 120 FPS with everyone running on Ultra at a native 2560x1440. While my machine is very high-end in nature, the game scales phenomenally across all hardware implementations, seeing Ultra settings running smoothly on even older generation GPUs. Zero shader compilation or traversal stutter, not one single crash in 80 hours, and the game is a visual spectacle.

[h1][b]Conclusion[/b][/h1]
[i][b]Lies of P[/b][/i] is my GOTY for 2023. It's an incredible experience from start to finish, and I never felt bored or uninterested as I went through it... four times. The New Game+ system motivates you to go through again to push your passive bonuses a little further and to experiment with new builds, and the linear nature of the game complements quick runs. Where your first may take you 30+ hours, subsequent runs can be done in 6-8 and feel completely new due to the vast array of builds available.

my main critique is the linearity of the levels. I'm spoiled by dark souls 1 and 2, where you have some options in which areas to explore first. This game takes it's design que from DS3, where your order of exploration is more or less set in stone, which makes it feel like progressing through a hallway. This isn't a very serious complaint, as the game is still fun regardless. Just figure I'd mention it because people who like souls-likes tend to compare them to DS. 

The environments in this game are all very beautiful and distinct. The enemy design is varied, which is something indie/lower budget souls likes tend to mess up, so points for this! I'm also surprisingly liking the story. I thought grimdark Pinnocio would be something I'd roll my eyes to and generally hate, but it's serviceable. I know the rich are weird, but I didn't think they were *that* weird.

This game captures the essence of what a Dark Souls game for casuals should be like. The difficulty as a main focus point is not terribly nuanced, but let's talk about why that's even as a con, I would still consider that a pro.

[b] Variety and Flexibility [/b]: Lies of P offers something that we saw a little bit of beginning in Elden Ring, and I'd really like to see developers expand on with future souls like games: weapon and tool combinations. Lies of P has a robust weapon combination system that drastically changes the way your skills affect your weapons. If this weren't enough, you can also imbue them with specific abilities, and you can then further customize those with grindstones. They took it even one step further by letting you do the same thing with your gauntlet, which is a bit like the sekiro tools with more flexibility in their use. 

[b] The Music [/b]: The music sort of lurks in the background, and it is definitely Sakuraba quality, if not better due to a classical element that lurks within it. The music hangs out in the background, almost as a pleasant white noise until the moment when it needs to crescendo, and oh boy does it do that well. I think the addition of the record player system also adds a unique element- restoring "humanity" is done through a mechanic focused on specifically music.

[b] Combat [/b]: The combat is smooth and intuitive. While not as complex or quick as games like Sekiro, the combat definitely feels fun and enjoyable. The weight of weapons feels immaculate overall, until you run up against the big bad bosses who just sort of shrug it off because well- an ant won't make a bird stagger often. The weapon skills are all definitely unique and combo really well with the basic attack combos.

[b] Lore [/b]: I thought I had an idea of what I was getting into: Pinocchio, robots overrunning the city, chasing after a wish or something. Let me tell you, the name of the game only scratches the surface. The story is so much deeper and so much more well told than I anticipated. I do feel that the level of lore is somewhat shallow, but overall the storytelling and the quality of existing lore is definitely a solid 9/10.

[b] Complaints [/b]: I think if I had to have one complaint about this game is it feels a bit rushed/short. The zones immerse you just in time for the boss room and the end of the zone. I think that with a bit more content, this game would definitely feel as expansive as a True Dark Souls game.

I think I'm a souls like gamer now. This is only my second souls like game and I was even more obsessed with this one than Elden Ring. Everything about this game is perfect: The Characters, the story and lore, the soundtrack, the weapons, the gameplay. I literally can't think of any criticisms.

Honestly, what an amazing game. Typically, I'm really not a fan of soulslike's that aren't done by anyone other than Fromsoft. In my opinion, they're always lacking something, which is to be expected, they are derivative, after all. 

Warning: below I will be delving slightly into vague spoilers, regarding the overall premise.

But with Lies of P, I was skeptical, albeit interested. A game taking its main point of focus from the story of Pinocchio, yet wearing the guise of a gearpunk coat of paint, which then leads into a subversive lovecraftian angle, and is then eloquently juggled and eventually meshed together in what I can only call genius.

As for the gameplay part of the game, the controls feel tight and responsive. Now, while it isn't as fast as Bloodborne, Dark souls 3, Elden Ring, or Sekiro, it does have the rally mechanic of Bloodborne, and the parry mechanics of Sekiro. And while it unfortunately it lacks the trick weapons of Bloodborne that we desperately wanted, it has it's own unique compromise, in it's handle/blade system, which allows you to deconstruct the blade and handle of any weapon, and then combine it with another weapon to make a new weapon,  which allows for insane customization and freedom regarding combat. and I always was excited to see what I can make. The bosses are all rather well designed, with only a few leaving me with a neutral response, so the main opinions I had were from great to amazing. And as for their difficulty, they're all fair, but rewarding.

There's only a few complaints I have regarding the game, and that includes the lack of more options for advance (your magic stat), the admittedly small arsenal of legion arms and their lackluster upgrades, and the sort of samey clothing options in the game. 

Other than that, the game is a fantastic play. It controls like a dream, looks fantastic, has amazing art and sound direction, and it just superbly fun. I highly recommend it, if you like soulslikes and will personally be excitedly waiting for more in the already confirmed sequel and dlc.
Please describe what you liked or disliked about this product.

If you've finished the Dark Souls series, Sekiro, and Elden Ring and wanted more of the same in a different skin, Lies of P is... fine. It borrows mechanics from the aforementioned games but never innovates in any meaningful way to set it apart from them—worse, it often reverses QoL changes made in recent FromSoft titles.

This would've been “Mixed” had Steam allowed for the option. The moment I decided on Negative was when I realised that I wasn't having fun—I was playing more out of obligation to satiate the stubborn, masochistic Souls elitist within me.

[hr][/hr]
[h1]Presentation & Story[/h1]
The worldbuilding is fantastic, and classic Souls lore items are everywhere. The music is phenomenal too.

However, the lying theme doesn’t go further than being a lame gimmick, and there’s a weird understanding of what it means to be human (i.e. you need to be a lying, [spoiler]murderous, riddle-solving music lover[/spoiler] to be a real boy, even in instances where lying is clearly the less “human” choice). The plot contradicts itself, and the game sequel baits with numerous loose ends.

[h1]Engrish[/h1]
Either ESL or KSL (or both) writing results in weird, uncanny valley dialogue. This is exacerbated by how the NPC permanently attached to you has a horrible voice actor who sounds like an influencer promoting crappy mobile games.

Tooltips are super unclear, which makes buildcrafting a headache. Guess what this upgrade does: “Enables dodging when on the ground” (Answer: [spoiler]Lets you press the dodge button when knocked flat on the ground to get up quicker[/spoiler]).

If your game has a western aesthetic and exclusively English voice acting, maybe put a bit of effort into making sure the English isn’t ass, yeah? [b]YOU DEFEATED[/b] is funny and iconic; [b]LIE OR DIE[/b] is just cringe.

[h1]Mechanics & Exploration[/h1]
Quests are straightforward (i.e. When there are quests or special items at a location, they will appear on the fast travel menu). This is one of the few good innovations, since I prefer to play the game instead of Googling where the fuck Blaidd went.

[u][b]Level design is superb:[/b][/u]
- No illusory walls (Thank God)
- Loads of ambushes and deadly traps
- Great tense feeling of clearing the way to the next Bonfire/shortcut

The reason I'd rather rate this as Mixed instead of Negative is because of how well the maps are designed. The people responsible for the maps did an excellent job at shortcut construction, baiting with shiny chests, various ambushes, cannons shooting at you from afar, groups of monsters charging at you, and so on.

These situations test your ability to deal with a wide variety of scenarios and adequately punish you for not paying attention.

[u][b]Recent quality of life improvements the devs stripped away for some reason:[/b][/u]
- Forced to return to the hub to level up (Can do so from the Bonfire in NG+)
- Respecs and Physick Flask equivalent require waiting for a stupid plant to grow and then harvesting said plant every hour or so
- You have to constantly fight the camera trying to auto-center to the direction you’re going in
- Dodge on button release instead of press; dodge buffering is hilariously long
- Annoying runbacks to the boss
- Stamina depletes even when out of combat
- The player character is worse at jumping than a paralysed 70 year old

[u][b]Gimped-or-overpowered upgrade system:[/b][/u]
In Sekiro, upgrades enhance and build upon the base mechanics, rewarding aggression and good play (e.g. Mikiri & Descending Carp). In Lies of P, you’re either lacking basic mechanics in NG or ignoring core mechanics in NG+. There is no in-between.

First, there are many upgrades that should’ve been part of the base kit, such as being able to press dodge to get up after being knocked down. This leads to portions of your first playthrough feeling gimped. (There are also QoL “upgrades” like consuming less Stamina when running, which is necessary if you dislike annoying runbacks.)

Next, later upgrades let you ignore game mechanics—especially the few new ones not plagiarised from Miyazaki. Dangerous red attacks you need to either Perfect Guard or outrange? Well, with an upgrade, you could just hold down block normally. The boss being able to regenerate a portion of their HP if you don’t attack them constantly, encouraging aggressive play? Completely removed with a few upgrades.

[h1]Combat[/h1]
If I call a Soulslike a FromSoft ripoff because the player loses currency on death and there are Bonfires, that’s not really fair. However, when a game so blatantly copies the smallest details of Dark Souls—all the way down to poison swamps, Boss Souls, Resin, Gestures, no pausing, the level-up process and stats, and even the fucking menu layout—it opens the door to comparison, since they’re riding on DS nostalgia.

I finally started DS1 after Lies of P, and the mechanic where your weapon DINGs off walls feels so much more natural in the 2011 game. For some weapons (e.g. Holy Sword of the Ark), this mechanic will drive you insane; for others, it's practically non-existent.

[u][b]New mechanics are uninteresting:[/b][/u]
- Fury Attacks, attacks you need to either Perfect Guard or outrange, are mediocre and a worse version of Sekiro’s Perilous Attacks.
- Staggering Enemies for a Fatal Attack is an imitation of Elden Ring's Poise but with an extra step that barely matters if you possess a modicum of patience.
- Breaking Enemy Weapons so they do less damage and have shorter reach is satisfying but ultimately useless. It rewards players who've Perfect Guarded a lot with something that doesn’t matter to (or actually hurts) players who’ve Perfect Guarded a lot (since the shorter reach makes attacks harder to read).
- Repairing your Weapon in the middle of a fight is bothersome because you’re never chased down hard enough to be punished—this is a worse version of finding openings to drink your Estus.

[u][b]Fighting your eyes and instincts and having to memorise attacks:[/b][/u]
One of the greatest things about Sekiro is how rhythmic it feels—it becomes a game of instincts once you’ve mastered the mechanics. And even the most comical of delayed attacks in Elden Ring make some sense.

In contrast, Lies of P necessitates [u][b]Memorising Timings[/b][/u] because of how poor visual clarity, tells, and hitboxes for many attacks are. Also, sound cues are bad—if not completely absent. (This wouldn’t be as bad in a dodge-focused game, but there’s a reason even the most cancerous Sekiro boss fights have good tells.)

- The timing window for Perfect Guarding some attacks is way before the attack hits; it’s way after for others. You have to memorise which is which.
- Some attacks seem natural and can be reacted to by instinct—others are just the boss raising their arm one moment then teleporting the arm to your face the next. You have to memorise which is which (and timings for the latter).
- Some bosses can manipulate gravity and somehow delay a full-body elbow drop by levitating in the air.
- Bosses can raise their weapons or even jump off screen at such an angle that it’s impossible to see what’s going on.
- The game prioritises flashy animations over the player understanding what the boss is doing. There is a 10-hit combo from a boss that visually appears like a 14-hit combo, baiting players to try to Perfect Guard the fake hits.

Overall, the worst part of boss fights is how awful the risk-reward ratio for Perfect Guarding is. It is often better to dodge or outrange attacks, which turns the entire game into a boring cakewalk.

[h1]Final Words[/h1]
If your favourite Sekiro boss is Blazing Bull—and if you think the Runebear and Giant Crayfish (i.e. lobster bro) in Elden Ring are great fun—then you'll probably like this game. If you just had a negative visceral reaction to the things I listed, stay far away (or at least wait for a sale and go in with tempered expectations).

A lot of people compared this game to the FromSoftware games like Bloodborne or Dark Souls. They are indeed similitudes because Lies of P is an hommage to the genre, but the comparaision is unfair because the game is more than that. Lies of P has its soul and offer a unique experience. The story, the lore and the interpretation of the classic Pinocchio is not only clever, but fantastic. The music is beautiful, the game looks very good and it runs very well (finally a great PC and Steam Deck port). The Soul-like mecanisms are well implemented and it's smooth to play. You have a good variety of weapons, legion arm mechanic, items, equipements, costumes and power-ups. Some people will not like the more linear playthrough, but I think it's perfect for the story the game wants to tell and for some people like me who works a lot: it's easier to complete it. My only con for this game, which is nitpicky, is the game is too easy for my taste because of the hardcore Fromsoftware's experience like Sekiro or Bloodborne.

Steam Deck performance was great. I played with a locked 40 fps with FSR2 Quality at 12 watts. The game can also run at 60 fps with some dips to 50 fps. At the time of writing, Lies of P is classified as Playable, but I think it should be Verified. I saw no bugs/glitches, but the text size in the menus are kinda small. 

No spoilers here, great game. Completed it twice and it was just as fun the second time as I continued to experiment with weapon combinations. One playthrough takes about 20-25 hours, but probably varies quite a bit from person-to-person.

Round8 did not try to hide the FromSoftware inspiration and down right mimicry in some aspects. What they copied was executed very well and did not feel like a budget version at all. If someone told me the developers at Round8 had ties with FromSoftware, it would sound believable. Despite taking several gameplay mechanics from multiple different FromSoftware titles, it was still able to create its own unique identity. 

[h3]What I liked:[/h3]
The combat feels great. Every player character animation has a slight pause afterwards and input buffering is included. This may feel clunky to some, but I enjoy the harder commitment to an action and the required deliberateness of each button press. While the game heavily encourages the player to perfect guard, the use of guarding, dodging, and spacing from attacks provides a great mix of viable options in fights. The perfect guard sounds great as well. Being able to break weapons from multiple successful perfect guards was super cool, and a fun way to reward to player for nailing the timing. I also think it justifies implementing the player character's weapon durability mechanic. While it may feel tedious at times to repair your weapon, it's only fair that if boss weapons can break, then so should yours. 

I will not say too much about the boss fights to avoid spoilers, but I just thought they were unique and were simply great! 

Weapon customization was one of the best mechanics implemented in the game. It made finding new weapons much more exciting since you get to try out new blade and handle combinations. In souls games, finding new weapons can sometimes be disappointing because of stat requirements or because it scales better with a different build. This issue does not occur in Lies of P because due to weapon assembly and handle modifications, making exploration feel more rewarding.

I liked the character progression system through the P-Organ. While the abilities you get are not super unique, was a nice addition to make P stronger outside of just leveling up. The progression system through the leveling system was not very interesting and I don't feel like there is much distinction between choosing between motivity, technique, or advance since you can alter the scaling on handles anyways. 

[h3]What I disliked:[/h3]
I think the weakest part of the game is the level design. I wish there were more hidden areas or branching paths to make exploration more fun. Overall, I still found the level design to be just ok.

The gold coin mechanic felt out of place. Overall, the way this was implemented was strange, but I didn't find it problematic as this whole mechanic can be ignored. The rewards for trading gold coins also seemed underwhelming since most of them are specter buffs. Similar to FromSoftware titles, the summons used in boss fights completely trivializes them, but I'm still glad it was implemented for those who would still like to experience the full game, but struggle with bosses.

I found the the most of the dialogue options to be uninteresting, but giving the player the option to lie is cool.
I did not find the Legion arm to be interesting and often found myself forgetting about it. 
I wish Geppetto would stop calling P a good boy.

9/10. Extremely excited to see more from this studio in the future. And no, this is not [FromSoftware Title] from home!

Lies of P may be the easiest soulslike to recommend to a beginner because of a few tweaks to gameplay. First, holding block is far more rewarding because of Guard Regain, which lets you regain chip damage by attacking or parrying. Second is that heals are generous and virtually infinite, you can always attack to regain a spare heal if you run out. Essentially the game rewards defensive gameplay only if you are willing to follow it up with aggression and risk, which feels like a fair compromise.

Lies of P feels like a soulslike that prefers to offer you the satisfaction of beating a boss rather than keep you there until you've memorized every attack pattern, opening, and parry timing, it's okay with letting you scrape by. It's not an easy game by any standards, but if you're properly upgrading yourself and your weapons, and understand the mechanics, you will beat some bosses on the first try.

If you're coming from FromSoft games, the worldbuilding in Lies of P might feel offputting. FromSoft is especially good at establishing a consistent tone, something you take for granted once you realize Lies of P doesn't execute as well. Voice acting can feel strange, some accents feel out of place, and dialogue feels too casual at times. But in other areas, like music and artstyle, the worldbuilding is fantastically done and is genuinely beautiful.

Level design in Lies of P is simple but effective. It is more linear than I expected, and the spaces seem larger than they actually are. You'll find areas of the map that are sectioned off and are only there for window dressing, and it can feel frustrating to realize how small the playable area of a level is. There is often one main path, and one side path, and it's not always clear which is which. But it's effective in that a level will always entice you to explore all of it, typically with items that are just out of reach, or blocked gates that invite you to find the other side and unlock shortcuts.

There is a lot of content in this game, probably more than you're expecting if you've played for just a few hours. Enemy variety is a standout here, the game gradually invents new enemies that make exploration more interesting and tense. There are a respectable amount of weapons in this game of every variety, you're likely to find a weapon with a moveset that you really click with and a playstyle you enjoy. I didn't rely too hard on the Legion Arms, but their designs are pretty inspired, they look great, feel good to use, and I could see myself using them more on a second run with a different build. It's honestly overwhelming at first how many game mechanics there are, but it's never necessary to engage with every single one. If you want to fly around with Puppet String and spec into Fable Arts, you can do that. If you want a parry and riposte simulator, you can choose that, it never felt the game punished me for choosing to neglect those mechanics, you control the buttons you press.

Ultimately it feels wrong to compare this to Sekiro or Elden Ring or any Souls game because I think you could easily find things it does a bit worse than its predecessors. What it does achieve is being a fantastic game in its own right, and is probably the greatest game like it made by a different studio. I feel lucky we get to play a game like it.

What can I say about this game that hasn't already been said better? The game is phenomenally well made by people who, you can tell, care a great bit about their craft. If you had told me this was a fromsoftware title I would have believed you, which is one of the highest praises I think you can say of an aspiring "souls like". 

For anyone on the fence about this game: don't let the comments about it being hard dissuade you. The game is not *easy* by any means, but it is not unplayably difficult. It will require some patience, but I think the reward is well worth it. There is always a way to beat that enemy you're stuck on, even if not readily apparent. Boss fights are engaging yet not impossible, and the optional summon makes things a lot more manageable if you are having a rough time on them. 

I would get this game simply for the ambiance and the story alone, and yet it still nails the souls like formula perfectly, making it truly a one-of-a-kind game

Lies of P is a dark fantasy twist on the kids story “the adventures of pinoccio” they take heavy inspiration from dark souls and Sekiro almost to the point of borderline plagiarisms. Id say if fromsoft is chill with it you should be too. If you like any of fromsoft souls games you will certainly enjoy this one. It’s Story, secrets, and side characters are not all directly “one for one” taken from pinoccio but some references and themes definitely show up during the game. 

-Music
Why this game didn’t win best soundtrack is crazy to me. Seo J, Did such amazing vocals for songs like feel, and Quixotic. Maybe I’m just a sucker for jazzy classical themes. But it’s the best music I’ve listed to in a while. And love the record player in game that promotes their own music not in a selfish way but more along the lines of giving credit to musicians and artists that may not always get the publicity they deserve when being featured in games. I honestly wish more games did that. Even going as far as to fit its music into the game as a mechanic is a nice touch.

-Combat
Sekiro stagger and perfect block made its way into the game, If this games combat felt a little less clunky between attacks and recovery times after actions kinda. I don’t think you could tell that this game wasn’t made by Miyazaki. Very solid

-Mechanics (Potential spoiler warning)
 I like the new mechanics such as weapon assembly I fiddled with it a bit early game but once I got boss weapons I never touched it again other than to make cursed weapons like a fire axe head on a rapier handle. I’ll be lookin to YouTube for wacky weapon mods, and terrible weapon combo runs. grind wheel I liked only in open world, because having to sharpen in the middle of a boss battle was just kinda annoying to me but items in the game help this issue. The cube was interesting I’ll probably use it more on my NG+. but first time around I only used it once and couldn’t cancel the action of casting it so I died insta and never pulled it out again. The P organ I was nervous at first because I’m not typically a fan of skill trees in games like these because there’s always something on them that trivializes the game, but I didn’t actually mind it, there were useful tools to min/max but didn’t break the game. I still got canned by final boss plenty of times even with a pretty full p organ.

-Conclusion 
8/10, fantastic souls like, looking forward to future DLC or a new installment. Congrats to Neowiz on their success, I will def keep a eye open for new projects from this team

Bloodborne at home. Real talk this game plays great, looks great and runs great. Only thing it lacks is compelling level design, it's a very linear game that doesn't really promote exploration or feature satisfying loop around shortcuts like most of the "real" Souls games. No co-op either, although you can summon NPC phantoms to assist on bosses.

Theme is awesome though and it has some unique ideas like the weapon system, which allows you to mix and match handles (move set and scaling) with blades (damage type, speed and range). 

In any case its one of the better if not the best none fromsoft souls games and if you liked bloodborne or sekiro you will absolutely have a blast here.

I usually don't like "souls like" games because they feel like cheap imitations of Fromsoft and are unable to capture what makes soulsborne amazing. This game, however, feels like a genuine fromsoft game. It's difficult to describe what that means exactly, but this game was amazing. It takes all the best combat mechanics from souls, bloodborne, sekiro, and ER and combines them into a unique (yet familiar) gameplay that was super satisfying. The Pinocchio plot/setting was also brilliantly executed and the game had a mix of Bloodborne and Bioshock's aesthetics, which really scratched an itch in by brain that I didn't know I had. The final cut scene teases a Wizard of O game in the future-- definitely getting it.

After 100%-ing the game, this is easily my game of the year.

If you love Dark Souls and/or Elden Ring, you need this game yesterday. The developer's clearly loved and studied the Souls series to create a game that could easily stand alongside the best of FromSoft's games. The big differences I noticed were the following:

- Builds are limited to melee via DEX builds, STR builds and Quality builds. There is no option to make a ranged or magic build nor is there any build that I would call a "cheese" build. Although it is compensated for via items that can be thrown, buffs via consumables and weapon upgrades, you are going to have to learn to "get good" via guards, parries, and dodging.

- You actually know what's going on in the story. There's lots of world-building via item descriptions, collectible letters/diaries/posters, conversations, and visual storytelling, but you aren't going to be left confused on what is going on with the narrative. It leaves stuff open for interpretation but you aren't going to YouTube for an explanation on what just happened.

- Out of all the bosses there are only three, maybe four, that I have any real complaints about. Some bosses that come out towards the end of the game don't know when to chill out with their animations and have small timing windows for you to attack, making them last longer than they probably should. I not expecting to button mash but I barely have time to get ONE hit in before they start another combo that uses up all my stamina blocking/dodging. Still, I wouldn't call them unfair. Difficult, even if you manage your stats correctly, but not impossible.

Long and short of it is, the few complaints I can think of are just nitpicks to a game that captured my attention enough for me to go for 100%. You have to be something truly special to make me want to do that, especially if doing so requires multiple playthroughs. Strongly recommend the base game at full price.

Lies of P is undoubtedly the best souls-like game I have played to date. From the story and atmosphere to the gameplay, I was hooked until I beat the game and already started my first NG+. A truly polished game with little to no performance issues made by a smaller developer. Quite the fantastic treat given the current state of AAA games. 

Below, I will summarize the game and my thoughts.

[b] SPOILER WARNING

In Lies of P, we play as P, a puppet thrown into the City of Krat. This city is sprawling with other puppets, except something is tragically wrong. Within the streets lies countless dead human corpses and the city is on fire. All we can find are other puppets mindlessly killing civilians, and I couldn't help but think, what is going on?

We eventually come to a hotel, which houses individuals seeking refuge and shelter from the puppets wrath. The main person of interest to us is Sophie, who originally called us from our starting point to meet her at the hotel. We find out the the City of Krat houses a rare mineral called Ergo. This mineral was then used by puppet-maker Geppetto to further his creations. This lead to puppets being made to work jobs around the city. This on paper solved a lot of things for the cities population, however, the puppets rebelled, which caused an even known to us as the Puppet Frenzy. After we learn this, we come face to face with our maker, Geppetto, after saving him from a Stalker who is trying to harm him. Stalkers are humans who go out and kill as many puppets as they can. Many if not all of them are hellbent on killing Geppetto, as he is the creator of all the puppets, who are now killing innocent people.  

This game follows a mostly linear path after we arrive at the Hotel and save Geppetto. We are tasked with doing multiple different things, but our main goal is to eliminate the puppets terrorizing the city and save as many people as we can. We encounter many bosses and characters along the way, but the main standout is the antagonist, Simon Manus.

Simon Manus is the leader of the alchemists, a faction of individuals who experimented with Ergo. We are told from Manus that Ergo is a pure crystallized form of human souls, which in part, is why it works so effectively with puppets. With all the experiments conducted, the Alchemists created a mutation/disease - which would be later called the Petrification Disease. This disease mutates the host, starting with blue growths on the body and face, until it fully takes over and turns the host into a monstrosity. From this point, we hunt down Manus and find him at the Isle of Alchemists. We kill him, and in theory conclude the game, but, there is one more choice that must be made.

Throughout this game we are given dialogue options to choose from. One answer is us telling the truth about any given situation. The other is us lying. While on the surface, this may seem like something useless, in this world, puppets can not lie. They have been programmed from Geppetto to always tell the truth. So what gives? Why can we as P lie, but other puppets cannot? This brings us to the true finale of the game.

We find Geppetto underneath where we fought Manus, and he asks us a question. He wants us to give him our heart, so that he can turn us into a "real boy". The only trick is that Geppetto wants to use our heart and insert it into a puppet named Carlo. We are thought to believe all throughout this game that we are Geppetto's true son, when in reality, he built us and used us to strengthen the P organ (our heart) so that he could give it to Carlo, his actual son. This decision leads to the different endings in the game. We either give our heart and die (bad ending) or refuse and fight the nameless puppet. No matter what ending you choose, an end game cut-scene will play, hinting at a DLC / 2nd game. 

I highly recommend checking out the video done by Gingy on YouTube. 
He is by far my favorite video game channel and does amazing story breakdowns/retrospectives.

This game has it all for me. A fantastic story, choices that change how the game unfolds, amazing weapon design and combat system, and enemies that pose a real challenge. I have seen many people say it plays too much like a FromSoft game, and is almost a "rip-off". I disagree. Are there elements that are similar/the same, yes. Does this take away from the unique and stylized game that is Lies of P, no.

I would highly recommend this game to anyone that enjoys souls-like or FromSoft games.

I loved this game, truly a gem. Coming with experience from FromSoftware games, Lies of P really holds its own. It shouldn't be labeled and referred to as a "Souls-Like" game, but a rather "Souls" game. It does many things right, from combat mechanisms, weightiness of combat, audio, responsiveness, level design, story elements, visuals, music, etc. It just feels sooo good to play and experience. Never once did I feel cheated by a boss or stage mechanic. When I died, it was a "Yep, I deserved that. Now how do I overcome that obstacle/boss with all of the tools the game gives me."

The game did crash twice for me (message about UE4 crashing), but other than that I didn't experience any other bugs. I do wish some of the characters, especially the story villains (minor and major) were more flushed out and received more screen time. But other than that, it was a great experience. An amazing game that I would highly recommend to those that enjoy Souls and Souls-Like games.

Now in all seriousness, this game is great. It is quite challenging (especially in the second half of the game), but the quality is up there for sure. I would say it is even on the same level as FromSoft games.

This might be an opinion not many share, but I enjoyed this game more than Elden Ring, but that is probably because I prefer the parry mechanic to the classic dodge roll (which is why I liked Sekiro more than the Souls games that I played). Make no mistake though, as dodging is still required in many places, you will not be relying solely on parrying (or Perfert Guarding, as it is called in this game).

The story is quite enjoyable, but also way less obscure than the way narrative is presented in FromSoft games. Some people may not like this, but I do prefer this style of storytelling.

There are many more aspects of the game that are worth detailing (such as the customization options in weapons, the legion arm, P-Organs, how well the game is optimized etc), but I will stop my review here.

If you like soulslikes, and are not afraid of a (quite difficult) challenge, I wholeheartedly recommend this game.

Very good game, if you like souls-likes you will enjoy this game. While it does have a focus on blocking, don't let that fool you, you will still dodge most things that you cannot reasonably parry. You will still need to dodge on parry timing anyways; your dodge timing is tight like Dark Souls parry timing, but your parry or "Perfect Guard" timing is even tighter. Take a page from Capn Jack Sparrow; sometimes the best strategy is to run away to fight back (literally, dodge an attack or tap the dodge to backstep, then run away, and run back in to punish works for a LOT of bosses).

The game takes some time to adjust due to its own mechanics being slightly different (no generous roll windows, no poise, skim amounts of hyperarmor on heavy weapons), but it gets much smoother as you play more. I definitely recommend having a quick weapon and a slooooow weapon on hand, some enemies can be spammed to death and others you can abuse the small amount of hyperarmor at the end of meaty charged heavies to chunk their health.

Anyways the game is like others have said: it's hard but fair, and once you figure out the unique mechanics you'll really love smashing puppets

Almost walked away from this game in the first few chapters, and definitely glad I didnt. Ngl, the beginning of the game, I hated it, all of the enemy attacks felt super janky, and the parry very inconsistent, coming from someone who has hundreds of hrs in sekiro, and platinumed every fromsoft game, and countless other souls likes, I wanted to scratch that itch, specifically that parry itch. In the beginning, all of the enemies would wind up like 7 times super slow then suddenly attack, which I didnt like. Felt like when enemies would attack (specifically puppets) they would attack in 15fps. Also, didnt find the game challenging at all, the first 10 hrs or so I had only died a couple of times to being overwhelmed by trash mobs, or a status effect debuff, none of the bosses gave me any challenge and would kill them all first try, maybe healing once, which was definitely disappointing. I kept playing solely because I just spent 50 dollars, and wanted to see why this game was getting so much praise. After about halfway through, I genuinely started to like the game, and the bosses and enemies actually took some effort to kill, and the weird attacks began to make a little more sense. The parry started to click, and now starting my 2nd playthrough, I genuinely like and recommend this game, at first it might seem a little janky and very easy, but trust me, just see it through, anybody who loves soulslikes will surely like this game, especially the 2nd half and beyond. I recommend trying out a bunch of different weapon and handle combinations, as this game will flood you with upgrade mats, and at the end, can purchase all mats for up to +9 for regular weapons, dont be stingy, try new weapons...to think I almost abandoned this game due to its differences from other souls games Im "used to"... Definitely not one of the hardest souls like at all, but I still appreciated the setting, and style of the game. Props to these devs for going with something different, to think at first I thought this was a "complete bloodborne ripoff" lol

I love this game for all the things it isn't. It isn't open world. It isn't "beat your head on the desk" hard. It isn't an incomprehensibly obtuse world I can barely relate to. It isn't wildly different character classes and build customization. It's just a classic game that tells a great story, has great combat, and hits all the notes along the way. 

For me, the best thing about LoP is the combat. It just feels enough faster and snappier than my vague memory of DS3/Elden Ring without the developer going out of their way to try and kill me every 50 steps. The level design is straightforward but never feels linear. The more you play the more you appreciate the weapon system (which is a little hard to grasp at first). Lot of ways to make things easier like spamming throwables or using spectres on boss fights, but the challenge is there for those who want it by only using their weapon and their wites.

Although the "levels" are generally much easier than FromSoft's titles, the bosses are still troublesome (especially in the last few chapters) because it's hard to take a breather. You can't iFrame dodge as much as DarkSouls or block like Sekiro your way out of a flurry off attacks and perfect parries are almost over emphasized in LoP (and unforgiving when you inevitably miss A LOT). 

Personally, there's something tedious about replying FromSoft titles, but I'm loving multiple playthoughs of LoP and it feels like a more streamlined, less vindictive game with just the right amount of challenge in a wonderful setting.

This game was truly exceptional. I have never completed a souls like game before so this was quite an accomplishment, even if i got stuck on a boss, I had the ability to get creative and think outside the box to complete the task at hand. The design of every little detail is immaculate. Truly a 10/10!

The progression:
Every time you upgrade your character, the upgrades actually make a difference. The different builds and weapons really complement the upgrades to wear you can iron out and perfect a build. 

The flow: 
The pacing of the game was great, you never felt too under powered when facing your next challenge. Just make sure to explore a bit and grab good loot, because even if you die you keep all your items except for ergo (currency).

The Combat: 
The combat was truly exceptional!! I love the parry system, it was very satisfying when you parry at the right time and break an enemy's stance and/or weapon. When you parry enough times you can stagger an enemy and deal a great amount of damage. The regular enemy and bosses are all very unique and give a perfect amount of variety. It makes you think light on your feet, and use your build in different ways that are extremely satisfying.  
(My set up is The Puppet Ax with the Police Baton Handle, the Puppet String Legion Arm, spec'd into motivity and capacity. Its awesome!) 

The Story: 
No spoilers here, the story was captivating and left me wanting more. I wanted to explore more to get more story and world building. The scenery was absolutely stunning and really hammered in the story was trying to tell.

TL; DR: 

9.5/10

BEST SOULS-LIKE OF THE DECADE. BUY IT. 

---

- 优秀的美术风格，和性能优化，即便是我的SteamDeck和MacBook Air也能跑满60fps，游戏本更是2k 120。在2020s这狗屎优化/劣质游戏满地爬的年代，真是可遇不可求。服装作为纯装饰品也是个不错的设计，至少不会影响我暖暖了。

- 相比魂系，游戏对玩家来说更加友好，每张图都标配的捷径，boss房外掉魂，以及npc支线提示，对玩家的惩罚没有那么大，玩起来不累，能够一直有热情玩下去。可选的npc助战（虽然我还没试过），配合上炼金师那买的方块，只能说非常轮椅，不会有人这样还打不过吧？

- 富有魂味的地图设计，陷阱，机关，柳暗花明的捷径，符合逻辑而非纯迷宫的室内外地图，不能说完美，但也可以说是优秀的模仿。虽然大部分时候对于魂ass来说可能是意料之外情理之中，但打完黑兔帮后直接回到了酒店，还是把我惊到了。

- 没有联机可能失去了一份和朋友一起游玩的快乐，但考虑到剧情，其实是情理之中，而且没有魂5入侵让游戏体验大大提升。

- 战斗可能是大多数人觉得不行的点。在我看来主要问题还是人物常驻韧性和出手韧性都太低，拼刀拼不过小怪，不马上翻滚还能被boss一套连到爽 —— 要是我也能像对面的白人偶一样打都打不动，那估计爽死了。但对于刺剑/小雨伞从头玩到尾的我来说，90%的战斗体验其实还不错。个别几乎没有硬直，还连招贼多的精英怪/小boss确实让人血压飙升（忍耐锯骨刀蓄力，请），大部分更多的是熟练度问题。
  - BOSS战说难真的不难，说简单也不见得简单，但整体来说BOSS的出招和派生其实都比较直白且简单，多被打几次肯定记住了，解法也没有非常复杂，吃的就是基本功，这一点更像是只狼 —— 打过一次就有一万次。但问题就出在boss的血量很长，且伤害高，导致不熟练的情况下容错率大幅度下降。对我目前来说，初见过的boss只有那个马戏团古达和菜鸡维克多。如果你习惯魂系的云里雾里过boss战的话，可能要多坐牢一会儿了。
  - 不过话说回来，这个完美格挡的时机确实难了点，多个一两帧（60fps）可能会体验好不少。加上没有狼的抖刀术，初见不建议无脑弹反，该使用超长无敌帧的回避。

- 作为一个类魂，LoP除了完美复刻了魂的经典元素之外，也加了不少属于自己的东西：与剧情相关联的撒谎系统，提升主角性能的P器官，可以根据自己的喜好（手感，技能）随意组装的武器，跟Sekiro借的高级忍义手（后期甚至能带俩？），还有好听又放松的唱片。是一个内容丰富且完整的游戏。

- 既然他能被拿来和正统魂系作比较，不论输赢，LoP作为Neowiz的第一作类魂，都已经非常成功了。而且在我心中他远比早期魂系优秀。

------

怎么还有人会觉得他差？能不能先玩一玩游戏。抛去玩家自身的Skill Issue，LoP是一款短板很少的“类魂”，也是最接近魂系的作品。

Lies of P is one of the games that has positively surprised me the most in last few years and it ended up being one of my favourite and most enjoyable recent gaming experiences. I've always been intrigued by the Souls-like formula and concept, watched a lot of gameplay and tried several titles from the genre, but I couldn't genuinely enjoy any of them all the way through due to minor gripes. LoP "fixes" most of those for me.
A lot of my appreciation comes from personal preferences when it comes to combat style and pacing, story and characters, aesthetic, soundtrack, RPG elementes, UI & UX etc., but I think it's at least decent enough if not quite amazing regardless of that.
The various influences are very obvious, but there is some original flavour and the developers did a good job combining it all. Difficulty is consistently present in different aspects as expected, but it doesn't feel unfair or artificial. There are so many ways for you to adapt, change the approach and play style or make it easier / harder. It's certainly dark fantasy and while it may not be as impressive as FromSoft titles in certain regards, the existing content and systems are well done and I loved how it doesn't shy away from breaking up the grim and depressing parts both thematically and visually from time to time.
The game also runs very well and I haven't encountered any bugs or issues in my ~50 hours of play time.
I recommend giving Lies of P a try both to fans of original Soulsborne games, since it is the closest to FromSoft quality and experience I've seen so far, as well as people who are simply into more traditional action role-playing titles as long as they don't mind a certain degree of difficulty.

This game looks amazing and it's very detailed. I love games inspired by old stories. Great game. Pinocchio is hot - would smash. He's my favourite puppet, even if he isn't one*. The music and dialogue at the end made me depressed and want to disembowel myself in a hara kiri ritual for making a few mistakes. I stayed loyal to Geppetto because I'm a good boy and I felt sorry for him. 

This game is very fun, detailed and immersive.



*Believe it or not, there is no puppet in this game or in the Pinocchio story. In the old Pinocchio story, Pinocchio is a marionette, not a puppet, despite the author, Carlo Collodi's usage of 'puppet'. In this game, Pinocchio is an automaton. He is both biological and mechanical, so he's basically a cyborg too. Anyway, if Carlo can call Pinocchio a puppet, then these devs should of course just call this mechanical cyborg automaton thing a Puppet because otherwise, you'd be kind of ruining the connection to the story a little bit. At the end of the day, nobody cares and it would be weird if this game didn't refer to Pinocchio as a puppet considering the story he comes from did. So why am I mentioning this? Because I'm bored, and if I want to point out a fact nobody needs to know in a review to satisfy my extreme boredom, then I will.

So as I was saying

A puppet is something you shove your hand and arm inside.

A marionette is what has strings and is controlled from above. Kind of like that real boy that's got no strings to hold him down.

An automaton is a mechanical robot thing. Some of them are nightmare fuel, but they are very cool.


Spell-check wants me to change "Geppetto" to ghetto.
