This is a long review, but I really want to stress just how beautiful the music of this game is. Please at least listen to the music. 

Souls-likes are always fun to play and are my favorite genre for a reason. Some of the best gameplay elements mixed with a lovingly crafted and extremely detailed world... at least, they should be. However, many "souls-likes" replicate the gameplay, but never the vast lore and world-building found in Dark Souls or Elden Ring or Bloodborne. Lies of P, does this phenomenally, and is probably one of the best "souls-like" that isn't actually a souls game. 

First, lets get past the stuff that I didn't like personally. I found that the zones and maps that you trek through were kind of empty. The environments were beautiful, with so much to look at and so much environmental storytelling to observe and appreciate. But besides from a handful of areas, these places aren't as in depth, maze-like, or sprawling as Bloodborne (this game's main inspiration.)  A lot of areas had maybe one or two things to go out of your way for, and that was about it. This game is very straightforward, and from start to finish you will always be on goal. Now I haven't looked anything up, so if there was an optional area I missed, or a whole bunch of items passed me by, that's my fault, but I feel that the average player shouldn't need to look up all that stuff, though, part of a "souls-like"'s charm is unraveling the mystery inside the maps of the game. One other thing I wasn't a big fan of was the Gold Coin Fruit system. This is mostly a personal thing, but I feel that in a "souls-like", there shouldn't be any unlimited currency that just appears over time. But those are my only persevering complaints. 

Now, you might ask what's good about this game? All of it. It is the closest you can get to a Soulsborne game while still experiencing new and fresh ideas that will keep you engaged for the entire game. The combat was incredibly fun, with the fantastic perfect guard system that kept combat satisfying and tested my deflecting abilities. The Legion arm was also a ton of fun, with a ton of different arms that all played a little differently, suiting plenty of styles. I found that the Aegis was my favorite as it helped my blocking build immensely. The equipment was also very nice. This game introduces an interesting feature "weapon assembly" allowing you to swap the handle and the blade of a weapon. This often results in very wacky looking swords and spears, but it is incredible with the level of customization you can do. 

The story of this game is phenomenal, but most importantly, it actually strays away from the storytelling style of the Soulsborne games. This is perfect for me, because I know the Soulsborne games have incredible stories, but I don't feel like becoming Sherlock Holmes to figure out why one boss is sad all the time, and I especially don't feel like watching a 12 hour video on the lore of the game. Lies of P gives you all the tools to make sure you can experience each character's story line and the lore of the land without you missing out. Not everything is told to you however, as there are certain stories that you'll have to do some digging to find. With this story telling format, Lies of P is able to tell you a heavy and dark toned story, and fill it with more twists than any other "souls-like" I've seen. You will be on the edge of your seat at the end of it, and you will hate some characters that you loved in the beginning. It is fantastic. 

Now, saving the best for last, what is the one thing you should play this game to experience? The music. The score of this game is one of the most incredible pieces of music I've ever heard. I'm convinced that the composer for this masterpiece only created the game so more people could hear their music. I love it to death, and I will continue to listen to it. Music is also extremely important to the story of this game, as you can collect records to listen to in the hub area which will affect the game as it goes along. Trust me, every single piece of music in this game is downright beautiful, and I love it to death. There were multiple times I stopped just to listen to this wonderful soundtrack. 

Lies of P understands exactly what it means to be a "souls-like" while still adding new elements to prove that they're more than just copy cats. This fantastic, bizarre, and beautiful spin on Pinocchio is perfect for any Souls player, and I recommend it wholeheartedly.

This is a nice "Bloodborne at home".

Developers haven't simply checked all boxes for a "modern Soulslike game" (although, quite a lot of game design decisions look like they were made just because "you gotta"), they truly brought some new ideas, some of them quite bold, like the weapon assembly system or attacks that completely ignore i-frames.

But of course, if you have played Souls/Bloodborne/Elden Ring you would notice a myriad of direct borrowings from there, some of them almost outrageously straightforward, like "talk to coughing people behind closed windows", "very nimble swordswoman that undresses in the second phase, calls herself a sharp-edged weapon of some other person and has some infuriating combo-attacks", "character named Manus that has an enormous hand" and so on and so on. It is not bad per se, it's just... Confusing?

But all of these strange things aside, that's a solid and VERY polished game that is fun to play, intriguing to listen to and is generally well done.

Nice job, guys, looking forward to that teased sequel :)

They say that imitation is the most sincere form of flattery and this game proves it. It copies straight many things from several From Software games. The combat is a combination of Bloodborne and Sekiro with a twist and the level design seems like its pulled piecemeal from the entire franchise. Albeit much more linear than what you are used to. I think that is one of the weaker parts of the game. 

Copying things is not bad mind you. Its like the game was made by a souls fan that really understood what made those games great. He then copied and applied those ideas perfectly with excellent skill while putting his own spin and expanding on some areas. 

For example: The combat system in a vacuum is probably better than most From Software equivalent. Or at least more complicated. Instead of just dodging everything you are expected to either dodge, block or parry depending on the boss and the attack. Thus making things more interesting! 

Another thing they did well is that the heavy attacks are actually useful now. In FS games you usually just spam the light attack as the heavy ones take too long and does not help you all that much. Here they have three attacks with three movesets per weapon combination. Light, heavy and charged heavy. And while the heavier attacks might be slower they often have advantages like longer range to compensate. Which they don't in FS games. 

Also just like Sekiro, part of the combat is often to break the enemy poise to kill bosses faster. You can do that by perfect parrying the boss or by hitting with a charged heavy attack. This existed in dark souls too. But were rarely used. But here its often essential which makes Charged heavy attacks useful. 

The block system lets damage through, but it can be regained by attacking just like in Bloodborn. The difference here is that it only apply to blocked damage. Which is a fine compromise. 

All in all a very good game! 9/10 probably. Game of the year for me 2023. (But I have not played Baldurs Gate 3 yet.)

Oh yeah and the soundtrack is one of the bests god I love it.

As I watched gameplay videos of Lies of P, I was a bit afraid that it would be too much like an unremarkable souls-clone that I'll like enough to play but nothing that'll be of note to me. I am so happy that I was proven wrong. From the polish, enemy design, boss fights, ost, lie mechanic, and the weapon system, Lies of P really blew all of my expectations in terms of quality. 

Despite looking nearly identical to the fromsoft games, I was pleasantly surprised to find that it actually does a lot of things differently. For one, it mixed up the Sekiro-style parry system with the Dark Souls combat, resulting in various ways to deal with the various fast and punishing movesets that the bosses have. Pair that with the weapon disassembly system and the lie mechanic for the story, the game ends up with some pretty good replayability. All while letting you roam a pretty world and a great OST to listen to while you go at it. And the P-Organ upgrade system adds a sense of progression that's pretty unique to the souls-like genre.

But what about the combat? I will admit, in the beginning, I thought that the parry windows were too tight, the attacks were too fast, the dodge i-frames didn't last long enough, etc. But once you get the hang of weaving through attacks and knowing which ones are worth more when parried, the combat flow becomes really really satisfying, especially with the hit effects of the game. And as mentioned before, the weapon disassembly system can lead to some really fun and bizarre combos of movesets and weapon blades. While some weapons are much more viable than others, most are enough to get you through the game. 

Overall, I really recommend Lies of P to anyone looking for a souls-game worth playing. I daresay that it's even 100% worth on full price.

I really enjoy how easily this game lets you switch and swap different weapons that you might like into your build, with how the scaling is tied to the handle along with the move set, then the damage coming from the blade. You can also switch out how each weapon scales (to a point, only moving a letter at a time, B->C or  B->A) for the 3 different attributes that scale your weapon damage, allowing for pretty much any weapon you want to use, with pretty much any build and keep it working and doing damage. This seamless process is also not difficult to understand and is introduced to the player very well. Gone are the days of sticking to one build for the entire game, now you can do whatever you want, whenever you want in the game, as long as you have the materials to change your weapon scaling and then to upgrade it. 

my only complaint is that you can hear an NPC coughing relentlessly from one of the Stargazers "Bonfires/Grace" and I sometimes like to just sit at the rest spots and chill, this was not one of those locations.

This game also runs very well on my laptop, versus world of warcraft which CHUGGS the shit out of my laptop for seemingly no reason.

My only problem with the game is that in NG+ there are barely any +X charms and almost all of the +1 parts you get for defence are worse than the highest tier from the first play through until you reach the highest tier parts from NG+, leading to you being incredibly squishy in NG+ always.

Good

As someone who's played almost every FromSoftware souls game (one day Demon's Souls remaster will come to PC), I really like this game. The controls feel responsive, most bosses feel unique and have fun patterns. The story was pretty engaging, with an incredibly immersive atmosphere. At one point you are able to look over the whole city and pick out areas you have explored and the paths you've taken to get there. The areas that you explore feel fun to traverse.

For the bad parts of the game, while the areas are enjoyable to explore, there's not much exploration to do. At most there'll be a slightly tougher enemy to kill for a slight upgrade or a new weapon that you may or may not use. There are some sidequests in the game that are at most a "make sure you come back and talk to this guy after progressing through the area", but not many sidequests. I think the game would have done a lot better with maybe one whole optional area with an actual boss. Speaking of bosses, the entire latter half of the bosses were all overly difficult, all relying on the trope of having multiple health bars and usually transforming into almost an entirely different boss with different movesets. This does the game a disservice, as this type of mechanic should be used sparingly, in my opinion. Imagine my surprise in my playthrough when a seemingly unimportant swamp monster turns out to have a second phase for no good reason other than it being closer to the end of the game.

Also the end-credits scene was stupid. Imagine if at the end of the 2008 Iron Man movie, they had the scene of Nick Fury showing up and bringing up the Avenger Initiative lead into another scene where Stark buys the Avenger tower and puts the symbol on it, just to really hammer in the point that it was THOSE Avengers and not anything else like it wasn't already obvious.

Before I picked up this game, I was relatively hesitant as although I love souls games, I've heard a lot of people complain about the parry mechanic. I've never been good at parrying, and I couldn't even attempt a game like Sekiro. But I bought the game and tried my luck, and I am unbelievably happy I did. This is not just one of the best "souls-likes" I've played, but I would argue that it was genuinely a better and more fun experience than half of the souls games, and at the very least rivals Bloodborne in terms of quality. The world is beautiful and the setting is amazing. The writers knocked it out of the park because practically every single character is lovable and a joy to hear dialogue from. The gameplay is incredibly satisfying and rewards aggression, and the parry system is actually extremely fair. The game has it's faults though, like the slower weapons feeling not worth using at all on some bosses or enemies, half the legion arms being pointless, etc. But overall, I truly did enjoy this game and although I just barely caught it before the end of the year, I'm glad I did as it's one of the best games I've played in 2023. I hope you consider picking up Lies of P, and thank you for reading.

Overall, I would rate this a very solid 9+ in terms of a gaming experience.  Bravo to the devs.

Honestly it's quite shocking to me that it took this long for someone else to finally and properly emulate From Software's formula with such a noteworthy caliber of polishment.

This game is one of the few ones that I've played over the years that wears the "Souls badge" as an undivided inspiration and definitely lives up to its premises instead of just trying to jump on the bandwagon copying and pasting concepts on a surface level. The developers at NEOWIZ seems to really understand what makes Souls games intrinsically remarkable experiences.

Lies of P succeeds at what it's trying to do on every level and seems to never drops it's quality. The moment to moment gameplay feels super satisfying, combat feels precisely engaging with plenty of room for player's expression, the level design is phenomenal, there's a good balance between direct and indirect storytelling, plus the great art direction aligned with the soundtrack makes for a magnificent atmospheric presentation.

I think that is also important to mention that the PC version is excellent with great scalability and runs like a dream. Fortunately they didn't inherit From Software's technical problems, which is kind of funny in retrospect when I think about every From's Souls games back at their respective launch excluding Demon's Souls, be it on consoles or PC and I say that as someone who considers Bloodborne one of the best video games of all time.

Now, where's my Bloodborne PC port?

Absolutely recommend this, especially if you like other Souls games.  Its a familiar formula that you will recognize.  The game can be hard in some aspects but once you learn what the game expects from you, progress is fun and fair.  This is a very well done game, showing lots of good decision making.  There is room for improvement for sure, but for a first try at a Souls game from this developer, this is a home run.

[h2] My opinions after 100%ing [/h2]

Overall and in general, i think this is an absolutely well made Souls-Like that that stands out with the unique systems you have available to modify your tools to fit your playstyle (P-Organ, weapon disassembly system, grinder)
The general look and feel of the game is great and i [b]truely[/b] think this is hands down the best Souls-Like in the style of the original souls games, that ISN'T developed by FromSoft!

[h1] My personal positives [/h1]

The level design feels well thought out with the shortcuts you can unlock and some neat hidden things here and there in evey zone.

They implemented very nice quality of life stuff to show the player that an NPC has new dialogue or sidequests that can be continued in different zones.

Bosses are very fun to learn, have overall well telegraphed attacks. You don't have to rely on perfect guarding, i played through 99% of it just dodging and spacing. (And you can summon a Specter (an NPC) to help you fight bosses if you want)

All the lore is easy to understand(!!), the concept of lying is well done and has actual influences on characters, with there also being sidequests and little sidestories for you to explore [spoiler] and it gives you some optional fights depending on your choices [/spoiler].

Yes some of the lore is hidden behind item descriptions (mostly collectible stuff like books and notes and so on), but the vast majority of it is told during exploration and speaking with NPCs
The cryptic text on some boss dialogue is also neat imo, so if you wanna take the time and read it, you will find some more hidden lore. [spoiler]But also if you're playing NG+, it just becomes readable, so if you just play through without bothering to read the cryptic stuff on your first playthrough, it will give you a different feel re-experiencing the story through NG+ [/spoiler]

Ah yeah.. also gearing and fashion are separated!

[h1] My personal negatives [/h1]

For my first point i wanna preface that, this being the developers first Souls-Like of that scale, they've really done their homework in how to make a game like this..
BUT the main story progression is very liniar, with no way of influencing the order.
While it works to tell the story, i just wish there were more ways to deviate from the main path and explore more, i hope they give you more options if they really do a sequel.

On that note..
The game only has a single, pretty short, actual zone that is optional [spoiler]with an underwhelming end to it [/spoiler]
It feels very "Demon's Souls-y" with how little exploration outside the main story it has, minus the choice to do areas in different orders that you'd have in Demon's Souls. 


The only other negative point i have, is probably very much my own fault due to how i skilled, so take it with a grain of salt before you keep reading.

I wish had more reason to use the different Legion Arms while exploring.

Some Legion Arms [spoiler](Flamberge, Fulminis, Pandemonium)[/spoiler] only do decent damage when you skill into Advance and they can inflict status effects, but while exploring and fighting new enemies the status infliction felt pretty slow and i ended up not bothering to try and find out what is and isn't effective on enemies anymore.
For those Legion Arms it must 100% be a Me issue, because i didn't skill into Advance very much, and ended up refraining from using them, since the build up is too slow (because the build up probably scales with the damage the respective Legion Arm does).

[b]But[/b] even for Legion Arms that scaled better with Technique or Motivity, they just felt very slow to use for the damage they dealt [spoiler] Deus Ex Machina[/spoiler] while exploring.
And for moments where there are ranged enemies that are further away and maybe a bit more difficult to engage, [spoiler]Falcon Eyes[/spoiler] would have been great to use i guess [spoiler] especially on the stationary enemies that throw stuff, that you cant pull with the Puppet String, or big enemies that you want to chip down[/spoiler], but throwable objects are just way too strong and often 2-3 shot those enemies, so that Legion Arm kinda doesn't feel worth using at all.. unless you're out of throwing objects i guess.


[h2] In conclusion [/h2]
The large amount of positives massively outweight the negatives, and simply put if you're looking for a great Souls-Like experience, i can't recommend you enough to try it out and pray with me that the sequel or DLC won't take too many years :')

Thank you for reading and enjoy!

Absolutely astonishing game. To see a company nail this style of this game on their first attempt while many others fail time and time again is insanity. I have beaten all Fromsoft souls-likes on PC except DS2 as of right now over the past year, and I can confidently say that I enjoyed this game more that the DS series (I'm still working on my DS2 playthrough, but this game stole me). 

In terms of gameplay, I ranks above Elden and DS series, and sit sits next to Sekiro for me, but overall I would still rate Elden Ring and Sekiro over it, as I like the narratives, exploration, and set pieces throughout more. Lies of P lacks side levels, limiting exploration, but it makes up for its stellar combat and amazing level design as a whole. Absolutely no filler content, but the final act/major level drags a bit IMO. 

I give lies of P a 9/10. It's not perfection, but it doesn't have to be. The game has a fantastic foundation, it's built upon extremely well, and a solid story as well. There are areas I hope they build upon in DLC or future installments (side levels, side bosses, maybe having the lying system impact gameplay in some way, but these things lacking does not hurt the game they have now). 

HIGHLY recommend. It's hard, but the best tip I can give is that dodging is more important than some may expect when guarding is highly encouraged throughout. 

BONUS - Current Ranking from my souls-like experience:
1.) Sekiro
2.) Elden Ring
3.) Lies of P
4.) DS2 (not finished, and I know that would have me killed in some states, but I like it)
5.) DS3
6.) DS1 (loved lvl design, did not enjoy combat, but it's just old so its not really fair)|

This game is a total love letter to the whole soulsborne series and it shows. I thoroughly enjoyed my experience with this game.

Pros
-Boss fights are fun and memorable (except for probably two of them) 
-Great combat system and very stylish as well as engaging
-Story and atmosphere are on point
-Level design is on par with the rest of the souls series.
-Music is killer
-Has a lot of quality of life things that should be standard in all upcoming souls games
-The overall pacing is fantastic
-Performance is great! Nice to see a modern PC release not have BS performance issue (All of Jedi Survivor, Dead Space Remake cut scenes and stuttering, and the entirety of The Callisto Protocol)

Cons
-The way the belt system works is awful. The lack of any hold to go to first slot function is absolutely unforgivable
(The souls series wasn't best but I would argue after DS3 and Elden RIng there is not excuse.)
-Weapon Durability - This might be controversial, but I am not sure. Besides applying buffs to your weapon, the entire durability mechanic was either negligible or downright aggravating, I absolutely despise having to repair my weapons in the middle of the fight. I know that there are rings and items to help, but if you have jump through so many hoops to mitigate or complete remove it than why even have it. Completely useless mechanic in my opinion. * Cries whilst having DS2 durability bug PTSD

Overall I would recommend this to any souls veteran whether they be casual or super hardcore into the series. It's really nice to finally see a true souls like experience that is on par with its influences and in some ways better. 
I would not recommend to new players who have no experience in any of the games, Obviously I'd recommend new players playing one or two the souls series games, especially Bloodborne.

Congratulations on the team that made this game possible. Can't wait to see what they put out next.

Excellent borrowings from the Souls games. If you are a Souls fan you owe it to yourself to play this game. Linear level design makes exploration a little less satisfying, however I ended up enjoying everything the game has to offer.

[b]Score: 8.5/10[/b]

There are many doppelgangers, plastic mimics, and shoddily-crafted counterfeits that crack with the slighest nudge among the now-generous Soulslike genre. One of those... Lies of P is not. It's true, it takes liberally from the mechanical and environmental design of the Miyazaki catalogue, sometimes to the point where it's annoyingly fond for From, but alone amongst its equals, it executes them to the very same level. I didn't think it possible because of how often it's been fumbled, but the game outright feels just right, just like how these games best feel. The combat and animations, enemies and visuals, are across the board top-notch. Though I regard the game as being a healthy notch more upbeat and happy than any of the Souls series, it still absolutely nails the dark fantasy atmosphere at every opportunity. It's tough, undeniably, especially in regards to a player that's new to the genre (exceptionally linear locations aren't necessarily a problem because of the fantastic checkpoint placement and enemy progression keeping things snappy and moving, but they do prevent finding alternate paths around tough spots), but the vaguely Sekiro-like prosthetic arms, and vaguely Bloodborne-like Guard and Regain system open up combo and combat depth options that are immensely exciting to try and chain together. A good machine is the form the player's arsenal takes, dashing in, cranking out a wicked attack, dashing out, gearing, winding up, grinding, ugh, it's a delight. The sounds are excellent, the music competent (would've preferred something slightly more aesthetically unique, though there are one or two absolute bangers). The voice acting... leaves a little to be desired, and the dialogue is mildly annoying (Gemini in particular I could have done without), but there's not too much talking to make it a proper nuisance. The story is simple, sweet, and enticing enough to get your P-organ pumping a little by the end, not much to say on it. I appreciate finally getting to play as a twink in a well-written game with some emotional pull to it, rare demographic it seems. To summarize, exceptional combat that surpasses some Souls titles in my opinion, fantastic visuals, very linear but well-realized locations, good story, and nothing that gets in the way of any of that otherwise. It's not doing enough on its own to be a legendary title in the way of From's best, but it'd be a crying shame to rank it anywhere else than right alongside the inspirations it cherishes so dearly. Lies of P isn't for Perfect, but it's made itself pretty damn Precious in my heart.

Okay - as much as I wanted to love this game, I really couldn't. It's Bloodborne's younger challenged brother, trying so hard to be its inspiration. When the game is not trying to be Bloodborne, it's great, but then falls flat on its face with poor and emotionless voice acting, certain poorly designed enemies that will stun you into oblivion no matter if you try to block, because another one will bend you over from behind, a combat system that wants you to block even though you might be more interested in dodging, boring NPC stories and basically no choices. The silhouettes in the windows felt more like a shoddy reference to Bloodborne than anything, with your choices ranging from 'shallow' to 'really shallow' to 'this seems deep... oh no, wait, I can't not give the Fox a gold coin fruit'. The game is filled with the most fetchiest fetch quests in the world.

Krat is alright, nothing special. The soundtrack is generic and forgettable besides a few compositions here and there. NPC voice acting besides like three of them is the worst I've heard in a long time... Their tone never changes, and their talking mouth animations are absolutely horrible. Not to mention the slightly boring character design of a few of them. Every time I was met with a new NPC or choice, I was left disappointing with the outcomes. NPC's not commenting on big things happening was just a cherry on top. Items aren't craftable and rewards just get worse and worse near end game. 

Now being in the last area, the game feels dragged out and like it should have ended 10 hours ago. I never spent more than an hour on a boss, usually getting them in the first few tries, so it's not like my hours are due to bosses. 

The theme of the game is all over the place.

Gemini is the most useless and eye-rolling companion since Paimon from Genshin Impact. It's almost like the developers didn't believe the player had half a brain cell to comprehend anything that's going on in the game. I often wished you could just throw him out or disable the voice.

If only this game didn't try to be another Fromsoft rip-off, maybe it would be worth the money. Overall, it's the most 5/10 experience in my opinion. The game is just a frustrating experience. There really are better ones out there.

A lot of non-fromsoftware games usually have the problem of:
1. Gameplay and movement feels jank or sluggish
2. Levels design is boring
3. Not enough enemy variety
4. Too short
5. Uses vague story telling to hide the fact that the story or lore of the world is not actually interesting
6. Looks ugly
Lies of P doesnt have any of these problems and I think has some improvements to the standard formula
The combat is very tight like Sekiro, but you still have the customization and build options of standard dark souls or bloodborne 
Although it takes a lot from the Souls series it still has its own vision

A pretty decent soulslike that can be best described as a mix of Dark Souls, Bloodborne and Sekiro.

However, a few of my gripes with the game:
 - Delayed attacks. 90% of the attack patterns (both from simple enemies and bosses) are insanely delayed. And not just that but also very counterintuitive and poorly telegraphed. And some attack are not only delayed but when the enemy finally swings their weapon it's just slower than what you'd expect, so you'll still block too early. And the timing behind flurry attacks makes no sense. As if the devs just chose random delays between the attacks with no real consideration. I have a really hard time believing they carefully tested each boss and concluded "yes, this is perfect". If we consider Sekiro's deflect timings the golden standard then this feels like a poor Chinese (or in this case Korean) copy. Despite all this, the game is not that difficult, it just ultimately makes most of the bosses not fun.

 - Linearity. The level design and progression is a 100% linear. Unlike in Dark Souls where you have access to several areas from the get go, here you always have one path you can progress towards. They tried to copy the shortcut system from the souls games too, but they ended up being meaningless.

- Cheap traps. This game has way many of those, and like 50% of them just don't work. Either the enemy waiting in ambush lunges out too early or too late, but in most cases they just miss. Enemies dropping from above when you walk up to a suspicious loot is also a recurring theme that consists throughout the game. And it's not like they do a plunging attack, they just drop near you and get staggered from the landing so you can easily take care of them, which makes this type of "ambush" even more pointless.

I've always loved parry mechanics in games, from Street Fighter 3 to Sekiro. I've loved the Souls series and challenging games. When Lords of the Fallen was announced I though about it but heard so many of the reviews about how that game doesn't feel much like a souls game but Lies of P does.

Originally I played this on game pass... beat it... days later I couldn't stop thinking about how much fun I'd had. When Elden Ring came out it was my GOTY. Now For 2023 Lies of P has taken that title. The game is good enough "in my opinion" to go from a game that I got on game pass to something that I felt I should support by buying the game on Steam. I'm not rich but I do understand that investors in game companies don't care about a parry mechanic, an awesome story, cool combat, branching paths, sick weapon designs, and enchanting music. They care about the money... how much did it bring in and if their investment paid off. So I did what I thought was the right move to keep GOOD companies that make GOOD games going, by supporting them. 

If you like souls games, like parries, robots, monsters and ear worm music "close your eyes" (once you play it you'll know) Then you'll love this game. I loved it so much not only did I get all the achievements but I'm writing my first review on steam. It's that good.

Great game. Feels just as good, if not better, than a game that was developed by FromSoft! Will some SoulsBorne veterans dislike the combat/game since parrying is encouraged? Probably. But one thing this game does better is it encourages utilizing BOTH parrying and dodging instead of relying solely on just one (like some FromSoft titles). Personally, I found I enjoyed Lies of P more than Elden Ring!

Some notes:
-If you're coming from Elden Ring or enjoy open world, you will find the game too linear. Whether that is a pro or con is subjective. 
-Good *general* story telling by following the general dialogues, NPC interactions and cutscenes. You get a lot more out of reading item descriptions as well
-Parrying tip: For people who've played parry heavy games like Sekiro or Thymesia, you will find the parrying in this game is NOT executed by *tapping*. You will have to press and HOLD your block key a few frames before it would connect.

The best game I've ever played. 100/100 Perfect
Plays like Sekiro, but spamming parry key is not allowed. Every attack is parryable - even huge AoE clouds and even grab attacks, but dodge is also viable (more viable than Sekiro). The weapons are fun for customization, but Two Dragons sword was like picking an entirely new class - huge variety of attacks and even parry hidden in the charged heavy. The most satisfying weapon to play in any game.
The game has unique elements from all 3 Dark Souls 1, 2, 3, but also weapon customization as in Bloodborne and Elden Ring (being able to select the stat scaling and weapon art separately; also being able to select handle size, moveset and also the speed of a particular moveset), with a parry like in Sekiro, but slightly slower and cannot be spammed, but more responsive than the one that's similar in Lords of the Fallen, and another parry option like Golden Parry Buckler in Elden Ring.
Playable with keyboard and mouse, but I also played with KBM Dark Souls, Elden Ring, Sekiro, Lords of the Fallen

Lies of P is a remarkable game that excels on multiple fronts. The storytelling is gripping, weaving a tale filled with mystery and intrigue that kept me engrossed throughout. The characters are nuanced, adding depth to an already compelling narrative.

The combat mechanics are top-notch, offering a seamless blend of strategy and action. Each battle feels dynamic and requires both skill and thoughtful decision-making, making every encounter immensely satisfying.

One of the game's strengths lies in its well-placed secrets and subtle hints. Exploring the world uncovers hidden gems, rewarding curiosity and adding an extra layer of immersion to an already richly detailed environment.

Lies of P is a standout experience, seamlessly integrating a captivating story, engaging combat, and a world teeming with secrets. It's a must-play for anyone seeking a deeply immersive and satisfying gaming adventure.

In a different timeline where George R R Martin said no to writing the story for Elden Ring and Fromsoftware instead decided to create another mainline souls game after Sekiro (and set it in a similar setting to bloodborne while integrating gameplay mechanics of Souls, Bloodborne and Sekiro) then THIS is the game they would have made.  
Calling it another soulslike is a disservice, its a mainline souls game!  

For Elden Ring only players - this is basically one big end-to-end Legacy Dungeon, but if you decide to try it you will need to learn to parry multiple attacks as only dodge rolling doesn't cut it on the bosses (also note, this is single player game with an AI spirit summon option only, no multiplayer summon options available).

Theres a demo available, however it only shows a small part of the game (chapter 2) and the setting of the game is a lot more varied than shown in the demo and keeps improving after chapter 3. 

Lastly, the game is extremely well optimised and will run well on most mid range PCs and up.

100% recommend if you're a Souls/Sekiro fan.

First let me say, this is an excellent game. It looks fantastic and runs like a peach, and most importantly there are no stability/crashing issues or bugs at all that I experienced. That being said, it's hard for me to recommend it to people for a few reasons which I'll go into below. But I'm not going to give it a negative review because it's the best game I've played this year and do really think it's a fantastic experience in its totality. Let me clarify that I'd recommend it to everyone as being a great game, I just wouldn't recommend it to people who don't know what they're getting into. Before you spend $60, I'd read about the game for sure. 

First off, it's a soulslike (more like a soulsexact, but that's a topic for another day) so the main conversation will always be surrounding difficulty. There are a few points I have here. The real trouble with the difficulty in Lies of P comes through its curve. The first half of the game is insanely easy. You could play it blindfolded. Pretty much any gamer of any skill level, if they utilize the tools the game provides, could beat the first half of P (let's say up to the Swamp Monster) no problem whatsoever. And then the rest of the game is so insanely difficult, so often gimmicky, and so annoying to traverse, that you're left cheesing bosses with throwables more often than not (exceptions being the Walker of Illusions and Laxasia, which are phenomenally designed, fair, rewarding fights). And traversal becomes less so walking through the world encountering enemies than fighting a mini boss (who has a more unpredictable moveset and does more damage per attack than the actual bosses) in nearly every room you have to walk through to get from point A to point B. The mini bosses in this game are astoundingly difficult, typically moreso than those encountered in the main quest, and are also usually not designed that well in my opinion. The door guardian is one of the worst bosses in the history of videogames; whoever came up with that idea should not be in the industry any longer. My other main complaint here is that most of the endgame enemies are reused from earlier in the campaign, albeit with different (and you guessed it, more annoying) movesets. So with some exceptions, my answer to the question of is this a difficult game is to ask a followup: which game? It's a tale of two halves, and of the 30-odd hours it took to beat the game I probably spent 8 on the first half and the rest on the second - which is arguably okay, since most people want endgames to be harder than when they start. But the rate of progression is completely unacceptable to me. You go from one hitting everyone you see to unparryable 20-part attacks and other random bullshit insanely quick. And even though I spent way more time in the second half, I actually felt more rewarded from beating most of the bosses in the first half. Beating the King of Puppets/Romeo felt like I learned something and improved each time I attempted it. Beating Simon Manus felt like I got lucky. I don't dig that, especially since endgame should be where your boss fights shine (Elden Ring also fell into this pattern, which was one of my main complaints when that game came out). There's gotta be a better way to scale souls game difficulty into the endgame than just throwing shit at the wall and seeing if it sticks. Really I just wish every boss was Laxasia.

The comparisons to From Soft are inevitable, and I'll use that as a segue. In my estimation, the combat in P is slightly better than the From Soft games I've played (all of Elden Ring and Bloodborne, a small bit of Sekiro and DS1, and a tad of DS3). The reason for that is not the weapons (I like the handle/blade assembly system here a lot but From Soft just has better weapon variety and they're generally more fun to use) but rather all the extraneous stuff the game gives you to use in combat. (Circling back briefly to my point on difficulty, you'd think this would assuage some of the late game issues but it really doesn't). But you do have a ton of options here: fable arts, throwables, elemental application to your weapon, the wishing cube, a patient gamer-core tree that grows you battle aides. And defensively you can do more than just roll. You can parry (and you have to, a lot), perfect guard, just get out of the way, run, dodge, etc. The combat feels fluid and fun and unlocking some cool advanced legion arm tricks helps there too. This is where the big missed opportunity came from in my opinion. They had a great chance to make the boss difficulty really scale with your power as a player, but it doesn't feel like you keep up with the insane hp bars (almost always two full ones, by the way). The combat is too fun to feel like it's lagging behind artificially herculean boss design. 

Where this game falls short of From Soft is definitely the vibes (although great, nothing can live up to the stunning vistas of Elden Ring or the cosmic horror in Bloodborne). I love the story of Pinocchio and they really tie in a lot of great stuff lore-wise but it's not quite there in its totality for me. World exploration also falls much flatter. It's more linear which is a good thing (no googling every 10 seconds where to go because you're lost), but there's also not that much to explore outside the main storyline which shows you exactly where to go - with a couple area exceptions that I found more annoying that complex. Oftentimes you'll go down an alley for a minute only to find a chest or a pointless drop, an enemy (maybe) and nothing else: then you have to backtrack back to the main path and feel like you wasted your time. So while not as rewarding, the world exploration and terrain reversal does feel less frustrating than From Soft. The side quests in P are also pretty stupid. I did one or two the entire game because they were short and the rewards weren't good. The only reason to do them is for the lore tidbits. 

Overall, this is the best 2023 release that I've played and I have mostly good things to say about it, even if it doesn't seem like it in this review. I'd rather provide some criticisms because I think this studio has a true masterpiece in them, and I can't wait to see what they do next (watch the end credit scene in P for sure). Props to everyone for working on the game. My one line takeaway is: tone down some of the bullshit and make the difficulty scaling more fluid, and this shit would be near flawless for me from a gameplay perspective. Aesthetically there's some room for improvement despite it being great, and I hope they work in a less drab setting next time. 

For the most part, I had an excellent time playing Lies of P and will definitely be embarking on NG+ adventures sooner than later.

TLDR : It's a great game, I definitely recommend it!

Duration (first playthrough) : 
My first playthrough was just under 30 hours and you can definitely take it slower than that and explore every nook and cranny of every level.

Overall :
The combat is fun, the art style is well defined and entertaining and the story is an interesting reimagining of Pinocchio (the writer of which is Carlo Coloddi to whom the game is dedicated to) although there is more to it as you will discover.

Soulslike :
In terms of "soulslikes" it's linear but (mostly) interconnected like dark souls 1 or 3 and the combat is much like Sekiro where the ultimate strategy is a well timed block. As you progress through a level you start unlocking shortcuts that lead back to the original "bonfire" (stargazer) making it really satisfying to unlock everything and explore around.

Weapons and upgrading :
The weapon variety is great, and the system where you can mix the handle and blade of different weapons is a great twist on the standard weapon upgrade system. The scaling of your weapon goes off of the handle and so does the moveset but the blade determines the overall damage. Both parts have their own "special move" and you can combine them as you please. The game showers you in upgrade mats late game (and they are purchasable from an NPC) so you can try multiple weapons at max rank. At the end of my playthrough I had 3 max upgraded weapons.

Bosses :
There were very few points of frustration, mostly one specific gank bossfight but ultimately the fighting is fun and doesn't feel unfair. All bosses have 2 phases so don't get too comfortable. You will need to refight the first part of the boss to get to the 2nd one over and over. It sounds worse than it is. Usually, after a few runs, you are able to defeat the first boss pretty easily and move on to the "real challenge". Learning the moveset of the first phase will help a lot for the 2nd part as well.

Performance :
The game runs very well, there are no laggy areas or anything that breaks your PC. (I have a 3080 and all my PC parts are about 1 or 2 years old at this point - your milage may vary depending on your set up, of course)

First to the positive:
Great enemy design
Very good story
Good overall atmosphere, very fittig for the game
Ok graphics - much console fit
Level design is all right - Some shortcuts make no sense while on other levels you would want to have a savepoint more.

So far looking good but now my main issue with the game: The combat system.

You basically have to parry every hit to avoid dmg.

Of course, you can just guard, but you lose a part of your health, as well as a good amount of stamina.
You can regain part of the lost health by hitting the enemy again after guarding but especially early game you quickly run out of heals and late game when a boss snaps 1/3 of you health with one hit.

When an enemy throws a long combo and you aren´t full health, yes you can die or you run out of stamina and can´t evade or continue blocking the attack.
There are also attacks, you can only block with a perfect parry making it overall frustrating.
Paired with some enemys / bosses that constantly throw fast and many attacks, it is a dissatisfactory experience.

You also find a surprisingly high amount of scripted enemys waiting behind corners for an ambush.

I can´t reccoment it for casual players, while souls like fans might have fun with it.
For me, the first playthrough was a pain, the second one was medium difficulty after figuring out how the enemys work.
Didn't think I would like it at first but it really grew on me, great game.

Lies of P is one of the best souls-likes ever made. While it borrows nearly every system it has from one FROM soft title or another, it executes them to excellency - gameplay systems, artistic design, technical state. My complaints are minor: the English translation is sloppy and confusing sometimes, the level design sometimes have useless shortcuts, and the bosses are serviceable but not great.

The combat is tight and feels weighty, precise and responsive as any good souls-like should, I particularly like the blade-handle system, one of the game's few original ideas, as it solves one of souls-like's age old problems, that being the average player will ignore 80% of all weapons they find because they could only afford to upgrade a handful of them. 

The graphics is great both technically and artistically. The city of Krat is both beautiful and horrible. And the game runs wonderfully - 60-90 FPS on highest setting with DLSS (quality mode) on my RTX3070ti laptop, with no stuttering or bugs whatsoever.

I've never really been that into Soulslike games, to be quite honest. So, when I first saw this game being announced, and then later when I first saw the gameplay... I was surprisingly, really interested. 
Loved the demo when it came out, and promised myself I'd eventually get around to buying it and playing through it.
I am very, very glad I did. This game is just AMAZING. The storytelling and lore of Krat is so interesting that I just wanted to learn more and more, the gameplay is tight and polished, if hard to get used to at first, but when you do it's like a whole new world is opened up and you can just explode into it. Even the soundtrack is spectacular.
I think this game is more than worth the price. Play it. It will challenge you, and reward you, and make you feel.

Lies of P is a really exceptional souls-like that capitalizes on its macabre setting and loose connections to Pinocchio. Challenging, but not overly difficult. I think I played it after some patches were made earlier this year to adjust the difficulty.

Really good gameplay (it better be, considering they took Sekiro, Bloodborne, and Elden Ring and mashed them into one). Boss fights that range in quality from pretty good to incredible. Solid level design, reasonable difficulty, enjoyable world/lore/characters. Surprisingly enjoyable story (you also don't have to watch a Vaati video to understand it). Soundtrack is good as well. I'd say the game is highly replayable, but mileage may vary. Everything "new" this game does it does well (that being said, it doesn't innovate too much). The game is linear, and a lot of enemies have really nasty delay attacks, so if you hate either of those things you probably won't like this game. It also has slight variations in damage when you attack (you can roll -10% - +10%) for God only knows what reason. It's not really noticeable except for when a trash mob sometimes takes one more hit. The voice acting is also questionable at times (never down-right awful, but it's definitely noticeable). I also don't care about voice acting in games, but it is worth mentioning (only played in English). There are also a few instances in both text and voice-acting where I'm not really sure if things were translated to English as well as they could have been. The final area of the game could also be cut in half and it'd probably be more enjoyable. It's clear actual effort and possibly love went into this game, and it's not just some slop trying to cash-in on the recent "soulslike" trend.

Despite some drawbacks in the battle system, it's undeniable that NEOWIZ has delivered an amazing soul story and fantastic music.

You might not immediately notice, but the narrative subtly unfolds a story of generational, or more precisely, regime change. 

As a puppet protagonist, you are presented with a pivotal choice: to preserve the traditional methods of dominating the world or to lead it towards an entirely new direction.

If you are the fans of the story like in Dark Souls 3 and Elden Ring, PLAY IT and you will not regret it!
Seriously challenging, seriously good, seriously frickin' amazeballs!!    Why so serious?

This has been the best game I have played in a LONG time, and I've played some really amazing games this year! I even enjoyed it more than BG3! This has been such an experience for me for a lot of reasons. The largest of which being this is my first true souls-like experience and this game has actually opened me up to playing Fromsoftware games like Elden Ring and Bloodborne and I've been loving those as well (though not as much as this one to be fair). Everything from the aesthetics to the leveling system and combat have all been really enjoyable for me and it has been a top-quality gaming experience.
There are only a couple things I'd list as a con such as some attacks from enemies have massively long wind ups and hit boxes that feel needlessly generous. I do also HATE that your heals can just be canceled from being hit by ANYTHING (made me very angry more than once). Otherwise this game feels extremely challenging but also balanced and fair. I'd highly recommend this for people who want to try out a new souls-like experience! I can't promise people who are new to the genre (or are as unskilled with gaming as I am) will love it as much as I did but if you're down for a challenge this is a great game to pick up!
hard? yes. fun? yes.

first off this game is really really good and enjoyed almost everything from the bosses to the atmosphere to the story but it does have a few issues that while could be frustrating never stopped me from playing.

pros: good weapon selection and with the ability to mix blades and handles for standard stuff made for an interesting way to create a weapon both suited for you or a particular boss.

the bosses themselves were mostly all really cool and interesting and while many have a faze 2 i do not believe this is a bad thing like others do, and while the stalker fights can be easy they do tend to add to the story based on who they are.

the combat is really fun feeling like a mix of sekiro and other dark souls/souls like games and while the parry timing could be a bit funny at times they have definitely fixed it since launch and even when bosses were particularly hard (i am not a souls vet only play 1 sekiro and elden ring) they never felt impossible and while some people complain they are too easy i think the vast majority will find them to be a good challenge at first.

the story is actually very interesting and piecing it all together as you go along isn't as bad as some other games ive played its a really interesting take on the story on pinocchio story especially with the 3 endings and lying system.

cons: like and souls/souls-like game this isnt for everyone so if your not into that style avoid.

there isnt as much need to make certain builds like in darksouls/elden ring except for a few situations with bosses but even then if your looking for something that makes you think about what armor and weapons you want to use this isn't that kind of game.

unfortunately they haven't completely fixed the parry system and sometimes its not as smooth as it could be and definitely not sekiro levels like i would have liked but its still not terrible hopefully they fix it.

Final thoughts: i love this game despite its flaws small and big it truly did something worth looking at for a souls like game unlike some other souls like games ive seen and while not everything game play wise can be considered original it doesn't take away from the fact they did it really well and it was incredibly fun to play through and i will be doing more runs to 100% it and for whenever i wan't
(too those who complain its a copy of bloodborne all i have to say is good i never got to play that because im not buying a ps4 for one game and its not on pc and most likely wont ever come to it unless sony decides to be nice with the remaster)

When I say that Lies of P is one of my top five games of the year, I don't just mean 'Games that released this year.' I mean games I've played this year. And I've played some absolute banger games this year. Mario Kart, Ratchet and Clank, and plenty other games that are all Masterpieces in their own right. 

Lies of P stands up there. More than any other game this year, it sucked me into its world, its music, its culture, and I wept at one point, and I weep now remembering how it made me feel as I write this. 

The goal of a game is to create a world that didn't exist. To connect to something that isn't real and feel it as if it's something you've personally lived. And Lies of P is one of the most expertly world-built games of all time, and just existing in it gives you a feeling of what life must have been. 

And that's just the story and set dressing. 

The gameplay is peak. Challenging in all the ways it should be. It is absolutely one of those games where you spend an hour losing to a boss, putting the game down, go to sleep, and get back up and then it clicks next match. That's the kind of game Lies of P is. It's a perfect follow through of intent, challenge, and pacing.

Some of those boss fights stick out in my mind as the greatest of all time. Some of them even standing next to the Masterpieces of Dark Souls Artorias of the Abyss fight or even Orenstein and Smough. Heck, even the Soul of Cinder from Dark Souls 3. 

If you aren't convinced, play the Demo. It's hard. It's absolutely got those "Hurdle" moments that just test you. But when you put the game aside, and return the next day... It's something special. 

Lies of P isn't just a good game, it's worthy of your time and attention. And if the overwhelmingly positive score hasn't told you how much it means for so many people, I don't know what I can say here that can get you to follow through.
As much as I played any of the Soulsbornekiro games, Lies of P is the best souls-LIKE game that I played so far. It will definitely scratch that itch.

A fantastic action RPG that combines elements of Dark Souls, Bloodborne, and Sekiro into a great homage to FROMSOFTWARE's modern game collection. The story, while not exactly a masterpiece, is a fun take on the story of Pinocchio and managed to be good enough to keep me invested. The game also has great art style and presentation. A focus on blocking and parrying with enemy animations that can be hard to read can make the otherwise great feeling combat somewhat frustrating.

Poorly designed and unoriginal. Systems on top of systems that add nothing, an uninspired Bloodborne-esque setting that is entirely superfluous, and horrendous game design. It juggles dodging, blocking, and parrying but the system at play doesn't reward it because you have to eat each enemy's individual attack style once to get the timings for each. There are attempts to address these decisions, which I have to give Neowiz credit for, such as the Regain system, but there is too much wrong to even be positive about that. It takes a bunch of ideas from things the developers clearly like, the Pinocchio story and FROMSOFT games obviously, and crams them together in a poor imitation of each. Presumably, if you are skilled at the game there's a lot to enjoy, so if you fancy yourself someone that leans to playing games with high technical skill, it may be a rewarding experience. I didn't run into much difficulty but that was solely because I found a high damage output build that didn't make me engage with the systems. The systems are so hobbled though that I found no genuine want or need to engage with them, and that is a damning realization for a game with so many. The game copies what FROM does without ever reaching the highs but has all the lows. I beat it once and then promptly had Valve remove it from my account.

I'm honestly enjoying this game so much. The combat and systems are deep but approachable. The original story is captivating. And the music is super good. I've heard rumblings that this game is too difficult even if you are coming from similar Fromsoft games, and I just want to say, have some patience and lock in with it. It's very much it's own game and benefits from being played that way. Definitely recommend.

Completely surpassed my expectations. I was slow to take to it at first, but eventually it clicked. Now it is up there with my favorite souls-like games. Some of these issues are on the developer. The translation is messy on occasion and does a poor job explaining certain mechanics unique to the game. Plus, the naming conventions and dialogue is bewildering at times. "Strength is motivity?" "Why is Gemini like this???" "P Organ??????????"

Once you do get used to how everything works and adjust to some bad dialogue lines, it combines to be one of the most satisfying playthroughs I've had in this genre. I am still on a high from just how fun the combat and bosses are. The more direct storytelling and quests were a refreshing change of pace from Fromsoft's games. Honestly, the story ended up landing for me. Even if the writer for Gemini can't jump, lest they fly off into outer space. I can't wait to see what comes next.

Also, sick Pluto reference.

Disclaimer: I'm only about halfway through my play-through, but I wanted to give massive kudos to the dev team who created this awesome game.

I knew this was a "souls-like" game, but never imagined that a team that wasn't Fromsoft could create something this amazing within the genre. The atmosphere/setting, story, exploration, and side quests are top shelf! Never a dull moment within this world, and the constant feeling of progression drives everything forward in a way that never seems rushed or forced. 

The combat is super fluid, and there are no shortage of weapons or builds to expand upon. I very much enjoy the way that the weapon system works in this game. Mixing and experimenting with different weapon builds is something that continues to be so much fun, and allows a lot of room for player expression.  The boss battles are intense without ever feeling cheap or unfair, and the enemy variety continues to surprise me. I would recommend this game to anyone at full price. I'll be sad when my first play-through is over.

Also....do yourself a favor and listen to "Feel" from this soundtrack. I haven't felt this connected to a video game OST since Persona 5.

Initially I thought some of the game was over tuned and while I do still view the last couple of areas being a massive pain and very much needing re-balancing I realized something in the way the game was balanced.

It's tough. It's aggravating. It's borderline unfair at points.

BUT.

I realized they WANT you to break this game. They WANT you to find your playstyle and use it to max efficiency.
They WANT you to use it so efficiently that its outright OP. Whether it be quick and nimble, a heavy and unbreakable wall, someone who uses weaknesses to their advantage, a mixture of what you see is the best for the job at hand, etc.

There is a build that if you find out how to use it right you can easily break this game. Focus on your build and minimize it's weaknesses while maximizing it's strengths. And don't be afraid to mix it up. Anything can be used how you want due to the weapon system and the skill tree gives you boosts to any playstyle you settle on.

I understand the comparisons to Bloodborne are numerous but that's how this game plays at it's core.
Be aggressive and cautious and you can break this game.

Where other souls like games fall short in 2023, Lies of P excels in what it does best. The presentation, music, game play, and story are all tight with quality. A lot of thought and care was put into the overall package. 

It's not perfect. There are a few bosses which could have been done a lot better (thankfully it's only two mandatory bosses and the world stalker bosses). The normal weapons are dwarfed by a few boss weapons. There are some achievements that are easily missed without a guide which could take up unnecessary time. 

However, if you're willing to put in the time and effort, there's so much substance to the core game play and build crafting that no run feels stale. Overall a good time. I can't wait for the DLC and sequel to this masterpiece. NEOWIZ/ROUND 8's first entry in the souls like genre absolutely knocks it out of the park.

I refunded lords of the fallen to try this game and wow. 

The graphics are quite stunning for a souls like the art direction and gothic nature is very much like bloodborne which may be a positive or downside depending on how you like games atmosphere to be but i think it is very fitting and works well with the narrative.  

The story in this game is told quite well even though I am not far in i can tell what is going on without having to watch lore videos such as dark souls or elden ring for example. ( vaati is the GOAT) 

Now the combat and the combat at first was quite hard to grasp for dark souls veteran as you cant really dodge to win here you have to parry and break posture in order to get a  stun attack a visceral if you've played bloodborne before adding an interesting but really challenging combat loop. 

The systems within the game are qutie good for player expression with the weapons being able to be dismantled into new ones that you can make which ive never thought of before and it is just great. It works really well with the legion arm system in which you have a robot arm that can be changed to give you new abilities like a hook or a shock attack.

Bosses are quite challenging and fun and the OST in this game is really really good.

TLDR : good challenging souls like that is very unique with great systems 9/10

Unfortunately I can't recommend this game. The problem is not the difficulty but a rather boring gameplay design that relies way to much on one mechanic with extremely small margin for error.

The story of Lies of P is somewhat intriguing as it loosely uses the classical tale of Pinocchio as its premise but twists it around in various ways. If you know the children's story then you can recognize the various characters from it that you're encountering and just like in Pinocchio itself lies play an important part in the early parts of the story.

Visually the game is serviceable. It's not exactly impressive by current standards but also not ugly.

In terms of gameplay it borrows heavily from Dark Souls in the principles but also makes a lot of the same mistakes with inventory management for example which is just as much of a pain here as it is in games like Dark Souls and Elden Ring. Everything must be prepared before a fight because you can't just pause the game and change something. Everything must be done live during the fight which always carries a lot of potential for frustration.

The thing that actually breaks the game for me though is the gameplay during combat itself as it is centered entirely around blocking (or rather parrying as you're doing the blocking with a weapon and not with a shield). When you "block" and attack your character takes reduced damage and you can recover the lost health at least partially by attacking the enemy. In addition you can do perfect blocks by timing the blocking perfectly to damage or destroy an enemies weapon and/or stagger them more quickly for a heavy damage attack. Dodging is possible but severely limited in effectiveness. So if you cannot block attacks perfectly in terms of timing then you have to rely on static blocking and slow movement with occasional dodges to then deal out heavy attacks in the small time frames you have available. In addition without perfect blocks you cannot damage or destroy an enemy weapon from what I've see so far.

The gameplay therefore (when you cannot block perfectly) comes down to:
1. Walk to an enemy
2. Hold block until weapon combo is done
3. Strike enemy 1-3 times
4. Hold block until enemy combo is done
5. Strike enemy

Rinse and repeat. 

There is a secondary weapon in the left arm of the character but outside of the grappler and flamethrower type weapon arms which can be used to affect enemies at a range (pull them in or put them on fire) I haven't seen any use for the off-hand. I have tried that once or twice but the energy management is annoying and the usability is limited. 

In any way if you have good timing with the blocking ability you could get fun out of this game. If however you are like me failing 9 out of 10 times when you try to do a perfect block and have to stick to more basic strategies this game may become very tedious, frustrating and boring.

It's unfortunate as with more options in making blocking and the perfect blocks more easily usable and dodging a more viable alternative the game could be more fun even if the enemies and bosses were overall tought to defeat.

[h3] Lies of P is a masterpiece [/h3]

I finished my first playthrough after roughly 23 hours. This included collecting most of the loot, secret items, and some NPC questlines that the game has to offer. 

What makes this game really hit home is it's beautifully crafted story and the immediate familiarity one gets when it comes to mechanics, level design, and overall gameplay of the souls series. For context I've played all of the From Software games except for Dark Souls 2 and lies of p is way up there as one of my faves. 

[h3] STORY [/h3]
The narrative is simple and straightforward but the world building and environments you explore really do a good job at setting the tone for the whole game. NPCs add a bit of complexity with the various interactions you have with them. The game does a good job at connecting their storylines and giving you a few options as to how you would want to respond to a conversation. The whole puppet and human thing.

[h3] ENEMY VARIETY [/h3]
I've had no issue with enemy variety. In fact, I found it very interesting every time I would encounter a new foe in a new area and that it would completely make sense as to why these enemies look and act a certain way. It doesn't feel generic and every single area has something to keep you on your toes

[h3] COMBAT [/h3]
Combat is challenging and satisfying. The dodging, parrying, and stagger system feel just right. Everytime I die, I understood why and didn't completely feel like random BS (Except for one boss). Also, I don't know who thought of the whole separate blades and handles system but it is genius. I would find myself spending a lot of time experimenting with builds just to see how a specific weapon handle would work with a new blade I found.

[b] This game was a good experience, definitely a must buy for fans and first timers to the genre 
P.S. The soundtracks and music in this game are phenomenal. [/b]

I was never into the souls-like and never really liked it at all, until I started playing "Lies of P" that changed my perspective on the genre overall.

Originally based off of "The Adventures of Pinocchio" by Carlo Collodi, the game takes the fairy tale into a dark and twisted turn with a souls-like theme. You play as Geppetto's puppet, also known as "Pinocchio" or "P," and you're job is to go around Krat to kill off enemies and discover what's really going on in the city. Throughout the game, your choices affect the characters around you and the protagonist himself. Will you dare to lie your way through, or tell the truth?

The plot in the game is linear, but topped with clues and hints for the players to have an idea what really happened before the fall of Krat. When you do your first run, you wouldn't know much while you follow the story in a straight line until your 2nd run. The 2nd run is when things get really, really spicy. It gave "Nier" and "Drakengard" vibes, which quickly grabbed my attention right off the bat as I'm a sucker for Yoko Taro's work, different scenes/dialogues, and choices leading to multiple endings. 

The art direction is phenomenal, and is the main reason why I stayed. As an artist, I incredibly admire the world building in the studio's own way even though it's based off of a fairy tale. This includes architecture design, culture, characters, and graphics. Especially the legion arms, outfits, and the protagonist. I love the grim tale series, and "Lies of P" perfectly fits in that category! If the devs do decide to continue on re-creating fairy tales into a dark souls-like game like "Lies of P," then I would love love LOVE to play them all.

The key in the game is timing and parrying, and planning ahead. I came into the game after they adjusted the difficulty, but as a newbie to the genre I still had a hard time in my first run, until the next run later. Memorizing small enemies/boss attack patterns help and aren't too complicated to master (sometime). You can build whatever you want Pinocchio to be, either  mainly strength, dexterity, magic, or in this case: Motivity, Technique, and Advance. You choose how comfortable you want to fight, but parrying and timing is incredibly important.

The challenge and the thrill of killing a difficult boss after dying so many times brings a wave of satisfaction. It is your typical RPG with a sprinkle of pain, trial and error. While playing the game the first time, I was overwhelmed by enemies along the way, not knowing how to level up and properly upgrade weapons until a friend guided me through. Eventually, I managed to finish my first run on my own. Now, I'm on my third run, and eventually will be doing my 4th run. I came into the game with high expectation, and instant dislike right off the bat. But, "Lies of P" helped me cope through a tough time with personal struggles, and now it has a special place in my heart. The game opened my eyes to the souls-like genre, and I decided to give it chance. I would love to go back and play Bloodborne, and maybe Seikro, now that I have a better perspective in the genre.

If newcomers are coming in to try, I highly suggest this game first. Surprisingly, the game is short once you've mastered the mechanics, but the game is always incredibly fun in multiple runs.

- However Lies Of P is made to be parried

- It has predictable LENGTH from one bonefire to another and has rhytm which helps you to predict what's next

Overall - yeah I recommend it. It has plenty of issues though...
It's no "Bloodborn on PC", not even close, but it's a good game on itself.
the design, the artstyle, the world and the mechanics are all mesh together beautifully.
BUT THERE'S A BIG BUT, the game sill has its issues (as of my playthrough of version 1.4)
sometimes weapons attack and legion weapons straight up didn't respond, I found myself plenty of times tapping the buttons just to be sure they'll get the attack.
Same goes for dodging and parrying - and that's a HUGE issue I had with the game, the game expect you to have pinpoint accuracy at some cases but it seems that the game just can't handle so many actions at once or the response time just can't handle the players response time, that was a huge turnoff for me..
and there was a certain boss that her attack launches you in the air, but for some reason I stayed up in the air instead of landing, the game response by killing me - happened twice and I got lucky that I just didn't let her do that attack on me the third time
->>>A game that requires full precision from its player and is itself with unpolished mechanics, and reaction times that do not match the player's reaction speed and the challenges it poses to the player is a game that must undergo further polishing before it goes to market.
Also I'm not a huge fan of locking the best weapons for the near end of the game or even worse for the NG+ run.
Other than that,
some of the late level designs were just tedious and felt like they were built just to add padding, lots of cheap cliffs to die, lots of ladders and elevators do make a shortcuts instead of giving the player a checkpoints, BAD BAD BAD platform sections, and enemies that can jump and smack you even if you were a mile away from them

-> yeah it's a good game, but it needs more polish before it can be a really great game
-> I do truly hope to see the studio improve of it's work and looking forward to their next project.

Lies of P is not only the surprise hit of 2023 but it also exists on a level few games have reached which is to elevate the experience from just a game to a work of art. Anyone who has avoided this because they don't like souls games should be aware that they're missing out on a crucial piece of our modern zeitgeist. 

I think that this game will eventually find its way alongside games like Bioshock because little moments just kind of stick with you and it has mechanics which improve the gameplay so much that it's hard to go back to the way things were. I recently played through DS1 remastered again and definitely wished a few times that I had a weapon repair tool on my arm with infinite charges.

Without being long winded, the last thing I want to call out about Lies of P is its music. The soundtrack in and of itself is something of a marvel. They're bringing back jazz pop songs from the 20s and 30s but with modern feels and instrumentation. I don't want to spoil it but it cannot be overstated just how great the music is and its done in such a way that everyone who experiences this music is taking it all in without distraction. I was genuinely shocked when I first heard these tunes and this is the first game I've ever played where I was actually tempted to buy the soundtrack. As a fan of jazz I'm thrilled that this game has introduced this music to a new generation.
This game has the fluidity and polish that you would expect from a From Software game. Very well executed, and the closest thing to Soulsbourne you are going to get from another developer.

It's got The Sauce while putting its own spins on the formula of the games it's compared to and inspired by. There's a lot of battle mechanics which are still a little overwhelming to me but leads to a high skill ceiling, and once you figure out how to juggle them in a fight you feel the intuitiveness and fluidity of combat as it becomes natural to you. The premise of Pinocchio in a Bioshock-esque futuristic steampunk world leads to both really funny bits of tying the sci-fi horror to the material it's referencing and also genuinely laudable worldbuilding and character moments. If you like the Fromsoft soulslike games, it pulls a lot of great things from all of them without just blindly copy-pasting them but rather understands the role of every aspect which makes them such unique experiences. Also, if you're engaging in the Sisyphean task of patiently waiting for that one game--you know the one--to come to any modern platform, I would recommend this one without hesitation.

As an amateur player of Souls-like games, I find "Lies of P" to be a story-rich and authentic game, definitely catchy with a combat system forgiving for beginners. Those who rush through Sekiro like the wind and enjoy perfecting parries against enemy attacks will find themselves quite comfortable in this game. Same for those who prefer dodging or attacking from a distance with a big sword - you folks can too defeat bosses and progress through the storyline. My point is that this game is a good fit for both types of players and is highly recommended for those who enjoy interesting story plots.

"Lies of P" is among the top three best games of my 2023, and trust me, it will be a valuable addition to your Steam library.
