So I just finished Lies of P... Actually a good game, bosses are tough but NGL a little unimaginative (with 2 or three exceptions). But gameplay itself is VERY solid and responsive once you get into the swing of it. Story and world building are good, less esoteric than dark souls and elden ring but I appreciated that personally. It has true RPG choices. I think it's the closest thing we will be getting to bloodborne on PC. If you can run it, and have the money definitely worth your time.

I say closest thing to bloodborne but it does stand on its own two legs too. Has a bunch of unique and innovative mechanics that I hope to see elsewhere, namely making your own weapons. You can take the blade of a strength weapon chuck it on the hilt of a dex weapon and tune both to scale with your stats. Don't think I used legendary weapons once because my custom built weapons were so personalized and powerful, which does have its drawbacks because i'm sure those legendary weapons had some sweet move sets.

I don't know how Round8 did it on their first try but I think they've knocked it out of the park and created something I'd say is on par with FromSoftware's titles. 

Difficult but satisfying combat that rewards mastery, insane boss fights (seriously Laxasia almost made me cry), a good amount of build customisation provided in the various systems and a unique weapon system that can be mixed and matched. All of this is tied together in the brilliant re-imagining of a classic story in a beautiful setting with great music.

Only thing I can dock points for is enemy variety could be expanded a bit more and some weapons are so bad and have no upsides unless you are purposefully trying to make the game harder while others are just giga broken. It would be nice if everything was at least viable as a baseline.

That said, my complaints did not affect my enjoyment of the game in a major way so well done to the team. I'm looking forward to seeing how Round8 builds on this. I feel like it can only get better (hopefully).

The mini bosses were harder than the bosses. Kind of a spoiler (not really) Weasel and circus puppet bosses need to be fixed, tracking is terrible and gives VERY little room for dodging. Other than that 70$ well worth spent!

I've seen some criticism of enemy hp regain that i feel like i have to counter. Here is a specific example - 
"I don't care that I can remove this with the P-organ mods, this shouldn't have been in the game. This game doesn't encourage aggressive play and this mechanic showcases this problem."

This is just factually wrong. This mechanic exists to prevent getting a hit and two in every once in a while and playing it very safe. But this mechanic just existing shows that they do want you to play aggressively and encourage it. Saying it discourages it is like saying that a time limit means they dont encourage fast play. Its nonsensical when its inherent to the gameplay

This game is very poorly optimized and doesn't live up to the hype it is getting. Compared to some other Souls-likes, it is quite good, but that is quite a low bar. It also shares many of the same issues these games have, such as Poor telegraphs on attacks, clunky animations, unclear mechanics and at times questionable enemy design. I would normally tolerate this, and the overall game is a satisfactory experience (5/10?), but the performance is not.

Freezing and Frame drops is extremely common. Even running the cutscenes has significant frame drops. Any time the game loads in a new asset? Frame drops. Talk to an NPC? Frame drops. There is no chance in hell that an i9 / RTX 3090 / 32 GB Ram PC is not powerful enough to run this game on default settings. The environments are linear and small, the graphics are adequate but really not beyond anything released in the last 10 years. Performance should not be suffering on this game when more taxing games run without issue on this PC.

This game has been out for some time now, a game should not be released in this condition as it is, but by now it most certainly should be patched. Even on sale, I cannot recommend this game.

This game is damn good. The developers honestly had no reason to go so hard, but they did. They really did. Lies of P is by far the best souls-like that has ever been made, and it's on the same level of From Soft's work. The weapons in this game absolutely slap. Every time I got a new weapon, I wanted to swap over and use that instead. Not to mention this game has one of the coolest weapon mechanics I've seen. You can mix and match weapon blades and weapon handles. The handles change the moveset of the weapon, and the stat it scales with. Meaning if a big strength weapon is too slow, you can combine it was a faster weapon handle while retaining all the upgrades you've applied to the blade. It's dope as hell. Parrying makes you feel like an absolute god in combat. Plus the story is actually good, I can understand it in one playthrough, and I actually care about the characters. Not all of that can even be said about From Soft's games. Really the only thing I don't like about this game is the lack of poise, but it's something you get used to. If you're a souls fan, this is an absolute must play.

I am not huge into Souls like games, sure I own Dark Souls 1-3 and Bloodborne but the Souls games are mainly due to sales and Bloodborne I liked a fair bit though I am not sure I got past the 4th boss, but Lies of P feels great to play because of how the weapon system is where you can make a weapon fit your play style as a pose to having to make your play style fit the weapon.

For example my two weapons blades I didn't like the attack style but liked the blades where a electric weapon you get fairly early and a great sword, two of the hilts I likes where a swords one and a saber one, do I took apart all 4 weapons and I put the two hilts onto the two blades. So now instead of having two weapons with a swing I don't like now I have an electric weapon that has a tight enough swing that I can block easier and since I am using it to just apply a status effect I am ok with it doing a bit less damage than on a hilt that fits it's style more, and I have a nice long blade that is still snappy when it comes to getting to where I can dodge sooner which in turn allows me to play the way I want to play while still keeping that same type of challenge where you have to learn how enemies attack to be able to properly respond to their tells.

And the nice thing is, it doesn't take any resources to break apart or glue together the weapon parts so you can test all the combos until you find one you like. Enemy design is good, level design is good, enemy placement in the level is good, it feels like a Souls game just without the controls feeling intentionally jank.

I just want to give some appreciation to some of the subtler aspects of the game design. Everyone's saying they know exactly what makes a soulslike good, but what does that actually [i]mean?[/i]

For starters, the performance is smooth. I've experienced no stutters or framerate issues, something that can easily make a soulslike feel horrendous to play. Animations feel fluid, and telegraph attacks well while still demanding a level of memorization, and the hitboxes feel accurate and representative of the attacks they're attached to. The fundamentals are 100% there.

Lies of P takes a really creative approach in addressing many of the criticisms people have had with the various fromsoft titles, adapting them instead of simply removing them. Case in point, the poison swamp. A classic in the souslike, something we've all gotten used to but hate nonetheless. Lies of P addresses this by never outright forcing you to get poisoned. This is achieved by ensuring there is always an island or river embankment within the player's reach, forcing them to approach the situation swiftly but cautiously, ensuring no enemies are in the way. It rewards both patience and aggression when the times are right, something you'll come to find is a recurring theme. In addition, a decent portion of the poison areas are actually just simply drained at the end of the level by dropping a giant torch on them, burning all the poison away. It's an incredibly satisfying reward for reaching the end that allows you to reapproach the area with more free exploration, with things often hidden beneath the poison.

In a less-subtle tweak, we have the weapon system. In Lies, weapons come in two pieces, the blade and handle. The handle determines the scaling and basic moveset of the weapon, with the blade determining damage output, damage type, and the weight class of the weapon. You can put a greatsword blade on a curved sword handle to make a heavy curved sword. You can put that same greatsword blade on a spear handle to make an incredibly long-ranged greatspear. You can put an elemental blade on a dex-scaling handle, simply bypassing the special stat requirement you often see. In addition, both pieces contribute their own special move, one that expends a special bar seen beneath your stamina, known at fable. The blade is often a strong attack or buff, with the handle often contributing a defense buff or special parry. The system doesn't just encourage experimentation, it facilitates it. If you want to try a new blade, just put it on your handle. If you want to try a handle with different scaling, there's a training area in the game's hub area that'll let you test its moveset and decide on a respec. It's so much fun, there's no other way to put it. You're no longer just building for a single weapon or loadout, you're building for a playstyle.

I feel like i could go on and on about stuff like this, but at that point I'd just be explaining the whole game and not much more. I didn't even touch on boss design since I feel like they're all great and need to just be experienced. The positives of this game are self-explanatory and evident from the start, and that's the best part of it all. All in all, while I don't feel like Lies manages to hit some of the explosive highs of the fromsoft games, never once did I ever feel like something in the game was mediocre or bad. There is no Bed of Chaos or Capra Demon, no Curse-Rotted Greatwood or Farron Keep-type area. Everything this game has to offer is at least good, and that's an incredible achievement.

Possibly the closest you can get to From Software level quality in the soulslike genre. 

Fantastic enemy variety, good (if not a bit linear) level design, and a number of bosses that rival even the greats like Lady Maria of the Astral Clocktower. Absolutely no jank to be seen either, something that tends to be a plague with games of this type.

Aside from a fairly low distance dodge and a possibly below average swing speed for certain weapons there really are no good reasons not to fall in love with Lies of P. 

Its hard, its polished, and it innovates in ways I hope the rest of the genre take note of.

It's very, very good.

Lies of P is such a genuine surprise. The mature take on the Pinocchio fairy tale is very refreshing and the world/lore is very well crafted. I’ve played all the dark souls games, including Elden ring and bloodbourne. From soft could take some notes on what the developers have implemented here, especially narrative wise.

My only very minor dislike would be the linearity of the gameplay and level design. Don’t expect dark souls 1 connected world levels. Having said that, the linear design is a great match for how the story progresses and I had to make myself stop playing the game.

Also loved not having to rush to bosses as they put stargazers (bonfires) very close.

Highly recommend for fans of the genre!
Fantastic soulslike. I haven't felt this good since my first playthrough of Bloodborne years ago. Fantastic.

One of the greatest and most consistent video games ever made. The weapon-handle system is one of the most creative, and fun combat mechanics in a "souls-like" ever made, allowing you to use blades and such, without sacrificing damage because of your chosen playstyles, allowing players running a Technique (Dexterity) build, to use weapons of Motivity (Strength) as an example. Not only that, but swapping handles also changes the weapons' moveset, to that of the handle. Although this can nerf weapons that deal a certain physical damage, if the moveset doesn't contain gestures of attack, such as Slashing. 

The Story is also pretty tight knit and well done, it may be predictable to an extent, but the way it is told is just so much fun to experience. The bosses all have their own unique challenges, movesets and designs, as expected, but the care put into their animations is truly unlike anything I have seen in any action rpg in a while. I don't hear too many people praising the visuals as much, and also the score, which are both so beautiful. "Feel" is definitely one of the best songs in the game, and one I've been listening to outside the game itself. 

I was also able to run this game at a mostly consistent framerate with my mid range PC, which is genuinely a surprise, as most games passed 2020 have ran like crap for me. So seriously, the optimisation is fantastic. Overall this is a great, tight knit package, and definitely worth the full price. I hope more and more people play this game, and understand how amazing of an accomplishment this game is, adding on to the fact that this is the first ever game from this developer. Bravo Devs, thank you for such a joyous experience. I'll continue to replay this game for years to come. I'm excited to see what's next from you all

I think this is an extremely mid game.  If you compare it to literally anything but a Souls game, it's serviceable... okay, make sure that's a narrow range of games.  Like, compare it to something bad.  There are things that will just fall apart about it having "cracked the formula", which frankly I don't want to get into.  As for why that is, while I think for a first effort, even Demon's Souls obliterates this game in terms of things like map design or, just overall, general themes... these are things I don't think most people actually care about because they don't know why they're making this comparison in the first place, let alone whether this comparison is actually true.  And it's the part where you know they don't actually know or care where I'm not going to waste my time.  

I'm going to go in an admittedly backhanded direction just so say, instead of saying why I think this game wasn't that good to me alone, I'm going to instead list why you might want to get this game:

IF you happen to dislike Souls games, but you want something extremely watered down and simplified but in a way that is in no way going to be apparent to a low attention span or investment, absolutely get Lies of P.  If you love playing dodge/take turn with things in a way that feels like what an awful single player version of Tekken would be where you can't just punch someone out of an unblockable/hard to block able, absolutely play this game.  If navigating maps with actual substance to their being interconnected is difficult to perceive, often not being interesting at all even on this game's own merits, definitely play Lies of P.  And if you want to just experience having stuff in a game whether the designer understood why it was interesting or tolerable in the first place, DEFINITELY get Lies of P.

There are clearly people, who are defensive of the game, who really feel like this is "their game."  You may be one of those weirdos!  In action games, just being good at something can be its own reward, so much that you have to realize you're likely talking to someone high off their own shit.  I beat the game, I did a lot of stuff, I felt like my time was mostly wasted because there was never a moment where I was ever impressed.  A lot of it just comes down to what you want to hear and if you happen to like struggle games where the struggle feels extremely arbitrary and is focalized through a void that is apparent in someone's soul, where nothing can mean anything or is actually ever significant, this crappy game is for you!  

Just expect a lot of odd moments where suddenly the game really requires you to fight poorly designed fights with overtuned things, cause it thinks that's what you have to do.  And mainly the point of contention there is moreso the combat system and the difficulty, which if you're a weirdo you're gonna have an amazing time.  Get the game if you check that block, couldn't be me.  Beat it, did the block real good with the timing, experienced it for the sake of it, I actually think the DLC hook could be interesting, but I don't recommend this for someone who actually wants to play a game that Lies of P so desperately is trying to imitate but does mostly in superficial ways that don't merit much credit. A very competent "souls-like" with great setting, art direction and graphics, recommended for fans of the genre. The PC port runs well (play with a controller though). Audio is great. Combat is fluent and difficult, which is one of the most important ingredients of a souls like. Voice acting goes from great (most of the main characters) to poor (a few side characters). First couple of levels are fairly linear, but many of the later ones are labyrinthine ones where paths fold upon themselves. A few things are improved upon the Souls formula, like xp dropping outside of boss arenas on death, new NPC dialogue available being shown for areas, etc.

Looking forward to future titles from this studio. Hopefully they dare to deviate more from FromSoftwares formula in the future and find their own voice. A few things goes from "Souls like" to feeling derivative "Souls clone" i.e the stats system, some animations, the chaste/demure coded lady NPC at the central hub who allows you to level up... Some writing could be improved too, like a villain that actually goes "Yees, my secret plan is coming together - muahahaha!" in a cut scene. Minor complaints though. Mostly a great game.

as a huge fan of Grimm brothers' novels, I thought I needed to wait and check out the reviews on this game, by time I went ahead and bought it, my initial thoughts? "best non-fromsoft souls game I played so far, amazing plot very immersive and brilliant" now thats what felt like completing the game first time around, I had few doubts at first up 'till I started the NG+ and thats where the game mechanics became much more clear as I kept upgrading my character's stats and leveling up. 
First issue I noticed is the scaling, it doesn't make sense having high stats in Defense and Resistance while still die from foot soldiers with a couple of hits, my level currently is 196 and yes, I still die from literally two-three hits by regular enemies (first chapter). 
With that said, the scaling issue unfortunately extends the bosses and mini-bosses, not only that, but almost 90% of the time it feels like the bosses are privileged with abilities, stamina and speed that extends far beyond yours, no matter if you are level 500 or ten, you'll still experience the broken boss mechanics, you'll immediately notice this after the tenth boss (or ninth) you can't miss it : sometimes they would go on illogical frenzy where no matter  how high your health and stamina are, you won't be allowed to dodge nor parry, why? cause the bosses are much faster than you and sometime they can reach you from across the room with charged attack or fable attack, they can chain link their combos even if was after their fable attacks (when they go red) and charged once which makes you think, how much stamina this enemy is packing?! None of that happened first time playing the game.
Some bosses you can't hit when they are knocked down flat on ground, some you can. whereas the minute you fall, their attacks will land on you, dodging will still not be an option, though you are allowed to guard sometimes when you are knocked down flat on the ground. Moving on further with this critique, I think this is my last point, more like a question really, Why is it really easy to get staggered by enemies (so much so by regular chapter one enemies) while its harder to stagger them in return?  personally I can only recommend this game only for first round completing it, the NG+ mechanics and scaling really needs some fixin' and adjustin'.

I went on a brief [i]Pinocchio[/i] kick after finishing this game for the first time, watching the Guillermo del Toro movie and listening to an audiobook of Carlo Collodi's original novel. All that thanks to NEOWIZ taking all the weird and wonderful shit that happens in the story and adapting it to a solid mix of Dark Souls 1's, Sekiro's, and Bloodborne's gameplay.

Last year, I wishlisted Lies of P because I, like many others, want a 60FPS remastered PC port for Bloodborne, but LoP does its own thing with the combined elements from the aforementioned games that I would have to get my own Playstation with Bloodborne to truly get my fix. It takes quite a bit to get used to for veteran Soulslike players, but I think this and DS1 make for great entry points for this type of action RPG. The enemies and bosses can both wreck careless players, but they have wide, predictable tells for their attacks much of the time; such that they can be blocked or parried with good timing. There is nothing quite like parrying several times in a row, seeing the enemy health bar get bordered with white, and landing one strong attack to stun them, affording the opportunity to knock out yet another significant portion of that health bar with a riposte attack. 

The binary choice mechanic is one of the game's more unique (for a Soulslike RPG) elements, which fits the Pinocchio theming. It plays more into which of the three story endings one will get than how it affects relationships to the friendly characters. There's not much else to say about that.

In conclusion, this game's playable Pinocchio is cute and I want to take him out to a night on the town. The game's as hard as it should be for one of its type. I had my frustrations with it, but I nonetheless had my fun. Solid game through and through.
Best Souls-like game there is. Takes all the good things about the souls series and adds to it. Absolute must for any souls fan.

I can't give it a 10, because there were a few things that bothered me, but they're kind of minor, so let's go with a solid 9.

Things I didn't like:
- I found that 2-handed, slow weapons weren't worth the trade-off in damage.
- Some areas kind of drag on.
- It starts very slow. To me, it was a "kind of boring" for the initial Krat area, but as I unlocked more, and as the story progressed, I was glued to it.
- Gear weight. I found myself putting more of the weight stat than my main damage stat. At the same time, again, there's always a positive, even if I was to go into NG+, levels would still give substantial stats. I'm not mega hard capped and then wondering what to put my points in going forward, like souls ends up being most of the time.

Things I liked: Everything, but more specifically:

- Weapon customization, the way they did it, is very *very* cool! But at the same time, it goes hand-in-hand with my first con. We're talking giving a 2-handed blade a 1-handed moveset type customization. It kind of invalidates some of the non-customizable weapons in my opinion. Still, I prefer tinkering and trying things than keeping the same boss weapon throughout the entire game (Remnant).

- The story is cool. It's possible to make a somewhat cryptic game without it being 99.9% cryptic and have a strong emphasis on story. I wish to god NEOWIZ makes more grim, dark takes on childhood stories like this to be honest. It's right up my alley.

- The world is amazing. Light Bloodborne vibes through and through.

This is by far the best souls-like game I've played that was not developed by From software. The game plays similar to Bloodborn and has a clockwork / steam punk type feel to it and the story is a morose adaptation of Pinocchio. As a graduate of the Sekiro school of Souls-Likes, I felt right at home with this game from the start. Perfect parries? Yes please! Modify my arm? Yessir!

I finished the game with a Motivity build and only really struggled in the midsection. I might have over-leveled to compensate though, so later parts of the game felt too easy at times. I like that the Boss fights encourage you to optimize your loadout.

I enjoyed the atmosphere of the world and the story is easier to follow than with most genre titles. The level design is very linear, but I happen to like that better than open areas. The cut scenes are gorgeous and especially the Bosses are beautifully grotesque. The music, while not outstanding, does the rest to sell the fantasy.

On the tech side, this game is outstanding: No stuttering, solid framerate that isn't locked at 60, very quick loading times.

Highly recommended!!

The game "Lies of P" has both positive and negative aspects, and I want to start by saying I didn't finish the game. Therefore, some of these issues may have been fixed or worsened since my playthrough. I played around launch to give you a picture of when I played. 

Let's discuss the positives first:

The game encourages a fast-paced, close-quarters combat style reminiscent of Bloodborne. The emphasis on blocking over dodging adds an interesting dynamic. For instance, when you get hit while blocking, a translucent HP bar can be recovered through a perfect block. Additionally, you deplete the enemy's invisible stamina bar(perfect blocking also depletes this invisible stamina bar)., potentially staggering them and creating an opportunity for a charged attack, leading to a stun and the chance for fatal attacks (riposte).

Furthermore, the game features a weapon system where you can dismantle weapons into blades and handles. This allows you to mix and match, adjusting stats and changing the charged attack based on the handle(I believe not 100% certain on this because I haven't played in a while). Not all weapons can be dismantled, as some are special. Additionally, the game has visually pleasing graphics and a lie system which is just this game's choice system.

Now, let's delve into the negatives:

The dodging mechanic is underpowered because of the insufficient distance. Using it often results in getting hit more than it helps, creating an issue since the game doesn't always favor blocking and actively wants you to dodge sometimes. While the dodge can be upgraded, it requires P-organs, which are rare and obtained mainly from boss fights and side bosses. The upgraded dodge, allowing a roll off the ground and double dodge, improves the distance but turns more into an I-frame button than a repositioning tool as the game progresses.

Moreover, the player lacks poise, making nearly every attack interrupt actions. Some attacks require perfect blocks, and the window for this is extremely tight, feeling close to frame-perfect. Compared to Sekiro's parrying system, with a more forgiving window(I was told this by my friend who also played the game so I can't confirm or deny this). There are instances where enemies can double-hit you, making the perfect block pointless since it will hit you regardless, this becomes more of a problem with longer enemy combo strings.

As the game advances, longer enemy combo strings make boss fights increasingly challenging. I encountered one boss fight where a specific attack prevented effective dodging or blocking, leaving me with limited options—either continuously attacking to stagger the boss before they could get those attacks off or relying on perfect blocks throughout the entire string of very long attacks. Status effects, like decay, have nearly instant build-ups. The combination of quick build-ups and Decay draining weapon durability and HP can be frustrating though I don't mind decay for merely existing just how easily it builds up is a problem. depending on the enemy, some attacks are poorly telegraphed or look similar to others, making it challenging to predict and parry effectively and this just makes fighting bosses in this game an absolute dread as they are the worst offenders of this.

The game encourages you to kill all enemies with some placements that are cruel, punishing attempts to run past them for progress not inherently a problem just a thing that exists. However, there are particularly challenging enemy placements, such as some with ranged attacks while you have to cross narrow beams which potentially causes you to get hit with an attack that could knock you off and make you restart from the beginning. 

TLDR, the game has its strengths and weaknesses, with room for improvement in gameplay mechanics, especially dodging and perfect blocking.  With that being said the game does have DLC coming and a potential sequel so hopefully it will fix these things in those.

Great game!!

I played the demo and came away with mixed feelings.  The combat felt clunky, parry mechanics were odd, but I loved the art style, effects work, and weapon designs.

I'm glad I purchased the game.  The combat is fun, the use of Legion arms allow for a lot of flexibility in build design (Puppet String lunge/drop attack with Motivity weapons hits extremely hard), and there's lots of room to explore.

It's a fairly linear game, paths wind and double back on themselves for shortcuts in a Soulslike fashion, but there's basically one route to follow in the main path.  That said, the environments are far more varied than 'Victorian-era streets and rooftops' that the demo portrayed.  It also ultimately pits you against more than just the frenzied puppets rampaging through Krat (the city in which this takes place).

Boss designs are varied, gorgeous, imposing, and disgusting.  My jaw dropped on some of the boss intros and phase changes.  Boss movesets are learnable, varied, and difficult to master, some starting with the same few attacks but switching it up with a backswing, dive, or other 'gotcha' requiring better reactions from the player.

As with most Souls-likes, lore can be buried behind items and descriptions, and the player has to check windows and listen for clues to possible quests in certain areas.  The story is much more prevalent and openly presented than From's titles.

Weapons are amazing.  The ability to interchange weapon 'heads' and handles to create a multitude of Fable special attacks and weapon movesets is the best I've seen in a Souls-like.  The unique boss Ergo weapons (which can't be modified like the found weapons) were equally varied and were strong in their own right.  I found myself gravitating towards an end-boss heavy hitting weapon in NG+.

I'm about 35 hours of play time in.  My NG+ playthrough is going significantly faster since combat has 'clicked'.

It's worth full price.  Pick it up on sale, too, if you need to save some cash.

detailed review:

the game is great but has a few shortcomings mostly when it comes to mechanics instead of the story.

it is true. the game is probably thus far the most correct souls-like adaption that has been made by a non-fromsoftware developer. Ever. In fact i cannot think of a single game right now that is a more venerable adaption. The game is a mixture of Sekiro, Dark souls and Bioshock
~~~~~~~
-Overall:
There are a total of 11 Chapters if i am not mistaken. Which is fairly short. Now i am against forced game prolongation by making you walk in places where you do not want to go back and forth doing quests just to grind the main mission. 
This is not like that. I believe you can just do minimal interaction with the main characters and still get away with ending the game. Which is fair and nice. 
~~~~~~~
-Main storyline:
The main story is pretty entertaining and holds a few decent twists that i really enjoyed. Unlike other modern games (all brown-shooter games) the characters are not forgettable. You will end up wondering who is where and what are they doing, what will they offer, what are their backstories. Just like classic fromsoft games a lot of details about the world are crypted behind messages, leaflets and various collectibles that hold the actual Lore of the world. This is a negative point for the read-lazies but positive for the exploration kind of gamer.
~~~~~~~
-Mechanics:
O man where to start. As mentioned above the gameplay itself is a venerable copy of sekiro and dark souls. You have dodge-rolling, full block, full deflect. On top of this some extras are added like weapon durability and debuffs that affect it. Once in a while your weapon will lose durability and you have to grind it. This is a a non issue once you unlock the skill tree that the weapon gets auto grinded when you use your secondary. Because you can put 2 weapons of the same playstyle at your usage. But until then it can be an actual factor in prolonged bossfights. Just like fromsoft games the bosses (not mobs) will read your input commands and stall hits if you are spamming deflect. But not if you hold block. This is imo STILL a bad practice withing these kinds of games. But it is the least relevant point, because the main problem is the deflect itself.
You see games like Sekiro that have sword deflect mechanics rely on a simple principle. Frame timming. When you fully press L1 (p.s joystick) to block, the character holds his weapon upwards. The whole animation takes 1 full second from start to finish. The first half of the block animation is the actual deflect. That means if a hit lands while you are in the first half of the animation, it counts as a deflect. This puts the brunt of the skill on the player, and by such logic the devs SHOULD make this a skill based system and not a memorization based system.
Yes the deflect is giga broken this game and i am probably not the only one who feels like it. The block animation is also a full second. But the deflect time FEELS much shorter than 0.5. It feels on the edge of 0.2 sec from my fast eye. Which is ok. The main problem i have are the enemies. Some bosses (will not spoil) can cast an attack in less then 0.1 seconds. Running at 100 fps means you have 10 frames to react. 
This time-frame is beyond what the human eye-brain-hand synapse can account for. In fact even most CSGO pros peak at 0.145 sec eye-brain-hand reaction time. And that is when the brain is in auto-click mode on a website designed for you to click once. Here you have to account for other factors too. As far as fromsoft games go the only thing i can think of that had very few frames to react were few attacks from Isshin. Namely only few of the charged wind slashes fell under this category of attacks. Where you cannot react, you must memorize the timming. If you have played the last Isshin you know what i am talking about. Now imagine for example all of Isshin's auto attacks cast as fast as the wind slash. 

This is not inherently a bad thing but i think it takes away from the skill-factor. Because you force the player to either memorize the timming or just glue their finger to the L1 block. 
I also disagree the player should be able to heal after blocking and attacking. The higher stagger damage is fine but why heal? Up until mid-game the bosses are very easy,  which takes away from the satisfaction of beating them; the players needs not heal off of autos after a block.
Another important thing to note is that if the player fails a deflect he will go into a very short stagger animation and CANNOT recast deflect immediately. Even if the player is not actually staggered/stunned you need to wait to cast deflect if you failed to deflect. This is detrimental against bosses that spam attacks in melee quick-succession. Your best hope is to have invested 80 points in HP and see if you can fit in a dodge-roll real quick. 
~~~~~~~
-Gameplay:
Very satisfactory semi-exploratory. Why semi? The world  is linear. If you get lost here is probably because you have not figured out yet that there is truly only 1 path. Which is also ok because the design of the worlds itself is very immaculate in my opinion and it makes up for this. Besides not everyone is an open-world enjoyer.
~~~~~~~
-Weapons:
The second weakest point this game has. Weapons fall under only 3 categories of fight-style. Rapier, sword, heavy sword. The animations are the same for all weapons in the same class. The differences between weapons comes mostly from the stylistic art and whatever effects you want their handles to have. This was very underwhelming so i stuck with the rapier Umbrella for all the game because the rapier actually breaks the game. 
Yes it is a very OP weapon that will literally go unpunished, which imo is AI fault. Heavy swords can do a lot of stagger damage but also drain DOUBLE the amount of stamina per attack. And each attack is 3x slower than other weapons. This means the rapier dps is actually insane and you should use heavy swords only for critical attacks once the enemy is staggered.
The umbrella is also too OP because it becomes a mini shield once you cast a heavy attack. Blocking any enemy hit that lands during the animation. This combined with the stagger talisman make the umbrella TIER ZERO in this game. 
~~~~~~~
-Shields and attires:
There are no shields this game but attires are the number one most underwhelming point. There are too few of them and they offer very little. They are mostly for fashion and i was hoping they could actually make-or-break full builds like for example in Elden Ring. Very disappointing the attires and their attributes
~~~~~~~
-Side/Main Characters:
I personally loved all characters i was presented with this game. Especially Sophia and Gepetto. There are very few characters in this game overall but that makes it even more commemorable and special once you complete their specific quests. Over all character design 10/10
~~~~~~~
-Items and various consumables
Nothing too out of the ordinary you have your hp flask, your anti-debuff flasks ... practically everything you expect the game to actually have and a few more for show. 
I loved the addition of the clock that teleports you to stargazers. I would have been actually tilted if that was not there considering how much you have to walk.

~
~
~
Overall i'd give a 7.3/10 with a should-be retail price of 50$

[h1]Lies of P is a perfect mix of Dark Souls, Sekiro and Bloodborne.[/h1]

[i]Lies of P is a thrilling soulslike that takes the story of Pinocchio, turns it on its head, and sets it against the darkly elegant backdrop of the Belle Epoque era.[/i]

[h3]Story[/h3]
The story in Lies of P is really good, and I'm not going to spoil anything here. What I can say is that during the course of the story, you have to make choices several times whether to tell the truth or lie. There are different endings to certain characters' questlines, and different endings to the entire game, depending on how truthful or untruthful you have been. You can even miss the final boss if you choose the "wrong" choice at the end, so it might be a good idea to check that out beforehand.

[h3]The City of Krat[/h3]
The environment in Lies of P looks pretty much the same throughout the game. There are not really any memorable areas. If you compare to Dark Souls, each area is unique, and it is easy to remember these areas. In this game, the city of Krat is gray and dark, whether you run on the streets, on the rooftops, through apartments or through factories. Even parts when you run through forests and swamps, everything is very gray and dark.

[h3]Ergo & P-Organ[/h3]
In Lies of P you level up by spending Ergo (Souls), just like in Dark Souls or similar games. For each level, the number of Ergo needed to level up increases. The difference in this game compared to other games is that the increase is minimal. When I played NG+ I noticed that it increased by only 1 Ergo per lvl, which is nothing! It hasn't always been like that, but I noticed it around lvl 125 when it took about 16,000 Ergo to level up. Then after lvl 150+ it started increasing more again, but still not that much. There are only 6 stats to choose from when you level up, so you hit those softcaps very quickly and easy, too easy. These stats are:

[u]Vitality[/u] (Health, Defense & Guard Regain)
[u]Vigor[/u] (Stamina & Defense)
[u]Capacity[/u] (Weight Limit, Defense & Legion Bar)
[u]Motivity[/u] (Strength & Defense)
[u]Technique[/u] (Dexterity & Defense)
[u]Advance[/u] (Legion Bar, Legion Damage & Resistances).

There are no spells or magic in this game, so there aren't that many ways to go when it comes to spending your Ergo. Basically you go either Strength or Dexterity.

There is also another leveling system called P-Organ. P-Organ is a skill tree that features both passive and active abilities. You unlock these new abilities with the help of a special material called Quartz, that is available in limited quantities in each playthrough. The P-Organ skill tree consists of several phases, where you have to spend a certain number of Quartz in phase 1 to unlock phase 2, then it continues to phase 3, 4 and 5. Here you can increase the number of Pulse Cells (Main source of healing, like Estus Flask in Dark Souls), strengthen certain attacks, reduce the amount of stamina used for certain actions, etc. When you progress over to NG+, one more phase is unlocked, phase 6. NG++ unlocks phase 7, which is the cap. This increases the replayability of the game, which is great, because then you have something more to strive for while you play the questlines again to achieve different endings.

[h3]Enemies & Bosses[/h3]
The bosses are the funnest part of this game, no doubt about it. They are extremely well done in combination with how well done the combat is in this game. There is no Co-Op in this game, but you can summon a Specter to help you in almost every boss fight. The enemies are of good variety with varying attack patterns that you have to learn if you want to achieve Perfect Blocks.

[h3]Combat & Weapons[/h3]
In Lies of P you have your main weapon in your right hand, and your left hand is your Legion Arm, similar to Sekiro. There are different variants of this arm that you unlock as you progress the game and you can then switch between them. Each Legion arm can be upgraded with a special material that unlocks new abilities for that arm.

Experimenting with different weapons in Lies of P is a lot of fun, as you can build weapons yourself. You can take a handle from one weapon and put it together with the blade from another weapon. Basically, the handle is the source of scaling with different Stats and determines your move set, and the blade determines Base Damage and Damage Reduction while Guarding. There are more to this, but I'll leave it at that. There are also boss weapons that you cannot take apart and rebuild, they are simply as they are.

You also have something called Fable Art Attack. Each handle has its own Fable Art and each blade has its own Fable Art, which is something you also have to keep in mind when building your weapon. It's about finding the Fable Arts that you like.

There are no shields in Lies of P, instead you block with your weapon, called Guarding. When you block an enemy's attack, you take less damage, but you always take damage. Reduced damage while Guarding will be transferred to Guard Regain. Guard Regain allows the player to recover a portion of their health by attacking the enemy back, if you are fast enough, similar to Bloodborne. Each weapon differ in how good your Guard and Damage Reduction is. There's also Perfect Guard, which means you hit block just as the enemy's attack is about to land. Then you take no damage at all, plus it can be used offensively to interrupt an enemy attack, Stagger them, or even destroy their weapons. This is extremely satisfying and what makes this game extra fun. This Perfect Guard system is reminiscent of Sekiro as well.

[h2]The Verdict[/h2]
Lies of P is a perfect mix of Dark Souls, Sekiro and Bloodborne, and which at the same time does its own thing. This game exceeded my expectations. I think Lies of P is the best non-FromSoftware soulslike game out there right now. 9/10.

An amazing soulslike that combines some of the best features from other titles in the genre, while including its own unique mechanics like Legion Arms and blade + weapon handle combinations that change the entire movesets of the weapons, making for interesting builds during gameplay. A big plus was that the game also encourages respecing by unlocking it about 1/3rd into the game, and makes it unlimited (although having higher costs each time you do it). I highly recommend this to anyone interested in a fun soulslike to play.

A solidly designed souls-like. Very competent -- more than I expected coming into it.

The Pinocchio/puppet aesthetic I anticipated would wear on me and was what put me off the game most. However it was handled quite well and you get acclimated to it very quickly. The world building and story have that typical souls-y feel but manages to be its own thing and not merely another in a long line of copycats. That can be said for much of this game. It's familiar enough that you feel content playing it, but is unique enough that you aren't bored by familiarity.

A shorter experience, but rightly so considering the quality of the game design. Level design especially was handled masterfully; it was more linear than some in the genre but I actually consider that something of a boon to it,

My biggest gripe is that the "strength" (called motivity in this game) build seems just objectively stronger/easier to play than the "dex" build. Difficulty is also not that high, though some of the bosses are bound to give you some trouble, but that might vary depending on your build as just stated.

If you like souls-likes, give it a try, it's a more compact quality game in the genre to tide you over for more 'major' releases.

Lies Of P is a great addition to the Soulslike Genre. My first playthrough took just over 30 hours (I afk'd 2-3hrs and steam counts that). Be warned, Parrying is key - if you do not wish to practice it, you will likely struggle with this game.

The good:
TONS of interesting weapons to experiment with.
*I experimented with strength, dex, and elemental weapons, switching things up while learning boss move-sets.
Beautiful world with great shortcuts throughout to make exploration smoother.
Almost all of the bosses have a helper-summon for players whom are struggling.
Combat system is easy to learn, hard to master.
A few of the soundtracks were amazing.
Overall pacing and progression.


The bad:
A few boss run-backs were too long for no reason. Luckily this was only a small amount of occurrences.
Multi-phase bosses (I do not find it fun having to beat phase A to practice phase B, I find it disrespecting of the player's time, but that's just my opinion)
Sometimes the camera is a bigger threat than the boss you're facing. This is common in this genre and LoP is not an exception.
8/10 story with rich environments, jam-packed with an insane amount of enemy variety. 100% Recommend.

Review from the big Souls and Sekiro fan:

This game is the closest we have to Bloodborne on PC. 
- Character- and environmental designs are beautiful 
- Linear level design that gets a bit boring towards the end
- Handle and blade mechanic allows modification of weapon movesets. Finding the suitable moveset for a specific weapon is fun
- Combat pace is similar to Bloodborne, but the responsiveness is much better due to 60+ FPS. A Sekiro-like posture break mechanic rewards aggressive gameplay. Chain parries are viable and are accompanied by satisfying sparks and sound effects. Parry timing is a little bis less generous than in Sekiro. 
- Boss fights feel really good. Getting good is required and is rewarded with the joy of victory just like in a Fromsoft game. Hitboxes are almost always well-done. Some boss attacks could be telegraphed better. The boss fight soundtrack fits to the setting but is not exceptional

I've needed 34 hours for the first all bosses playthrough. I highly recommend it to everyone who enjoys fast-paced combat and gitting gud.
An incredibly crafted game with significant attention to detail, stellar combat, and a story that is more present than your usual souls like. 10/10

First game I completed in years. Great at walking you through the mechanics of the game.
Lies of P doesn't get repetitive as every stage is different and parts of the game between all boss battles are like a well thought out training program.

Honestly Lies of P is an amazing surprise and a towering achievement for the soul-like genre, and the studio behind this title. i highly recommend playing this game if your a fan a the souls like genre 


Gameplay
 this is where Lies of P really surprised me to be honest. The combat looks very similar to other souls like on the surface but that hides a depth of design that really makes the game stand out. it borrows a lot of separate  elements and weaves them together in a gameplay system that never really has you taking for granted what you should be doing. From Sekiro the game takes a perfect parry, press the block button at just the right moment and you take no damage and put the enemy into a staggerable state. from blood borne we have the rally mechanic where you can attack back to regain lost health. however unlike bloodborne where you get hit and can regain health from the health lost. in Lies of P you block and then can attack to regain health lost. combined with the basic of i frame dodging and you have a plethera of moves on how to handle enemy attacks and the game doesn't discriminate what you should be using. wanna roll away from an enemy swinging like wild? go for it. wanna stand in the middle and perfect guard it all? exellent choice. wanna just stand there with your high damage absorbing sword and eat it? perfectly fine. the game really encourages you to find out what works for you. 

Story
Another pleasant surprise while nothing thats gonna win an award for best story Lies of P does a good job. getting you invested in its world, its characters, and more importantly its premise. the puppets you meet in Lies of P predominantly want to kill you. but along the way you find touching moments of humanity that give you pause. You will have Empathy for most characters and disdain for others. not all characters are equal in this but none of the characters feel like cardboard either. hell one of the most enthralling characters is a puppet. 

Level Design. 
Lies of P never quite reaches that level of interconnected world you would probably expect from a souls game. but thats not really a deal breaker for me. levels are fun to explore have a good amount of verticality to them that makes it all feel more real and the shortcut game is on point. but the levels are just that Levels incredibly well designed levels though. 

Enemy Variety 
Honestly really nice and on point while the beginning levels of the game keep the enemy design mostly samey its not long at all before the game starts introducing new enemies and it pretty much never stops.
im serious a new enemy type will appear maybe every level to two levels. the game gets an A+ for enemy design

Length
I'm not gonna lie (probably) I kept expecting lies of P to end. like 3 times i would think Okay thats the last fight what a nice game really had a lot of fun and... oh its still going SWEET. and thats the important thing i never wanted lies of P to end. i just thought that surely thats what would be coming up at this point right? and when the game didn't it was always a pleasant suprise. Guys i got 30 hours on this game. Thats with Zero grinding, a normal amount of exploring and except for a couple exceptions doing most bosses on my second and 3rd tries. 

Conclusion
Lies of P is wonderful and unfortunately much like the first dark souls game something of a sleeper hit. those who have played the game all seem to agree on the level of quality and care put into every aspect of this game especially the combat. so buy the game and tell your friends about it!

My only gripe with the game was that some enemy attacks are quite difficult to read intuitively, which feels a bit unfair. But that is a very minor gripe in an otherwise outstanding game.

Looking forward to the next project.

My favorite thing about Lies of P is it's potential for player expression. You're allowed to beat the game (mostly) however you want. You can 'Perfect Guard' every encounter, dodge every enemy attack, or do a mixture of both whenever you see fit. Typically, there are better approaches to every fight, but the game will meet you on your own terms and give you the freedom to choose how you tackle it. You're allowed to build any weapon you want by combining different blades with different handles or use any special boss weapon from the various fights throughout the game. If you want to stick a giant wrench to the end of a dagger handle, you can. If you want to put a greatsword blade on a rapier hilt, you can. This simple tweak to a standard weapon selection system adds so much variety between every playthrough and every person's experience with the game.

You'll encounter several boss fights over your 30-hour playthrough of the game. Most of them are good, if not great, while a few of them not so much. Bosses are incredibly aggressive, but readable and reactable, say for a few 'Fury Attacks' which require memorization in timing as opposed to testing of reactions. I was actually surprised to see how many fantastic fights this game offers. There are several bosses I would understand seeing at the top of someone's favorite Lies of P boss list. The game is also a lot harder than I was expecting with several bosses taking over an hour, sometimes up to 3, to beat. 

Another thing to note is the game's story. I won't be giving any summary here, but I'm surprised at how invested I actually was in the characters and story surrounding them. It's a refreshing change to see a game in this genre with such a defined and explicit narrative. There were more than a few characters I grew to genuinely really like and feel for. Complementing the story is the great soundtrack through the game. This includes boss themes, as well as the vinyls you can obtain and play in the Hotel hub area. The songs used give the desolate and depressing world so much more life and context. The world of Lies of P is beautiful and feels lived-in and overrun by the puppets and corrupted roaming about. It could have done better with more impurities in the objects around the levels and architecture, but that's more of a nitpick than anything.

The game isn't perfect, however. It falters towards the end and stumbles in it's final act. After [spoiler]Laxasia[/spoiler] , you feel like you're closing in on the finale, but then it sort of just continues for a bit too long before the actual end of the game. The reason I take issue with this area is because up until this point the game has done an incredible job at making every location feel fresh with new or remixed enemy types, level design, and area visuals. But this final stretch feels like a retread of the last few areas without enough of a difference to warrant being included. You could argue that this serves as a sort of down-time before the final fight, but the enemies here are just as aggressive as usual and you'll probably end up running past all of them at this point.

All in all, Lies of P is one of the biggest sleeper hits in recent memory and surpassed the expectations I had for it by a  long shot. It's one of the best 'Soulslike' games I've had the privilege of playing, and I'm incredibly excited to see the upcoming DLC and whatever next game comes from this series.

This game is a masterpiece. Inspired by the souls' genre but also creative and unique at the same time. The characters you encounter and the voice acting it's all well thought off. You find yourself "feeling" for them. The coziness of hotel Krat is very warm and calming. Yet a tragedy occurs and you are on an emotional roller coaster. OVERALL: 8/10
Lies of P is a wonderful game that experiments with the souls-like layout, sometimes to its detriment. If you were told this game is bloodborne or sekiro you will be disappointed, but it would not be lies of P if it were more like either. Definitely worth full price if you love the formula, Lies of P is a gold standard of what a FromSoft-like can be.

PROS:
A robust combat system that almost demands you interact with every part of it at some point.
Weapon heads changing the animation speed of your attacks offers more trade off's beyond simple stat changes.
A decidedly FromSoft inspired world that feels gently caressed by Miyazaki's blood-soaked hands.
Beautiful Visuals from character models and environmental effects.
Set piece boss fights with tight parry times and uniquely tricky enemy movesets due to most enemies being robotic.
Quality sound design, and solid voice acting that brings feeling and energy not usually seen in FromSoft games.
CONS:
Denuvo. There is no PVP, why is there anti-tamper? There should not be anti-tamper.
Weapon customization starts and ends at Head + Hilt + Crank, which feels less than it should even though it's technically more than dark souls.
Many weapon combinations, although humorous to look at, are not practical and some whole weapons feel like filler.
Despite bloodborne being its most obvious inspiration; weapon movesets have heavy animation commitment and strong enemy tracking once again makes aggressive play and dodging attacks feel punished. Weapons overall never fill enough situations to feel complete like every weapon from that game.
Weapon durability makes another case as to why it's a bad idea in a souls-like, A unique idea was had in special grindstones but the, again, bloodborne levels of speed sometimes makes even running low on durability a death sentence.
The ability to chain dodges, dodge after performing certain actions, and other abilities that should be base mechanics, are locked behind progression and fairly deep in said progression.
A great and FAIR soulslike. Love this game, can't put it down. Please give us some DLC, stat! <3

It meant that instead of being able to try new weapons or diversify, I got stuck with already upgraded weapons instead.

I really did want to rate this positively with a thumbs up, but after thinking about it over the course of several weeks, a thumbs down is what I've ended up with. TLDR, it's just kind of boring with a series of decisions that were ALMOST good. 

Visually, and audibly, the game is wonderful. There are spots in this game that had me stop and stare, something guaranteed for me to do in a From Soft game. Everything else about this game feels like a series of decisions that were ALMOST great, but fell into the hole of mediocrity. And I hate to immediately compare this game to a From Software title, but that's what this game is trying to imitate. 

It saddens me to say that the balancing of this game is all over the place. Your character doesn't feel nearly fast enough to parry or counter or dodge attacks from enemies whose attacks are quite fast. Enemies hit for quite a lot of health, and nothing felt particularly "challenging" on a skill based level, more on a "gank" based level. It gives me Dark Souls II Scholar of the First Sin vibes if you can picture what I mean. Something just feels off with the execution. 

Of course, I am aware I don't have too many hours logged into this game, but if you're the "Trust me bro, it gets good at the ten hour mark." you've been brainwashed. Entertainment needs a "hook" at the beginning to keep an audience engaged, after all, and if I'm not having fun because your game is boring, that's not on me. 

That brings me to my next point, how boring the game is. Story wise, you know what's happening but you just don't feel invested. This was more like "Go to the hotel and I'll tell you what's good." Then you get there and you get "Now go and do this thing." There's no motivations, no particularly interesting characters. You just get a mound of information, and you're expecting to find things interesting with what little they've given you to chew on. 

Finally, and the worst thing for me, everything you do in this game is inconvenient. Save points are either too close or far too separated, which leads to a lot of runs where the enemies you caught the attention of will follow you to where you last died. Then, of course, there's the fact that you HAVE to travel back to the blue chick to level up. From Soft moved on from that design with Elden Ring. It's annoying and makes the game more of a chore than it is fun. The design feels old, nothing new has been added, just designs from From Soft titles bundled into one package.

Firstly, I really enjoyed the combat and the music is great. It is souls-like and it really is a love letter to FromSoftware games. It has really cool mechanics with the legion arms, good character progressions and cool weapon arts.
Just like other souls-like when you are exploring the game(non boss-fight areas), there will be no music. So, it really is up to the sounds of the environment/enemies that must create the atmosphere. <Some spoilers ahead> There is an area of the game where your character is in a train station platform. All the enemies here affect the character with decay. It's dark and you will be able to hear the sounds the enemies make, the sounds of the air blowing, the echoes of your footsteps all amplified by the cold. It's eerie yet beautifully crafted. I was just in awe of this game especially during that level. 
The level design is wonderful too! The way different shortcuts connect you to an earlier stargazer(bonfire) even though you would have started from a completely different one.. Mind blown! 
You must try this out at least once. It is worth every penny!

My review of this game will never reach the caliber that this game is. When I first heard of this game last year I was intrigued; curious to see how the devs would make a souls game based around puppets and lordie, was I impressed. I played the demo when it was released several months before release and the feedback the devs got they took to heart because when this game officially dropped it was like a bomb. They improved the gameplay and mechanics from the demo drastically and unlike a lot of the AAA games that were released this year on PC, the devs made damn sure that it worked first day and any issues got ironed out immediately. I am a loyal fan for life with these devs as they obviously care about their customers. As far as gameplay, it has become one of my favorite souls games ever. The unlimited ways you can customize your run is insane and they even allow you to make your own weapon by dismantling handles and blades from weapons you find and combining them with each other to make interesting and new combinations. The game ran like butter and I loved every single level, boss, NPC.....everything. The bosses were challenging, especially up to NG+2 and I tried a different build for every run making the consecutive runs for the Platinum achievement fun and not repetitive. I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys souls and I cannot wait for the DLC and the sequel.

Had mixed expectations about this game, as Soulslikes not made by FROMSOFTWARE generally did not scratch that type of itch, but it overcame those expectations and then some at every step of the way. It very much feels like a mix of Bloodborne and Sekiro, but it brings a TON of original additions that elevate the gameplay to maybe even above what it is inspired by.

 The game is very much linear and mostly only focused on the combat, but what incredible tools they gave us to engage with that combat system. Finding new weapons that do not work with your current/desired build or playstyle doesn't immediately make them worthless because of the blade-handle swapping. And the weapons also all feel unique and badass in their own way with a different moveset or Fable art to try out. I ran a full Technique (DEX) build with unaltered weapons for most of the game until I found a Motivity (STR) blade that perfectly fit with the weapon fantasy I wanted and I didn't even have to respec any stats to use it!

 Despite its considerable length my first playthrough did not feel like a drag at all. The level designs are sometimes very straightforward and I didn't have a lot of wow-moments when it comes to loop-arounds or shortcuts, but they did show that they know what makes a good level. There are ample opportunities to catch a breather and there is a good amount of variety in platforming and themes. No location feels like it overstays its welcome and there are no horrendous design moments or incredible long run-backs. This is also complemented by the large array of enemy designs. They are unique and memorable, and feel logical for their point in a playthrough. The developers didn't just copy-paste the enemies to later parts of the game with the only difference being inflated stats.

 The soundtrack is wild (especially those records are amazing), the animations of enemies/bosses and your own moves are clean and readable, and the art and setting are downright beautiful. Honestly where did these guys come from to make such a good game in this genre?!


Also:
Please dont block the clear path forward with a steel gate we've been previously shown to smash through or a simple box T_T

Lies of P is a great game. I could dissect its mechanics and systems, but I can't say anything that others havent; it mirrors and faithfully replicates many elements of mainline souls titles as well as sekiro and bloodborne. 

That being said, there is one aspect that I can comment on that I feel is left mostly unsaid; the symbology and themes bizarrely match Elden Ring's in some major ways, which I find amazing considering what must have been overlapping development periods. Now I know even ER's symbology is derivative of christianity and other world religions, as is the case with most souls games, but it is the way those are implemented that is so similar between both games. I wont got into detail, as it is lore/spoiler heavy, but if you are learned in the occult, alchemy, and religious symbology, as well as the lore of ER, it should be apparent to you that the Lies of P devs directly took, but also surprisingly deeply understood some themes and symbology from ER after it's release.  Considering this, I feel Lie of P is basically a linear companion piece to Elden Ring; the experience you will have with each enriches what you will take from the other.

I would recommend it to any souls fan; pretty much a must play.

To all new players, you are not playing bloodborne nor dark souls! I see many people getting frustrated because they think they can overcome the game by smacking everything on their way while also relying on a fixed build they feel comfortable with. 

Lies of P encourages adaptability, imagination and pattern recognition. Hallways are getting too narrow? better off switching to a smaller weapon for now, enemies on this area are too fast? modify your weapon to a better suited combination, the game has so many options for you it can feel overwhelming some times, and that's without considering the extra layer of possibilities when including the different legion arms with their own abilities and character traits.

Adapt your play style, experiment with different weapon combinations, use your consumables!

Maybe the best souls-like game i've ever played, considering that i've already finished sekiro and elden ring before, which tells a lot

PROS

1) Game fixes all the flaws that usual souls-bornes are not fixing, and there is a lot of them. Firstly, it's the camera. I have never complained during my previous two playthroughs about the camera, maybe it's the design of world, or just the pace of this game allows you to avoid such situations where you die stupidly, but the camera never betrays you during mass fights, which means there is a fair chances for you to survive the encounter

2) Finally the developers realized that the souls(ergo) in the boss rooms should be left outside the boss arena, because sometimes it's really frustrating, when you reached a good amounts of ergo, and then surprisingly appear in the boss room and just can't get these souls back. It was infuriating in previous souls series games, but not there, which means you can fairly reorganize your spendings and inventory after the fight

3) Intuitively understandable system of shortcuts and levels. The problems with Dark Souls 1 was that despite having an interesting level-design and rich amounts of secrets inside them, it never was undestandable for you, which meant that when you approach certain level, bu going further, you increase the risks to forget where must you go after you die. Considering the vast size of a Dark Souls 1, it was really hard to track your destination, and you can even enter the area for a levels too high for you, which meant you can be stuck in the areas like TOmb of the Giants if you approach this place without the lordvessel

It's not the same story for Lies of P, despite having a linear Level Design, it still preserves an interest in player to research the areas while making it easier for them to find the necessary shortcut = it is really clever, because this game is already difficult enough to compare itself with sekiro, and the understandable shortcuts will save the player their time and nerves, and make it interesting for them to observe the area's secrets

4) Optimization. Damn it, never have i questioned my sanity when i looked at the FPS tracker between LoP and DS Remastered and noticed how smoothly and quickier the optimization in this game works in compare to DS1, which was released in 2018, 5 years before LoP damnit. And it still works better than Elden Ring or Sekiro, they also had problems with FPS

5) Combat system. Honestly, i was quite surprised, while waiting for the PC version of the bloodborne to receive the child of Bloodborne and Sekiro, where i will indulge myself in Parry mechanics, which was fun to study. Having a fast paced and smooth gameplay during fight and boss-fights, it creates an aesthetic pleasure to make certain moves and combos with prosthesis and weapon during boss fights. This combat system is far better than of the Elden Ring or Sekiro, because it is more versatile and allows you to experiment a lot, which allows players to make their own builds and styles to beat this game. It really is fun, and i take it as a really fun part of it.

CONS:

Despite being a polished and calculated perfectly masterpiece, some parts of the game still have a problems. The first is:
1) Movesets of bosses and mobs. I noticed, that compare to ER or Sekiro, where the attacks of bosses are easy to block because of their smooth pattern, the pattern of bosses in LoP are way smaller and faster in compare to them. It ,eans that when we have a preparation before the attack and the attack itself, we see that the attack of the mobs are almost immediate, which makes it really hard to react in time when we need to block some attacks. The visual hints are also not intuitively understandable, which means when you are trying to teach yourself to block some attacks of cetrain enemies, it becomes easier to learn the time pattern of the attack, rather than the visual hints, because they are too quick and small to notice at the first time, so parry is quite hard in this game and you need to spend a heft amounts of time to nail it

2) Dodge system. The numbers of i-frames of the dodge are too small, which means that you can't rely only on dodging in certain times, and even if you are doing dodging well, there is a problem of the wide swinging attacks of the bosses. Which means that you can probably dodge one attack, but the second will reach you soon after. And it happens almost everywhere in this game, when the attack of mod will have a wide range or the demi-boss have a vast combo, you just can't dodge in time after the first dodge

That is all the problems and Pros that i've noticed whileplaying this game. And honestly, in compare to the previous souls-likes LoP is like a jewel, and coming back to ER or DS 3 after LoP was quite hard, which meant that the quality set by this game is better than the standard Fromsofts made before.

And yeah, this game is harder than Sekiro, so good luck and have fun with a fair challenge

i tried and refunded it

It tries to be a souls game while having its own puppet story and universe, but I feel a sense of contradiction or imbalance since I started. 

The game tries to mix Sekiro's perfect block system and prosthetic with slow attack by attack pacing of dark souls series, but this does not work. Sekiro's pacing is very fast. Swing is fast and recovery is also very fast and windows are tight. Failing to block does not cause health penalty. Dark souls' pacing is relatively slow and encourage cautious act but fail to block also not cause health penalty. In Lies of P, fail to block reduces health and perfect block requires pin-point timing. Attack actions, like Dark souls, is slow and clunky. The pacing in Lies of P is rather awkward and confusing for me. I tried to dodge but walking away is more efficient. I tried to block but my health just keep going down and no way I can perfect block 100%. HP recovery from guard recovery is not nearly enough to cover the reduced HP of imperfect guard. Sekiro's perfect block system is difficult pull off here as it is much slower than in Sekiro. I would need to stop my attack and pay attention and time and block and hope the block is perfect. With the same time cost, I'd rather just walk away and keep my distance. No need to block and guarantee no HP reduction.

No mini-map. Scenery is not very catching for me. Action is less polished than a FromSoftware game. Overall quality is expectedly less than that of FromSoftware game and It felt too much like souls game. The maiden, the bonfire I would just play a souls game. The field of view is short and the camera keep looking down.

I recognize that there are some original idea. The puppet, the story and universe, the weapon assembly system. I like those elements but they are not necessarily bound to the souls' like gameplay. I would prefer it to be a more Devil may cry style or full Sekiro style or any other style that are relatively fast paced and less punishing to failure than the typical Souls' slow, cautious and punishing gameplay. For a story rich game, the slow paced gameplay is very distracting.

Try on sale, but not recommended for full price.

If a Round8 employee is reading this - please add a difficulty select instead. For everyone else, here is how to rollback the game to the release version:

1. Win+R
2. steam://open/console
3. download_depot 1627720 1627721 6414528620246400900
4. Go to the download folder, and copy all files.
5. Right click "Lies of P" in Steam, then "Manage" and "Browse local files".
6. Paste all the files, overwriting everything in the process.
7. Go to the "Binaries" folder, and then "Win64".
8. Create a file named "steam_appid.txt"
9. Enter it using Notepad, paste "1627720" into it and save.
10. Run the game using "LOP-Win64-Shipping.exe" in the same folder.

Recently finished NG+, and I think this is one of my favorite games ever. I don't know if I've ever played a game that gave me such a confidence boost in my own abilities; every victory feels like a shot of caffeine straight into my veins. I love the quality of life improvements on the Soulslike formula -- such as dropping your currency outside the boss arena on death (where you can just take it and run if you need to) or being able to charge up an additional healing pulse after using them all. Parrying is hard to learn, but man, when you nail it, it feels so satisfying. The soundtrack is also surprisingly beautiful. I do kind of wish there were more secret areas or alternate pathways between regions -- just something to make the world feel slightly less linear -- but I can easily forgive that. Easily a 9/10 for me. My favorite game of 2023.
