Lies of P is a masterpiece. A truly amazing game with beautiful art style, interesting story, well-balanced difficulty, satisfying combat, lots of weapons, great soundtrack and... yes ...femboy protagonist. My personal GOTY
...if only this game has a map.

This is, apart from Hellpoint, the first Soulslike that actually gave me the feeling of jumping into a Souls game again - specifically Bloodborne. The vibe, story, characters and locations are all wonderful. The music is truly amazing, and the boss fights are - for the most part - fun and challenging. 

The system of letting you deconstruct weapons into blade and hilt and recombining them is so cool, and gives each playthrough even more variety. It's a shame that boss weapons can't be deconstructed though - seems like a missed opportunity. 

Also having armor being only cosmetic is nice, because you can just wear what you think looks cool. Though that also leads to the actual defensive gear being very cookie-cutter - just the same thing, better stats, more weight. Oh well, that's a minor gripe.

It is very linear, but I didn't mind that, because the levels are designed really well and shortcuts are frequent and still give that "Oh, I'm here!" feeling. But I would like for them to experiment with a more interconnected world in the sequel.

I only have one major complaint: This game is RELENTLESS when it comes to wall bounces. Please. It's too much. If you play with a wide swinging weapon you will curse it every. Single. Minute.

Other than that: Highly recommend. I'm looking forward to DLC and Sequel, and I want to see this series prosper as much as the OG Dark Souls.
good

Finishing this game has been this year's highlight for me. I honestly cannot commend it enough. It's unfathomable that something with this much polish and promise is a FIRST BLOODY ATTEMPT by the developers. In a reality where Lies of P (and arguably Harper Lee's To Kill A Mockingbird) wasn't a thing, I would have laughed at anybody saying so.

The following is just what came to mind in the little time I set aside for this recommendation. I want to clarify again before starting that I love this game to bits, and I hope it only gets better from here on.

[h3]Pros[/h3]

The intro cutscene right after the name drop. It absolutely slaps.

Combat feels focused and tight, which is something missing from several souls-likes. Unlike Sekiro though, you cannot feint an attack into a block in the startup frames, so you have to find openings and fully commit to either offense or defense (I totally did not learn this the hard way)

The "bock to rally" is perfect, and the duration the rally stays makes it a viable defensive option that requires CAREFULLY EXECUTED OFFENSE to fully capitalize, as getting hit by any attack will remove the entire rally pool. This is a welcome change from "unga-bunga go" moments with Bloodborne's rally system, as it forces focused play.

Getting a heal item back by playing well delivers moments with rushes of adrenaline you wouldn't think were possible from sitting on a chair and starting at a screen.

*Weapon variety is insane, but I feel it kind of shoots itself in the heel by introducing special boss weapons, that are pretty much better in terms of raw power, and come with unmatched flair. Still, for people that stick to non-boss weapons, the playground here is huge, if somewhat limited by the decrease in power introduced by putting a blade meant for a specific type of damage like striking on top of a handle meant for another type of damage like stabbing. Case in point, a hammer on top of a rapier handle. This makes sense, obviously, but it does limit what you can do with the system.

Narrative pacing is great. The atmosphere and story is intriguing, and the theme of "awakening" is presented very interestingly. The game's endings feel complete, but open many doors to follow which I hope the devs do later on. I won't spoil with examples, but if you like Isaac Asimov's works or other media around such themes, you are very likely to appreciate this game's presentation.

NPCs storylines are good (except Belle) - you grow to care for them. I genuinely panicked at a certain moment in a certain Chapter, and that speaks to the quality of the voice acting and character work that went into this game.

[h3]Non-Pros, Non-Cons[/h3]

World is linear, but honestly whether you like it or not is completely subjective. I was okay with it, but I know that some might not be, so I am putting this in neutral.

Would like a few more interesting side quests. However, the game does take place over two game days and nights, and since the side quests we do get are fairly nice (again except Belle), I chalk this up to a design decision and therefore neutral.

P isn't voiced. Again, this feels like a design decision for a studio dipping its feet for the first time in a very intimidating pool of games, and personally not a dealbreaker for me. Multiple endings probably makes it really hard to decide how the character should be voiced based on various branching decisions up until that point. So, I would rather not have a voiced character than have one poorly done.

[spoiler]If time turns back when P dies, how is it that choices made from the last moment of rest to the moment of death aren't undone? It doesn't make sense, unless time manipulation is exclusive to the subject like Inoue's powers from Bleach. I don't recall this ever being explained, and it's a little nitpick I have with the game.[/spoiler]

[h3]Cons(?)[/h3]

The depth of weapon move sets feels a little lacking. What we get works fine, and this is primarily a personal feeling for me as even FromSoftware haven't really tried it, but I would LOVE to see some take on feinting attacks to force enemy reactions. I would additionally like to see the ability to chain lights into heavies, and heavies into lights with specific attacks for these transitions.

The lips move, but don't seem synced (English). Again, this is not what the game's focus is on and so it classifies as a nitpick, but it would be nice to see some more animation work on the narrative end of things in general.

Belle's character literally does nothing, so I am hoping we get to do something in the DLC.

*I want to stress that despite my problems with weapon assembly, I put it as a positive because the concept is quite good, and I would love to see it fleshed out further, e.g., by introducing weapon type as category rather than damage type. This would preserve realism. For example, if there is a sword category, one of them should have a moveset that primarily utilizes slashing, another that primarily utilizes stabbing, one that uses half-swording or so with some strike attacks from the hilt, and one that is balanced in all respects. Something like this might work, and would suit all playstyles. But, it takes a crap ton of work and research, so this is merely a suggestion.

[h1]Final Remarks[/h1]

I personally am not sold on DnD and turn-based combat, so while I appreciate Baldur's Gate 3 getting so much praise, and I have no doubts the praise is rightfully targeted, I argue that Lies of P does the same for the general souls-like genre. Soulsborne and souls-likes are some of my favorite things in life, and all things considered, Lies of P frankly delivers an experience so familiar and yet so memorable that I am happy to consider it not just a souls-like, but a fleshed out Soulsborne game in its own right. I was hoping it would win an award so as to get it more recognition, but oh well, it got nominated at least. It's my personal GOTY :)

I also want to spend more time playing it, but honestly am just too busy to do so. However, I look forward to getting all the achievements, the DLC and the sequels the developers have promised, and I wish them best of luck in topping their own miracle.

9.5/10. This game is so, so fun. Beautiful visuals, sounds and music. I enjoyed the rally mechanic the most, as it rewards aggressive and high risk/high reward playstyles. All the miniboss and boss fights were pretty unique and coherently designed;  I found myself looking forward to each one even in subsequent playthoughs. Also pleasantly surprised by good mob variety as the game progresses, especially when different mob types melded together and gained extended move sets. This kept the field combat and overall gameplay fresh with a small dose of familiarity, lending to a sense of continuity that ties the entire narrative together. Worth every single cent at full price.

By far one of the best games I have ever played, this game never ceased to impress me. For starters, the combat in this game is AMAZING. The high-risk high-reward perfect parry is perfect and makes fights feel more fun and cinematic. If you would rather just doge instead of learning to parry, you can play through the entire game without parrying and not run into any problems. The difficulty in this game is good as well. The fights weren't too hard or too easy, of course some fights were easier than others but there was always a good balance. If you are looking for easier boss fights as well, you could always summon a phantom to help deal damage to the boss and take aggro. Finally, the way weapons work in this game is perfect as well. You can customize almost every weapon in this game and make them tie into your stats and play styles without having to equip a different weapon. Overall, I would rate this game a 9/10 and would recommend this to anyone who is a fan of souls-like games.

This game is a solid and enjoyable experience from beginning to end. Non-From Souls-likes can be hit-or-miss for me, but this one never left me unsatisfied. Combat is challenging but fair, boss fights are all pretty good, lots of diverse weapons and skills. Graphically and artistically, the game looks fantastic. I wish there were more optional areas (I think there's literally only one area you can miss the whole game), but I also appreciate how straightforward it is. Not quite a masterpiece, but I'm looking forward to a potential sequel. 9/10.

I can't believe a goofy, dark, edgy retelling of a 19th century children's novel has become one of my favourite videogames. Lies of P is absolutely incredible. It combines the gameplay of Fromsoftware's two best games (Sekiro and Bloodborne) and condenses it into a nearly perfect 20-30 hour package. It has the best roster of boss fights in any "soulslike" game I've played. One boss near the end of the game rivals Sword Saint Isshin and Slave Knight Gael in terms of quality. The combat is fun and engaging. The tight parry window takes awhile to get used to, but once it clicks it feels great.
If you are a Dark Souls fan, you should play this game. It runs well on PC. No bugs or significant frame rate drops. Highly recommended.

The mix and match of blades and handles is amazing with how many combinations you can do to suit your needs. Personally this is my game of the year.

Plus fantastic bosses, solid story, great atmosphere, just a fantastic game overall.
Genuine Souls game quality with fantastic twists that give it it's own fascinating and unique identity, Lies of P is a Real Boy among a sea of its otherwise artificial competitors.

Good game. Pro tip: Leveling advance (the special stat) on a weapon with no built-in elemental damage (IE, most of them, there are exactly 5 and none of them are boss weapons) will not improve damage on that weapon, even if it has scaling for advance. Advance only improves elemental damage, not physical damage. So don't bother putting an advance crank on a non-elemental weapon. Or, putting an advance based handle on a non-elemental blade.

Intro:
Welcome to the only developers who took a fantasy game with the terrible battle system of Dark-souls theme which whoever likes must be shot immediately and ACTUALLY made a phenomenal masterpiece without ruining it with woke. The game is based on Pinocchio who is trying to stop the puppet frenzy who has turned on the humans and started to massacre everyone. This is totally not the plot to “I Robot” but I like it.

Pros:

Story: Hands down the script that was written for the story was beyond unbelievable, with every chapter the game got better. This game left me in suspense in wanting to find out more. The details they put into the characters, the ways you react to certain events, the choices you can choose to make to alter the entire story will leave you wanting to replay the game again. 

Characters:

A Wonderful job in keeping the Character all the same to the children's book, whilst introducing more into the game. I found that the more you dig into the characters' past the darker the story got, which I thought was more fascinating considering the major plot twists.

Battle-System:

I will put this in for all you masochistic Dark-souls smash your heads against the wall to feel any emotion (over-exaggerating I love you all). Yes the battle system is to be patient and time your block. Whilst doing more forward rolls then the entire Olympic Gymnastic team because that is how realistic fighting is done. Please try this in real life and see what happens <3.

Cons:

Battle-system:

I will put this as a Pro and Con, only because not everyone likes having to focus and be patient in timing your strikes. I miss the old hack and slash like Devil May cry, where you only had to dodge once or twice and move around. I hate this only because when you are exhausted from working all day, you want to play games like this to find out the story you end up dying so many times to the point the game no longer becomes fun. I gave up after completing it once and lost all interest and youtube the other two endings because I no longer wanted to put myself through all that hell again. 

For those who want to just play it for the story. You enjoy the experience of the wonderful storyline of Lies of P, it truly does ruin the gaming experience. 

Overall:

This game I would give it 7.5/10. I truly loved the Story, The plot twist at the end made it worth completing and made my jaw drop. The game truly flourished in this beauty and artwork. It’s upsetting that I can’t give the game a 10/10 only because of the battle system. I wanted to enjoy the game to its fullest but constantly having to dodge and slash and die really put a downer on it. I highly recommend for those that don’t like Dark-soul themed games, just watch some pros on youtube for the story, it’s worth every second and not worth the pain and suffering.

Peace out all and hope you enjoy it.

The parry system is kinda like that of Sekiro, but unlike Sekiro you are encouraged to mix parrying and dodging a lot and weave between them, with some bosses being easy parry targets and others being much easier to dodge roll - but no bosses feeling like only using one or the other alone is the best strategy.

Started playing this game with 0 expectations and Immediately fell in love. I like the level of difficulty this game has to offer but also the amount of utility at your disposal to overcome it. You have multiple ways to deal with enemy attacks, you can guard them or dodge them by rolling. I enjoyed the guarding mechanics especially having come from other games in this genre that punished you for doing so. It was a change of fresh air from constantly spamming rolls. I'm writing this review because I'm concerned that the purported difficulty of the title might put you off from trying it for yourself. First things first, I find this to be much easier compared to Sekiro, Bloodborne, Dark Souls 3 and Elden Ring. This is because parrying, dodging, and blocking are all viable strategies which may be used either in conjunction with each other or by themselves in the course of a boss fight. The health regen from damage taken while blocking is also very generous. Of course, do not expect to breeze through the bosses, they aren't easy. However, they are very learnable, and so long as you go into a fight first with a view to learning/understanding/memorising the patterns and tells before starting to do any damage to the boss, you will get along just fine. When all else fails, I'd say that the summon you get for each boss encounter practically trivialises the boss because of how tanky the summon is. 

You will also have a wide variety of weapon combinations to experiment with to suit your playstyle. So far I've found that the policeman's baton handle with the saw toothed blade work extremely well together, outputting greatsword-like damage with the speed of a medium weapon, but that's just one of many viable sets that you could use in your playthrough. 

With that out of the way, the game is absolutely gorgeous and each new area (of which there are 11 all in) are unique in their design and art style. Game also runs flawlessly on my RTX 2080 with everything on high @ 120fps with dips down to 110-ish on the very very rare occasion which I notice only because I've got the FPS counter in my peripheral vision. 

Kudos to the devs for putting together such a fantastic game!

I was holding off of getting this because of Denuvo and a lack of a demo to check how well the game plays.  As it turns out, this game runs perfectly on my computer.  I have an Nvidia RTX 3060 and I haven't had any stutter or slowdown.  Compared to other recent releases, this is a pleasant surprise.

As for the game itself, I'm loving it.  It's a Soulslike, but all of its mechanics are well thought out and polished.  Getting a perfect block does no damage while blocking early does some damage that can be healed by attacking.  The game also has a stagger mechanic which lets you do massive damage.  The game really reward aggressive gameplay. I kept dying at the first boss until I stopped hiding and looking for openings.  This is not Dark Souls.

This is an excellent souls-like, with creative world building and excellent combat. It clearly takes inspiration from both Bloodborne and Sekiro in its combat systems, with a bit of Dark Souls 3/Elden Ring weapon skills added in for flare. It distinguishes itself from From Software's work by being much more upfront with it's storytelling, allowing most players to grasp the details of the world more easily. It's greatest flaw is that there is a relative lack of build diversity as, after the second boss, weapons can be customized in such a way that where you place your stat investment is significantly less important. The P-Organ System helps with this slightly, but not by much. There is also a relatively low stat soft-cap for both your damage and health stats, after which point leveling up can feel less and less impactful. In short, this game suffers from a sharp drop off in replayability. Overall, I have played to NG+3 and I doubt I will keep playing until new content is available, simply because there was nothing new to do, really. I had every item, had used every weapon/handle combination, and had gotten every ending. That said, doing that still took me a substantial amount of time, and I enjoyed every minute of it. So, in short, this game is excellent and has plenty to offer the souls fan, it just isn't as replayable as some other titles in the genre, which is more than made up for in terms of up-front fun.

In July of this year, I decided to take a deep dive into the Souls-like genre by finally dusting off my copy of Dark Souls III and completing it for the first time. After enjoying my time with the game, I completed Sekiro (a masterpiece) and about half of Elden Ring (a game which I did not have a good time with and probably deserves its own review at some point down the road). Before moving on to Dark Souls, Dark Souls II, or a Dark Souls III replay, I decided to move off the beaten path and check out Lies of P. I am happy to say that Lies of P offers some of the best that a Souls-like has offered thus far.

Lies of P uses a combat system that employs a mix of other Souls-like games, taking the dodging and rolling from Dark Souls and combining it with the "perfect parrying" system of Sekiro. This blend of combat keeps fights feeling urgent while also leaving a lot of choice up to the player as to how they beat certain bosses. Getting a feel for a boss's attacks? Perfect parry them until you break their weapon, negating most of the damage they give out. Finding it hard to learn timing for said attacks? Dodge around them to get behind the boss and sneak attacks in. Even if not every boss is amazing, the combat system feels great and keeps you engaged throughout.

Aesthetically, Lies of P is also a huge success. Using the Pinocchio fairy tale as a barebones framework, the devs construct a world that blends steampunk influence with corruption, zombie-like creature design. The overlap between these two, especially in the latter half of the game, is striking. These gorgeous visuals combine with a lush soundtrack in a really masterful way.

My major gripes with Lies of P are mostly found in the third act of the game, and largely have to do with an overreliance on status effect encounters. Balancing in a Souls-like context is tough, and oftentimes devs have to ride a very fine line between satisfying challenge and frustrating challenge. Unfortunately, the amount of enemies (both bosses and normal enemies) in the final third of the game that inflict obnoxious status effects on you is staggering. These status effects range from decaying your weapon faster to just killing you immediately. They are easily the worst the game has to offer, which may be a positive thing in a game full of stuff to love.

The boss quality in Lies of P is great overall. Although the game has its fair share of your average beast-like Souls bosses, there are some pretty stellar fights scattered throughout that feel like fast duels which really force you to learn there moves. One in particular, Laxasia the Complete, is perhaps one of the best fights in a Souls game period. The feeling of slowly learning her attacks and chipping away at her until you finally best her calls to mind many of the best encounters in Sekiro, which is some of the highest praise I could offer a game of this caliber.

All in all, Lies of P is a very good Souls-like that makes improvements not yet incorporated even by Fromsoft. I look forward to the DLC for Lies of P, as well as the other games they make down the road. If you are at all interested in Souls-likes, you would do well to check out Lies of P..

Picked it up because of the autumn sale, based on other reviews. This is definitely an Elden Ring-style HUD with the combat speed of something like Bloodborne. Very much a "get gud" game, and when you get combat right it feels. So. F***ing. Good. 

Art style is also awesome; like a marriage of Bioshock's art deco with Victorian steam punk, Lovecraftian horror. I don't know how the designers made a bunch of really disparate ideas and themes come together so fluidly with a Pinocchio story in a Souls-like game, but it's phenomenally done and absolutely scratches the twink-murder itch finishing a souls game leaves in your heart.

Edit: Played about 20hr more of it and I still love it. 

@Devs: Major QOL improvement could be made on the P-Organ screen making the select system free-move with the joystick instead of grid/cell-based. It's really clunky and awful to navigate as it is.

Edit again: I'm to end game bosses/areas and the way they managed difficulty gets cheap. It's the trap many Souls games fall into where instead of making bosses require consistent, great skills, they just let the bosses cheat. Whether that's making them meatshields, energizer stamina bunnies, impenetrable poise, or whatever, it's lame and cheap and having to constantly cheese minibosses (because you sneeze and there's a miniboss/elite at the end), it's putting a negative slant on a game that's been so incredible up until this point.

I had my doubts, but now that I'm roughly 65% into this game, I must recall the wisdom of my old AP English teacher from high school. 

"Sometimes originality can be overrated. There's nothing wrong with a cliche so long as it's a cliche done right."

Yeah, they've earned full price.

[h1] Lies of P is the sleeper hit of 2023 [/h1]

(Score and summary at the bottom)

I want to preface this review by saying that before I played Lies of P, I have never finished, or even made it to a boss of any of the other Soulsborne games I tried. I played the beginning of Bloodborne at a friend's place a few years ago and got destroyed for a few hours without making it to a boss though had fun learning the game, and I also own the ps3 version of Demon's Souls, which I stopped playing really early on as well, and after having finished Lies of P, I'd love to revisit at some point.

I'm a bit of a literature guy and love games that tell darker retellings of classic literature (if you haven't played Alice Madness Returns, 100% recommend that game) so seeing this game retell the story of Pinocchio, it caught my attention, even with many reviews stating this game is harder than any other Soulsborne they had played.

The story for this game is so interesting, with a memorable cast of characters that you truly start to care about as you progress through the game. Each character brings something to the table, and also subtly hint at information that'll make more sense later on. The tragic world presented here is top tier and the environmental story telling is some of the best I have seen.

Now for the meat of the game, the gameplay. I've heard Lies of P described as Sekiro and Bloodborne combined and having watched videos of Bloodborne, and picking up and finishing Sekiro after finishing Lies of P, I think that's a fair description of the game. This game is brutally hard and the best advice I can give is be patient. Because the devs are evil and made most of the enemies puppets, the arms on swings will wind up 4 or 5 times and then just snap onto you. Enemies will constantly fake you out, delay attacks, attack much sooner or later than you'll expect, the variety of encounters in this game is fantastic and makes every new area you explore so much fun. I don't wanna spoil encounters for those who want to enter the game blind, but I'd say the challenge in this game for veterans of the Souls-like genre is that NEOWIZ knows how you like to play and they basically give you the finger. I actually think me entering this game with no experience in the genre helped because I didn't have a set play style and habits for tackling games like this, so ironically, a game that challenges the most hardened Soulsborne players may be easier for folks who are new to the genre! Though having picked up Dark Souls 1 after finishing Lies of P and Sekiro, it saddens me that the "parry everything" strat isn't nearly as viable in DS1 so in a way I ended up developing habits that'll make Dark Souls even harder for my first time playing which will be interesting to see as I progress that game further!

The music in this game is absolutely beautiful and the use of vinyls in the hotel to help Pinocchio gain his humanity is such an interesting way to use music in a game. Also the use of lying throughout the game makes for interesting story beats as well. It's established early in the game that puppets cannot lie, Pinocchio being the exception, and I enjoy this different take on the classic story since [spoiler] the game equates being truthful with being a puppet, whereas lying is being human. Painting this picture that there's nothing more human than to deceive, to tell a lie. Even the death screen in the game (which you will die a lot playing this game and ever Souls-like needs an iconic death screen) with the phrase "Lie or Die" hints at the fact that lying is humanity. I love the use of this, it's like the game's way of saying that to be truthful is to obey, is to be a puppet. Whereas lying is to think for yourself, to rebel, to be a human. Which also adds to the character of Geppetto who constantly says that Pinocchio needs to be a "good boy" and always tell the truth. I love the way the game subtly hints that Geppetto is just trying to manipulate Pinocchio, and later in the game Pinocchio becomes the puppeteer. When Geppetto asks if you trust him, you already know damning information about Geppetto, so if you pick yes, Geppetto believes you since he's convinced you're still a "good boy", but in reality, that answer is a lie. [/spoiler]

I know I put spoilers over the last paragraph, and if you haven't played this game, I highly encourage you to enter this experience as blind as you can in regards to story, because this is one of the best I have seen in a long time.

Lies of P is going to get a 10/10 and I am extremely picky with scores, but even with a few minor flaws like back stabbing being a bit finicky, Lies of P is one of the best games I have ever played and I loved it so much I immediately started playing Sekiro Shadows Die Twice and finished it. If you have the patience to learn this game's systems, you'll find probably the best Souls-like game not made by Fromsoft, I'd argue Lies of P may actually be better than some of the Fromsoft games. There's so much more I could cover in this review like the creative weapon assembly system, the immaculate level design, and the incredible boss fights, but I think these things are best experienced for yourself. 100% buy this game right now, it is absolutely worth it!

This is my first souls-like game so I don’t really have something I can compare this to.

Nevertheless, I loved the game. I loved the visuals and gameplay. I like the fact that you get to prioritize which attribute you want to increase. I also like that the game doesn’t rely heavily on grinding and that you can defeat bosses through skill—which can be increased as you try to defeat a mini-boss/boss. I have issues with the dodging, blocking, and parry system but I realized that this makes the game challenging.

I highly recommend this game 👌🏻

If I didn't look at who the developer was, and if you lied to my face and told me that this game was made by FromSoftware, I would have 100% believed you, without a doubt. It is uncanny, how much this game resembles the Soulsborne games in all the good ways. The art direction, the animation style, the feel of the combat, the voice acting, etc... And while the resemblance is uncanny, it does have its own unique setting, atmosphere, and story from FromSoft games. It manages to stand on its own as a unique game, and it's probably among one of if not the best soulslike games I've played.

My Game of the Year without hesitation. Magnificent, with immersive gameplay, a dark atmosphere that will make you feel lonely and desperate in a nihilistic world that is not without reminding our current times, where technology has destroyed society. While dystopic games often fall into clichés, Lies of P surprised me many times, making the experience less linear and more organic.

As for the gameplay, I don't know why some people say this is harder than Elden Ring. I personally found it less difficult; if you choose a weapon specialization, it's extremely fair. The variety of mechanics make the fights satisfying, and the bosses are quite interesting and different from one another.

I didn't know NEOWIZ & Round8 Studio before playing this game and I will be sure to keep an eye on their work. Hugely talented developers. Thanks a ton for offering us this gem of a game. Cheers!
Super fun and the game gets harder as you are getting op to keep the scale in check its a great game.

This is the soulslike that i have always wanted. There's an actual story not just an esoteric convoluted mess of lore that you need a phd to understand. The combat is tight and flows really well with a mixture of dodging, blocking and parrying.  The weapon craft system is a really great addition to the soul formula. This game also respects my time. When i lose souls in a boss arena, they're waiting outside for me, instead of buying homeward bones or beating the whole game to get a return item, it was given to me inside of 4 hours.  So far this is my favorite souls game, fromsoft or otherwise.

I haven't ever played a soulslike game before, but Lies of P caught my attention for the dark, steampunk retelling of Pinocchio. The game is quite brutal, but extremely rewarding and satisfying when you learn how to play and face off against enemies. 
The tone set for the game is perfect; foreboding, haunting, mysterious and intriguing. The more you progress through the story, the more you want to learn of it, the characters, the lore, everything. 
With how customizable weapons and stats are, along with a few choices of dialogue (and the fact there's three endings), there's replayability to be had with this game. I am yet to complete it, but I am already looking forward to another play through.
This game is absolutely incredible and I want to see more from this studio of similar games, doing a fun twist on a classic fairy tale. I look forward to it.

[h1]Very good, highly recommend, 10/10. [/h1]

[h2]As difficult as Sekiro, but with more freedom in equipment. [/h2]Combat is incredibly satisfying, moves are flashy and diverse, and (perfect) blocks feel weighty. None of the enemy moves felt unfair, and I could easily understand why I died and how to fix that each time. Many enemies and bosses suffer from joint pain like in Elden Ring, so you'll be waiting up to 7 full seconds between their attack starting animation and their actual swing, so beware. Weapon/Legion arm abilities are unique and rewarding to use, was surprised multiple times at how much damage they would do. The weapon/handle swapping system was interesting, but didn't use it all too much as I ran boss weapons after chapter 4 or so. Elemental weaknesses can be figured out without an external guide and contribute quite a bit. 

[h2]The music is amazing[/h2], I stayed in the lobby way longer than I should have just to enjoy the disks. I just wish there was a way to continue his piano performance. 

[h2]The environments and level design are insane[/h2], the areas flow into each other naturally, with some creative shortcuts back to stargazers (checkpoints/bonfires) and even between areas. The final area was dramatic and memorable. They kept off-and-on players in mind; the progression through the game is straightforward, and forgetting where to go is not a problem.

fantastic entry into the genre, and one with a boisterously unique presence. fans of souls-like will feel right at home but challenged, map exploration is vast and rewarding, a story you can actually find, visuals kick butt and you'll always want more. Not a perfect game: some bosses feel cheap and unfair, and one is completely not interesting or fun, but instead frustrating and unfair, if you've played you know exactly which one.
But growing pains aside, this is a strong contender for those looking for a new one of their old favorites. Just be patient with its more frusterating mechanics.

I adore this game. It went from being a planned intermediate while waiting for another games release to one of my all time favorite games. I cannot recommend it enough. If anyone ends up reading this please pick it up. You won't regret it.

The combat in this game just feel so smooth, the player can play in so many ways depending on their playstyle.  Plus there is a sizable amount of unique weapons, each one with its abilities , it feels refreshing to switch one's weapon. 
Unlike a lot of souls games, this game is generous with upgrading materials , so the player can use different weapons throughout the game.

The one downside to this game compared to fromsoft games is it is a bit too linear, there isn't a lot of side content to fill in the gaps, exploration most of the time is straight forward, not many secrets lying around.

Besides that, this is my best souls game outside FROMSOFT.
Also considering this is new dev, this game has perfect performance for my gtx 1060 , best settings no frame drops. It is well optimised.

I do highly suggest this game if you love soulslike games.

It's early days but so far it just seems so incredibly PRETENTIOUS!

Things that should be easy are made unnecessarily difficult to create the illusion of challenge. Things that should be simple are made unnecessarily complicated to create the illusion of sophistication. A great reminder of why hack 'n slash is a fairly niche product.

Movement is incredibly stilted and jerky. Maybe this improves as the character develops or maybe it's part of the silly puppet conceit. Either way, I'm finding myself persevering rather than enjoying. I'm playing out of frustration and drive to beat this stupid game rather than revelling in a new world or basking in a sense of satisfaction. This game seems to be 90% about mastering the control system and 10% making your way through the world. I'd like those proportions switched around.

The story so far is confused and completely idiotic. I have no idea what the "lying" metaphor is supposed to contribute other than adding even more pretentiousness. This game does not need more conceit. It has plenty without the cryptic, apparently meaningless, figurative plot device.

The American accents of the voice actors in an Italian story with a Victorian London-ish setting are so tacky and tasteless. Every time I hear California drawl coming from a supposed East-End street rat, it jars me back to reality. The soundtrack overall is nothing special and the music is AWFUL and I cannot get any sort of respectable surround sound happening.

Graphics are UE5 beautiful but sparse and it runs really well, but this game is so, so full of itself. Think Final Fantasy takes a trip to 19th Century Europe. EEeeeuww!

At least the awful voice work adds a little comic relief.

This game is almost a masterpiece. It is by far, leaps and bounds beyond any other "Soulslike" game out there. No, I don't feel it is as good with the combat mechanics of Elden Ring, which was fleshed out slowly but surely over the course of more than a decade. The combat is still very solid and very well polished, with a big emphasis on parrying, but don't let that discourage you because the dodge works too, just a bit less forgiving than a game like Elden Ring is. Where this game falls behind in combat to the Dark Souls franchise, it stands toe to toe, and in a lot of aspects, exceeds it, in atmosphere. I also feel that this game improves an aspect of Soulsborne games with it's weapon customization. You can get some really cool combination of weapons, which I really think will be expanded upon further in future dlc or future releases from this studio. I'm pretty sure this is their first game from this studio, and I really look forward to what they produce next. Since they refuse to release Bloodborne on PC, this is the game for you then.

Overall recommendation 8/10

Has many of the best qualities of souls-like games. They do a good job with the atmosphere like most games in this genre. Definitely less build variety than Elden ring or Dark Souls, but they still leave a decent amount of room for customizing weapons play styles. I ended up using my starting weapon for the entire game, as every time I switched to another one it just did not feel as fun. That just proves that you can pick any weapon you want or customize and level it up to have for your entire play through if that's what you have the most fun with. 

I would say its on the easier side of souls-like games, but I would also not call it an easy game. I very very rarely died outside of a boss fight throughout all 28 hours of playing. Blocking/guarding is also very forgiving as the mechanic called Guard Regain lets you get back some of the health you got while blocking if you hit enemies after taking blocked damage. If you use the specters to help you with boss fights, many of them become almost too easy as the specter will soak most damage and the boss will just focus them while you freely get in damage. Without summoning specters the boss fights are challenging but fun. Most of the bosses and their move sets feel fair with only the occasional cringe "what am I supposed to even do against that" move. The hardest boss in the game is an optional boss at the end, but I recommend fighting it. 

There are different physical damage types in the game (slash/pierce/blunt) that both the player and the enemies do / are resistant to but I literally never paid attention to the detail (except the very end of the game) and everything went smoothly, I'd imagine it would matter more in NG+, though. The elemental dmg types, however, should definitely be noted and utilized as they are extremely helpful and switching your resistances for them can be a life saver. 

I found it was much more fun and rewarding to parry than to dodge most of the time. so more like Sekiro than DS/ER in that regard.

A masterful entry in the "soulslike" genre.  While Lies of P seems to bring only minor enhancements, the more you play the game the more you realize how huge the ramifications those enhancements are.  Great graphics, music, sound effects, storyline, level design, and especially art direction and combat propel this to the top tier of soulslikes only occupied by actual From Software games.

The game is great, it is refreshing to see a truly amazing souls-like outside FromSoft. However there are a few issues to be aware of. The parry mechanics in the game are not great and for a game that seems to have it so vital to the overall gameplay having such punishing guarding feels odd, there is just so few frames for perfect guards, and being unable to cancel attacks into dodge rolls on top of this feels like an odd choice, but this isnt a FromSoft game and it will probably grow on most people. There also seems to be some sort of bug that causes the game to massively hemorrhage frames and I am unsure what causes it, there were many times in my gameplay in which I went from over 150 constant frames to suddenly 10 for multiple minutes and capping the frame rate did not seem to help. Other than those two issues the game is great the environments are lovely the music is great and it really fills the hole many are looking to fill since bloodborne, you can tell this is made by people who get what makes a souls-like good.

Edit: The frame issue I was having has since been seemingly fixed so I feel there is really no reason not to play this game if you are a souls-like fan.

So I've played a couple soulslike games on top of Dark Souls/Elden Ring/Bloodborne, and typically they're good at scratching the itch but tend to have flaws that put them below that of their namesakes.

I think Lies of P is the first one where I feel like a soulslike is giving From Software a run for its money. It is absurdly high quality in a way that I'd only expect from the creators of the genre.

The combat (which, of course, is paramount in any soulslike) is great and the hitboxes are very tight, but it takes some getting used to since your dodge is significantly weaker baseline. It has less distance than a fat roll and definitely less i-frames. On the other hand, there is now a focus on perfect blocking, especially since enemies will occasionally throw out a bright-red Fury attack which pierces i-frames and normal blocks (and thus can only be perfect blocked). The Guard Regain system further encourages blocking over dodging by allowing you to restore health lost during normal blocks by fighting back, Bloodborne-rally style.

Ultimately though, you can upgrade your dodge and keep your equip load under 30% for Light encumbrance (which is much more valuable here than in dark souls) if you want to focus on dodging over blocking, and doing so is perfectly viable. There's really only one boss that very nearly requires perfect blocking, and if you've played the game you know who they are.

Your combat options are also quite expansive. Non-boss weapons have a blade and a handle slot, and you can mix and match blades & handles of different weapons to find a combination that suits your playstyle. The blade determines the base attack power of the weapon and the speed of the moveset, while the handle determines the moveset itself and how the attack power scales with your stats. You can stick a greatsword on a rapier handle and poke enemies with a giant stick from 3 meters away if you want, but it'll be a lot slower than a dagger on the same handle. I found this system really weird at first, but I appreciate the possibilities it allows for in builds.

The presentation and world are very high quality. The environments are on par with Dark Souls level design, in my opinion [spoiler]with a few less poison swamps, thankfully[/spoiler]. I thoroughly enjoyed exploring them, and there's a lot of secret items to be found. The story, while not incredible necessarily, is better than Dark Souls. That's honestly not a high bar though--nobody really plays Dark Souls for the story. You are the only puppet that can lie, and you are heavily encouraged to do so. This is one of the few pieces of media I can recall where lying is treated as a [i]good[/i] thing.

There's some very helpful quality of life improvements too. NPCs with new dialogue are highlighted on the map selection screen, making it easy to track the different questlines and know when to talk to them again. None of the Dark Souls games did this, and Elden Ring only noted NPC positions in the world, not if they had new dialogue.

The soundtrack is also really good. On top of the typical area & boss themes, you'll also unlock pieces of music to listen to on a gramophone in the hub area. While you are incentivized to listen to them, they don't really need it. The tracks are great.

One thing I do find odd though is that it seems like there's some low quality explanations for some abilities & upgrades. "Lowers the Guard Regain reduction" is not exactly easy to understand, especially when it actually means "the amount of health lost from guarding that you can restore by attacking decays slower".

Overall, this is--surprisingly--well worth the price, and that's rare for a $60 game nowadays. I went in expecting to scratch the soulslike itch but instead got something that goes beyond Dark Souls in many ways.

A great souls like game for beginner gamer who want to have fun playing the game without too much difficulty.

Pro :
- Attribute is simple, you literaly only upgrading 4 attribute based on you play-style.
- Combat mechanic is fun, with so many weapon to choose and combine without worrying about requirement.
- Boss is quite slow, but hit hard. Dodging or block is recommended.
- Great level design with interconnecting path to stargazer (save point)

Cons :
- Pricey for a game with only 30-40 hours gameplay. (Only buy on discount)
- Few weapon choice on early game.
- Repetitive normal mob/enemies, kinda boring facing almost same enemy with just slightly different design.
- Controller disconnected sometime for no reason

Lies of P is the first Souls-like to match and even surpass FromSoftware's creations. I know how that sounds, and I wouldn't have believed me either, but you will regret skipping this if you're a fan of the genre or fun in general.

Unfortunately, some people are throwing around a lot of vague complaints and buzzwords, saying the game "feels bad" or it's "unfair" or it's "poorly designed." This is to cope with the fact that their self-awarded "Souls Veteran" badge doesn't exempt them from their own adage: git gud.

I played and finished this game on Xbox Gamepass but bought it on Steam because I really want to see what this studio does next. 

I did not expect to enjoy this game as much as I did. Now, I've played a few FromSoftware games, and as much as there are undeniable qualities to them, all of them have tended to frustrate me for some reason or other, sometimes leading me to leave them unfinished. So when I decided to try Lies of P on Gamepass, I went in with some apprehension. But not only did the game prove my misgivings wrong, it actually made me realise exactly what I didn't like about FromSoftware titles in the first place (it isn't the difficulty). 

Yes, you heard me right: I actually prefer this game to FromSoftware games in general. This of course being my own opinion, please don't hate me too much. 

If I had to summarise why I prefer Lies of P: this game is much better at teaching the player how to "git gud". This includes feeling fair, encouraging skill and not shaming failure. Mostly, the changes Round8 made could be considered slight tweaks to the genre’s formula, but I think they impact the experience in a profound way. 

Yes, of course the player should get their ergo back at the entrance of a boss room so they can focus on actually learning the boss. 

Yes, of course ergo should be recoverable even after multiple deaths, only in smaller amounts, so that players who are not as skilled can still level up and not feel shamed in being in the process of learning, not just reward already skilled players by making the game easier for them because they lose their ergo less often and thus can increase their stats more easily. 

Yes, of course the game should offer situations where the player can actually take mobs by surprise if they're observant instead of feeling like the whole world is just waiting in ambush for this one dude to arrive at their spot. 

Yes, of course a game whose gameplay revolves around melee parrying and dodges should be very controlled with a status effect that results in instant death, since the mechanic circumvents that gameplay loop. 

There’s very little bulls***t, no health item farming, no enemies that snipe you from the other side of the map, no excessive groups of enemies, no locking out the player out of side content as punishment for dying too much and, again, no abuse of the instant death status effect to hinder the player from using their actual skill in the combat system. 

I thoroughly enjoyed learning this game, even if I had to try bosses again and again. The difficulty never felt unfair, and I didn't feel like I was slapped and mocked for failing, unlike even some of FromSoftware's own games. 

Plus all the other things that other people have already remarked upon: great boss designs, linear but very polished exploration, very good graphics with great performance on PC and straightforward but effective storytelling.

Some cynical people could point out that this is just a copy of what FromSoftware does. But even if it is, it's a great copy, and my wish now is that FromSoftware would copy Lies of P.

I can say without a hint of exaggeration that Lies of P is the best souls-like ever. I was anticipating this ever since the first trailer dropped two years ago, and it absolutely delivered. The best way to get across how fantastic this game is is to list everything I DON'T like about it, as it's a very short list. Walls and obstacles hate you and your weapons bounce off them way too much. A couple particular bosses are a bit annoying. That's it. You get a variety of weapons with unique movesets, and the option to attach any weapon's blade to any other's handle is a real game changer that more or less guarantees you can make at least one weapon you really like. In particular, I like that weapon durability is now interesting instead of an unnecessary hindrance like it is in most games. Weapons will take damage and break in real time unless you repair them with an infinite-use grindstone, though it takes a few seconds. This makes for fun scenarios against bosses when you have to pick the right time to repair.

I'm told Lies of P is particularly hard in a genre known for being hard, but honestly I don't get why. It does expect you to perfect guard at least sometimes, and it is rather precise to do, but it can be adjusted to with a bit of time. The game will certainly lay you out at first, but the same can be said of the likes of Dark Souls 3 and Sekiro. There are a lot of movesets to learn, and dying is a natural part of that process. I wouldn't say any of the bosses quite reach Sword Saint Isshin status, though they will offer quite the challenge. The areas are engaging to explore, full of secrets to look out for and regular enemies arranged in interesting ways that'll keep you on your toes. Any elite enemies that are particularly tough to deal with will reward you fairly for killing them. The plethora of shortcuts and the number of times you loop back to the hub area really evoke that feeling of "Whoa THIS place was next to THAT place all along?" that Dark Souls 1 gives you, despite being far more linear. It's remarkable how interconnected everything is. Compared to most of From Software's repertoire giving you a pocket dimension of sorts to settle down in, Hotel Krat feels very much like a location in the world just like any other. Your route will take you to and from Hotel Krat several times throughout the game as more locations are unlocked.

The story makes for a unique take on the classic fairy tale that is Pinocchio. Most famously, the puppet's nose would grow when he lies. Here, though, you are encouraged to lie because it is a distinctly human act, and something puppets normally cannot do. Other human things, mainly appreciating music, are encouraged as well. It actually TELLS you its story as it happens, which I guess some people dislike, but I consider it a refreshing change of pace in a genre that generally expects you to dig for story elements yourself. Still, it doesn't exactly spoon feed you the events of the game. You do have to be paying attention, and it rewards you plenty for doing so.

I would touch on other aspects like the graphics, but just look at the pictures on the store page. It's gorgeous. The collectible music discs give you some lovely songs to enjoy. I'm a big fan of boss themes, but most of them in this game are a bit underwhelming with a few exceptions. Overall, though, I cannot give Lies of P a glowing enough recommendation. Almost nobody in my friend circles has even tried it, which is incredibly sad.

A Souls-borne game based on the story of Pinocchio, but that’s where all similarities end. A twisted take on lies, where instead of becoming our downfall, lies become our way of achieving humanity and protecting our companions. Compelling characters, easily digestible lore, and likable and evil characters alike. The main character P seeks to save the city of Krat from the mad puppets only to fall in a rabbit hole of an even greater evil. 
Pros: 
Smooth gameplay, fast combat and perfect blocking system is where action combat is streamlined together for the most satisfying gameplay experience.	
Rechargeable pulse cell (heals) during combat, a nice way to reward the players who excel in combat and make use of the Perfect Parry system it has saved me many times during critical moments. 
Custom weapon set-ups, high replay value, humanity system, sound design, P-Organ system.
Cons: 
Camera issues in critical moments: This was infuriating at times, when you are cornered by a large enemy and the camera shrinking into itself making combat near impossible and you end up in a stun lock and are unable to escape. 
Stats have a significant efficiency drop-off after a specific level which makes leveling useless after a certain point. Maxing all stats at 100 will be not much different from 50s across the board. 
TLDR:
Despite some issues I had during my experience they were significantly next to nothing compared to all the positives. I normally don’t go out of my way to plat a game but this game is different and heading into NG+ ill be finishing the last few achievements. All in all, this game is amazing and having played DSIII, I’ll say this with confidence: Lies of P is the best non-From Soft game ever. Highly recommended, even at full price, it’s worth every damn penny.

Aside from various plot holes and some cringe/nonsensical dialogue - all forgivable - there are some major issues with this game for me personally. I will try to keep this spoiler-free or have mild spoilers at most.

[b] About the reviewers perspective [/b]
I am a soulslike enjoyer (mostly FromSoft) and bought this game because of the Bloodborne aesthetics and reviews comparic it to the former.
My negative review is based on my personal experience and is meant for players like me.
The game is not bad, but rather infuriatingly close to being good.

[b] Immersion [/b]
The entire scenario of the game is that something horrible happened, lots of people were killed and we try to find out why.
The atmosphere is grim and dark... until you have carefree conversations with residents needing a bottle of wine, unarmed civilians showing up in deadly zones, a cheerful hub area and the most annoying PoS sidekick imaginable who explains the most obvious shit and gives us "comedic relief" we didn't want or need.

[b] Design [/b]
This game is trying to copy Dark Souls / Bloodborne wherever possible, from status effects to weight, leveling, hub, stats, bonfires, traversal, jumping and dozens of other mechanics to actual copied substages.
This is not an issue most of the time and often feels familiar. They overdid it in quite a few areas though.
In some levels, you can encounter 5+ doors that open from the other side and 5+ collapsing floors/bridges.
Another issue (labeled "great QoL over Bloodborne") is that every collectible, sidequest, backtracking,... is spoonfed to you by showing it as "teleport here!" or "this NPC wants to talk!", making it worthless to think about things you encounter.

[b] Gameplay / Combat [/b]
Traversal is mostly fine, while the combat varies between tough and interesting fights, grinding through hordes of mobs and complete horseshit enemies.
I love tough bossfights. I want to be challenged and die a few (dozen) times until I figure things out.
Some enemies and bosses are just ridiculously annoying and it felt like luck/rng plays a big role in too many fights, while other fights are trivial. The parry timings and attack times feel disconnected at times.
There seems to be close to no hyperarmor for your character which makes slow weapons, especially charge attacks, incredibly frustrating to use at times when an enemy deals close to no dmg but cancels your attacks over and over again.
Many enemies are recycled over and over again, just as adds or with a different color or more numerously.

[b] TL;DR [/b]
Nowhere near Bloodborne levels of greatness.
Decent when on sale.

[b] Addendum [/b]
Addendum: other reviewers talk at length about pacing and camera issues and the generally weird nature of some decisions like the fact that this game is - by design - unsure whether it wants to be dodge and hit, block and hit or aggressive.
The plot holes only get more nonsensical towards the end.

Lies of P is very satisfying to play on a moment-to-moment basis and offers an addictive sense of progression in your personal skills as well as the story. If you want to play a """souls-like""" then play this. While this game borrows very very heavily from its predecessors, it executes each mechanic far better than any of From Software's games.

One of my main critiques is that there are a lot of two-phase boss fights where if you die in the second phase you have to redo the first before you can try again. This gets exceedingly tedious, particularly in the penultimate fight of the game, which gets boring after the first couple of times you beat it since all of the boss's attacks are very samey and drawn out, and its health pool is predictably bloated. 

Lowering the required number of parries for the boss's weapon to break, then concluding the first phase if the player manages to meet that requirement could rectify this issue. To be clear, the boss's weapon shouldn't remain broken in the following phase. As it is, the enemy weapon breakage mechanic is very underutilized, which is a shame since it's a really fun addition.

The fourth boss needs some polish. There are some faulty hit boxes,
It's not Elden Ring, but a great linear adventure souls like experience. Sometimes you just need a good fun linear game to vibe with and this one has great story and music.

[*][strike]not sure if i haven't unlocked it yet, but so far i haven't seen a respec option for your ergo level and quartz skilltree - this is desperately needed imo[/strike] there IS indeed a respec option - but you cannot change your path. if you chose strength - well - sucks to be you, the best weapon in the game by a landslide has S scaling in dexterity, so enjoy 6 wasted levels you will never get back
[*]equipment and amulets do not appear on your character and make a visual difference - a big missed opportunity - sad
[*]outfits and masks do nothing - they are just visual. feels completely useless. would be incredible if they would add some bonuses and stats - like grime did with a patch later on
[*]i get that it's supposed to be pinocchio but i would have loved a character creator
[*]imo enemies in the later chapters need to reward more souls (ergo). the very first enemies in the game give 60 - the ones in the very last chapter give 180. Leveling takes forever in the end
[/list]

Why this game fails at being the very thing it has stolen from far superior games.  Summed up in one word "Balance" the one thing all of FromSoft gets right and what makes them great. This.....doesnt do, it has a weapon customization gimmick, thats the extent of the originality here. It took all the negative aspects of souls games and made them features. Fat Rolling, nobody starts a souls game and immediately over encumbers and starts fat rolling and says, "yup, this is how i want to play this" well you said, "hold my beer because im going to make dodge rolling crap so you have to use our block mechanic."

Your block mechanic is like Sekiro, but worse, if you miss the perfect block in Sekiro you still block 100% of the damage, here its, perfect or die, you dont have the standing as a developer to demand, block perfect or die and like it. FromSoft can, they dont, but they can, you....cant. You havent figured out the balance portion to demand such things. Why is my carry weight stat the second highest investment, second only to my main damage stat......thats should not be, ever, its a failure on your part to have found balance, instead you artificially manipulate depth and complexity by making it so for every 2 points in one stat, I HAVE to put one in carry weight, so by the end of the game i can barely have 2 weapons and the part upgrades teetering on "HEAVY" and "SLIGHTLY HEAVY" again, this is something that should not be, especially when every single enemy has super human, uninterruptible attacks, when you can get whacked out of your weapons special move in its last few frames, zero "HYPER ARMOR" one of those balance things you failed to take into account from the games you stole yours from.

Why does every single enemy have unlimited stamina with the ability to chain 4-8 hit combos back to back then performing the unblockable move that i no longer can block because i missed one perfect block in one of those furies from your standard enemy, it just ramps up for bosses. Again, zero balance, enemies clearly do not have to follow the same rules of physics your confined to, apparently we're the only puppet that cant move like an X-Man, cant barely roll out of his own way.
Enemies have infinite tracking, even while in the air, they can turn and hit you because they dont want you dodge, they want you to use their block mechanic and thats it, if they didnt, it wouldnt punish you for just blocking or rolling out of the way, maybe they decided it was too easy with an actual dodge roll, so they created a problem for artificial depth and character.
Either way, you failed.

Where are all the souls streamers doing no hit runs? why are all the fans of this game asking, "why its not universally loved as the greatest souls game." Because its not, plain and simple, it lacks the balance FromSoft has spent decades perfecting. Sure there are a few no hit runs, but NOWHERE near the level of the actual Souls franchise you obviously got your.....inspiration from. It had potential but is ruined by the constraints you hide behind the weapon customization.

One of the best souls-like games I have played, at first I hear a lot of people say that this game is similar to Bloodborne, but other than the setting that is very far from the truth. This is not a Bloodborne-like game, it is a Sekiro-like game and if you play this long enough you will understand why. Especially true towards the end game where you will be perfect-guarding/guarding more than dodging (especially true for my gameplay). Compared to the fast fluid dodging of Bloodborne, this games dodging mechanic is not as smooth, and can feel clumsy at times (my personal opinion) So just like how Sekiro also have dodging, it is not the main mechanic in defending yourself in battle.. instead you have to learn the deflect timing to be efficient in battle, very very similar to this game where guarding the attacks seem more battle efficient, more so if you can get the timing right and do a perfect guard (THOUGH! Sekiro has a far better fight mechanic, i'm not saying the fighting is bad in this game, just not as tight in terms of timing). Now that that is out of the way, this game is extremely well made, I had encountered no errors, no bugs and no lags whatsoever! (there are occasional weird textures but very negligible) Kudos to the developers for making such a well made game, and not mistaken this is their FIRST souls-like game too and to make it almost at the same level as FROMSOFTWARE I am extremely impressed. Will wait patiently for the DLC and hope for more games like this from this developer in the future!

Underrated and extremely worth getting if you like the genre. Probably the best souls-like that continues to innovate on the core design. The modular upgrade system (P-organ), the weapon crafting system, and simple design concepts like leaving souls/ergo in front of the boss arena and marking side quest progression changes at travel stations are all welcome design changes building upon what Fromsoftware has done. Combat is the best its ever been since Sekiro and art direction/animation is great at every point in the game. The music was always good and sometimes great. I genuinely enjoyed collecting all the records and listening to them all the way through. The story and the lore were both interesting and interwoven nicely with the gameplay and decisions made by the playable character. Using Pinocchio the the backbone is a nice touch compared to the drawn out dark fantasy settings (Demon/Dark Souls + Elden Ring) to the point in which I want to read the original work. I've always appreciated multiple endings and NG+ material, but this is the first game that I've fully committed to completing fully. Thankfully, the game offers some additional content and intensives for doing so. There are some areas/aspects that could be improved on and some design choices that may feel lackluster for players. The game is strictly designed linearly and that might not sit well with returning souls veterans right off the heels of Elden Ring, which touted its open world design. At the same time, the level design for each chapter seems fairly basic. The path the player travels never strays too far from the main path and there are very few dead ends. While this may sound like a good thing, some people - myself included - still like getting lost and exploring paths with perhaps minor rewards. Minor upgrades and and weapons maybe hidden throughout the levels but that sense of exploration is nearly gone.
Arguably, "Lies of P" is one of the absolute best titles in the Souls-like genre.

I am revisiting my review after playing ng+ and ng++ and replayed the game to ng and ng+ second time. I played each update from the start. Saying that this game is like incredibly good. Before updates their was alot of complaints about difficulty but even before the updates the game was incredibly fair and always gave you tools you needed to fight any boss let that be a Electric type of weapon to deal damage on puppet types or throwables to deal with gank fights. The boss roster is incredibly strong as well with i think outside of sekiro might have the best boss line up quality wise in souls games in general. Very fun combat loop as well with parrying/blocking and dodging.But you might be wondering what makes this game stick out  compared to other games like darksouls or bloodborne. Besides its more Bioshock like aesthetic its very linear in level design which is really up to you if you dislike that or not since i believe some people might enjoy linear and less confusing/Convoluted layout (and i know a decent amount of people have been turned off by the souls series for being as confusing/convoluted and this is a great game for people who want to play a souls game but not get a headache and need a wiki to find stuff) It also has alot of good QOL (from elevators resetings to tell you when you can level up by turning your ergo blue their just alot of good QOL that doesnt make it a hassle) and brings a unique weapon system i haven't seen in a souls game which is a combo system for handle and blades. Blades are the damage/attack type/ Elemental/ and range/speed with each blade having its own fable art. While the handle defines the attack animation and has its own fable arts and their around 29 Handles and blades that are all interchangeable. Their also weapons that are 1 piece which are boss weapons are their really fun to play from a sekiro like sword to the range of puppet ripper. Their so many weapon choices that really its up to you to find your favorite and stick with it lol. The story is also really good but does suffer from some meh translation but most of it is fine just 1 off issues here and their. the ost is really good. Like REALLY good from the boss OST to the music discs you can collect. Lies of P has alot going for it. If you enjoyed Sekiro and or bloodborne combat i 100% recommend this game to you! If your wanting to get in to souls games and couldn't really get in to dark souls i recommend you try lies of P as it easily one of the more casual takes on the souls genre thanks to alot of its quirks.

Having played almost all of the Fromsoft games, Lies of P not only scratches that "soulsborne" itch, but in many ways it expands upon the traditional formula that made Fromsoft so successful. The level of detail, customization, and exciting combat shows the care and research that went into development.  
There are definitely some things here and there that could be improved upon or expanded, but I don't think any one thing negatively impacted my game-play to the point of distraction. Combat is definitely difficult, but over time, I think the player will find the play-style that works best for them. Again, the level of customization in this game allows players to experiment with how they want to engage. 

Overall, if you fancy yourself a bloodborne or sekiro fan and have played the dark souls series, I think you'll find this to be a fantastic experience that does more than just stand in the shadow of other titles - it really shines among them.

If you liked Sekiro, just buy this now. It's that easy to recommend. It matches the rewarding feeling of mastering bosses and getting perfect blocks. It's that good. You'll feel right at home.

If you like souls games in general, STRONGLY consider getting this. Lies of P doesn't feel like "we have souls at home" it feels like having souls at a fancy restaurant. No it's not your usual place but everything you expect to be there is there. Like I don't even have to say "it's good except for these things" like this game has no really obvious flaws IMO. And once you play it and realize how good it is, your first thought is "great, really impressive stuff but there's no way this game is as long as a From Software game", wrong. This game is easily 40-50 hours long. For me it was 50.

I hope once this game gets some discounts more people will pick it up because this is definitely flying under everyone's radar. This game really is just a pleasant surprise. Everyone who is still waiting for the Elden Ring DLC (or god forbid, Sekiro 2), just play this. You will be happy. This is your fix.

Directly comparable to FromSoft. If you recoil at that statement, play the game and see for yourself. Only the lore and the linearity don't meet FromSoft standards, everything else is top-notch, Level design, combat, enemy design and diversity, it's all there. Impeccable.

Gorgeous game, sterling musical direction, with an incredible aesthetic and a robust combat system. The bosses are a little jank sometimes, but otherwise, phenomenal. With one caveat:

I'm not sure who designed the Grenadier puppets, why they're invariably placed one to two stories up and out of reach from the player, nor what kind of trauma that person is working through to want to hurt so many people so badly, but I sincerely hope their kneecaps get repossessed.

Great Game!

The best souls-like not made by Fromsoft. Amazing atmosphere, brilliant soundtrack and engaging storytelling makes the presentation unforgettable. The combat deserves the highest of praise. With a ton of build variety and well thought out mechanics (particularly the perfect guard) you will never get bored of the many though battles you will face in this game. I would have liked the game to be a bit less linear but aside from that I cannot recommend the game enough to veterans of the genre. 10 lies/ 10 pies!!!

This game is utterly incredible and I cannot sing it's praises enough.  After I didn't have a great time with elden ring due to it invalidating my build choices (Not engaging with magic and summon system mainly), it is wonderful to have a souls-like that encourages a very in your face melee focused combat system.

The game is quite difficult and you will need to both get good at knowing when best to dodge and best knowing when to stand your ground and perfect parry. It's like a middle ground between dark souls and sekiro.  This sort of defensive variety and the amazing boss design in -every- single boss means every encounter with a big baddie was a joy to learn and defeat.

My favorite thing is the weapons, you get a lot of weapons as you play through Lies of P and you can mix them how you want.  The 'blade' part of the weapon determines speed and damage, the handle determines stat damage scaling and the moveset.  Using this I crafted a long heavy weapon using the bone saw and a pickaxe handle.  With this I was able to beat the entire game and every boss by using -just- the charged heavy attack in between boss attacks if I dodged or parried them into a stagger state.  The fact I could beat this game in an enjoyable way with such a slow BONK focused weapon was amazing.  Most other games would demand me to use a fast weapon or abuse something like a jump attack over and over and damage trade with bosses while they fly around the arena with the power of god and anime on their side.

I really can't recommend this enough to my friends.  If you like souls-like games you really REALLY should play this.  I can't wait to see what these devs do next.
I want them to make another game already :( This was perfect.

I make this review with little comparison to the rest of the genre. I have played every game, 100% of all of them, I am not a elitist of the genre but I enjoy them a lot. I speak from the casual dad, familiar with the genre.
Graphics: Beautiful top down. Big note for me, I want to be drawn in. I don’t want to spot imperfections or remember it’s a game. I want to be excited, interested, and enjoy the developer’s hard work. That said, the game is flawless in artwork. The environment, layout, the detail kept me focused on the game. Nothing stuck out and made me get distracted and focus on the bad points of anything. The setting, the lighting, and the music and tone are married together in amazing harmony. In the artistic viewpoint, the game crushes it is setting the ambience, scene, and tone. Truly A+ Here.
Weapons: This game is the best in the genre, my one of two comparisons I intend to make. This is the best in genre for picking a weapon you want, customizing it how you like, and playing with it. There’s only a couple of weapons that make the experience “easier.”  From my view, any weapon is workable, and fun based on your style in this game. Sweats will say this is the case for any entry. I speak as a casual dad with sweaty hands (sometimes.)
UI: The interface and HUD are very clean and simple. I like that the game has notifications for when side quests progress and reminds you of the location for the quests. It’s super helpful, and nice not to have to refer to google and fextralife to understand what steps need to be taken.
Below is where we start to become critical of the game.
Difficulty: I found this to be an easier game for the most part. Aside from 3 bosses with aggravating skills and status affects and 2 world areas where they throw lots of mobs and multiple effects at once. The aforementioned 5 points are not hard they are just punishing. This game is heavy on the parry, only in a handful of spots it’s your dodge helpful. You’re gonna be tested heavily on your parry. This game starts to fall off for me because, the “challenge” is punishing enemies with 2-9 attacks continuously, and one missed block can be detrimental. Now, some of you may read that and say, well that’s a fair challenge. But there’s 2-6 enemies doing the same thing. This may come off as a whine but play it yourself. You’ll see. Added note, You as the player have a plateau of damage, meanwhile the enemies will only get stronger and more health. 
Story/Mechanics: The story started very interesting, quickly got predictable. Loosely explaining it to a friend, we were able to guess the ending clearly. The story is easily found throughout the game in pick-ups, which is nice. Unfortunately, the plot twists don’t catch you off guard. The “Lie” mechanic that determines the ending, but “lying” in the game isn’t always clear what’s the lie, and what’s the effect? Theres a actually “nifty” easter egg drop, after the game for the sequel but personally I have no interest in a sequel. 
The game captures the bones of a SoulsBourne game but, it lacks some creativity to really be a great title for me. It’s a good game, but some glaring issues for me in between the lines. The last third of the game starts to get un-creative and punishing. It's great visuals and weapons don't pull it that hard. If they do make the sequel they hint at, there's a good amount to fix to really make it a great game and an original entry. It’s a solid 6/10 game, play it once.
A souls-like on the level as fromsoft!

I loved everything about this game. The story, the artwork, the parry mechanic and fighting overall, the bosses. I really hope they will create other games based on famous novels.
