Great Game.

Gameplay will be very familiar to anyone that has played a souls game and especially sekiro. It's more like ds3 combat with a stagger system and perfect blocks, and instead of weapon arts you have fable arts that consume fable that is recharged as you fight enemies. 

But what really intrigued me more than the game-play was the world and the story. Much more than CodeVein ever did, or any other souls game. Especially the story, there is more of a clear message/theme with this game, which makes sense as it's a dark re-imagining of a Pinocchio. What really does it is that as you progress in the game, and become more "human", the little details the game adds. The cat in the hub area gets more friendly, and you get better at playing music at the piano. 

The lore is also very interesting, and definitely still need to read the notes scattered around the world to get a better sense at everything that was going on. But the game also makes sure you understand what is happening even if you don't read anything. This game is more narratively driven than fromsoft souls games.

and with it's puppet-organ/p-organ progression system(that carries over, and apparently gets to even higher levels until I believe until ng3 ) and ng+ narrative elements(like Nier:Automata, you can now know what the puppet bosses are saying more clearly) it has been the only souls game that made me really want to play the game over again right away.

Lies of P is my favorite game that's come out within the past year. It's by no means perfect, but takes the perfect parry emphasis of Sekiro and throws it into a souls-RPG system with really cool weapons and a beautiful, underrepresented aesthetic to boot. 

Mechanics that stand out: 
-Recharging your health pot when you are out by dealing damage
-Mix and match weapons (blade gives you size and damage type, handle gives you moveset and scaling)
-Fable Arts - Special weapon abilities bound to blade or handle, Similar to Elden Ring's Ashes of War but you get two 
-Stagger/Fatal attack mechanic is very fun
-Armor is boiled down into a couple of equip slots which leaves you to fashion it up without worrying about stats
-I love the setting of this game

A couple of small pain points:
-Leveling needs to be done in the hub location, you can't do it at the checkpoints (past the demo chunk of the game)
-Perfect Parry timings can be rough to get used to at first if you come from a Sekiro background since the parry needs to be held down over the hit, not tapped
-A lot of disjointed and/or wonky attack timings - Need to approach new enemies with block to get a feel for the moves
-"Sneak" attacks are wonky and hard to pull off. Jump attacks feel like an afterthought
-It's not super clear how certain stats work, and some translations are a little off (cube anyone?)

IMO, most of those pain points are pretty easy to overcome besides going back to the hub to level (seriously, who thought this was a good idea?) and Lies of P brings enough new ideas to differentiate itself from other entries of the genre. 

This game has managed to grip me in ways that very few single player games nowadays do, as well as inspire me to actually put a review out and for that, I give it a strong recommendation.
It's similar to Bloodborne in regards to its play style but it also has its own charm.
Souls like with much more plot. Love the cinematography. Challenging as well. Don't give up!
Play it
The combat, encounters, locations, music, and story throughout make this game absolutely incredible and worth your time. A ton of fun and loved how unique each weapon felt to use and adjust

This game is incredible. A world drenched in style, art, and music, with genuinely likable characters and an unexpectedly moving story that touches on deep philosophical themes. 

The combat is a perfect blend of Bloodborne, Sekiro, and Dark Souls 1 systems, striking a perfect balance between aggression, parrying, blocking, and dodging. It's very punishing, but extremely rewarding once it all clicks. No other Souls game emphasizes a balance of dodging, blocking, and parrying to this degree. 

Lies of P is the synthesis and evolution of the Fromsoft Souls games. It's my Game of the Year. Check it out. You might be surprised to look up and realize how invested you've become in the story and the characters.
It's a solid souls like with a big spike of difficulty at the end of the game that was frustrating but other then that a good experience.

What an amazing game.
This game gets so many things right!! The souls-like approach is evident but misleading in a sense, yes it is a souls-like but as much as swimming in a pool compared to swimming on the sea, in both you swim but they are very different in approach and trainning. 
Defending is not just defending and waiting for your turn to attack when the boss finish his combo. Yes, there is the option to dodge and attack, but with fury attacks that can't be dodged(at first) you will be forced to learn the parry and OH BOY does the game open from that.
Enemy variety is great and follows the story in why the enemy is designed like that and why he is on that biome, when they mix it is understandable, not once did I think that an enemy was out of place.
I played this game after the nerf patches and to me the game always seemed fine from a difficulty perspective, you have throwables, consumables, a specter to help you fight, the game is designed for the player to find the difficulty he wants to conquer, be it using nothing but the dodge and weapon, or using everything.
The weapon system is great, instead of chaging a weapon to a better one from late game, Lies of P make the blade and handle different parts so the player can test and find what he prefers, just like the legion arm that would be youf off hand weapon and becomes a very powerful tool later on, there are lots of legion arms to choose.
The gameplay really ties well with the theme of the game, choice.
Story wise I am dumbfounded by how well they tied the robot aesthetic with Pinocchio story and themes, literally it is an amazing way to feel the meaning behind the story, and tells a lot about lying which is truly complemented with the superb voice acting from the entire crew. If I had anything to harp is that some minor villains are given big roles but not enough interactions to make a true decisive impact, the impact is still there for some but could be a lot better.
The game is way longer than I expected, clocking at 30 to 40 hours un my first playthrough.
One very special part is the music, what a great soundtrack, for ambience and SPECIALLY for the collectables.

This is a very, very well polished souls-like that opens possibilities for new interactions in the future and rivals From Software for the first time in their own backyard.
If you want a good "souls-like" get this game.

This game does so many things right. The setting reminded me of Bioshock in a good way, and I think this is what stood out most. Many of the mechanics feel familiar, but the story and setting are what set it apart. I think they did a great job creating a game that feels like a tribute more than a copy. The story sets up so much potential for future titles and settings as well. 

As far as gameplay, my only complaint is difficulty. Personally, it was too hard but I made it through. I give the devs credit for hearing feedback and tuning the NPC summon to help on bosses. I think the buff to the summon makes the game much more accessible for most players. I like the Legion Arm mechanic for approaching bosses in ways that suit your own playstyle. There aren't as many weapons as a Souls game would have, but the handle swapping adds a layer that was fun to play around with and I never felt like I was lacking in interesting weapons to try. 

Lies of P is my standout surprise game of the year. I'd been following it for a while curiously and it delivered.

Changed the distance for auto lock to be as close as possible, etc. I’ve even swapped to a brand new controller thinking that it was causing that issue. But the same thing happens. 

It’s honestly made the fights go from hard, to almost impossible. 

I would recommend the game because it genuinely is a good game. But the lock on mechanic really is effed.

Pretty good Soulsborne type of game not made by From Software. The scope of this game is considerable smaller compared to Dark Souls games or Elden Ring. But smartly the developers didn't overextend themselves and just stuck what works. That does mean that the game is somewhat limited in level design, weapon variety, enemy variety and classes, to name a few, but what is in the game is done very well, and this really is the best Soulsborne game not made by From Software. The game's story is also much more straightforward. The world is well established and you don't need to guess or piece together what has happened, the game tells you. That doesn't mean that the story is anything special, but the use of the source material of Pinocchio is pretty unique. Still, it's told well enough that it keeps you going. Though I have to say that the ending(s) was a bit anti climatic.

Probably the easiest Soulsborne type of game that I have played. Took me a little shy of 30h to finish the game and the only boss that gave me trouble was the very final one [spoiler]The Nameless Puppet [/spoiler], if you chose to fight it. That said, I got the game only after the 1.30 patch was out, so maybe that made the game easier, but all the bosses, except the final one, were pretty damn easy. But I guess the NG+ and NG++ and NG+++ and so on, will truly test you.

All-in-all very good first outing from this developer. I can't wait to see what they'll cook up next. The post credit scene promises more fairy tales - or fairy tale characters - to be included in this Lies of P universe.

10/10 incredible. It rivals FromSoftware in terms of quality. But putting comparisons aside, even if you've never played a Souls game before, this is a must play. It's very difficult and that's gonna turn a lot of people off, including long time FromSoft/Souls fans. But if you can stick with it, if the game clicks for you like it did with me, this is one of the best experiences of 2023 and my personal GOTY rivaling Armored Core 6.

A couple of criticisms though: The emphasis on parrying is great, I love the mix of Bloodborne/Sekiro. However, the parry windows are a bit too small, certain attack chains and furry attacks basically feel impossible to parry, especially with how janky and unnatural the enemy puppet animations are. Another issue I feel is that the tracking on enemy attacks is too high. The way the game expects you to play is that you either parry or dodge attacks, which means that, a lot of the times, there is a weird rubber-banding effect that happens when an enemy attacks you, because the game is forcing the attack to land in order to force the player to engage with the systems. I feel like this was unnecessary and it makes certain enemy encounters, and even some boss fights like the Green Swamp Monster really frustrating.

All that said however, the game is still absolutely a masterpiece. The flaws I pointed out did not ruin it for me, but I felt like they should be mentioned anyway. If you're gonna play any Soulslike this year, make it this one.

This is without a doubt the greatest attempt to reach the souls type of game play, from dogging, bosses, and so much more this game is incredible. The nice refresh of an almost linear story and world exploration through an immersive, mix of a Gothic-steampunk world. 

GAME PLAY:
Perfect parrying was difficult to get useful, but is so rewarding and fun to use. Weapon diversity and customization is crazy how fun and unique it is. Legion, although feeling under powered eventually as you play, becomes a amazing way to alter how you approach different bosses and areas. However, much like souls games, there are strong bosses and there are weak bosses, for example, the "final boss" (IN MY PERSONAL OPINION) is clunky and unfunny to play against, but the boss preceding it is one of the most cinematic and difficult hurdlers to play for the first time and required me to adapt and break my previous souls knowledge and master perfect parries. Areas, as mentioned are linear yet not simple, and reward the player for completing them.

IF YOUR ON EDGE:
One main thing if you are reading this review and considering playing this game. PLEASE, and I mean please understand, this is not a fromsoftware game however, it is not another Sekerio or Bloodborne like people say, it has its own combat, so avoid the baby rage of the combat "feeling different" and learn it just like you did when you first played those games. The game is hard, and definitely punishing but that brings along charm. One of the beginning bosses took me 4 hours, yet was so worth it. 

OVERALL: 9.5/10
This is an incredible game with an immersive story and environment, and is defiantly an amazing title to come out especially during the drought of no Fromsoftware content (besides Fires of Rubicon) until the Elden Ring DLC. I recommend this whole heatedly to anyone who likes Demon-Souls-Borne (or Elden Ring) style games. Just get past the initial difficulty hurdle and you will love it I can see taking 60+ hours on peoples first runs.

Don't be put off by the talk about this game's difficulty. If you've played any other Souls-like, you're capable of seeing this game until the end. It's really not as brutal as people are claiming. This isn't a "git gud" speech. That phrase was invented to scold people like me. I only complete games like this through sheer attrition. You've got this. The only bosses that really gave me grief were the first handful, and only because I was stubborn about not learning the systems and always dodging instead of parrying.

Considering how long this game is, it's remarkable how sustained the quality is from beginning to end. Every hour feels polished and well paced.

Lies of P has a much more linear story than any other Souls game and it makes for a more rewarding final act. I was not prepared for this game to be so emotionally devastating. I can not wait to see what the DLC has in store. Genuinely, this is a beautiful story, with some really harrowing reveals.

Having played this game extensively first on console and now on Steam (which is where I'll continue to play for Ng+ etc) I would like to say this. 

The people who worked on ''Lies of P'' took what is the Souls formula and truly innovated on it. The combat alone is so addictive that you'll have an extremely hard time putting that controller down. The Art design is easily one of my favorites out of any Souls game I've played, up there with DS3, ER and Bloodborne. The music? I have no words, the music will make you cry with joy at how beautiful it is and how seamlessly it fits with the whole aesthetic of the game. It's PERFECT and all the Artists are incredibly talented. Just perfect, I have no words, I absolutely love it...

Now for the story. This is a twisted re-imagining  of ''Pinnochio'' mixed with extremely dark elements and an outcome that solely relies on your decisions, which do matter in this game. Make no mistake, the fact that it's based on the classic tale does not mean that it's a shameless copy, on the contrary, ''Lies of P'' is a story on it's own while only borrowing elements of the classic story. It's deep, impactful and everything a lore lover could ever want.

I will not go into  detail but I'll say this. The level of detail these people added into this game is astounding. It's pure quality in every turn you take, incredibly well polished and obviously crafted with a TON of love and care. There is nothing that they did not think of and on top of that added so extra little details that you as a player would have never noticed were missing if they hadn't, but they did and it gives the game a lot more immersion and some of those details will really tug on your heartstrings. It's amazing.

This Soulslike is so good that it deserves it's place next to the best of Fromsoftware's releases. Easily.

If you're looking for a new Soulslike that not only nails every detail of the souls formula but greatly innovates on it at the same time, then this is where you should stop looking. It's a thousand miles ahead of it's direct competitor which was also released recently on UE5 engine and I've also played and is lackluster to say the least. 

''Lis of P'' is worth every penny especially if you're a souls fan, you will fall absolutely in love with it.

With that said I would like to thank every single person that worked on this game. Not just the developers, but EVERYONE. It's clear that you gave it all the passion, love and care that you had in order to offer us this absolute Masterpiece. You're all extremely talented and it shows.

So thank you. 

I'm eagerly waiting for the DLC and of course your future games.

Honestly wasn't a fan. The combat felt not as fluent as Sekiro for a game that has such a high focus on parry mechanics. The heavy attacking felt not as smooth as a dark souls game. And i'll be honest the aesthetic wasn't a big plus for me going in.

Now that I've beaten the game, I want to give a more detailed review. To be clear- this is overall a very well made game. My negative review is tentative, and hopefully I will change it into a positive one in the future, but that depends on if the development team is willing to make slight quality of life changes that would drastically improve the enjoyment for the player. This game does a lot well: the level design, the aesthetic, the music, the weapons, the various "legion arms," all of that is great. However, I do genuinely think this is the absolute limit of difficulty that Souls fans are going to be willing to put up with.The lack of animation cancelling and the unnecessarily tight perfect guard windows are incredibly frustrating, both things that Sekiro does better. There are decisions in this game that come across as oversights at best and spiteful at worst. The deflection system comes across as overly punishing with red attacks not being able to be dodged as it's entirely arbitrary as to what can be i-framed and what can't. There are also an over abundance of red attacks in comparison to Sekiro where they felt more special and thoughtfully placed. Another issue with the deflection system is how inconsistent it is in conjunction with grab attacks- while unblockable attacks glow red to let the player know to either perfect guard or avoid the attack entirely, there are also grab attacks that need to be perfect guarded or avoided entirely that don't glow red, and the only way to figure that out is to perfect guard the very first time it appears or to be punished for something you've never seen before. Another thing I hate is how the game tends to break its own rules- the guard break system in particular. Normally if you posture break a boss it slumps down so that you can get in a critical, but the second rabbit boss fight the big brother does a crazy flailing swing when you "guard break" him (literally going against the name of the mechanic) to get in a few cheap hits on unsuspecting players that could cause an unfair death. This also happens with Laxasia and it's just a cheap surprise. The worst instance of this ways throughout the whole game, big enemies falling down don't have a hit box as they collide with the floor, but the shitty Door Guardian boss does, and his head hitting the floor actually killed me, causing a huge chunk of my time to be wasted. And why are we still doing the weapon upgrade system? Of all of the things to copy from Souls, this is the worst. How can I be expected to experiment with different weapons if I have limited and expensive upgrade materials? If the game is also going to include a weapon durability system (which is pretty harsh in comparison to something like Das1 or Das2), then at least let me change weapons on the fly without worry of how upgraded a weapon is. Lastly, I hate the withered health. Losing stamina to blocking is trade-off enough, and it's obviously just something from Bloodborne the devs wanted to shoe-horn in.
femboy simulator.

Since my time of posting my initial review, I'd still highly recommend it. Similar to what came before, it punishes mistakes and rewards skill. If you played games like Sekiro, Jedi: Fallen order, Jedi: Survivor, or Bloodborne, Your skills will carry over. 
Similar to aforementioned games, parrying is king. While you can block, you lose health and stamina where parrying only results in lost stamina as well as build up of the invisible stagger meter, once full it will allow for a fatal blow if you land a charged heavy attack when the health bar is flashing white. 
I want to address movement complaints I've seen. This game is not focused on movement, you can dodge, however, the game is focused on perfect guarding not dodging.
If you do end up taking damage while blocking, it has a mechanic similar to Bloodborne's rally system. Rewarding a portion/all of your recently lost health back. So far, a worthwhile buy, I'm giving this my GOTY. A fun game to play in 2023 and beyond.

Truth of Peak

So, Lies of P? Next best thing to Bloodborne on PC? The Soul-clone to eat all other Soul-clones? An overrated piece of crap with bad design? 

No, its none of these things. What it is is a super solid refinement of elements you most likely have already seen, mixed together in a pretty and interesting setting, with good voice acting, solid story and suburb presentation. This game is the manifestation of the idea of refining the wheel, and it does this super well. 

One notable standout is the focus on parrying in combat, and how it  can make almost any fight a hell of a lot more easy. While not as necessary in my experience as it is in Sekiro, its still a linchpin in most viable strategies, and it does shape many boss encounters, and that has its perks and drawbacks. This I think is will the biggest watershed if players will enjoy the game or not. For my part, I did, and I kept enjoying learning patterns of the many interesting bosses you fight in this game. 

Now for some critique, even if its minor: While this game refines many of the good features of other souls-titles, it suffers from similar problems: The camera can, and will screw you over against faster and bigger enemies, random death traps that get you ones are dotted around the game, adding nothing expect a sigh from you as you have to run and fetch your Ergo again and the armor system is very, very basic, with mostly just basic stat improvements at the expense of weight. For many players coming from DS3 or Elden Ring, they will also find the game much slower then those two, with longer regeneration on stamina and more limited dodge spamming. 

At the end of the day, I full and utterly recommend this game to people who love Souls-games, and are looking for another fix in this gene, and do not mind similar elements being refined and implemented in interesting ways. For those completely new to this kind of game, I would recommend Elden Ring first, as a solid introduction, but if the aesthetics, theme or weapon-system in this game seems more interesting, then this can serve as a solid introduction to this genre of gaming. 

Capital work from the Studio.

This one is fantastic. The graphics are solid, the actual fighting mechanics are great, I enjoyed that there was a story, and I would recommend to most.
The only small thing I would point out is I felt like some enemies had almost unlimited stamina. They could get 8-10 attacks pause for one second and go right back at it. Excellent! At first I merely liked the game, but the longer I went, the more deep, interesting, and emotionally charged it revealed itself to be.

Lies of P takes a lot of cues from Bloodborne and some from Sekiro, and it's a great addition to its genre. Apparently some people say it's harder than Elden Ring, but I didn't find that to be the case. By building a character with strong health and armor for my first playthrough, I gave myself enough room for mistakes that I actually overcame many of its challenges in about 1 to 3 tries. But I don't consider that a bad thing; it felt intense in the moment all the same! In the few spots where I did need more tries than that, I was late enough in the game that I had lots of different weapons and other tools to try new approaches with.

It's true what you may have heard about the English translation being imperfect, but it's a minor thing, more on the level of "that's not quite the right tone and diction for a history book" than actually being difficult to understand. The voiced lines tend to sound more sensible than the written text, and the performances are solid!

The smallness of my nitpicks with Lies of P are a testament to how good it is. One is that the enemy variety and environmental detail are a little bit sparse compared to From Software's works, and I do mean only a little. Another is that the enemy attack animations are harder to read than I'm used to in Elden Ring and Sekiro, so it can be tricky to get perfect parries until you study the enemies for a while. Even so, I suspect it's intentional that perfectly blocking everything the first time you see it is hard, and I probably wasn't much better at it my first time through Sekiro.

The lore and story leave some things unsaid but aren't as shrouded in mystery as, say, Dark Souls. For me, it's just right!

Anyway, if you're a fan of the Souls-like genre, this one's definitely worth a try!

I have been telling all of my friends who enjoy souls-like games to play this.
It has told the most compelling souls-like story that I’ve ever had the pleasure of experiencing. 

It’s three parts. 
They set you up with a good backstory.
Then you have the environment as you explore.
And the story unfolds as you interact with other characters, and defeat bosses.
The music is instrumental to the telling of the story, and the main characters growth.
Every element only further enhances, an already good narrative that you can keep up with.

40-50 hr play through
2-3 play through required for all achievements

The game also gives you multiple play styles. The weapons are pretty sick - the blade and the handle of every weapon you discover with the exception of specials/unique weapons you can switch out with others - altering them and it’ll change up how that particular weapon attacks. They are also upgradable. With unique technique skills like in Dark Souls / Elden Ring.

Then you have your Legion arm, which is basically a sick metal arm that you can use that has different abilities depending on which one you have equipped. As you upgrade them they unlock special abilities for each unique arm.
Electric blast 
Flamethrower 
Hook shot 
Cannon
Shield

This game has a lot of pros and also some cons. Some of the boss fights are too easy once you summon a bot/spectre to beat them. It would be better to not have that option at all, and re-balance the fights around your own individual skill. I don't like the way the parry system works at all. The precision in which you have to time it isn't very fair. Especially compared to Sekiro's parry system which is awesome. The theme and aesthetic of the game and the story are excellent. But I think that if you've played Elden ring and Sekiro and Bloodborne, the mechanics are a little of a step back. I think if they tweaked the parry system to be slightly more forgiving, it would be a lot better. Overall, a good game. There are more good things than bad to make it justify buying. You have to get good at parrying otherwise you may want to look elsewhere.

This is the first souls game I have played. i am not really a fan of souls games period, the first time i heard of similar games to Lies of P was when i was looking for interesting weapon combinations. I tried the game on game pass and immediately fell in love with the combat mechanics, the soundtrack, and the story in general. I am over 35 hours in, third play through, and i would highly recommend this game. I did not buy on game pass due to steam having the better price at the time of purchase so it was an excellent buy. This game is punishing, so learning how to parry is awesome and rewarding. It is a lot to learn and a lot of deaths required to fully master a specific boss with specific weapons. For context: I am a motivity player (in all my runs) so i exclusively run the Mjolnir (unchanged) and the exploding pick axe handle along with the Black steel cutter head. I learned to parry enough to survive the boss encounter with at least 4 pulse cells remaining. If parrying is not possible due to the used up stamina, the Mjolnir has a clutch perfect parry fable which the Nameless one does not like lol. This game is my game of the year, it is fun and engaging. This is not a game to switch off the brain and have some mindless entertainment, this game requires you to be on your tippy toes till the very end. Arche Abbey still pulls at my heartstrings every time i ascend that place. 10/10 i would recommend.

Patch 1.3 POV.

Most of the time, based on other Unreal Engine-built soul games I've played, I thought the engine sucked as hell when it came to the genre. Collision, movement, combat, optimization - everything seemed so damn scuffed and unrealistic (ha-ha) in games like jedi, vein, remnant. But this game literally proved me wrong. Game may still not be perfect at mass combat, but every 1v1 experience is neat, smooth, and satisfying - I freaking loved smashing and crushing things here! It just feels. And it feels great.
The story is decent, the difficulty is quite low, maybe 2 times easier than Sekiro even during NG+ where everything slaps you as mosquito, a lot of cool new mechanics including QoL, variety of gameplay and hard working developers with all these patches makes this game a real gem.

However, the downside for me is that the game is short and the locations are almost always the same. It's not that they are bad, no, the atmosphere is great, but not like in souls with a huge variety of biomes, more like Sekiro... but still smaller and generally without a shitty backtracking.

Good game but only a few "tough bosses" otherwise it is pretty much a breeze for a souls game.  Even the "tough bosses" are insanely easy once you figure out the move set. I instantly changed up my playstyle for NG+ to make it a harder run because of this. 

If they are taking the DLC where I think they are taking it it could be cool and if they do what is right and really expand on it they could make this an unbelievable experience with multi-DLCs and make it a huge "Fairytale Souls Game" that just keeps expanding out and out.  Hopefully they take this approach and make it a huge world with a ton of DLC that just keeps expanding upon itself.

Lies of P Pro:
Great Play, great fighting great fun.
Polished for optimization from the first day of release: Kudos for making sure it was flawless from the start.
Good graphics, art, animation, fighting.
The P-Organs were an awesome addition for a "skill-tree". Unique idea and love how it adds to it for NG+
Actually having additional items in NG+ was cool... could have definitely took this up a notch though and added more. 
Some open world "mini boss" fights.  Those were awesome.  You could drag the boss around the map and setup drop attacks. (This was really cool in some areas).  I wish they would incorporate that more.

Lies of P Cons:
Easy for a souls game.
Fighting is basic.  Heavy attack, light attack, parry. 
Are starting to bend toward the weak gamers and are coddeling them. 
No harsh punishments of hitting NPCS.  Can't kill NPCS and ruin story lines.
Leveling up is way to easy.

8.5/10.  Play it, it's fun.  Hopefully they expand crazy on the DLC.

Note:  Review was written after 100% completion.

Beautiful edition to the Souls style games! It actually has a decent story and not just lore, and is well done. Movement, combat, art, and overall quality of the game was top notch, no complaints at all. In terms of difficulty I'd put it about mid-tier, while each boss was challenging I never felt like it was impossible to overcome. While, a few of the bosses will definitely be remembered for years to come. If you like souls like games, Lies of P is a must add to your collection. If you've never played a souls game but eager to try, this is a good starting place as it teaches you all the basics and gives you what you need before each boss fight. In addition to, none of the respawns are that far from the bosses for quickly getting back to try again if you fail.

Eagerly looking forward to the DLC and the sequel.

[h1] The most annoying soulslike [/h1]
If I had to describe [b] Lies of P [/b] with one word - it would definitely be [b] annoying [/b]. Every decision the devs made leads to a remarkably unpleasant experience. In all honesty, I can [b]not[/b] recommend this game either to the fans of soulslike genre or to the newcomers. If you want a game with deflects just play Sekiro, it's much better.

Here's a more comprehensive list of issues (and some good parts) about this game:

[h3] Pros: [/h3]
[b] + Graphics:[/b] The game looks quite good and can stand toe to toe with other 2023 releases in terms of graphical fidelity. Sure, it may not have pathtracing or some other bells and whistles of the recent titles, but that doesn't really take away from the style and atmosphere this game presents.

[b] + Performance:[/b] For how good this looks, the game performs very well and i've never had a CTD or a drop beyond 144 fps. Can't say how the performance scales on lower end machines, tho.

[b] + Art style consistency:[/b] You get what you've been promised. A re-imagined story of Pinocchio with a wicked twist on the familiar characters. While it's not my cup of tea, it's definitely inventive and deserves praise in terms of setting and atmosphere. 

[b] + Boss designs (art):[/b] Every boss fills like a part of the world and like they are exactly where they need to be. Also design-wise, each boss is varied and somehow looks like one of the best From Soft's bosses.

[b] + No heal reading:[/b] Bossed don't attack you just because you disengage and heal. That's good. 

[b] + Regaining last heal:[/b] You can regain one healing item if you run out by attacking enemies. That's also a great idea and helps in a pinch without affecting the tension of running low on heals.

[h3] Neutral: [/h3]
[b] = Story and storytelling:[/b] I personally couldn't care less about Pinocchio's story and the game haven't convinced me to care. The more traditional and 'in your face' style of storytelling didn't help either. I do recognize that some people crave a more digestible story in a soulslike and that game provides it, i guess. But i found the story quite boring and uninspiring. 

[b] = Weapon system:[/b] Cool idea of mixing and matching blades and handles. On paper. In the actual game you quickly find the one thing that you like and play with it for the rest of the game. Also the coolest weapons (boss weapons with cool and unique movesets) are exempt from the system and can't be mixed and matched. That only raises the chances of you not engaging with the system much.

[b] = Humanity mechanics:[/b] It's okay. Lying is fun sometimes, but it doesn't affect the game nearly enough for me to care. I also hate that you have to listen to the entire songs you find to get more humanity. I don't like the songs and I don't want to listen to them, period.

[b] = Enemy weapon breaking:[/b] Once again, cool idea on paper but severely underutilized. Enemies don't change their attacks or behaviour, you don't get some material\weapon reward for it. You just make an enemy a tiny little bit easier.

[h3] Cons: [/h3]
[b] - Parrying and defense mechanics:[/b] The game tries to be both Bloodborne and Sekiro and turns out to be the worst of both worlds. Let's start with the parries. Just like everyone else has already mentioned, the parry window is too tight. Especially for how erratically most enemies attack. ESPECIALLY for puppets. Their wind up animations are ludicrous and timing a perfect parry is extremely hard. Great choice for the first enemies in the game, the enemies on which players will be learning how to parry. Puppet bosses suffer from the same thing. Oh you want to parry? Let me delay my attack just enough so you'll get hit. You also can't fan the parry button like in Sekiro, so you either commit to a block or go for the perfect parry. With an extremely tight perfect parry window this results in you eating the attack most of the time and dying. 

Rallying mechanic (regaining health by attacking) is locked behind a block. Why? Instead of being able to regen any lost health, you can only regain chip damage you got while blocking. This creates a bigger gap between committing to a block or going for the parry. Because IF you get hit you won't get a chance to heal from attacking. 

Dodging is just pathetic. Very little distance and very few i-frames. Oh, and remember the red unblockable attacks bosses and mini bosses do? They ignore dodge i-frames and still hit you, have fun! 

So what we get is a play style that's not aggressive and relies on rote memorization of attacks to counter them. You never really set the pace for the fight, you just react to what the boss does (and hopefully you react perfectly, otherwise you either lose health or boss regains it) and you whittle the boss down in small windows they give for attacks.

[b] - Poise and staggers:[/b] You have no poise and can be hit out of basically everything. That makes some of the enemies and bosses extremely hard to stagger to deal a big attack. It's much worse with heavy weapons and handles on which heavy attacks do multiple hits. Since stagger only applies on the last hit. This leads to the situation where the boss is staggerable, and you find a window to fully charge a heavy attack, AND you hit them, but you only manage to hit them twice out of the 3 attacks you have in the animation - and the boss hits you out of it. No stagger for you and some lost health as a gift.

[b] - Boss mechanics:[/b] While boss art design is great, boss game design is awful. First issue has already been mentioned a million times: 2 phase bosses. They are not fun, especially when it's a completely different boss in the second phase. Sure, one or two surprise appearances spice up the game, but when basically every boss after the 3rd one is some variation of a 2 phase boss - it's just annoying. 

Bosses are too tanky. You never feel like you damage the boss, rather you just chip away at the giant health pool they have. Add to that the health regeneration and you get extremely annoying boss encounters. And you usually do it twice :)

[b] - Boss runbacks:[/b] Why do they exist in a post Elden Ring world? Why do I have to run to the bosses door each time I die? Just why? Your souls spawn outside the door, you basically get no punishment for dying besides spending your consumables. The only punishment is you have to slog through half a level holding the B button to fight the boss again. Sure, they are mostly not long, but they shouldn't be there at all. No one likes boss runbacks. 

[b] - Level designs:[/b] General level design is boring and too easy. This creates a giant difficulty spike between levels you play and bosses you defeat on those levels. The developers seem to think that everyone likes poison swamp, rolling boulders and status effects in soulslike. So you get a lot of extremely annoying places where you'll be poisoned and trapped. Again, this kind of thing can spice up a level or two, IF you don't expect it. In Lies of P basically every other item pick up or bridge is a trap, you become accustomed to it and just get annoyed when the fifth bridge in a row breaks under you. 

I also hope you like dealing with status effects, since there are a ton. And a ton of levels where status effect dealing enemies and props are a big obstacle.

[b] - Enemy designs:[/b] Annoying. That's it. Too many status effects and too tanky.

[b] - Item drop rates:[/b] Why do I have to buy items that would literally be abundant trash in other soulslike? You even have to buy pebbles (cogs in this case) to throw and get the enemy attention. 

[b] - Gemini:[/b] Shut up already, I don't want exposition thrown at me and listening to his snarky comments makes me sick. 

[b] - Enemy health regen:[/b] I don't care that I can remove this with the P-organ mods, this shouldn't have been in the game. This game doesn't encourage aggressive play and this mechanic showcases this problem.

This is by no means a bad game and it's a decent souls-like. I thoroughly enjoyed all systems that I came in contact with during my playthrough. I recommend the game to anyone who likes these sort of games.

However, I ultimatively refunded this game because the combat just feels really lacking and stiff to me. The stiffness I would assume is due to everything being mechnical puppets. It makes sense for the animations to feel more rugged and less organic.

I am not a huge fan of parrying mechanics so I knew ahead of time that there will be some periods during my playthrough where I am not enjoying it as much as I would like to. That said, the parrying feels really bad compared to other titles in the genre. 

Bosses especially, quickly turn into a slogfest. This is the only souls-like where I have experienced this much frustration and apathy during boss battles. I can die 30 times to any given boss in the Souls-series, Elden Ring or Nioh-series and still have a good time. In Lies of P however, this is not the case. Which is a shame, since the bosses I have seen in the game are pretty cool.

It might just be personal preference all the way through. Therefore, it didn't sit right with me to not recommend such a quality title. Unfortunately it simply did not have the magic of the genres pillar titles.

Currently the best soulslike out there, very satisfying game play, great soundtrack, many great bosses. The weapon assembling system is very fun to play with, though I did wind up mostly playing with various bosses weapons which you can't disassemble. Game also has good replayability, since NG+ and NG++ allows you to understand the puppet bosses, gather more records if you're an audiophile, and has extra P-organ upgrades.

Main con are that a couple bosses are not as great, though there's only one I truly find to be anti-fun (but not impossible). 

9.5/10, highly recommend if you enjoy soulslike games. Had a blast 100%ing this and am very much looking forward to the DLC.

People say this game is hard. I don't agree. Well... not compared to Bloodborne or Sekiro anyway. This game feels fair. It just makes sense to me. I struggled with Bloodborne, and I started Sekiro recently. Those games got difficult very quickly. This game is definitely more forgiving. It's not easy, but it doesn't feel unfair either, which is quite rare for this sort of game. When I die in this game, I rarely feel like I was cheated or killed by jank. Some bosses feel tough to beat, taking most of the healing items to beat, only to find it has another phase. At first I thought there's no way of beating it. But after a few tries and learning its patterns, it becomes a lot easier. I love this about Lies of P. I haven't finished it yet, but I'm level 50 and still going strong, and still very much enjoying this game.

If there was a neutral rating, this game would definitely qualify. But since Steam doesn't allow it, I guess the positives outweigh the negatives a little.

Pros:
[list]
[*] Parry-focused gameplay - the parry or 'perfect block' system requires very little windup, compared to prominent Soulslikes (like Elden Ring) - it's much closer to games like Jedi Fallen Order/Survivor and Thymesia. There have been comparisons made to Sekiro, but I haven't played that game. Mastering it also makes a lot of enemies much easier.
[*] Good enemy variety - a lot of enemy variety (common and bosses) with different movesets and strategies needed to counter them, especially for a game that isn't all that long.
[*] Innovative customizations - You can combine the handle of one weapon with the blade of another - creating bizarre but unique weapons e.g. a greatsword with a rapier handle will block a decent amount of damage, while also being a reasonably fast weapon. Further weapon modifications, variety of gear, and the skill tree combine to provide some build variety.
[*] Decent storyline - For once, a game in this genre actually has a fully manifested storyline, with twists and turns, characters having their own hidden agendas, and mysteries to be uncovered. It's a whole lot better than an outline masquerading as a full story like a certain other game - 'kill+loot demigods, burn tree, kill Gods.'
[*] Music - near the start of the game, you get a gramophone record from an old lady, as reward for a sidequest. This might sound like a meh reward, until you actually play it, and then replay it a dozen times in quick succession. The same goes for most of the soundtracks in the game. In a nice twist, actions like listening to music, lying, showing mercy etc. impacts your level of humanity, and affects how the game ends.
[*] Graphics - quite amazing graphics, especially for this genre. Good to see a game that doesn't look like some dated PS4 stuff.
[/list]

Cons:
A whole lot of questionable decisions have been made involving the combat system. While there is some variance, the core combat loop in boss battles is to parry the majority of the boss's attacks (possibly breaking his weapon), retaliating with charged heavy attacks after each combo. Eventually, this causes a stance break, allowing you to inflict massive damage. Rinse and repeat. Some throwable items and special attacks (legion arms, fable arts) can speed things up, but this is the basic loop.

[list]
[*] Parry timing is incredibly tight, much tighter than the Jedi games or Thymesia. Collective opinion seems to be that it's tighter than even Sekiro, which was considered the hardest game in the genre.
[*] You get no reward for parries - no instant stance break after a long series of perfect parrying. There is an upgrade in the skilltree that supposedly does this, but I've never been able to get it to work. Instead, you must land a charged heavy while the boss is vulnerable to it (health bar flashing white).
[*] Parrying can push you back, especially if you've parried a long combo. That leaves you often too far to close the distance and perform a charged heavy, before the boss can power up another combo.
[*] Fully charged heavies are *slow* - making it harder to connect before the boss retaliates. Later in the game, you get a throwable item called a shot put, that can stance break enemies when they're vulnerable, which helps a little - but it shouldn't have to compensate for a fundamental flaw in the combat system.
[*] In addition, you have no hyperarmor while using fully charged heavies - so even a quick jab from the boss will interrupt your attack. This makes entire classes of huge weapons very difficult to use.
[*] Some bosses make no sense, and have ridiculous designs. e.g. you meet a half-mad dude stuck alone in a puppet factory, and despite his condition, he somehow is able to continuously keep attacking (more stamina than the player who is a machine?). Parrying him is useless, even when his weapon breaks, he just keeps spamming attacks and interrupting your own. You end up having to dodge and backstab him repeatedly.
[*] The camera positioning is horrible, especially for large bosses - you cannot often see the attack coming because all of the screen is taken up by the boss's torso. In a game focused on parrying attacks, well....
God forbid that you end up with your back to a wall, and said boss right next to you, for then you're effectively blinded. It's 2023 guys, other games have solved or at least partly mitigated this camera problem.  This makes several boss fights unnecessarily difficult - Archbishop Andreus, Swamp Monster, Simon Manus etc.
[*] Not just the charged heavies, but even in almost every other aspect - the player is slow, extremely so. This is in stark contrast to many of the bosses, who blitz around the arena at speeds that make ER's Maliketh look tame.
[*] A couple of GOD-AWFUL boss gank fights. Tedious and tiring to say the least.
[/list]

PS: For those facing the issues above, going with a Technique build, starting off with a Rapier Handle+Greatsword of fate blade, and then eventually getting the Trident of the Covenant will help. Both these weapons have decent speed, blocking ability, damage and charged heavy movesets that have some range - it doesn't completely mitigate all the issues, but is better than nothing.

After all the nerfs, the game has become significantly easier and less punishing on the first playthrough. Once you've mastered guarding and perfect parrying, the last few bosses become quite manageable. They barely deal any damage and can be easily cheesed with high health, the use of throwables, and summoning specters. However, in NG+, the game becomes incredibly challenging, reminiscent of its pre-nerf first playthrough. Hopefully, they will restore the game to its original level of difficulty.

Aside from that, this game features cool bosses and a fascinating lore.

I'm glad I played and defeated most of the bosses before the nerfs. Hopefully, the skills I've acquired from this game will carry over to other Souls-like games.

I absolutely [b]adored[/b] this game. This is my favorite souls-like game to date, and honestly the level of polish of this game is comparable, if not on par, with some of From's finest works.

Despite the fact that I'm no stranger to souls flavor combat, having finished the Dark Souls trilogy/Bloodborne/Elden Ring, [i]and[/i] that I'm playing the game after various patches and improvements for combat have been introduced, I still got my ass handed to me so many times during this game--almost all of which, I should add, are very much fair fights. Nearly every time I fall to a boss, I will know exactly what mistake I made, and why I failed. It's a tremendous task to make boss fights difficult but still fair, and Neowiz had done an absolutely phenomenal job with their designs. [spoiler]With the minor exception of the Black Rabbit fights. God I hate those guys.[/spoiler]

What I particularly enjoyed about the combat system is the sheer flexibility of it: from the weapon assembly system to general approach to encounters, this is truly following the Souls' spirit of "use anything that will help you survive", and perhaps even more effectively implemented to a degree, just by its obligatory melee style and the sheer enemy difficulty. As I got deeper into the game, I found myself actively seeking out different play styles and strategies, utilizing all my resources, trying out all the weapon arts and attacks, learning to rely on something other than dodges... Because my old tricks that carried me through all the Souls games no longer suffice. I'm once again presented with challenges above my current skills, and I have to work [i]hard[/i] to overcome these obstacles. Nearly all the endgame bosses got my heart racing like I'm facing the Fume Knight or Nameless King once again, and that. Is. AWESOME.

The level design is also fantastic. It's no DS1 (but let's face it, DS1 is going to be one of its kind for a long, long time), but the shortcuts placements, enemy allocations, and the developer's clear mindfulness of player attrition are outstanding. This is a game that has been tested and played extensively, and all the balancing efforts are very clear even to a lay person like me.

Oh, and did I mention the art direction? The costumes, the weapons, the art pieces, the general atmosphere--gorgeous. Just absolutely gorgeous. And the music... oh the music. Let me just tell you, that first time I listened to the record in Hotel Krat reminded me of my first encounter with Gwyn. I still get goosebumps just thinking about it. I also love how each record's description is a small story all onto itself--I got teary eyed many times just reading them.

I can go on for days just to pour out my absolute adoration for this game, but if you're a Souls like enthusiast, or just a fan of ARPGs in general, you should definitely give this game a shot. It will not disappoint.

It's rare to see a studio completely nail a soulslike on their first attempt, but Lies of P is one of the best to do it. 

The setting is unique, and I find myself actually interested in the lore and story which is rare for this type of game. The combat is fast-paced and visceral, with some really unique and memorable boss fights and enemy design. 

Not to mention it runs beautifully, and it ticks the ever-important box of native ultrawide and high framerate support. 

9/10 highly recommend.

So with alot of upsides, this game stands out among the sea of souls-likes, however, there are some flaws here and there that I'll talk about too. I streamed this game on Twitch and while the vods won't last because I'm choosing not to highlight them, these are my thoughts.

Story: 3.5 out of 5
Not covering the actual plot, what I will talk about is the power of choice should feel important. The choices you make, the lies and truths in this game, act more as moral dilemmas. They're not really asking Geppetto's puppet, but you the player. That's all well and good, I'm all for that, but not here. Now some choices do lead to how your puppet is affected in the game, but overall, it does little impact to the endings. In Dark Souls, your "moral dilemmas" were more defined by what you did physically, it felt more like you were making impact to the evolving story around you and the npc lives. Personally, I think Lies of P would have done better with a linear story, or limited choices, have more personality with your puppet, flesh him out more. I know the argument could be made that because he's a puppet, it should be ultimately up to you and his free-will is a blank canvas, and while we do see hints of his personality with some bosses and npcs, I want more. A puppet that can tell lies would be more interesting if he had a forming personality as well.

Gameplay: 5 out of 5
Combat for this game is where it shines the most. Fights feel fluid and bosses are hard, but have good forgivings and openings for those that give good attention. Weapons and their different assembles you can make are fantastic. From rapidfire poking enemies with a hot iron blade duck taped to a piston, to going completely unga bunga with a bargin bin thor's hammer attached to a police baton. You pick and choose and go nuts with it. Honestly, its a very nice mixture of dark souls and bloodborne.

Music and sound: 4 out of 5
Boss music is kind of forgettable, aside from a select few stand out pieces, standard crescendos and that one would normally find in a souls like are here. What makes this higher is the records you find in game, and the sounds of the world. These two together really immerse you in the game, make hits matter, and build upon your emotions.

Overall thoughts:
If you're looking for a good and true souls-like, this is honestly one of the best entry points you can start from. See for yourself and enjoy the city of Krat

Probably the most fun I've had with a non-FROMSOFTWARE Soulslike. I'd even argue I enjoyed this game more than DaS1 and 2. Very nice atmosphere, very fun gameplay, a more personal story. Lies of P has a lot of the classic Soulslike elements going for it but it doesn't fail at having its own vibe that's somewhat different from what Fromsoft's games have to offer. It's not perfect by any means - movement and combat could be improved  a bit, level design is a bit more linear than From's stuff, some areas feel a bit bland and samey... but it's got soul. It's got its own identity. It's honestly great. If you want a fix of quality Soulslike content, you probably won't go wrong with getting this game.

Solid game, but not the god-sent Bloodborne II people are making it out to be (so far). A bit easier than From's games as well; I've died three times (again, so far), once to a boss and twice to clutter that wasn't breakable, and I'm past the third boss. So make of that what you will.

In terms of the new mechanics, I've not used them too much, but the ability to 'augment' (for lack of a better word) P with new abilities is nice, and looks like it has a lot of potential. I also like the addition of a 'shinobi prosthetic', to help diversify builds and play-styles.

One gripe I have (and this may change as I get deeper) is a general lack of enemy variety; most common enemies look very similar, and their attack patterns are almost identical, with some few exceptions. As annoying as ranged enemies might be, fighting the same enemy repeatedly is just boring. The bosses and minibosses are fine and all, but the stuff between them can be kinda meh. 

Again, I do recommend the game, but don't go in expecting it to be better than if it came out of FromSoftware. Easily, Lies of P is one of the best soulsborne games from another studio, but it does lack a bit of that Miyazaki flair.

The true spiritual successor to Bloodborne. It has a very common souls-like gameplay formula that you would expect from the series, with enough uniqueness to make it it's own thing. You get a mechanical arm that can be used as a weapon along with your myriad of other weapons. You can upgrade all your weapons and arm as well as create whole new weapons by combining hilts and weapon ends. So you could make something like a mace with a saber handle, and I have also seen melee weapons with pistol-like hilts that create some unique weapon effects. You can upgrade Pinnochio directly as well to enhance his stats and capabilities. There is a lot to love and do here.

Unlike Fromsoft games, Lies of P takes a more direct approach to story-telling and it benefits a lot from it, if you can get into the unique world-building. Essentially, the puppets have gone rogue and taken over Krat, and Pinnochio is on a one-puppet (man?) mission to end it.

The lie system is pretty cool. I am not 100% sure how it works, but I guess the more you lie the more "human" you become, which is an interesting mechanic. I believe it has different endings based on some of your choices as well. 

The game was not that difficult at the start, but the further you get into it the more relentless the enemies are. This is definitely not one I would recommend to a beginner of the genre, but there are plenty of tools and even help you can call upon to aid you in the most difficult challenges. There are tons of ways to solve combat situations, so get creative. Have fun on your quest to become a real boy!
Holds it's own with half of the FromSoftware games. It's unique enough and the same enough to be a great experience.

This was my first Soulsborne or Soulslike game and I have to say I had an absolute blast. Despite usually not playing action games it was a ton of fun, though the learning curve was very steep in the beginning. 

If you can just go into it with the attitude that you will fail a lot until you succeed it's perfectly fine. And eventually things will feel almost easy as you gain skill and achieve competency. 

The visual design is gorgeous, the music is lovely, the story is a really good deconstruction of the original Pinocchio, and the gameplay just feels rewarding once you get the hang of it, especially parrying. 

My one gripe with the game is that I didn't enjoy the last area of the game, at all. It was too long, too colorless and too much of a slog. Nonetheless did it again on NG+ and started a third playthrough as well.

Absolutely stunning! This is my personal GotY along with Baldur's Gate 3, but obviously for very different reasons. There are caveats and things to be aware of, as it's not a game for everyone.

First, the game is very linear, like extremely linear. Personally, it's refreshing, but it can be a turn-off.

Second, the game is very hard. REALLY hard. Granted, this is my first soulslike, but the game really pushes you to read the animations effectively and parry as much of it as possible, while also repositioning constantly and keeping track of your stamina, all in a breakneck pace. Pinocchio definitely gets staggered like crazy by some attacks and enemies, but it creates tension and makes for an interesting puzzle, at least to me. But every boss and even some mini-bosses will take at least 5 tries to beat.  I love that as it means every boss has something unique and interesting to offer, something that tests both skill and strategy. But, that's not something might expect from a Pinocchio game. Also, for the love of God, stop playing Lies of P like Sekiro/BB/Dark Souls etc. expecting it to let to do a no-damage run your first playthrough. This is Lies of P and should be played like Lies of P, not Sekiro, nor Bloodborne, and that's what makes this game truly special, IMO. It didn't make me want to quit or play more FS games, it made me want to play Lies of P. And that's what's important, it isn't for everyone not just because it's a hard game, it isn't for everyone because of it's unique gameplay that demands the player to parry AND dodge situationally. Some people won't like it, and that's fine, but some of the hate this game received is unjustified, especially in regards to animations (especially when it comes to parrying, as players tap the guard button instead of holding it for half a second longer, which largely removes any problems with parrying) and "sluggish feel" which is largely a result of poor stamina management in part of the player. It made me terrified of giving it a try, but thanks to the demo, my fears were wiped clean and I'm so glad. I would've missed out on one of my favorite games this year. 

Last, the theme, story and artstyle. VERY unorthodox, but very unique if nothing else. It also amazes me how many grotesque/horrifying things can come from this kind of thing. Definitely not a kid's game if the soulslike category didn't make that obvious. Personally, I found it very captivating. But, like the linear level design, it can be a pretty big turn-off.

That said, for how much I love this game, it isn't perfect. In terms of personal cons, 

 One, camera sucks. There's this weird change of FoV and shift of perspective when locking on, the former affecting "big" boss/mini-boss battles, and the latter in the sections where you have to traverse across narrow beams very high from the ground. 

Second, attacks getting cancelled by the weapon getting stuck randomly on a wall, railing, pole, tree or whatever that an attack get caught in... is EASILY the worst part of this game. I can't believe for all the BS this game receives, something this annoying somehow gets no flak whatsoever. It's not even like all attacks get stuck. Some attacks, FROM THE SAME WEAPON, mind you, get stuck while others don't. For weapons with a thrust based moveset, this is largely a non-issue, but for slashing weapons... ooooh boyy, let me tell you. Out of all the things that made me want to break a controller it was EASILY the most infuriating.

Horrible controls, the character too often does anything but what you are telling it to do, paired with difficult enemies that you can't beat without being able to properly control the puppet. That makes the journey a continuos repeating of the same set of enemies with no point in it as it's 90% luck to beat them.

Lies of P is the first true step-up in the FromSoftware formula, that does not come from FromSoftware.
Snappy combat, has its own learning curve, and stands on its own two legs.

Differentiatiors:
- You get to mix any blade you want, with any move set and specials you want!
- Elemental builds are *super viable*! These come in the shape of 'dude with magic sword wielding X', and not spells.
- First game of its kind where blocking, rolling, Perfect Guard'ing, and poise are ALL viable, useful options. This game does NOT have parry as a core mechanic.
- Map design is on-point! A lot of shortcuts and a self-enclosing maps. A lot to discover, very little chance of getting stuck or lost.
- Manageable amount of options, which only grow starting on NG+.
- Linear enough to get the gist of the story, doesn't go crazy in depth.

Lies of P is a wonderful addition to the "Soulsborne" genre of games. You can clearly see the games that have inspired Lies of P, and yet the latter has its own unique charm, and so much love put into it. 

The game is definitely not as open and full of exploration as, say, Elden Ring, but I don't think that this holds the game back in any way. The linear structure allows the developers to focus on the story first and foremost - and the story is full of layers - while putting its own spin of the fairy tale version of Pinocchio, while all the while staying true to the soulsborne formula and the grim setting that the soulsborne games - at least by FromSoftware - are known for. 

I hope that we will see more fairy tales adapted into soulslike games - there is plenty of potential to be found, as Lies of P has shown.

MINOR SPOILERS

Charming game with a lot of love put into it. Very linear even compared to Bloodborne. It's a fun game, but lacks difficulty balance. Puppets feel very hard to predict because they are constantly bobbling around like Hitler at the horse racing track. How can I predict movement when the enemies don't choreograph any movement? If you have poor reaction time and rely on learning movesets in Souls-like games, I genuinely don't believe this is going to be fun for you fighting many bosses. 

Difficulty: Easy until you fight bosses who are damage sponges and attack very unpredictably. Every puppet boss is going to make the game more challenging because of bouncing around and have little to no "tells" for upcoming attacks.

Story: The story is okay. I enjoyed a decent chunk of it, but sometimes the characters will talk for centuries about things the game doesn't share information beforehand to actually immerse you in it. I don't want to chat about something I have no stake in beforehand. Souls games generally keep the meat in the background and only give you little drips of water on the foreground. Not that this game isn't it's own entity, but it is basically Bloodborne-lite with puppets, so I think it's fair to compare.

Sound: Solid sound design, enjoyable ambience and pleasant soundtrack.

Now it might sound like there's a lot of complaining, so let's go into some of my favorite parts of this game. 

+Enjoyable combat, very fluid attacks and combos 
+Fast loading screens
+Great weapon diversity + balance for different playstyles
+Non-linear leveling and skill tree progression
+Very visually appealing
+Fluid movement 
+Fun story (Until it becomes convoluted towards the end)
+Unique boss designs both visually and in gameplay
+Solid Enemy placements on the map. Generally fair and the surprises can be predicted

Here's my largest qualms now 

-Poor difficulty scaling
-Too many throwables, which I think attempts to fill in for the difficulty curve
-Bobblehead enemies that you'll have trouble predicting
-Lacking in content for $60
-Hallway simulator
-Rambling nonsense NPC dialogue as you progress through the game
-Asking for Sekiro blocking without the visual cues that game offered


Overall I enjoyed this game. Would I recommend it? Yes. Would I play other souls games before it? Also yes. It's one of the best outside of FROMSOFTWARE souls games, but I don't think it can stand with any of those titles in terms of balance. For a "small" studio, I am very impressed with the level of polish this game offers. I believe the story and difficulty loses it's stability and becomes a bit off the rails as the game progresses, but still everything feels complete. I personally didn't enjoy a lot of dialogue and boss challenge as time went on, but this is a very polished game. It is a complete game. I believe $40 would've been a better price-point. I would recommend getting it on sale or first watching someone else play.

[h1] No developer apology letter here. [/h1]

Lies of P's concept sounds like a cool mashup of genres you would come up with for a game that won't ever be made. 

"Dude, imagine a souls game where you play as Pinocchio." Except not only was this game actually made, but it is in my opinion the best game of 2023.

This game excels in everything. First off, its 2023 and this game worked at launch. No glitches, poor performance, or developer apology letters. It is a fully baked game with an extreme level of polish made in Unreal Engine 4, which is not old news despite developers marketing their 150GB unoptomized UE5 games as next gen and revolutionary.

The setting and story is the strongest aspect of this game. The twist on the old fairy tale of Pinocchio works so well as a darker, expanded story with aspects of the original cleverly utilized throughout the entire game. The levels are beautifully designed with Belle Epoque era themed architecture, enemy puppet designs, and VERY BLOODBORNE inspired sections as well.

Mechanic wise, other reviews have already explained much better than I, but what's important is that the familiar and addicting progression/gameplay loop of all good souls games is here, with a lot of unique and new things here. There is a lot more depth to progression than just your levels, which allows for multiple different gameplay styles. 

The combat is the bread and butter of the game, and it is perfect. This game draws from Bloodborne's primarily aggressive combat style. Lies of P pulls through where Bloodborne's awkward "parrying" mechanic lacks, however. Blocking with the incredibly tight parry window in order to build stagger is intense and incredibly rewarding, especially when you land the staggering heavy and fatal blow. These are heavy hitting, flashy, and satisfying.

You can tell that the developers saw this game as a work of art above all. They should be incredibly proud and deserve every penny. 

[h3] If this game is on sale, wait and buy it at full price. [/h3]

Probably the closest a company other than FromSoftware has come to making something that feels & plays exactly like a FromSoftware game. The level design (excluding [spoiler]the first half of Arche Abbey[/spoiler]), the bosses, the weapon options, the overall feel of the combat, etc. everything about it slaps.

It might not be perfect, but it comes damn close. It's a little on the shorter side when compared to the mainline souls games (took me a little under 20 hours for the first playthrough), but with multiple endings and [b][i]REALLY[/i][/b] solid combat, the option to do multiple NG+ playthroughs is definitely there if you want it.

This game is incredible from start to end. The learning curve is very steep, and most bosses were a consistent step up in difficulty from the previous. Learning the move sets of all the bosses was incredibly rewarding, the flow of the combat feels fresh despite the obvious Soulsborne influences. The bosses are consistently good, and there are no gimmick bosses weighing the roster down. I never tried to use the summons but the fights felt fair enough that I never wanted to. 

The levels rewarded exploration and I never got stuck aimlessly wandering around. They did attempt to make the hotel a sort of firelink shrine, but you never have a reason to back track through old levels and you have teleportation available from the start. Makes it feel more like the hunters dream than firelink. 

I highly highly recommend this game

As of writing, I am still on my first play through but here are my thoughts so far;

Lies of P is the best Souls-like I've played that's not made by fromsoft and a fantastic love letter to Bloodborne. It's a little rough around the edges and sometimes it feels like a well-done mod (I don't know how else to describe it). The adaptation of Pinocchio mashed into a dark steampunk aesthetic gels nicely together.
 
It wears its inspiration on a huge billboard, right in your face. There's a poison "swamp" and Sen's fortress just to name a few. changing out weapon blades and hilts is a fascinating idea, leading to hundreds of combinations, however (probably my fault) I have no idea on what the effects of doing so are. There have been multiple times where the hit detection has been off, The guard or "rally" mechanic is a treat, making small mistakes recoverable.

I'll post a full review once I have finished the game.

Lies of P single-handedly brought back my love for souls games this year. I struggled on damn near every single boss. There is no multiplayer, so relying on someone to carry you through bosses is out of the question. Yes, you can spawn a specter, but with every boss having two phases, you can barely notice its impact. I ran the whole game with a quality build, but changed for the final boss. In fact, the last two bosses of this game were incredibly difficult. Very, very rewarding once beat. Simon Manus is easily in the conversation for top 5 toughest bosses in the souls-like genre. I haven't yelled playing a game like this since fighting Midir from DS3. I would pay $60 despite it being rather short. Great ending and can't wait to see what they do with the sneak peak at the end.

I love the game, but, big but: FIXED ANIMATIONS. I can forgive bad platform segments (like why tho? why do you need to put them in?), I can certainly ignore few mistakes in UI, but I really detest those fixed animations that go counter-intuitive to my reflex system - I really react to change in enemy pattern while P finishes a move and will be finishing for next two seconds. In the world of VR movement why do we even need fixed animation? It's just lazy coding. Or maybe I am spoiled with reactive systems... but when you press attack and then block and few seconds attack animation just plays no matter what you know the gameplay will be arcadey or non-sensical depending on how you take it. I took it to the point where I kicked my screen into sillicon heaven, then I realized "girl, that ain't no game for you, you just got stuck on a real boss fight (mad clown) where nothing you do has nothing to do with the gameplay - you gotta remember the loop and play around it, and you know what? A real swordfight ain't no loop to remember for next time. Love the lore tho.

A well made bloodborne-like soul game in general.

Pros: Cool attires and weapons design, cool early stage map design, good story telling, every NPC has its own little cool story line. Best part is the normal weapon assemble system.

Cons: (1) Very janky enemy movements on a game that requires frequent parry to success. Although parry window is already very strict, there is no real benefit from landing a parry. (2) Every boss has 2 phases, but for many bosses, their 2 phases are completely distinct in appearances and movesets, making me wonder why don't split those and make 2 bosses for good? (3) Late game map design is not good, plus most loot items are garbage. (4) Except bosses, there are like only 10 different types of enemies............

This is only my second ever review written for a video game.

I'm a HUGE fan of souls like games. I've put thousands of hours across numerous titles (Dark Souls, Dark Souls 2, Dark Souls 3, Elden Ring, Lords of the Fallen, Sekiro)

After reading reviews for Lies of P, it sounded right up my alley. I couldn't have been more mistaken. One thing I can NOT stand in these games is the in-ability to roll/dodge effectively. Lies of P demands you parry. You will not have much success otherwise, and this I absolutely despise. When it's my choice to parry as it's inline with my character build, then I am more than happy to do so. When I feel I am forced to parry as there is no other path to success I find it absolutely infuriating. 

I will say, the graphics are beautiful, the music is very atmospheric and suiting. I know this game will scratch an itch for many many gamers, but it is not a title that I would recommend to anyone who enjoys the freedom to dodge/roll out of the way of attacks.
This is the game of the YEAR FOR ME!

Absolutely LOVE this game. 

Context: Taken from someone with limited knowledge and playtime of Soulslikes. This game blew me away through every aspect of it. Its game-play is smooth and precise, with the dodging and parrying feeling fantastic, and the variety of attacks and weapons help make the game feel constantly unique and engaging, despite its initial learning curve. The environmental storytelling is one of the best I have seen, and I constantly was floored by the art design and graphics. I loved how the game progressed, and just when I thought I was reaching the end, the game kept giving more (let alone a challenging NG+ i cant wait to get into). Apart from some bugged/missable achievements and ease to become overpowered near the end, this game is my favourite game of the year, and definitely one of the best I have ever played.
