[h3]This is the review of Lies of P from the perspective of someone who had never played a Souls-Like[/h3]

Let me just start by saying that Lies of P is a beautiful game, the graphics are amazing and it is incredibly well optimised. It is refreshing when you take into account that most games released nowadays run like you'd expect an obese person to. From an artistic standpoint, Lies of P is the type of game that most other strive to be but fail to become. Everything from the world design, the music, the bosses the enemies and even the weapons are completely stunning. This game is appealing to the eye and it certainly helps when it comes to easing you into the endless deaths you'll have to endure if you wish to reach its ending.

[h3]The Gameplay[/h3]
When it comes to the gameplay of the game, you'll find that it's rather simple and direct. Combat consists of limited amount of healing, quick attacks, slash attacks and strong attacks (this varies depending on your weapons), blocks dodges and perfect blocks. Let me also add that it adds a fresh component with the arm mechanic. The arm is a powerful tool which you'll get to modify and choose to your liking. The arm can be a shield which deals damage in retaliation, a grapple to bring enemies to you or you to them and more. I personally did not feel the need to explore more of the arms since I personally found the puppet string arm to be the best one of the bunch. Overall, this simple yet responsive combat system keeps encounters fresh and fun. There are consumables in the game but ultimately, I found them rather useless and sold most of them except those which allow you to buff your weapon with elemental damage.

[h3]The Progression System[/h3]
The progression system is very well thought out. By fighting foes, you'll gain ergo which can be used to level up your attributes. Depending on the build you're going for, you'll be able to choose between 6 different area to assign these points. Ergo is dropped when you die but can be recovered by returning to where you died and picking it back up. Thankfully, the developers were smart enough to include a fail safe to protect your dropped ergo from being in zones which would risk killing you over and over again. As the game progresses you'll find Quartz and Components which will allow you to gain new skills from a skill tree, to upgrade your weapons and to upgrade your arm. What I particularity enjoyed with the Quartz system is that they tend to be dropped by mini-bosses, making fighting them worth the effort rather than a tedious worthless task. 

[h3]Making your own Weapons[/h3]
Finally, there's the craft system. As you progress in the game you'll find multiple weapons inside of chests. Don't get me wrong the loot is amazing and the combos you can create by assembling a handle and a blade is incredibly interesting. In a way, you get to forge your own tool of mass destruction to play the way you like it. However, by the time you reach the end of the game you'll most likely forget that feature due to the fact that you'll have committed to upgrading a single weapon. Once you're used to a certain play style, it becomes a bit uninteresting to change even if the game constantly throws new blades that are even more good looking from the prior ones you've found.

[h3]The Narrative[/h3]
I feel like Lies of P's story and side quests is one of the more interesting semi-linear story I've seen in a while. Although the world did not give me countless amounts of decisions to reforge it, it gave me the decisions which would reforge me and the way I saw it. You play Gepetto's puppet and you are essentially a robot. However, you are unlike the other puppets because you can lie. This ability can lead you to become something that is much more human. Without spoiling much of this aspect, it is difficult for me to tell you more. However, I can guarantee you that the story kept me more than engaged with the game and that it is a tale I'll remember for a long time.

[h3]The Bad[/h3]
Although I absolutely loved the game and I did not find it difficult but rather I found it just challenging enough to be fun, there are a few things which I feel were rather annoying. Let's start with the first thing: Disruption. In Lies of P, some enemies inflict debuffs upon your character. Although most debuffs are more than fine and completely balanced, disruption chose to be the black wolf of the bunch and opted to one shot kill you if your gauge fills up. One-hit kills are never a fun mechanic in any games. Disruption is not over used but in the short time span which it was, the encounters were much more frustrating than fun. Then, you've got the loot on the ground. Frankly, the loot in this game tends to be a bunch of worthless stuff which eventually makes you question why you're even picking it up. Consumables aren't interesting or required in a play-through and since the loot pool consists of mostly consumables, it makes the system falls flat a bit.

I've started a NG+ run and so far the whole thing seems alright to me. I'm somewhat disappointed that there aren't many changes to the enemies to create a bigger challenge but I suppose that 33 hours of content is already quite a bit for most games. Plus, I wouldn't be surprised if a few updates came along to make the end game more interesting, there's a lot of potential for it at the moment.

[h3]My Conclusion[/h3]
In conclusion, Lies of P is a FINISHED POLISHED game. Which means, you won't find yourself fighting against the game itself to have it run decently. The combat system is simple, easy to get the hang of and one of the most fun combat system I've seen in most games. The way progression is handled in Lies of P adds flavour to the overall gameplay and replayability to the eras you've already visited. In my opinion, if it wasn't for Baldur's Gate 3, Lies of P would be the game of the year of 2023, which it would 100% deserve. If you're scared of buying the game because it might be difficult, don't worry it's nothing you won't be able to handle. I had never played a Souls-Like and I managed perfectly fine. 

Lies of P is the game that got me into Souls-Like and it was phenomenal. Thanks to it, I plan on going for more than just a dip into the genre.

What better place to start then by saying this is without a doubt the best game you can currently find within the souls-like genre. After almost 100 hours and after almost finishing my second playthrough, it still blows my mind how perfectly Neowiz seemed to have studied what made Souls games so captivating and rewarding for thousands of players. If you are a fan of this genre, this should be an absolute must-play and is well worth the price. 

However, if you are simply looking for an action game with a good story and some RPG elements, you might be turned off by this game. Not because this game doesn't have a a great and nuanced story with detailed worldbuilding and a polished combat system that encourages diversity (which it absolutely delivers); but because the difficulty curve is one of the highest I have experienced so far in games. Although this game does offer some opportunities to lower the difficulty of bosses and area traversal (e.g. overpowered throwing items, NPC summons for bosses, low levelling cost), Neowiz takes the same approach of player perseverance that linear games like Sekiro adopt. Particularly in the early-game, this can be frustrating and off-putting for players, as many enemy attacks are quite punishing. I admit that I was put off by the game's oddly small window for successful parries and a seemingly disproportionate level of risk for the amount of reward you get for these individual actions when I had played the demo. You could absolutely interpret this as a fault of the developers and I would be hard-pressed to defend these developmental choices, but nonetheless I still purchased the full game and persevered throughout the rest of the game. And you know what? It was genuinely really fricking fun! 

That's it, that's the end of the review lol. Though I could delve into more detail, it wouldn't really add to the overall message I'm trying to get across with this review.

A fantastic souls-like that's the closest thing you'll ever get to Bloodborne on PC.

Fantastic visuals, great bossfights, fun weapons systems, solid worldbuilding and an interesting interpretation of the Pinocchio story. It might seem a bit silly before you start, but as soon as you're in the game and experience it for yourself, you'll understand.

It's more linear compared to it's contemporaries, but Lies of P still stands among the best of them.

Really enjoyed this one from start to finish and through multiple playthroughs. The combat feels good, the weapon customization system lets you experiment and change up your play style, the bosses were challenging but it felt amazing when you got in the rhythm and took them down, and the block/parry system allows for just the right amount of panic when going against new enemies and you are unsure how to approach them.

Overall, absolutely recommend this one and I hope they end up doing another one of these games.

This game is very strong for a first-time effort from the devs, and plays like a love-letter to all of From's portfolio  -  taking elements from their entire back-catalogue, especially Bloodborne.

pretty impressive, soulslike that lives up to the genre name. 

The weapon customization system is pretty cool. 

Bosses quite challenging, and require you to really learn them, rather than maxing out your HP and healing, and then trading hits, like you can do in later dark soul games.

You don't even have to play the game, just play Feel and Quixotic records over and over again. At that point you know there's lots of love put into this game's lore and how rewarding it feels to lie like a human.

On a more serious note, this is the most polished Souls-Like that is ready to take many hours of your life and still feel like something From Software created themselves. The mixture of the game's familiar, yet refreshing takes on their combat skyrockets this game's potential. A good balance of making the game hard but rewarding...the linear level design so I don't have to worry about missing everything...the absolutely straight-to-the-point great story and hidden lore.

I only wish I could regain the 60 hours of playtime to replay the game again like an excited child who got his very first (hard) video game for his birthday.

This is hands down the most surprisingly good game to come out this year. This developer team came out of nowhere to mix the soulslike genre with the Pinocchio story...and it WORKS. Not only does the atmosphere and setting blend perfectly into the genre, but the gameplay and combat system is pushed to its absolute limits. The culmination "best of" every Fromsoft game, as well as throwing in plenty of new ideas for the genre never seen before. I could simply sum this game up by saying it's better Sekiro with Bloodborne weapons and aesthetic, but there's so much more only to be discovered through playing, which I would 100% recommend if you like the soulslike genre. Is it the best soulslike ever made? No, I think it's better than Sekiro, not as good as Dark Souls III, and Dark Souls III is my 2nd favorite Fromsoft game, behind Bloodborne. Obviously that's my opinion and I just mention it for comparison's sake, I've heard plenty of people say this IS the best soulslike ever made, even above everything Fromsoft has made.

One of my new favourite games of all time.  It can be difficult at points, but the ability to combine handles/blades to create your own unique weapon to suit your play style makes it feel like a very fair challenge.

I expected just another discount soulslike, but what I found was a very refined homage to the soulslike genre. The developers took a formula that Fromsoft built and actually made their own twist on it. The Pinochio theme is really inspired, a fantastic way to build your own world based on a commonplace name. The game play is smoother than any other soulslike other than the OG, really felt good to play. My only complaint is that the different builds in the game dont feel particularly different. This also leads to no real way to "Cheese" a boss. In my opinion a very fun part of dark souls is discovering all the little tricks and secrets for beating each boss. There were no secrets to be found in the bosses of this game. The level design and boss design is inspired though, just not enough secrets and tricks for me. Fantastic game, rate it a solid 8/10.

A different take on Pinocchio, where you play as P. Its a 3rd person action game(Classified as soulslike).
Compared to other soulslike and fromsoft games, this game has its own unique identity.
Unique Features
You can mix and match weapon movesets and blades, with the fact you only need to upgrade the "blade" it makes it easy to test other handle and movesets.
Guarding enemy attacks causes chip damage that can be recovered by attacking(like bloodborne). Perfect blocking causes stagger damage.
A "upgrade" tree in addition to your stats, allowing you to modify your playstyle.(Such as dodge orientated or block focused), as well as the legion arm equipment, allowing for unique moves(Like a exploding shield or grabbing arm)

While the game is linear, the map itself uses clever shortcuts such that your starting position never change, bvut by unlocking doors you can take shortcuts. The maps on the other hand is disjointed, which I guess is to be expected when you need long corridors.
Enemys are tough but fair, with recent balance patches balancing things out.

Pleasantly surprised at how Soulslike it is, and yet has its own twist, parrying is amazing in this game with how it interacts and encourages a much more bloodborne-esque aggressive style, which works well with not punishing missing parrys and instead has you retaliate to regain health. The bosses start fairly easy and progressively get more difficult, and the choices of weapons and customisation is great.

It's hard to take the Pinocchio inspiration seriously, but the environmental storytelling and level design sell the experience for me. I just wish the boss fights were a bit more memorable or offered more of a challenge.

This is my personal Game of the year..

It's the same quality as Fromsoftware. The enemy variety is wild, there's so many. The bosses are amazing. Gameplay is top notch.

It's definitely on the difficult side, but if you wanted to trivialize fights there's summons, summon buffs and broken throwables. 

Only downsides IMO are no hidden areas, parry window could be slightly more forgiving and some areas are pretty linear.

If you like souls games, then this is a must. Initially it felt a little empty and the combat felt “floaty”, but the more I played, I adjusted and got so immersed in the story and the world. NEOWIZ have crafted an amazing environment. It’s beautiful and I took so many screenshots playing through. All the weapons are fun, and you can really customize how you want to play the game. The durability system is well balanced, and the combat lost the weird floaty feeling pretty quickly. The characters are awesome, and i don’t just mean P and the fact I think he’s kinda hot. My favorite characters, especially after getting to know their story were probably [spoiler]Black Cat and Red Fox[/spoiler]. I don’t mean to come across as rude, but I’m not 100% sure where everyone keeps saying it gets hard. I have played pretty much every soils game in the past, so it could just be I’m very experienced in these types of games, but that’s besides the point. Another thing is the music is AMAZING. If you aren’t a fan of the like old classical style of music you may not like it as much, but I loved it. Honestly is going up towards the top of souls games I genuinely enjoyed, and may even crack the list in best games I’ve played. 

If you want a souls game with a touching story, beautiful environment, and great music, this is a must. I 100% recommend, and look forward to any additions in the future. NEOWIZ have definitely put themselves on my radar due to this game. :)

Let me preface this review by stating I'm a diehard fan of the Souls/Borne games. Ever since the OG "Demons Souls" released on PS3 I've been ruthlessly addicted to the punishing genre. This was another wonderful entry into the small Souls/Borne category. Combat is reminiscent of the genre, meaning it's punishing but predictable. Learn your boss attack patterns and remember the five D's of dodgeball, dodge, duck, dip, dive and dodge. The weapons are where the game separates itself from the competition. Have a sick fireaxe head and want to attach it to your dagger handle? Have at it! Most weapons come with the ability to be split into two components and swapped allowing for creation of some rather unique weapons. Scenery is standard for the genre and the morality system is very interesting. Should you lie your way to your humanity or tell the truth and remain prisoner, forever locked in your wooden cell? Regardless I suggest you grab the game if you're a fan of the genre at all. You won't be sorry.

Lies of P feels exactly like a FromSoftware game, except Lies of P is a linear map. 
If you're familiar with souls games, i recommend this game, but for other players i would say probably not due to this game being more difficult than the average video game. 
Combat is great! Blocking attacks will take away stamina and take away health but can be earned back by attacking (and blocking if you get the skill from the skill tree). So if you know you cant parry, just block then attack to get your health back. Parry times are easy (to me, others say its too hard to parry. Just get good scrub). Weapons have special abilities that require "fate" (aka mana) to use, which is gained by attacking (and other ways that are acquired through a skill tree). The weapon abilities are more meant for elites and bosses so when you do need them you should already have some mana saved up.
Health Vials are similar to Dark Souls except the max amount of vials is increased by killing certain bosses and through the skill tree.
After a while, the player is given a special arm that has a ability to pull small enemies to the player.  Most enemies are slow so having the ability to separate enemies from groups is amazing. Later on the player can get upgrades for the arm and new arms entirely, like a flamethrower, acid sprayer, missile launcher and a few others.
Blades and handles from weapons are swappable. So you can mix and match weapons. Have a dagger but dont like the short range? Just change the handle to something longer like a spear handle.
There are 3 stat builds the player can do:
-Motivity (strength)
-Technique (dexterity)
-Advanced (elemental)

My friend did strength and didnt struggle with the game at all. We started the game at the same time but he beat it first.
I did 1 playthrough with Technique and another playthrough with Advanced. Advanced felt more flexible with the weapon types and dealt way more damage. So if you can decide on a stat build, i would say Advanced but make sure to use a weapon element the enemy is weak to (use shock/electricity when fighting puppets)

Main reason the second run was shorter was because i learned already was familiar with the bosses and locations. Bosses on my first run took about 5-15 attempts, meanwhile the second run i beat all bosses first try except for 3 (those 3 took 2-5 attempts).

This game is absolutely majestic and spectacular! From the gameplay, to the OST, this really makes me want to replay it over and over. The ost is beautiful, some of them even making me cry just by listening to them. I cannot express more on how amazing this game is.

It's quite Soulslike. Some of the things that really bother me about Fromsoft games aren't so much of a problem in Lies of P. It also uses the deflection system from Sekrio, but it's not forced on you, so you have more options. It's also harder than most Souls and Soulslike games.

Lies of P charmed my pants off. They successfully synthesized a souls game from many elements that would not normally be straightforwardly cohesive for the genre. Leaning into the innate darkness of fairy tales with contemporary explorations of Robots and humanity (Nier, Pluto) to supplement the puppet filled narrative. They assembled a voice cast that is honestly leagues above the expectations I had, and they completely sold the drama.

The Exploration is fine. The areas are overall pretty linear but tightly wound around the spawn points with plenty of shortcuts. If anything it's a bit too forgiving with spawn points for most of the experience, leaving many shortcuts little used. Plenty of set-pieces and minibosses to challenge you.

Combat is probably the most contentious part of the experience. It's very demanding and will be infuriating unless you're willing to learn and enter the flow state, but nothing feels better than landing a flurry of parries on a boss. Weapon variety is pretty good, you can mix and match common blades and handles to suit your play, but the boss weapons completely outclass them with their gimmicks and play style. Common weapons are most useful for utilizing free elemental damage (if you're having trouble on a boss literally just make sure to use elemental damage and enemy type amulet buffs).

By far the most competent non-from souls game with its own set of particularities, aside from Team Ninja titles (Nioh and the ilk are wonderful to play but the random loot driven aspect of those experiences weigh them down). Very excited that this game ended up being a surprise success and looking forward to whatever fun Fairy tale exploration NEOWIZ follows up Lies of P with.

Game is great, with some issues that could need fixing.

Pros: Weapons, abilities, and story is cool. Bosses are always different and fun to play against.

Cons: No map, you can get easily lost during chapters. No defined objectives. If you take a break from playing you better remember what you're doing, or just run around until something new happens since there no place to track current objectives. Finding npc's can also be hard. While they often will show up with their icons on the fast travel location, you have to look up where they are in order to find them.

Overall, the game is awesome. I feel like some minor fixes could be made to perfect the experience.

Arguably the best non-FromSoft "Souls" game to come out ever, nothing has really come close to matching them until now. With a mix of the Sekiro parry with the bloodborne rally mechanic and the insane amount of weapon customization, it really allows the game to stand on its own. 

If i had to knock it for anything, id say the game is relatively linear, but for a game of this size and fidelity its not necessarily a bad thing, considering this is the devs first foray into the genre and they really nailed it. Denuvo being added at release was also a bit of a cruddy move. 

I can forgive all this considering the devs are extremely receptive to fan feedback and take fan requests and suggestions seriously. They even included the soundtrack in the deluxe edition upgrade to make it more worth the price after feedback. Hopefully they remove Denuvo soon, the game runs great on lower tier machines (as well as the Steam Deck) and it will only run better after its gone.

Great game, probably the best soulslike I've played (and I've played most of the non 2D ones available). The atmosphere/sound design/aesthetic are top-notch and really evocative, worldbuilding is great albeit more focused on the audiovisuals rather than e.g. flavourtext (which is likely more appealing to most but I'm a sucker for lore in flavourtext too). Performance is great with a lot of PC options like various fps caps and DLSS/FSR etc.

The gameplay is probably my biggest criticism of the game; the at times hodgepodge feeling combination of dodging and parrying can feel weird and awkward to learn. Leaning towards one or the other ala bloodborne vs sekiro might serve the devs better in designing enemies/bosses, as well as reducing confusion in the player as to which system they should be trying to 'get good' at; this last bit is likely a big sticking point for many players when starting out with the game. Frankly I would place lies of P's gameplay as below e.g. Nioh/Wo Long (and certainly well below Sekiro) when it comes to tightly designed combat systems, but it is enjoyable enough and definitely passes the bar. As well, going into NG+ I expect to have to utilize more of the mechanics such as consumable combat items which should increase my appreciation of the gameplay.

Difficulty is challenging but reasonable, I'm a seasoned souls player and completed NG in ~22 hours, only dying to a couple of bosses. One particular boss did have my heart pounding at the end but otherwise I would describe most bosses as 'interesting/cool' rather than 'epic/amazing' in terms of gameplay. Most bosses are quite impressive in terms of their presentation and music though, with only a rare few blander fights.

Overall I'd highly recommend this game to anyone interested in (probably one of the best) soulslikes, or even just interested in the general aesthetic/vibe of the game; a gentle disclaimer to the latter group that they may have to get over some clunkiness/learning hurdles at the start, but I think the rest of the game more than makes up for it.

In this game you play as John P, a mechanical puppet who awakes in the hellscape city of Le Croissant, and fight to find their meaning as a puppet or something more, in a Soulslike heavily, and I mean very heavily inspired by Bloodborne and Sekiro, and it does the unthinkable, the imposible, making the game to seem it has been made by Miyazaki himself.

As you explore the world, you will have the choice of telling the truth or not, for example, if you find someone who says Xenoblade is a stupid horny anime game, NieR is a Hack and Slash and not a bullet hell in disguise and it didn´t need to replay the same events with new perspective, or worst, Undertale is a meaningless game for young kids, if you say yes to all of that questions, you will gain humanity, as lying is one of the most human behavior, if this sounds like a morality system to you, it doesn´t, because there´s like very little impacts in lying or not, but beside the philosophical aspect of it, there´s very cool surprises of lying that is worth to do a lie only as your first playthought.

Make a dex build because who plays strenght anyways, and use one of the coolest mechanics I ever seen in a Soulslike, making your own weapons, as you explore, you will find weapons like you would see in other souls games, but you can split them in two to fuse with other weapons you find, are you tired of playing all the time with your trustworty weapon? Just split it i two and put the blade in other handle to change their propierties, until you pass chapter VIII and got the katana, seriously that´s one if not the most fun weapon in a Souls game I ever played, as you parry, parry, dodge, and parry even more in the finest battle system ever made in the genre.

And if all of this sounds interesting to you, is even better that is sounds, because the art and sound desing is just exquisite, and feature the best QoL in this type of game, my only complain is about the skill tree, because to fully finish it you need to go for NG++, and it has very, very good upgrades, but isn´t too much because the game is really replayable.

[h3] Alright, I've never reviewed a game before. but I just had to for Lies of P. [/h3]

[b][u]TL;DR: This game is fantastic. It's my game of the year for sure. There are tons of issues and problems that I'll dive into a bit deeper, but none of the problems are dealbreakers. Meanwhile the positives on this game are really strong[/b][/u]

I've just went through the ending of the game and while I've played most Dark Souls and some other Souls like games, this is the first one where I feel the need to go through NG+ and 100% this game. I don't have a game on 100% anywhere except for Super Mario which I played with my SO for years at this point.

Lets start with the bad sides of the game:

[b]CONS[/b]
While souls like games revolve around the combat, I think the combat is the weakest point of Lies of P. Regular enemies are good solid fun, they're predictable, not too cheesy, their locations were solid but as a souls like enjoyer also very predictable. The problems arise in more tougher opponents and especially later on in the game with the bosses. As the bosses get increasingly more mobility and ranged attacks. The reason why this is a bad thing has to do with how feast or famine the combat is in boss fights. It feels like the game is pushing you towards the boss so there's not a lot of strategical movement, there's for sure some. The main thing that's expected from you is that you're parrying or at least blocking attacks. This is where Dark Souls wins in my opinion, dodging to get out of attacks simply just feels way better than hoping you hit that parry. I still haven't found a souls like game that combines dodging and parrying on an equal level, while Lies of P came close to this, the execution just isn't there.
Adding onto the point above is the hitboxes, they're inconsistent. You get hit by stuff that wasn't even close, or you're not getting hit when a sword goes straight through you.
Adding onto both is the relianc on parrying when the enemy attacks feel RNGish. They feel like there's a window in which they CAN attack but sometimes do it faster or slower. I can't 100% confirm if this is true, I've read some stuff that this is true, but it's beyond the point. Timing a parry feels terrible. Hitting a parry is decently satisfying but doesn't always have the impact that you expect or hope that it has.
The animation locking is a mechanic I wish never excisted. It's my main gripe with the game that I absolutely hate. It makes the combat feel clunky at times but animation locking is also absolutely terrible outside of combat. Killing an enemy, having to wait 2 seconds, picking up an item, having to wait 2 seconds, then being able to hit again is just bad. It's not fun, it's super annoying and I don't see a reason why this is the case. Picking up your dropped ergo on death doesn't require an animation, why does picking up an item need one?

A con apart from all of this is more or less my personal preference that some or most of you might not agree with: I don't like leveling like Lies of P does it. I don't want to respec to put my points in another stat to make different weapons useable. I also don't like that putting points into technique also means the threshold for the next lvl up on capacity increases. I'd much rather have seen the "utility" stats have their seperate pool apart from the "combat" stats and honestly have all the combat stats be seperate so that we can level them all up and use all of the weapons. I know this would require an insane rebalancing of the game and they shouldn't do this, it's just a point of feedback for me personally.

[b]PROS[/b]
So my paragraphs above are big and most people won't read them in this 5 second tiktok attention span society, but I feel it's important to give as constructive feedback as possible for the developers. For the pros I won't dive as deep into WHY I think they're pros, they speak for themself:
Lies of P map design is very linear but it does such a great job at connecting each zones that it feels like you have more freedom than most open world games do.
The attention to detail on pretty much anything in the game is simply astounding.
The voice acting might be the best I've ever seen, anywhere.
The different weapons, especially the special weapons are so much fun to play with. Mixing and matching weapons was the greatest call in development that they could've made.
The story is solid. Could've been explained a bit more earlier on and put a little bit less of the heavy lifting in the later stages of the game. That said, I actually have no complaints.
The choices are just a great addition, you can barely go wrong with adding choices. The humanity(?) system adds some deeper layer to Pinocchio.
Legion Arm, Fable Arts, Grindstone are really well executed. They all feel very powerful and useful in their own niche. 

I can keep going I think.
it's fun. well u suffer a bit in the beginning if ur not a soul-like player, but the game content is good.
This game makes my P-organ hard.

[h2]Long Version[/h2]
This has to be the best (and most difficult) non FromSoftware Souls-like. In my opinion, it even competes with some of the FromSoft titles.
[list]
[*] The visuals are amazing.
[*] The combat feels incredibly satisfying and well tuned.
[*] The enemies are diverse and 90+% of them are very well made and creative.
[*] The weapons and the combinations you can do feel cool to use and well balanced.
[*] Bossfights are cinematic, yet also well designed.
[*] This is probably the first Souls-like where consumable matter. They deal a significant amount of damage, and spending the skillpoints to make them better feels worth it.
[*] Speaking of: The skill tree is very well done in my opinion. It adds another piece of loot to the pool, that you are excited to find, because it unlocks cool new skills.
[*] I have a low-to mid range PC, and never had any performance issues while playing, which I did not expect from a game looking this good.
[/list]
Here's the issues I have with the game:
[list]
[*] Parrying feels a little [i]too[/i] difficult for how important it is to the games combat.
[*] In later areas, it is very common to find low level upgrade materials, which kind of feels like they are just there to fill up the areas with loot to pick up, but since by that point you can purchase them for cheap, they feel kind of worthless. Replacing them with consumables, Ergo items or slightly higher tier materials would help with that a lot.
[*] [spoiler]The final Area of the game feels a little too long.[/spoiler] [spoiler]I really enjoyed it for the first half or so, but after the Laxasia Bossfight, in my opinion, the final boss gauntlet should have started pretty much immediately. The area after that just feels a little dragged out.[/spoiler]
[*] [spoiler]After the Bishop boss, every main boss has a second healthbar, removing any sense of surprise at it happening. Just change it to be one larger healthbar and have the transition at 50%.[/spoiler]
[/list]
All those "issues" are really just nitpicks. I really enjoyed my time with the game, and I'm sure I will revisit it once I've played through all the other amazing games of 2023.

[h2]TL:DR[/h2]
This game is a solid 9/10 for me. I can strongly recommend giving it a try if you like punishing gameplay.

The first (and only) souls-like game I have played. It was brutal at times but the game does have ways of assisting even newbies through challenges in a variety of ways. For me, the Aegis legion arm got me through the whole game since I can't seem to get perfect guards down. The window is too small in my opinion but there are ways around it. The puppet string is another great tool once fully upgraded.

Aside from my poor skill, I was able to beat the game. Plus it just got a patch that should make it easier for anyone thinking about it. I think the story was interesting. It's a cool fantastic take on an otherwise boring story for me (sorry Pinocchio). The music is fantastic. And you can pet the cat!

Music is now available on streaming services. I highly recommend purchasing it as well to help support this wonderful team.

I came from Souls games (DS 123, Elden Ring, Sekiro, Nioh, you name it). All I hate in Lies of P is the combat mechanics. P is slow to roll (no I am not heavy rolling), he is slow to parry, even when you perfect the timing (I don't think anyone can get past black rabbit if they don't perfect parrying) and slow to use consumables (activating the wishstone takes precious seconds, using estus is slow idk). The world design isn't anything mind-blowing. Also, if you know one boss you know them all (there aren't really that many differences between one combat and another), just get in, smack, fall back, and repeat. P is too slow to maintain closeness and attack in between breaks and then roll through combos, you have to wait for the big breaks. All the "stay in between the boss' legs" and "dodge to the right because to the left you get smacked" strategies from other Souls games are useless, and the enemy attacks are very hard to read because they're not as telegraphed as in other souls games. Also, you have to invest in stamina because perfect parrying is one sure way to stun the boss quicker, and you almost always have to spam parry because even if it seems like the boss isn't rearing up to attack, you never know. 

Another thing, when Geppetto started talking about the "P organ" I almost laughed myself off the chair. This is absolutely the most absurd name for an ability tree I have ever seen. Most of the times I cannot bring myself to go to update my... 🙈 P organ using quartz because of how absurd it sounds.

I loved all souls games: DS, ER, Sekiro, God of war etc. They all had amazing combat mechanics, you didn't feel like the character was unresponsive to your keyboard as you feel in Lies of P.

All in all, the game is short, unsatisfactory in all areas (combat, graphic design, soundtrack, weapons) and just plain boring. Idk how to feel about paying so much for it because I fell for positive reviews.

For a first time Studio they sure as Hell delivered on a very unique story and Soul's like Game, Which is something that is gonna be hard to pull off with the amount of them now out or coming out.

Lies of P offers a very unique blend of Bioshock, American Mcgee's Alice and Dark Souls all rolled into one with its stunning visuals, Gameplay and Story. Full of unique characters that feel familiar yet unique enough to stand on their own.

The gameplay is a sort of mix between Sekiro and other souls games, Although the parrying window is a bit wonky and takes some getting use to. Not to mention like other souls games there are some bullshit attacks and abilities that can be frustrating it doesn't take away from the quality or final score.

I highly recommend this game and from what I have seen DLC and Sequels are on the way which I am defiantly keeping a eye out for. Who knew that we needed a Souls-Like Brothers Grimm classical literature universe and I looking forward to Wizard of Oz or Alice in Wonderland souls game.

Love this game. 
It did take longer for this game to click for me than most. It wasn't until Chapter 5 that I started to get the hang of it and not sucking, but once I got into the rhythm of the game it quickly became one of my top favorite games ever, and apparently my first game on Steam I've gotten all 100% achievements. 

The atmosphere in this game is soo good! The art direction, the mood of the environments, the character designs, and the great music! Some bosses, sadly not many, have some stand out tracks, BUT the collectable vinyl records are really something else to listen to when you're back at the main central hub area. Soo many are just such a treat that I've listened to all of them repeatedly on playlist. And has a decent story mixed in as well.

The combat gives you more options than it appears on the surface with being able to make an arsenal of mix n' match weapon blades + weapon handles, or unique special weapons, and special ability prosthetic arms. That all on top of a customizable skill tree of sorts actually gives players quite a bit to play around with to find something that feels good and fun to them. The game is hard, and it feels early bosses definitely hit you extremely hard before your gear and health start to catch up, which can make the early game bosses feel like huge hurdles to overcome, but over all I felt the difficulty of this game hit a sweet spot for me and it definitely felt well tuned and thought out, and not just randomly thrown together bull for the sake of being difficult. 

Overall, if you're into harder action rpgs, or souls games, there's a high chance you'll probably enjoy this as well.
Amazing game

Overall it's a decent souls like. It's got some great parts, and some rather... meh parts, and a few outright bad parts. But, overall, it's a good game that while not as good as DS1 or DS3 or Elden Ring, is better than DS2, and comparable SteelRising in overall quality. Each one has a few thing it does better, but both are still solid and overall enjoyable most of the time.

The upsides.
+ The core gameplay, it's pretty solid, I did find a few gameplay bugs butt just a few over 40 hours of play, so most times I failed it was, arguably, me that failed on a boss.
+ The art, it's pretty good. Looks nice, decent music, nice animations, some excelent animations honestly. Some of the bosses have amazing designs and amazing animations, and frankly I just love watching them or fighting them.
+Length, it's god some pretty decent length, not up there with a From souls game, given the limited replayability and stuff to search for or find, but the basic story and path is decently long.
+Weapons, you can modify weapons to better fit differnet builds, or swap handles and blades/heads for new interesting things on some weapon types. It's... not perfect and you often don't use it, but it does make it a bit easier to swap your build or try new weapons during a run more easily. Though when only one weapon or two can reliably be upgraded enough at any given time with limited resources, that really does limit how much you can try the different weapons sadly.

Downsides
-Samey and linear world. Most of the levels are brown, black, grey, and dark. While there is some variation in the exact locations they all have too similar of a feel so without a pallete cleanser at some point it just... meh... started to get tiring. Also there's very few of those "wow" areas where you just stop and stare as you enter a new amazing area. Most of this game is in enclosed city streets or narrow pathways, very little open areas, and when it is it's mostly just backdrops. The world is also linear, no options, real alternate paths or branches or anything, no hidden/breakable walls by the player, overall you don't really explore or engage with the world, it just feels ike any old games linear levels for the most part. So for a souls game, it's pretty bad honestly for how you interact with the world, it didn't keep my interest a lot, and not much is memorable unlike most souls games having tons of those unique or Wow areas, or interesting exploration surprises as you find something.
-Gameplay, while mostly good, it's also got some issues. The biggest is how the game relies on parrying so much, but it's got a delay, yet some bosses have rapid attacks you can barely keep up with so it's really pushing what you can do and relying way too much on a system that isn't up to the task to readily or fluidly be used I feel. Next, when you take a hit, you have recover times and it affects your ability to do things, timings on some animations, etc... this makes your character less responsive, and not feel like they listen to you right after any one hit. This often can result in one hit turning into a chain you can't do much against and then dying. Especially against a few enemies that have strong and fast chains. Losing control of your character because of any one mistake or miss timing is not fun, especially when the game is nearly forcing you to rely on parrying for many bosses, with again, rather bad and non intuitive feeling timing for the parry system. Camera and environment also play their role here, nothing like fighting an enemy the camera can't see their moves on as they are too big, yet right in your face so you can hit them back, or when you get stuck on random tables or chairs or things scattered around the boss level and die because of it. Some bosses you won't notice any of these issues on, good telegraphing, timings, nice open levels, nicely sized for visibility, some excellent fights... but some others do really bring out some of these issues badly, so it's a mixed bag.
-Story. While it's a nice idea... and there's some good story to be had here, some of it is also just... bad, or doesn't make sense if you think about it for more than a second, for even some major story elements, using the logic of the setting itself. So... I just can't get too invested in the lore or stuff overall, but still most characters are decent and there's enough story that's still good to enjoy, but it won't suck you in like a good soulsike can, so, it's good, but not great... I only put it here in negative because, again, the biggest issues with it are just that, big obvious issues they seemingly ignored and like an enemy with missing textures on his face, it kind of stands out when playing the game... a lot... Though, mostly end game and second play through when you can figure all the key details out finally.

Overall, it's got plenty of issues, but 70-80% of the time I was enjoying myself at least decently, and there are while some bad frustrating bosses or areas... also several excellent ones that really are fun and enjoyable to fight.  So I'd say it's worth getting, especially on sale if it is. And I do look forward to more from these devs in the future, as they clearly layed out the possibility for at the end. Hopefully next time they can refine a few of those issues better from experience, but for a first shot from most of the team at souls likes, great job!
Loved this game

I have a few complaints, like overuse of 2 healthbars per boss, the final boss having disruption (this games equivalent of deathblight from elden ring), a very restricted boss roster, where of the 26-27 bosses maybe 7-8 of them are optional, some boss fights feel far too difficult without using specters but become trivial the second you decide to summon one, and with the sheer amount of star shards you receive you could use them for each fight without worry. The weapon break mechanic is very cool albeit not very useful, most bosses require far too many parries in order to break their weapons, the only time a bossfight has a weapon break was a shield on their back, which didnt even fully break and still blocked back attacks.

But the game has plenty of positives, the weapon system with the variety of damage with the blades, and movesets of the handles is fantastic, and with the amount of upgrade materials you receive it allows you to use as many as you'd like, respecing stats is cheap, I really like how the choices have such short time limits as it forces you to choose instead of giving you the option of googling the best outcome, lying having such major consequences is fantastic. Combat is fluid, with a few exceptions it feels obvious when you should parry/dodge although sometimes it feels you're incentivized to block rather than "perfect block" as they push you away leaving you less time to punish, and the rally mechanic being attached to blocking rather than overall damage like in Bloodborne solidifies it being better in a good portion of cases.

When the dlc drops I'll be buying it 100% (hopefully they have less fights with 2 healthbars though)

Almost 10/10, but no game can truly be perfect. Lies of P blurs that line for what feels like infinitely. Like, 9.9999999~/10 but I digress. The combat is fluid and yet rigid. The world is breathtaking and huge, yet linear for gameplay purposes. The upgrades and abilities are varied and thought out to where you can approach combat with several different mentalities. The graphics are stunning and the story may not be fully in your face but is huge when it hits. 

The combat system has been deemed too hard by some but I disagree. The game doesn't hold your hand, no doubts about that. However, it also doesn't just give you rewards on a silver platter. The parry window is tight but the attacks can be timed off of instinct 80-90% of the time. Parries are also rewarded with breaking enemies weapons which makes the encounter infinitely easier. The weapons are varied and unique allowing for mixing and matching to fit one's play style as they see fit. The arms add unique abilities from a flamethrower to landmines to a grappling hook with their own upgrades as well.

The world feels lived-in and dreary yet with hope stemming from those you save. The story of whether or not this autonomous puppet will chose to follow orders or embrace his inner humanity is one that is so thick and full of character. The changes to the character as you move throughout the game are little but very noticeable after taking the time to listen and look.

Overall, the game is about as perfect in my head as a game can get. A wonderfully packaged story bound together with exhilarating gameplay and a deep sense of accomplishment as you work your way through the ruined city of Krat. It's not Dark Souls.

It's name is Lies of P.

Disgustingly good. Here's a few ups and a few downs:

The many good things:
- Outstanding realisation of the souls-like genre/formula. If you enjoy these games, you'll most likely enjoy this one. Think Bloodborne aesthetics, Sekiro combat, and general Dark Souls mechanics.
- Great story. That good mix of utterly obscure, deeply unsettling, and completely fascinating.
- Hub area is "Hotel Krat" and it's very charming. You slowly populate it with the survivors you find as you play, including your dad. He's totally OK and Definitely Not Crazy™.
- There's an in-game cat you can pet. If you can win its trust.
- The graphics aren't just beautiful, they're well optimised. You can enjoy this game's splendour without fretting too much about your framerate. There's also some technical hints and clues that suggest ray tracing will probably be added eventually.

Some downs:
- The combat is varied enough to be interesting but can be seen as rather "one-note" as it mostly revolves around mastering the /incredibly/ tight parry windows. No matter what build or playstyle you're rocking, you must eventually become Parry The Platypus if you want to finish the game.
- As with all RPGs and especially souls-likes, grinding will make the game easier. Too little and you'll be overwhelmed by simple enemies, too much and you'll breeze right through. 
- Ray tracing is not here yet, and we are all the poorer for it since this game has fantastic potential for it with already-excellent lighting, scenery, and visual direction.

I don't do numbers. No stars or ?/10s from me. It's a simple question of "Is it good or not good?" 

and this game is good. Very good. If you like the Souls-like genre then this is worthy of your time and money. That's all there is to it.

Definitely not the flawless game everybody claims it to be, but overall its a good finished game in a time of early access garbage. Here are my thoughts:

PROS:
- Amazing weapon and build variety 
- Unique story tailored towards your emotions
- Weapon Arts (Fable) Go brrrr
- Ability to make bosses much easier with an optional NPC Summon
- Satisfying Parry system (much less forgiving than Sekiro though)

CONS:
- Overused souls-tropes, (Enemies hiding behind walls next to items, Bridges breaking underneath you, etc.)
- Legion arms are terrible in most circumstances, its almost always better to just use your weapon or block normally
- Almost every boss has 2 phases with a massive health pool making the game feel more like a slog and I often didn't feel happy after finally beating a tough boss

Lies of P undeniably echoes the gameplay style and mechanics of Bloodborne and Sekiro to a significant extent. From the challenging visceral combat system, where precision and timing are crucial to the ominous atmosphere and grotesque enemy designs. However, despite the blatant similarities, Lies of P does manage to carve its own identity. 

The narrative, although shrouded in mystery, introduces unique lore and a captivating world leaving you hooked throughout. The incorporation of different environments and level designs paired with an extraordinary soundtrack showcases the developer's creativity and ambition. There is so much tactical acumen allowing for meticulous fine-tuning with tons of weapons options offering unique pairing options for each weapon head and handle in addition to a diverse and useful range of legion arm abilities. The weapon-grinding & weapon-break mechanic plays into an interesting dynamic, acting as a secondary battle to keep your weapon from breaking before the enemy's weapon. The grindstone also allows you to imbue your weapon with a variety of really useful effects. The bosses are magnificent, never failing to carry weight or momentum behind them paired with perfect music and entertaining fast paced move sets. The last boss of the game was truly incredible, a wonderful song of metal clashing metal with an astonishing zenith in the narrative to suit. One thing I would've wished is that your individual decisions had a greater impact on the story, it's rather the culmination of choices that has any significance. 
Overall I would thoroughly recommend this game if you're looking for a challenge and beautiful story.

Lies of P is a souls-like game recommended for people that like these type of games. Its not a mere cheap copy of souls games or sekiros game. The developer took the best mechanics from Bloodborne, Sekiro and Dark Souls and compile its mechanics in this game. Thus, you can play this game like Sekiro (which focuses on parries), Bloodborne (block attacks and regain it through counter attacks) or Dark Souls (roll and dodge).

Very fun game. Draws a lot of inspiration from Sekiro and Bloodborne. The parrying feels really nice once you get into the groove and attack patterns of an enemy, really makes you feel badass when you full parry every attack in a 7 combo. 

I liked most of the bosses, although the gank fights were annoying at first, I learned how to manage them and they became far less of a threat. The rapid fire combos can be a PITA at times but it gives a nice adrenaline rush when you pull off crazy counters and comebacks. 

After 100%ing the game and then some, I do feel the game lacks in costumes; they all look mostly samey. Weapon wise there is a vast variety of weapons and assembled weapons to choose from. I really enjoyed experimenting with them.
If I didn't know better I would've thought FromSoft made this themselves. Incredibly high quality, one of the best games of this style.

Gameplay is tight. Perfect Guarding is fun. Enemy variety is good. Level design is very linear with usual branches for aditional loot and shortcuts. Running through the levels never felt tedious. Build variety is around Bloodborne level (different weapons, scaling with different stats + arms/tools with special abilities like pulling enemies towards you or pulling yourself towards enemy). Weapon assembly system which allows you to mix handles and blades/blunts of all non-boss weapons. (some combinations are hilarious) Character progression system is great. Aside from normal souls-like stat levelling, there is a P-Organ skill tree with some game changing abilities. Boss encounters are phenomenal and satisfying to learn thanks to perfect guard system. Music is amazing. World-building is also amazing. Looking forward to DLC and sequel.

A game like this comes once in a decade. As a long time dark souls enjoyer, this game really hits the mark on that genre. I like the combat system with the combination of guard and dodging, adds a lot of options when fighting various enemies and bosses. Also the support for 144HZ deserves a recommendation in and of itself. 

Overall a great game and very worth the price. Lots of challenge but nothing unfair or overly punishing.
A phenomenal first attempt by a relatively unknown studio. Can't wait to see their new take on the Wizard of Oz.
Incredibly fun while also extremely challenging and frustrating at times, then when you finally progress..... rewarding!! I highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a challenge.

Pros: I love this game.

Cons: Modding community is lacking.

It's my first Souls like game and the difficulty and gameplay feel great

still a great game with amazing soundtracks

I have to say that I was not expecting to have so much fun with this game. I love souls and souls like games and Lies of P is a very good game from that genre. I usually skip NG+ in other games but here the game was so good that I bothered to finish NG+ and well... it was fun unlike in Dark souls games.

Pros:
- Satisfactory game-play.  It is typical souls like schema. Doges, parries, braking stance etc. Sure it is nothing new but here it somehow clicks very well. I felt very good when I managed to almost perfectly deflect all attacks of one of the bosses that I had a problem with on my first play-through. Pure fun.
- Interesting game mechanics. Games offer some customisation in order to make the game a bit more fair for the player. You have Legion (mechanical arm) which nicely adds some options during the fights. You can also upgrade the main character with P-organs. Those give some bonuses (attacks, guard, etc) which allow you to make some builds that suit your style of playing this game.  
- Setting. Industrial era but with puppet revolution. Great idea and well presented. I wish I could see how that world could work more.
- World building. I really like how the game was presenting me with information that made me believe that the world presented in Lies of P can be real. Environmental storytelling (maps, item descriptions etc.), npcs, story progression really made me immersed into that world.
- Very good soundtrack. It fits well into that game.
- Npcs. I was really engaged in finding out about Npc quests. In comparison to souls games I really like that it is hard in this game to miss npc quests. When you teleport you can see if something is going on for places that you can teleport. In the end I could finish all the quests without feeling that I missed out something which happened a lot in other Souls games. Apart from that I think that English voice actors did a very good job, especially Venigni.  
- New game plus. It is nice that the game gives you some more upgrades in ng+. There are even some new upgrades available in ng++ which was really surprising. In other souls games in ng+ runs game changes into i-frames dodging game, here it is quite fun due to having something new to play with.
 
Cons:  
- Game is linear. You can only go in one direction. There is only one place in the game that you can go to instead of going through the main path. (one of the cryptic vessel quests). I wish we could have some options where we are going.

In general Lies of P is a great game. Using concepts from a well known story for kids, creating a world around it and encapsulating it into the game is a wonderful idea. I wish I could see more of that instead of gender swapping, race swapping and disrespecting original works that nowadays occurs in a lot of western movies (see The Little Mermaid 2023). You can see that the creators of Lies of P respect the work of Carlo Collodi and wanted to pay tribute to his timeless masterpiece.

I strongly recommend this game. For me it is the game of the year.

"If you told me FromSoftware made this game, I would believe it."

Lies of P is an amazing take on the Souls genre which while may not diverge from the formula as compared to Nioh, does well in its own right. Unlike other games in the souls genre, Lies of P is completely linear from start to finish, there is no optional area or boss. The story is pretty straightforward going from one area to another, beating the bosses of that specific area. There are however, missable side stories that one can miss due to not exploring or choosing the right option.

Gameplay wise, the game encourages a playstyle like Sekiro where parry is king but leaves the usual run & gun option viable for players. The game also encourages new game+ runs where not only do you unlock new abilities (Up to new game+2 for P-Organ 7), better variation of equipment (+1 / +2 variants) and small lore tidbits for puppet boss fights.

As someone who has played the game through its different patches (on my last ending run as of this review), I am very happy to see Neowiz take charge of the criticisms and suggestions given by the players.
Overall Neowiz did a very good job on their first take on the genre and I look forward to the upcoming DLCs planned for the game.

Edit: I'm changing for a No Recommended, Steam really needs to add a 3º option... I'm changing because I felt that the game looses it's magic after the 3ish boss, without spoiling much but I was kinda disappointed to see that the Puppets Frenzy thing became a side line. the game shifted way to fast from a really unique setting to generic setting 565251 in a span of 1 area, they could've done so so much more with the premise of Puppets rebelling and keeping stuff somewhat grounded but no...
I lost all interest on this game, the shift in story / direction and the badly implemented combat made me just quit. Not happy with this, I wanted to love this work so much! but the disappointment is just to strong to keep playing. If they fix the problems with the combat I may return to at least finish the game...  

Maybe what I'm about to say is because I played 140ish hours of Elden ring before playing Lies of P and had so much muscle memory that conflicted with the mechanics here but still:

Every thing about Lies of P is great, the music, the voices, the graphics, the premise (until mid game....), animations, art direction, all top notch, BUT the most important part of this genre is one thing and one thing only, combat, and Lies of P is kinda weak on that, in fact, even with a mod to make the game less frustrating I'm still need to push myself to play it just because the combat never feels right. Fromsoftware games work because of 1 thing, combat fluidity, after a few minutes to a few hours your character in From games becomes a extension of yourself. in Lies of P, after some good hours I still fighting against my character more than my enemies.

Dodge feels janky, doesn't move you enough away and you can clearly see on the 2º roll that the animation and the distance of the roll doesn't match, P stops a bit before the animation finishes, feels super off. Perfect Blocking is so damn hard to use than I just stop trying, this is because of the system here, instead of copying something that works they wanted to reinvent the wheel and made a square out of it, it's not intuitive at all. And then it's the enemies attacks, the enemies wind up and release moves so fast you just can't react and then they chain together moves that you can't keep up. (I give some slack on the puppets enemies, because they need to spring up the movement to then release the stored energy into motion... it's thematically correct at least, but game play wise it's frustrating). Oh and you can't animation cancel to go from a swing to a block, you need to either commit to attack or block. 

Without the mod to make the game easier (read: less frustrating) I do not recommend, the difficulty is not because the game is a challenge but because the mechanics are way too off and feels like you're wrestling your character instead of fighting the enemies. 

With the mod I recommend on a sale and / or want to support the devs.

I really really wanted to love this game, but I can't just put up with how off the combat feels, it's like everything else is AAA quality and the combat is some Unreal Store assets quality. They copied so much from the inspirations and forgot what made those inspirations work in the first place...

Lies of P is my nomination for Game of the Year (on Steam, anyway) for the Steam Awards 2023.  Of all the games that I played this year, I came back to Lies of P the most, again and again. I couldn't, and honestly still can't, get enough of it. Never has a game come so close to matching From Software at their own game than Lies of P. Honestly sensational Soulslike, one of the best.

Having played almost more than half of the game i can say that this game is very similar to bloodborne minus the ability to change your weapon's form. The ambiance and visuals are terrific, however the storyline is kinda meh.

The map is very linear and there is not much exploring to be had in most areas, because of this side quests are very easy to complete and dont feel that engaging or very worth your time.

The weapons are unique but most feel the same..... large weapons have similar animations and smaller weapons are more quicker and stabbier that being said there are a few weapons with unique quirks that stand out. Your left arm can work in interesting ways but its hard to synergise it with your normal attacks.

Many others have complained about a difficulty spike midway through the game. I havent felt any difference, however i sunk time in other souls-like games so im kinda used to the way these games play out, for a newbie i feel it would take sometime getting used to the mechanics especially against tankier opponents but for others you can expect gameplay similar to other souls games. The game allows you to parry like in sekiro and parry window is much more lenient than in DS but can still get away with dodging and poking the enemy.

Leveling up and  stats are what you would expect in any RPG.

All in all this game is highly polished and the animations are crisp. I'd reccomend this game to anyone who likes a challenge. The creativity really shows when it comes to enemy designs especially the bosses. I'd give it a 7/10

This game is nuts, and probably one of the best and hardest games I've ever played and it was worth every penny even if I haven't beaten it yet. The story is enticing, the environments and astonishing, the bosses are jaw dropping difficult and the customization options for weapons, augments, combat styles (and fashion) is second to none, its a game that asks you to improve as well as delve deep into its story. Lies of P is a solid ten our of ten for any gamer looking for story, polish, and a challenge. Highly recommended

This was my first Souls game, so this review is less so through the lens of "if you like Bloodborne, you will/will not like this game" etc, as I think this can convolute much of the game's intricate value. 

Lies of P throws you into a phenomenally crafted world for you to become engulfed. It is set in a Belle-Époque-style era, a period in French history distinguished by the wealthy’s attempts to fall back into an artificially carefree, fairy-tale existence, while the dreadfulness of reality takes place just outside of their lavish ballrooms and red-carpeted opera houses. As a result, this class of people and the world around them were not prepared for the grim products of their own negligence. This is just at the surface of happenings you discover while going through Lies of P—The Puppet Frenzy, the Petrification Disease, and more complicated dynamics between puppets, alchemists, and those who seek power have their roots in places you would not expect. Seeing the effects of these ongoing tragedies and why they are happening in different parts of the world is very intriguing. 

The player learns things at the same rate as the protagonist Pinocchio, who has only recently awoken from a long state of dormancy during the climax of these events. In other words, the story never gets ahead of your thinking because you start off naturally oblivious, and rely rightfully on the world-building, from both the environment and a diverse set of characters, many of them deceptive, as the mysteries are received in pieces to a bigger puzzle. Additionally, unlike other puppets, you have the ability to lie, which makes for often difficult decisions in a world in which you ideally want to pave a pathway to betterment. With Lies of P having amazing art direction, collecting and linking these revelations in your head becomes an exciting motive while going through the story.

Finally, this makes the gameplay itself fun and rewarding because it simply makes sense for various types of enemies to be located in their respective environments as you go through the story – something I find inconsistent in a lot of other RPGs. The game definitely has great replayability for the first few times as it has different skills, weapon combinations, legion arms, and thus playstyles. My biggest complaint is that although the weapons are very cool, I think it is unfair to say that there are “over 100 weapon combinations” since many of them are just unviable or silly to craft. Also, I think the game is definitely on the harder side, more specifically because it has one of the tightest parry windows in any video game I’ve seen. At this point, however, a lot of this is simply preference, and I, being a non-seasoned Souls player, adapted just fine. Generally, the bosses are great and it feels intensely satisfying once I beat any of them. 

Lies of P is an inspired project taking from other great games and a popular fairy tale, yet it still manages to be beautifully unique on its own and that is something I really appreciate, especially during a time when gaming and other media has been lingering in sequel hell for quite some time. 9/10

Before i obviously give the recommendation, my experience is coming from both steam and gamepass on xbox(blind playthroughs as well). i have tried all versions but the demo, i have tried + beat from game pass at version 1.0(very challenging for me), beat it at 1.20 (a bit more easier to read boss fights) as well and now bought it a 1.3 on steam (overall hp tuned across and you get rising dodge so if u get hit you can try to dodge outta the stunned hit state ect..) With all these versions played and beaten can def say the game got easier or fairer however you want to say it. I appreciate the balancing the devs did (still gotta tune enemy hit tracking imo) that the average souls like player now has a better chance against the horrors in Krat. Game is its not perfect by any means but liking 95% out of 5% is a great ratio. Not a huge fan of certain charge attacks on weapon his just don't having that poise to trade hits but its ok you can mitigate with certain fable arts. i just had to get good with when i can use my attacks based on openings.  Game isnt going to be easy the first time and there will be jank with some hit animations or bad camera angle vs bigger opponets who is face hugging up, body blocking at times, ambushes you may not like or mechanics that seem cheap or even enemies with a flurry of attacks you are not expecting and they just delete you, but trust its part of the journey. the more you play the more you you know to takle the upcoming obstacles. some bosses even mimic mob enemy attack patterns which sometimes make the bosses fights more engaging since you just know what to do once you figure out the rhythm.

the story holy smokes, it reminded me when i was intrigued with elden ring where i just wanted to look for more stuff to find out more about what the heck is going on. the more you progress the story unfolds.the emotion i felt ranging from hating this game due to the first skill check boss was messing me up, satisfaction of doing a certain stupid tuned boss fight near the end 1st try(waaaay manageable now), the truths before and after knowing the lies it was amazing. the story itself scratches that philosophical itch side of interpretations of why i play souls like what is this game trying to teach me?  What on the surface of being a common folk story where we know about a wooden puppet "becoming a boy because dad" made him yada yada, gemini is your "consciousness" yadada, getting eating by a "whale" yada yada, this game just straight up flips the script and puts in a nice huge pile of effed up stuff thats going on in typical ds fashion.  but through lying it shows your "humanity" since the puppets in this reality cannot tell a lie, the only distinction to know "what is human" and what isnt.  Brought to life to find where is your dad only to find a story with many twists and turns all with purpose, for the most part i think. the last game that got me this obsessed in a sp game like this was elden ring, i cannot stop recommending this piece of art, this is a worthy full priced from a 1st time studio showing developers how to make a good game with tight mechanics great optimization good story telling, challenging fights, sure some bs but which souls game don't have that? Buy this so we can get the next game/dlc from these devs, you aren't a "P"uppet without a "brain" are you?

STR weapons are far too slow to recover from to be reliably aggressive OR evasive, and playing on new game feels like playing a NG2 or NG3 on any of the games that inspired it.

Overall, not a bad stab - just be prepared for some DS2-esque ambush frustrations, very tanky enemies and bosses, and long drawn out boss fights.

- Attacks not registering WAY TOO FREQUENTLY. Imagine a heavy swing at a boss at point blank range that swooshes through the air. Again, and again, and again, until you give up and write this review.
- Bosses will switch attacks mid-animation. Seems they can cancel any attack at any point, and switch to any other attack. Just a jumbled garble of random half swings.
- Seems every enemy has a small random chance to initiate a one-hit-kill instant out-of-nowhere attack if you're close range.
- I did a particular quest where I needed to talk to a particular person, but when I showed up they attacked me. I killed in self defense, but then I couldn't complete the quest. What?

a phenomenal and challenging experience for an action rpg dark fantasy souls-like game. For me this game stands out for what it borrows, and what it innovates on. 

Graphics are excellent, and performance on my PC (Ryzen 7 3600, 32GBram, 3070 @ 120fps 1440p) and steam deck (60fps) are nearly locked at those levels. Little to no bugs/glitches - and patches have kept coming to help with balancing and performance. 

aesthetic, setting and atmosphere are bloodborne inspired, but have a custom and unique take on the Gothic Victorian era architecture. Dark, foreboding and eerie, with no out of place elements or asset dumps distracting from a hand crafted world.

Level Design is not poor, but not innovative either. only one path to take, simple repeated tropes of the genera (floor breaks, hidden enemies around corers etc) but exploration is still rewarded, albeit in short bursts. 

However  the more simplistic level layout/design are appreciated as the enemies and game mechanics are the focus and can be very challenging. High reward for perfect parry, the strongest and most rewarded game mechanic right from the start. No amount of weapon upgrade, armor, level upgrade will out pace the parry skill.

Highly recommend for those who liked a similar sekiro/bloodborne faster pace aggressive/interactive defensive play style.

Simply put: Amazing

Lies of P is very much "We have Bloodborne at home" if Bloodborne allowed you to block enemy attacks. If you're a fan of the Soulsborne games, you'll definitely feel comfortable with this game. I've finished every Soulsborne game outside of Sekiro, so I think have a pretty good handle on how these types of games should feel although I'm no speedrunner or god tier gamer by any means.

The weapons seem to be pretty fun and varied, and the weapon crafting system really allows you to cater weapons to your play style. The enemies feel like they're just right on difficulty - combat is deadly, but it goes both ways. Most basic enemies will go down in 2-3 hits, but they can very easily get the the jump on you if you're not paying attention. The bosses, while difficult, don't have a billion HP, and the fights can be over very quickly one way or another. If you're struggling on a boss, the NPC summons put in a lot of work and can really turn the tide in your favor. 

The level design is pretty linear, although there are a few branching paths in each zone. You tend to be rewarded for exploring, even if the branches can be kind of short. I haven't really gotten lost in any zone yet - the paths tend to loop around with shortcuts, so you can explore a side area and end up right back on the main path without much hassle. 

I really don't have much bad to say about this game so far - I'm not super far in, I think less than halfway. The only real issue I've had is that your attack animations tend to kind of lock you in, so once you start a swing you'd better be prepared to take a hit if you didn't time it right. I think some of the enemies kind of attack too fast for this to really feel fair sometimes, but it means the game does tend to reward careful play over just spamming your attack button, which feels appropriate for a Soulslike. This could be down to weapon choice as well, but I'm not sure at this point in time. 

Overall I'd say it's like an 8/10 game, and definitely worth the money. Check it out if you're a fan of Soulslikes, and especially if you're a fan of Bloodborne.
