It is my first ever souls-like and, without knowing the entirety of the other souls games (but obviously have heard of them and seen streamers play it, or seen reviews of those games), I feel this game mixes up the different mechanics pretty well.
You have the bloodborne health regain by dealing damage (but only if you block an attack!)
You have the sekiro parry, stance breaks, perfect guards to avoid damage entirely, and special prosthetics for damage or mobility.
And it's just a soulslike for the combat. Everything feels responsive, yet "weighty" because of animation locks.
The creepy puppets, along with some monsters, work incredibly well for a soulslike too. The puppets are uncanny and the way they move is perfect. I also find the boss design to be wayyy better than in other soulslikes from what I've seen, and that's because there's less flowy random details on the model. It's a puppet, robotic, very clear hitboxes and movements.

The story is loosely based on Pinocchio, that much is obvious, but it's darker, grittier, and I feel this is just one game out of several more to come to adapt fairy tales and other such stories into soulslikes. In this case it's like... the "rogue AI" trope, but with magic/mystical elements involved.

For my first soulslike, I am hearing different conflicting stories. One of them is that this is the hardest game yet to carry a "soulslike" title. It's not some cheap knockoff imitation. They learned from the best, shuffled the best of the mechanics around, made it even harder in the process. It plays its own way and stuff you learned in other games don't perfectly apply here. And I feel that might be somewhat true?

The biggest deviation and the unique mechanic of this game, is the weapon grinding. Friend of mine disagrees heavily with this addition. Eventually, it becomes trivial, but for plenty of players it is an extra "healthbar" to pay attention to, especially in NG+ it feels like every strike just damages your weapon more, and you can't just fight forever. Then have a specific enemy type that applies 'Decay' which also reduces your weapon durability really fast, and you have quite a difficult time with managing that 'chore' as well. In turn, I don't mind it, but that might be bias because like I said; this is my first soulslike and I got used to it. I imagine it might be annoying for people who are used to other soulslikes though. So my only tip is: use stagger windows to grind weapons, instead of going all out on the offensive. You also don't always need to grind your weapon to full.

In my own experience... I learned this game first now and I find it somewhat 'easy'? Never truly felt like I was stuck anywhere, and theres only 2 fights where I got a specter, and one where I finished the boss with a handful of throwables because that boss sucked to fight (damn you, green swamp monster)
And I've gotten good at it. People saying that a certain boss (thunderlady, not actual name) is harder than malenia of Elden Ring, and I beat thunderlady in no time at all, it felt like (and without cheesing it). It feels like the game allows for all kinds of playstyles too just to get you started, but you'll quickly realize that you need to employ all the tools given to you. If you are only dodging, you will struggle with quite a few bosses unless you learn how to block and parry. Similar if you come from Sekiro and only block/parry, there are bosses you kinda have to dodge because blocking still applies status, or they keep enough distance from you that you can not regain your health easily.

Of course, like with other souls games, this game can be "cheesed" too, in case you're just struggling. Throwables are insanely powerful, with the tradeoff that you will need to spend some time farming ergo (the currency for levelling and shops) to get a decent shot at beating a boss. There's summons, allowing you to get help of a specter that merely just draws aggro, allowing you to deal a lot of damage to bosses, and you can buff that specter too with wishstones. But those wishstones have to be purchased with a special currency that can not be farmed, only gained by spending time playing.
The game knows it is hard, and gives you plenty of tools to make it easier, without straight up compromising with a difficulty selection. The only limitation is what you yourself are okay with using as a strategy. And I would say... feel no shame in using all tools at your disposal. It's just a game after all.

Because the story is good as well and worth playing through the game just for that. It's not like other soulslikes where you get a few sparse hints as to what's going on. The game is pretty linear in its level design and storytelling, with plenty of secrets to find. But it's so worth it. And from the ending... more games like this might be coming. It hints to a larger world, and I hope that happens :D

All in all, would rate this an 8 out of 10. It's a seriously good game, even if you're new to soulslikes.

All in all I certainly recommend it to fans of the genre.

The atmosphere, music and world design come together to create a fairy tale that has the feeling of an original Brothers Grimm, miserable and bleak. But, being a video game you can force little lights of joy and good if only you reach out to change the tale.

Lies of P feels great, looks great and had me playing nonstop (barring sleep) till I finished the game. It's weakest parts are certain voices, and lip sync outside cutscenes, neither of which really detracted from my experience. I'm not versed in putting to words how the systems of the combat flow together to create a fun toolbox to use for crafting a combat style, but that's definitely here. What I will do instead is talk a bit about the public discourse I saw during release.

I think a very important thing about reviewing/discussing soulslikes is to estrablish one key thing: This is not Dark Souls, it's not Bloodborne, it's not Sekiro, and it isn't Elden Ring. This is not a FromSoft title.

Yes, the game takes heavy inspiration, it is a soulslike and I'd even agree it's the closest thing to a bloodborne on PC we're likely to get. But the point of this is, I feel that many people will call out a game's mechanics, or the skills it demands of you as bad / unfair because they aren't as prevalent or demanding in the genre standard setters from FromSoft.

This is a parry heavy game, it's what they want you to do and how it's been primarily designed. I saw a lot of discourse about this being a bad direction to take this game, and I vehemently disagree. It wants to force you into it's own rhytm, and you'll be punished for failing to do so.

The actual issues with the combat system fell a little through the cracks of the public facing discourse on parrying, but are being patched, big one being Rising Dodge from prone being baseline instead of a (technically missable) unlock in the P-Organ to make the combat feel more fluid from the get-go. 

Some of the bosses were rather hard, and took me a solid bit to get through, (theatre, bridge, top of tower p2 to be specific) but that was before the patches reducing their health and buffing certain weapons etc, they're much more in line with the rest of the game now.

This game is a gem that stands tall on its own two feet in a genre full of passion projects that either fall flat or lean to heavily into the more annoying or even infuriating aspects of soulslikes without giving you the tools needed to overcome them, and I'd heartily recommend it to anyone who likes souls games with the caveat that you should be prepared to parry. (if you did sekiro you'll be fine, it's a little stricter last I played but still)

TLDR: game good, parry good, stop treating every soulslike as if it's made by fromsoft and let them breathe as their own games with their own philosophies.

It's honestly so good I can't even express it.  In my 12 years of playing Souls and Souls-like games, I would say this is second only to Dark Souls 1 among them.  One of my favorite games of all time for sure.
Got me actually enjoying a souls-like for a change.

Originally played on Xbox gaming pass, max leveled my char and got all achievements, loved every second of the game and decided to buy it on Steam to support the devs and to play again at my leisure.

The game is a great take on the souls-like genre while being its own game.  A classic case of a game that is greater than the sum of all its parts: the combat style is a mix of Sekiro/Bloodbourne, many quality of life features that make the experience more enjoyable (such as your vigor, the equivalent of souls in other games, dropping outside the boss room if you die, the Rally system feeling so rewarding even if you don't nail your Perfect Guards, the P-organ talent system making NG+ and your experience evolve over time, etc.), the story is an interesting take on a classic tale, the music is good enough to where you'll probably just sit and listen to it when taking a break, and the entire aesthetic is very appealing and immersive.  

Best part was that compared to many other games I play at launch, zero major bugs and almost no minor bugs (or at least they weren't distracting).  You can tell the love and care that went into making this game, and it really shows in the final product.  

Is it the hardest souls-like game?  No.  Is it the most technically complex?  No.  Is it the most sprawling an expansive level design?  No.  However, it doesn't need to be since everything together meshes well, where other games tend to specialize in one aspect while failing in others, compounded by tons of issues at launch.  It's not often we get games that are great day 1 and provide such a quality experience.  Cannot recommend this game enough!

When i first saw this game i never would have imagined it would become my Game of the Year for 2023, in a year packed with so many amazing games, but here we are. It's easily the best soulslike out there and in some ways even exceeds From Soft's games.
Oh and did i mention it also runs really well ? How about that !

Agrega una gran variedad de armas y objetos que le permite diferenciarse de un soulslike común y corriente.
Hay varias cosas que se explican de manera sutil, pero lo suficientemente para que cualquier jugador que juega su primer soulslike pueda entender la historia.
El juego en sí, tiene muy buenos gráficos y tiene muy buena historia. El mundo creado para esto, lo considero fantástico.
En cuanto a dificultad, deja un poco que desear, pero al mismo tiempo se siente desafiante a ratos.
Considero que el juego está bastante pulido, pero lo que más me ha disgustado es que el sistema de "timing" o "ticks" se siente extraño. Hay ciertas acciones que se sienten que funcionan de manera muy pulida (Como lo es el parry) pero otras habilidades se sienten que actúan en un sistema de ticks muy distinto (Por no decir que se siente que no respetan el mismo timing)
Y algunas animaciones que parecen no respetar completamente las interacciones (Como por ejemplo, el parry de una habilidad, la ventana se siente mucho más grande de lo que en verdad es. A veces, también, se siente que se realizó un timing perfecto, basado en la animación, pero el juego dice "Nope")
Yes, thank you.

Coming from a fan of FromSoftware's series, I appreciate the intrigue and captivating narrative that trailed the game while I played. Deeply engaging storytelling, interesting environments, and a twist on the tale of Pinocchio mixed with (to me) is the subversion of Isaac Asimov's writings. I felt deep empathy with the game, and more than once would spend hours focused on the game at hand.

While LoP's boss fights are exciting bouts of showmanship, it also shows an assessment and understanding of  patterns and move-sets. Bosses have unique attacks and animations, often with long wind ups (these are very helpful, thank you!) that require full attention to the enemy. While I still never managed to perfect guarding during combat, the game was fairly forgiving and always felt I had the room to breathe and improve.

While initially concerned by the scale of the customization (weapon movesets, legion arms, consumables, and even just what costumes to wear), I found myself charmed by how fluidly the character moved and performed during gameplay. Maybe someone else will have better luck decoding all the hidden details, because I'm sure there's a full well to explore here.

Exploration itself is fairly linear, which can literally be described as my only complaint with the game. I was begging for another secret passage or alternate route while playing the game, just something to indulge myself with just a bit more time in the game. Besides that, I want to give a major shout out to whoever included images when new dialogue was accessible with NPCs. You are a hero, and everyone should praise your willingness to throw the players a bone.

I can't wait to see what else is in store. Also, while I haven't started NG+ as of writing, this 100% is a game you would get a kick out of a second round just to improve your build and feel the fresh spray of blood in combat. Cheers!

[b]If you like FromSoft's games, you are going to like this one too[/b]. It is annoying how much this game follows the souls-like formula. They even replicated the stupid SPACEBAR control mapping, which allows you to roll, dodge, sprint, and jump with SPACEBAR. I hated that in Dark Souls and I hate it here. If you didn't tell me that Neowiz had made this game, I would have thought this was the latest installment from FromSoft.

This game is great and I will highlight some things that were extremely enjoyable for me:

 • The art in this game is superb; it's a welcome change of pace in this industry following the western uglification trend.

 • I think the spin on Collodi's story is fantastic, and I'm so happy they stuck to the original text and added a few hidden easter eggs that the general public wouldn't know about. The story draws you in and the dialogue is well-written.

 • One of the most enjoyable gameplay features that sets this game apart from FromSoft's games is weapon combination.

 • Legion arms are similar to Sekiro in that they are highly situational and that you will frequently swap them out, but they are fun.

 • Lack of wokeness is always a plus.

Since none of the games are perfect, this one isn't either. The following is a list of things I felt could have been done better in this game:

 • My biggest complaint about this game is that you can summon a spectre to trivialize every boss by keeping them at aggro and using the spectre as passive damage. This became clear to me after the [spoiler]Archbishop[/spoiler] fight, and for every boss after that it took me an average of five attempts without a spectre to figure out the boss's initial phase, after which I could summon a spectre and easily defeat the boss.

 • The boss phases are not proportionally difficult, there is a huge jump in difficulty on phase two with most bosses. Having beat Sekiro and Elden Ring, I can't recall it being that way there.

 • Even if you've mastered the boss's five-hit combo, perfect parrying accomplishes nothing. There is no reward for completing such a difficult feat, boss doesn't get staggered. It doesn't make sense why would you even try it, since you can just roll to avoid damage.

 • Humanity mechanic is not clear to me. Some choices seemed more humane to me than the lies you were supposed to tell to gain humanity. For example, I thought it was more humane to inform [spoiler]Eugenie that Alidoro was actually her brother[/spoiler] rather than the generic lie [spoiler]that he was a stalker, but lying makes you human.[/spoiler]

 • Some lies don't even makes sense. For example, [spoiler]we lie to Julian about his deceased wife puppet and tell him she loved him - even though there a writing on the wall saying she did. However, later on, when you speak with Polendina, he asks you: „Can a puppet and a human fall in love, have you ever met a puppet who loves a human?“ The truth in this game is: „Show the wedding ring“ which in this scenario would actually be a lie because since first thing was a lie.[/spoiler]

And finally I have some nitpicks that are not necessarily specific for this game:

 • I hate it when games create "joke" weapons; if a game is serious, it should create serious weapons, or at the very least, 50/50. After all, who enjoys using an [b]enormous toilet seat[/b] as a weapon?

 • The same is true for the clothes. Make the outfits decent; I don't like rags. The only outfit I like is the promo coat from the trailer.

In summary, this game is enjoyable and nearly a perfect replica of FromSoft's games, despite its flaws. All in all, you wouldn't be wasting your money on this game.

My opinion is subjective, and you are free to discard it if your experience differed from mine, or you feel it is uncharitable. That being said:
- Game plays like a derivative of Sekiro and Bloodborne with inferior combat quality. Enemies have animations that feel clunky and unfair, and sometimes lack important tells/cues. Enemies will successively attack you if you parry them, and the game wants you to break their weapons a la a poise break from Sekiro, but it just feels deeply unsatisfying. 
- VO is weirdly localized and sounds like it was written by someone who needed more oversight.
+ Graphics are beautiful and really where the game shines. Runs fantastic. 
+ Has real stylistic coherence. I don't like the sort of cutesy-robot Nier Automata art nouveaux thing, but it's aesthetically pleasing nonetheless and deserves credit. 
+ The hit switching is a cool mechanic that allows a lot of player creativity.
+ P is cute. 
Overall, if you're like me and you went "what's the big deal?" don't worry, you're not alone. Solid title but not good enough for $60. Cannot recommend at this price-point. When it's 30 bucks, sure.

I've always been a big fan of the more focused Souls games (Bloodborne and Sekiro) even tough the Dark Souls games never got me.

Lies of P is an amazing blend of the fast paced aggressive nature of Bloodborne, with the parry and prosthetic arm mechanics of Sekiro.

On top of that the game adds a ton of really interesting features that make it stand out on it's own. This is one of the souls games that "gets" it. The feel of the game is top tier! 

Put all that together in a beautiful world with great voice acting and  music and you have an amazing game.

Okay my hours in this game are not true as I tried this game on a game pass and had to get it for myself just to support the devs as this is probably the best none From software souls like there is right now and I absolutely love this game. Atmosphere is really good and I really like the setting they have put this game into. Combat has a lot of depth and mixes almost all good elements from the souls games and adds some neat little tricks of its own (you can take off the hilt from weapons for an example and you can mix and match you favorite blade with different hilt and vice versa). Music of the game is great and completing npc quests you get LP records as a reward that you can play in the main hub of the game (super cool idea and the songs in there are top notch). Characters are interesting and they tell you pieces of story in newspaper and articles you find in the world to give you some hints what has happened in the world. Boss and enemy designs are really good and all of the boss fights have been real treats and the enemy variety has been quite impressive so far (I played about 30 hours with game pass). And the best part is that the game runs extreme well considering this is a modern game and I don't have the most powerful PC anymore which is super rare these times (I don't have to name any examples here but yeah this game does not need modders to fix it :P). Small summary this is my GOTY for this year easily and I see myself 100% this one for sure and playing multiple playthroughs. Easy recommendation from me to souls fans and if the setting interest you give it a try just keep it in mind that the game is quite challenging at times.

Edit after completing the game: 
This game really was as good as it can get as a souls like. I have now played it three times and enjoyed every second of it. Now eagerly waiting for the DLC and the announced sequel. This was worth every penny I spend on it and I hope that this game gets more recognition as it deserves every bit of it.

I was so scared that this game would disappoint me despite because of all the hype I had built up around its announcement and demo: thankfully I came away from Lies of P overwhelmingly impressed. AND it has some insanely good PC optimization, I never dropped a single frame throughout the whole experience. 
I've played so many souls likes and every FromSoft souls like game, and if I this game was dropped on to my lap with no forewarning I'd say that FromSoft made this game themselves. It is just a great combination of Bloodborne and Sekiro.
I can't say it's for everyone, there are some difficulty curves that can't be overcome with some of the cheesier ways that the Souls games or Elden Ring allows: you HAVE to learn the mechanics and integrate them into your play. 
But in short, if you love souls games and souls-likes this is probably the pinnacle of taking what makes those games great and transforming them into a new experience. I'd highly recommend it, and I can't wait to get through NG+ and see some other endings.

Fantastic Souls-like game. 

In a way, almost harder than souls if you play like I do (preferring to dodge rather than block or parry). The I-frames and parry timing is EXTREMELY unforgiving. 

As many other people have mentioned, it feels very Bloodborne., both the feel of the graphics and the feel of the gameplay. It tends to reward being aggressive rather than defensive (more akin to Bloodborne or Sekiro in my opinion). Also, the locations of shortcuts and save points feels VERY similar to any Fromsoft game, to the point of turning a corner and expecting to find said save point... and it being there. But why fix what isn't broken? It's nice pacing and didn't ever feel too far or too near. 

I think my only complaint is how the enemies attack. The timings on their hits can be judged after a LONG time of observing them, but starting out, the attacks are unpredictable and difficult to read. The mobs also track the player far too well, making it near impossible to dodge or get out of the way, unless you time it correctly. Even as the attack is happening, the enemy will sometimes continue to rotate and track the player. Not a bad feature in and of itself, but it can be frustrating.

One of the best Soulsborne games ever made by a studio that isn't FromSoftware. If you loved Bloodborne or have wanted to try it, this game will scratch that itch and then some.

Visually and stylistically the game gives you that Bloodborne feeling with its own setting taking place in a dystopian version of Pinocchio.

Gameplay wise, Lies of P feels like a mashup of Dark Souls, Sekiro, and Bloodborne with its mechanics with some unique aspects thrown in as well. It has the interconnected areas of Dark Souls, the parrying emphasis and prosthetic arm of Sekiro, and the health regain system of Bloodborne. For its own twist, Lies of P introduces weapon creation where you can swap the blades and handles of your weapons to alter their moveset and skills.

The game is challenging and you will want to learn the mechanics well, but it feels very rewarding when you do. However, it is also doable to get through the entire game without parrying at all if you struggle with it. Blocking is a viable strategy because you can regain health lost if you counterattack before you're hit directly. 

The game feels smaller in scale than Bloodborne and the Souls series, but what's within those areas works well and doesn't feel bloated.

I was actually very invested in the mystery of the puppet frenzy within this alternate world of Pinocchio, and I very much enjoyed how they went about it.

Overall, this is probably my favourite game purchase of the year. I would 100% recommend this to Souls fans and I'm excited to see the sequel from this studio.

Wether you decide that this is inspired by or simply a rip-off of Bloodborne, either way you still have to admit that there was passion in its creation.
It may be cliche and done to death by now but I absolutely adore this grim and gritty rendition of a classic fairy tale and I feel it fits right in amongst the soulsborne genre.
The pacing and flow of the game feels quite natural in terms of events and exploration; whilst there's a lot to see and discover, you never get too lost or too constricted.
Combat takes some getting used to yet after a time feels familiar and intuitive. 
A nice feature of being able to mix and match different blades to handles means you can form the perfect weapons with the right damage types and move-sets for your play style, and there are a great many weapons to find and unlock (with this game having possibly one of the greatest and just straight up fun DEX weapon movesets in all soulsbornes, and I say that as a STR player at heart).
In regards to design, I feel that everything fits quite well.
Don't even get me started on the music. I thoroughly enjoyed all the tracks in this game, especially the records, just an absolute delight.
Visually, characters and locations are both beautiful and mysterious, enemies are equal parts cool and horrifying, I very much adore the old, Victorian AND eldritch horror style.
Attack timings can seem a little weird at first but they're nothing the average gamer can't get used to, just like with all games of this type you simply, observe, adapt, and overcome, or in other words, git gud.
One thing I could complain about is that when you talk to someone they lose their dynamic audio and sound like they're coming from the centre of the screen, even if they might be way off, at the same time you can't move your camera at all during dialogue so after certain cutscenes you're staring directly at the back of P's head and can't see the person you're talking to. It's not a great, big problem but it is a little annoying at times when I'm just out here trying to appreciate the visuals and the scenarios of the game.
But that's all I can think of at the moment.

[h1] Short review [/h1]

[h2] Base game [/h2]
If you miss Bloodborne love the Elden Ring bosses and love Sekiro. Love level design that folds in on itself giving shot-cut progression type levels this is most definitely the game for you.

[h2] Update 1.2.0.0 [/h2]
This is the same as the base game BUT, it will have more of an Assassin's Creed vibe when it comes to difficulty on hard. And it takes away the hard earned feeling of achievement when finally defeating a boss or level.

[h1] In depth review [/h1]

[h2] Base game [/h2]
Well where to start.
[h3] The Story [/h3] I loved the idea of a Soulslike Pinocchio. In the end I gotta admit they did so much to respect the source material and make it their own. It's an insanely well-done fresh take on it. But it never fails to stay close enough to it not to alienate you from the get-go or to divert so much from it it is unrecognisable. That said, as with all stories you either like it or don't. I'm really glad I can count myself among the people who likes it.
The world building, references and history of stuff'n'thangs found in item descriptions and collectables really ads to it like a FromSoftware game proper does. It really gives that feeling. They clearly Took inspiration from them and did it quite well. More on that later. All and all the game really gave me a story that felt fresh and new. I went in and thought I'd try to skip the story and descriptions. And ended up soaking it all in from the start till the end.
[h3] The gameplay [/h3]  As stated in short review the game most clearly took a lot of inspiration from FromSoftware games. And let's be clear, I know what I'm saying. Inspiration. Saying this is a copy of those games is certainly selling it short. There are things they did take from those games. But they added on so much fresh feeling stuff new stuff I haven't seen in other games to make it feel like its own thing. And not a copy at all. The enemies, weapons, fable arts, bosses and abilities really have their own identity.
The game is hard. Don't get me wrong I loved the difficulty and really felt a sense of achievement when I beaten a certain boss. That is why we play and love these games. No compensation and no quarter given. Just pure skill and getting good at it. Feel the dread of failing and getting better. And getting a rush of pride when you finally pull through and do what felt impossible.
But not everything is positive though. 
To be fair to the game I won't compare it to the gameplay of Sekiro or Bloodborne. Those are games by an experienced studio that knows their fan base and what makes a Soulslike a Soulslike. Hell they are the originals how could they not. But I with refer to them not to compare but to illustrate why it doesn't work in Lies of P. The biggest problem I found with the gameplay was the fact that deflecting and blocking are the same thing in the game. Your block deflects/perfect blocks within a certain set of frames. this is all fun and dandy but it doesn't work well cause when an enemy does a flurry attack the game doesn't always register what you are doing. And it has become a guessing game if it will work. There are instances you have you spam deflect so many times but your character just looks like it's blocking. In Sekiro this works cause it has and starts it's own animation every time. So you have a visual cue of what is happening. In Lies of P you just don't know if you're safe or in danger till it is too late or you feel like you just got lucky. 
When it comes to specifically bosses I have experienced something I didn't know existed. Boss fatigue. There aren't that many bosses not more than necessary. But there are quite a few of them that have a bull$hlt second phase that is just a complete other bossfight altogether. Not at all building of the moveset of the first phase. Just another bossfight. In FromSoftware games this works cause it has a story related purpose and feels logical and necessary. In this game it's just practically half the main bosses who do that. It doesn't feel good or fair. It just feels like you got cheated out of your progression in the fight and development. The first boss who does this felt great and new and was well done and well placed. The ones after felt like the game cheating the player cause it happened too much. On top of that when you stagger a boss you have to do a charged heavy and the last hit of that attack leaves you with half stamina at best. That is if you even get a window to do it. That is great and feels rewarding when you take the risk. But the game out of nowhere decides at a certain point that bosses must do a bull$hlt attack you're defenceless against if you don't level stamina through the roof. And worse than that there are bosses who do a flurry attack before they stagger, an AOE or both. It feels unfair and as if you're cheated out of your hard-earned visceral attack on the boss. Just for a cheap win for the boss.
The bosses are well designed and have cool attacks. But nearly all boss feels like an Elden Ring boss. Not a copy but just a big enemy that has stupid delayed attacks. So that you're just guessing the seconds it takes to land the hit rather than react to it. What makes games like Bloodborne and Sekiro so great is the continues aggression and pressure you feel. The quick reactions and skills you need. Elden Ring and Lies of P are more like learn to count to 3 or 5 and block and you will perfectly deflect absent skill.
Lastly between 1 and 3 more frames for a perfect deflect would make the game less punishing and more fun for people who don't have the time to spend hours in bossfights perfecting them or simply don't have that reaction.
[h3] Patch 1.2.0.0 [/h3]
I went from weight limit 59% to weight limit 51% over night, bosses were made easier, levelling was made easier cause you got more Ergo/Experience. This all results that this self advertised Soulslike is all of a sudden an Assassin's Creedlike. It's not what we want or payed for. I get the insecurity from the studio. But FromSoftware shows they don't need to be. Now given this cakewalk to the community there is no way back. We were promised a Soulslike we got it. And days later it was taken back from us. I remember trying the demo version and I gotta say - it looks like they tried really hard to make a few important changes at the last minute (especially combat/sound-related improvements). 

Now, some will say this is an interesting mixture of Bloodborne and BioShock but as a newbie to this genre, I can’t really connect all the dots together.
I can, however, say that what surprised me and got me hooked was how much I became mesmerized by the first video showing the game’s background and how P came to be. It felt like a really good Grimm Brothers film was about to begin. :) 

The graphics of the game are amazing (once in a while, try looking up and enjoy the view guys) and I was amazed at how much detail they put into the sound effects. But on a side note, I also kind of found the sound of the weapons clinking a little too high-pitched for my ears. Oh, and lastly, I loved the simplicity of the game as it helped me focus solely on the story and the game itself.

All in all, it looks like P and I will be spending many more hours together this fall. 
Fingers crossed P gets a cool Halloween costume soon! :D

The game is practically a mix of other games in this genre, specifically it has a light Sekiro style combat (either focus on avoiding attacks or perfect blocking), Dark Souls 1 map design (few "bonfires", but shortcuts are everywhere), a summon for boss fights to allow players an easier time dealing with them and a Bloodborne "theme". The story is good enough to carry through the game, but nothing exceptional. While there is a good selection of weapons I finished the game with the starting rapier as was the only one with specific moveset and upgrading is fluid in a way that it will max out close to end game, so it is viable whole game.
Overall is not a hard game (if one played other souls games), but keep in mind that the game also incorporated many bad design choices from Dark Souls 1, specifically precise platforming while dealing with enemies, ambushes that many times are instant deaths or will waste lots of heals (especially with items/chests baits), also some very annoying minibosses that are on the way just demanding to deal with them.

genuinely the single best souls-Like ever made hands down no contest.  I say Souls-like. in that i am referring to any third person RPG with stamina based combat not made by our boy Miyazaki and the team at fromsoft. 

the most  meaningful changes to combat are the improved version of Bloodborne's Rally mechanic, where all blocked damage can be recovered by dealing damage to foes, and the "blocked health" dissapears entirely if you take unguarded damage. additionally, unlike the majority of souls likes, throwables remain a very useful tool even into the late game, and the ability to restore 1 single charge to your "estus" when it is drained by damaging enemies ensures that healing is still limited, but even in a boss fight can be regained by skilled play.  additionally the ability to break enemy weapons with perfect blocks to lower their attack is a great feature and should also be extended to the bosses.

despite some slightly weaker level design this game is a 9/10

Having played through one and a half times now I feel I can adequately provide a review. 
The developers of this game did a good job capturing the feeling of Bloodborne with the relatively small seeming world, the interconnectedness of it, and the story of the game. Throughout my play I noticed several points, which I have listed below:
Pros:
The game is very aware of minor shortcuts that players would want, even if not consciously. Take for instance the hotel hub; the room on the upper floor that you'll be returning to throughout the game has a convenient break in the railing right outside, allowing you to immediately get back to the stargazer to leave. The game is full of small little shortcuts like this that save maybe a few seconds at a time.
The placement of stargazers is well spread out. This includes shortcuts as well, they always feel like you've earned them, and they are relatively frequent.
The weapon system is incredibly cool, though I did end up using a boss transmute weapon for the rest of the game once I got it as well as subsequent plays.
The story of the game as well as the optional quests are well written and build very nice characters.
The game tells you if you have any quest actions that can be taken in a given area when you go to teleport there. They don't tell you where to go, just a reminder that there is something you can do.
It used to be the case that bosses had way too much health and effectively encouraged you to use consumable items on them, though this has been adjusted in the most recent balance patch, making them much more reasonable.
The fact that the choices you make during the game have a tangible impact on how the ending plays out. Thankfully there's no umbilical cords you need to collect though.
The scaling into NG+ seems about right, I will update the review as I progress into later NG cycles.

Cons:
The quests could use a little additional work to make them harder to mess up. Specifically in the later chapters of the game, there are a couple quests that lock you out of the "good" ending if you do things in the wrong order with the reasoning being flimsy. To provide a specific example: [spoiler]The quest involving Alidoro's cryptic vessel requires you to decipher it before talking to another NPC otherwise you cannot complete it. This doesn't make much sense because the character could easily just go back to the NPC and say "In addition to what I told you earlier, here's more information." [/spoiler] 
The fact that once you beat the final boss, there is new postgame content (an achievement) that you can easily miss if you choose to go straight into NG+ from the cutscene. This one is relatively minor and most people would probably think to check, but because I missed it I have to redo one of the harder endings again.

Overall I would consider the game very good and a worthwhile play for any FromSoft fans.

This is it. This is probably the closest we will get to Bloodborne 2. The mechanics are great, the story is wild, the art direction is fantastic (although I miss my hunter clothes :P), graphics are gorgeous, optimization is impeccable, and the mystique is retained.

Additionally the music is fantastic, especially the records you are able to obtain throughout the game.

So far the difficulty has been less than Bloodborne overall for me. I have cleared up through the Archbishop at the moment. Even though it has been a bit easier that is not to say I have not been challenged. I suspect the difficulty will be ramping up shortly for me.

I'm also appreciating the single player nature of the game. It definitely adds to the atmosphere and allows items to be solely balanced for PVE. I really think they made the right choice forgoing multiplayer in this one. Although, PVP with these mechanics would probably be quite fun. 

There is a lot going on here with depth of mechanics and build variety. I have barely scratched the surface of what I can do and I'm loving every minute of it.

Edit: Beat the game and immediately went into NG+. This game is fantastic, the DLC cannot come fast enough. The only thing I wish there was more of would be costumes and more unique weapon options. Even with that gripe it is very minor. Excellent experience.

[h1] Surprisingly good, an 8/10 [/h1]

There is honestly not much to complain about, this game is a complete package and most importantly - working, running well and looking great even on PC, something that's more and more rare. Also, bug free experience, the game is just polished at every point.

A lot of people compare this to bloodborne, and on a first glance that is one Fromsoft game, Lies of P shares the most with. Although, in my experience, I would compare the general combat closer to Sekiro rather than Bloodborne. Combat is mostly dance of blocking, taking your chances and trying to stance break the enemy for a critical hit. If you have played souls games, you will feel right at home with the mechanics, as this game borrows most of them, but there are little twists to make things interesting, mostly for good. 

I only wish some levels (mostly found in the first 60ish % of the game) were perhaps more creative and bit more difficult. The difficulty in the zones mostly comes from fighting "mini boss" types of enemies, with their own movesets, withstanding about 5-10x the damage regular enemies do. In early levels, there is usually just one guy like this, which imo makes the rest of the level feel easy, unimportant. I also think the game would benefit greatly from maybe some smarter enemy placement and less "corridor" types of levels. 

Bosses on the other hand can definitely be quite a challenge, and I would argue most of them are pretty decent and fun to fight. There are some forgettable ones, but none that I would call straight up bad.

Overall, very solid souls-like that I would personally put above DS2 and Demon Souls. Definite success and for me personally perhaps the biggest gaming surprise of 2023.

Lies of P is an incredible souls-like for a first attempt. It is mechanically complex without being bloated. The story is quite good for a genre that isn't particularly focused on narrative. I hope that the studio continues to expand upon their universe and the mechanics within.
W GAME N SOUNDTRACK

I've been hooked on the game for two days now, and I recommend the game to anyone who wants to try souls-like games, but doesn't want hardcore.

Lies of P very well balances the line between “I had to spend the entire day in every boss fight” and “I’m too lazy to learn this game and will just spam attacks.” By entering the boss’s room two or three times, you begin to understand what to do, and you don’t have to do any crazy maneuvers. The riddles in the game are not very complicated and if you carefully examine the locations, you can find all the hidden and secret corners without any problems. In terms of the speed of gameplay and map construction, the game is closer to Bloodborne: shortcuts are everywhere, and you don’t have shields to 100% block the damage you receive.

I first played this when it released, and while it was great back then, it's even better now thanks to a big patch that makes the gameplay smoother. This is a fairly linear soulslike with some of the best hack-n-slash combat I've experienced. Both dodging and parrying are options, and if you master one or both, combat becomes an intricate dance. Broader options like magic aren't here, but combat is still fun thanks to awesome weapon variety. The story is deep and emotional, and it is told in a fairly straightforward way that requires no lore videos to understand (no offense to FromSoftware, but these days a straightforward soulslike story is a nice change of pace). The soundtrack is stellar and may be the best one of 2023. Furthermore, the amazing sound design makes for great immersion! For the love of God, anime, and the struggle to be human, play this game and learn to love Pinocchio.

This is the best soulslike out there, hands down. It understands what makes a FromSoft game so compelling and executes on that formula with just enough innovation to make it feel fresh yet familiar. While there are plenty of little nitpicks I could list, compared to the entire package of what this game gets *right*, they just don't really matter. Seriously, this game has it all - engaging level design, tough but fair combat, fantastic bosses, and well-crafted RPG mechanics, all set against a backdrop of a beautiful soundtrack and gorgeous art design. Any good thing that you could say of the Souls series, you can also say of this game. If you're a fan of the Souls games and are itching for a new game that scratches that FromSoft itch, this game is a must-buy. And if you've never played a souls game but are wanting to give the genre a shot, this is a great game to start with.

TLDR; this game is amazing and you should definitely buy it.

I had been keeping up with this games development for around a year and a half before the game released. It had been showing promise in almost all categories but the ones that stuck out to me the most were the music and visual style. When I actually bought the game I expected it to be good, but nowhere near the bar that FromSoftware had set for this genre. After a few hours the game absolutely blew me away, the graphical style of being in a ruined city that actually shows details of how it used to be thriving was so cool for me. The ability to take weapons I had been finding throughout my journey and combine with other ones to make a combo that really fit my playstyle was a very welcome addition. The bosses in this game are fantastic, probably the best roster I've seen in a Non-Fromsoft game. While there may be one or two bosses I really didn't enjoy, the ones I liked more than made up for it. Accompanying these bosses was some of the best fight themes I've ever heard in a game, and the records you can find also make this an unforgettable soundtrack. The combat in this game is dynamic in a way that allows to choose the route of parrying your enemies or dodging their attacks, you'll need to master both of them however because some bosses may make one strategy better than the other.

Now with all the good stuff I've said, you'd expect me to rate this a 10/10, however there were a few things I did not like. The first of which was the balancing of the player compared to the enemies, the developers have been releasing some updates to manage the health and damage of some bosses and bring up the player's strength slightly as well. My first playthrough was before these changes and I can definitely say they were needed. For example, having recovery dodge locked behind a perk you had to activate was a very bad decision and I'm glad they made it base-kit. The balancing could use a slight bit more work, mainly revolving the scaling of NG+ but other than that, the developers have been good on fixing this issue. The only other problem I had with this game was how some of the hitboxes were absurd, this issue wasn't prominent throughout the whole game but when it was an issue, it was impossible to ignore. There were attacks from some bosses that were miles high above my head or that I clearly dodged through, but would still find a way to hit me. Like I said, this wasn't an issue that many bosses had, only a few, but I believed this warranted being brought up.

In conclusion, I loved playing through this game, enough to go through getting all the achievements which meant playing through the game three times. The issues this game had were made up for and then some by all the positives that it had. The soundtrack, visuals, and story were all fantastic with all the other aspects being far above average as well.

9/10, I am very excited for the DLC and other future content planned.

Os personagens em si estão perfeitos, não tenho o que reclamar, O Pinóquio está simplesmente perfeito e um charme, muito cativante, O Geppetto, Gemini e o Vignini estão ótimos, tanto na personalidade quanto na desenvoltura dos personagens, Sophia simplesmente belíssima e uma graça e tem a moça de óculos que arruma nossas armas, lindíssima. Há outros humanos, não sei dizer se são amigos ou inimigos, mas não confio neles, o jeito traiçoeiro e perspicaz deles é ótimo, sinto que podem descartar o P a qualquer momento, com certeza não são confiáveis heuiheueuheuehue.
A ambientação está sublime, todos os locais até agora explorados por mim estão com esse ar de fim de mundo e agonizante, com morte, doença e praga para todo o lado, a cidade de Krat está realmente morrendo, e cabe a nós salvá-la ou tentar.
As roupas do P são tão bonitas e charmosas, deixa ele mais gato do que já é.

Espero que gane como jogo do ano, pois merece e MUITO!

Lies of P is the most faithful soulslike game to release yet. Although it holds hands with the fromsoft games, it combines the best elements of each release into an incredibly satisfying gameplay loop. The game is linear, but any fromsoft vet will be pleased to comb through each area to discover useful gear to unlock truly useful abilities. This game is truly underrated and underappreciated, and I am ecstatic to see what these brilliant minds will deliver with their next project.

Among Souls-likes, this game stands in a league of its own. The things that plague most Souls-likes are a lack of polish, and a lack of intention. This game so fine tuned and polished that I could scarcely believe it was made in the current gaming landscape.

tl;dr: a fromsoft game not made by fromsoft, a true "souls-like" at long last

If you had shown me this game maybe a couple years ago, without any context or information, I would have told you with extreme confidence "yep, this is made by Fromsoftware".
It's a feeling that goes beyond simply stuff like the combat and core mechanics. The atmosphere, the graphics, the animations, the NPC interactions and sidequests, the lore, the level and enemy design, even the music. Literally everything screams "Fromsoftware", it was clearly made by people who like that specific style and understands what makes those games great. This is, in my eyes, the only "souls-like" worthy of the name.

And still, this isn't just a 1:1 copy, or a Dark Souls mod with a pretty reskin, it somehow manages to take a bunch of stuff from Souls, Bloodborne and even Sekiro, blend them together and give them its own spin.

The combat in particular is something I can only describe as the love child of the games mentioned above. You have the standard light-strong attack movesets like in Dark Souls; your dodge roll that turns into a dash like in Bloodborne, and just like in BB you have no shields but you can still block a portion of damage with your weapon, damage that you can heal back up by hitting enemies; your left arm is instead dedicated to a mechanical arm with various special abilities like in Sekiro, and any hit can be perfectly blocked negating all damage just like in Sekiro. Enemies can be put in a staggerable state simply by chaining perfect blocks (Sekiro again) and subsequently staggered by landing a strong attack (BB again). Your arsenal is all made up of unique weapons with their own unique moveset like in BB.

Now for something that is unique to this game: almost every weapon is made by a blade part and a handle part that can be separated so you can mix and match them however you want, with some pretty silly results as you might imagine. Wanna put a greathammer head on a dagger handle? Nothing's stopping you. This will change how the weapon handles but it's not the only reason to do it, as each blade and handle have their own special combat skills so you have more of a reason to try it out on top of just "lmao greatsword with tiny dagger blade"
The leveling system is mostly what you'd expect but with an added skill tree that requires a specific item found by exploring and/or defeating sometimes optional strong miniboss-type enemies, rewarding you for essentially being good at the game.
There is a lie and truth system as well as a "humanity" system that influence NPC interactions as well as the game's ending, but I won't elaborate more since it's spoilers and better experienced for yourself.

Overall it's a solid 10/10 for me and I can totally see myself replaying the game over and over with different builds to get all endings and master all bosses, just like I did with Souls.
And yes, in the end, aside a few original mechanics and the Pinocchio inspiration, it's really nothing you haven't seen before if you're Fromsoft fanboys, to the point I can see how some might even call it "soulslop" and even agree with them.

But brother let me tell you... this is some mighty fine soulslop.

I'm currently playing through Lies of P for the fourth time, and I have to say, it's the best non-Fromsoft Souls-like game I've ever played! The game shines in every aspect, from visuals to story, level design, voice acting, and music. The soundtrack, especially the songs, is superb and a pleasure to listen to. 

The game follows the typical souls-like formula but with some variations, which don't make it stand out; however, it works as intended. The combat is genuinely the best part of the game, in my opinion. It builds on the mechanics of Bloodborne and Sekiro but also introduces some innovative new ideas that make it feel fresh and exciting. The ability to swap weapon handles and create crazy weapon combinations is particularly impressive. The enemies in the game are brutal and require strategic thinking to overcome, and the variety of enemies keeps the gameplay fresh. The boss designs are insane, and these encounters are some of the most amazing ones I've ever experienced in a game.

The writing department has done an excellent job. The dialogues are well written, and they effectively convey the story. There are also a lot of clever references throughout the game that will make you nod and smirk if you catch them. There was even a moment where I felt like the game became self-conscious and started telling me, through an NPC, how it felt about being a souls-like game. That could be just my interpretation, but the game made me think, which is a big plus.

I enjoyed playing Lies of P very much and highly recommend it to anyone who loves challenging games with excellent combat, stunning visuals, a great story, and an incredible soundtrack.

It plagiarized:

- enemies and bosses from a dream of a delirious drunk
- VIG/STA/VIT/STR/DEX/INT attributes
- level design with shortcuts and annoying mobs placement
and lots and lots of stuff, copy-pasted from SoulsBornes.

Some fresh ideas also present:

- reimagined world of Carlo Collodi
- nice visual design
In general, it is very enjoyable. Not so hard, though. If you hear lies about game being hard - it's a lie, it is super easy for a Souls afficionados if you pay attention to mechanic nuances, all lies probably come from puppets, trying to be humans.
Story, characters, bosses and setting truly worth some time.

So, install your Legion Arm, pick up huge smacking tool, say hello to your hub-girl and go, kill and lie, to clarify whether you are a puppet, or a real boy.

Lies of P is probably the best Soulslike game made by a studio that isn't FromSoftware, and especially when considering that this is their first actual game of this kind, they absolutely knocked it out of the park. Is it on the same level as FromSoftware's own games? No, of course not, but it's a damn fine game anyway. The story and world really are original, and I was surprised by how effective these two actually were. The narrative concepts of lying being human and so on, and the reframing of all the familiar characters and themes we know from Pinocchio were expertly done. The music and levels weren't superb, but they got the job done, and the animations and weapons were incredible. I can only recommend Lies of P, and I'm very happy about the announcement of a sequel.

Nukkekoti – kohtauksia eräästä avioerosta. Ensi-ilta Kom-teatterissa 8.9. Henrik Ibsenin näytelmän käännös, sovitus ja ohjaus Mikko Roiha. ★★★★

NÄYTTELIJÄ Aleksi Holkko tekee Kom-teatterissa järisyttävän hienon roolityön Henrik Ibsenin näytelmän Nukkekoti (Et Dukkehjem, 1879) suuressa pääosassa.

Ensin isänsä ja sitten aviomiehensä tahtoa kaikessa myötäillyt Nora on nyt Aron.

Näppärää, mutta täysin konstailematonta.

Esityksen käsiohjelmassa seisoo: Ibsenin näytelmän pohjalta vapaasti kääntäen sovittanut Mikko Roiha.

Kääntäminen tarkoittanee tässä yhteydessä nimenomaan suomentamista, ja linjakkaasti Roiha onkin siirtänyt suuren norjalaisen dramaatikon kansainvälisen läpimurtoteoksen tämän päivän kieliasuun ja vieläpä pitkälti pohjalaismurteille.

Erityisesti Holkolta pohjalaiset sananparret lohkeilevat luontevan terävinä iskoksina.

PÄÄHENKILÖN nimen ympäri kääntämisen lisäksi en havainnut Ibsenin alkuperäisteoksen kohdanneen tai edes kaivanneen mitään suurempia kiepsautuksia.

Ihminen on pohjimmiltaan sama kuin puolitoista vuosisataa sitten. Häpeä ja ylpeys toimivat edelleen keskeisinä liikkeellepanevina voimina, Pohjanmaalla ehkä näyttävämmin kuin muualla.

Eikä sukupuolella ole tässä mielessä mitään merkitystä.


Aleksi Holkko tekee upean roolityön, Tiina Weckströmin roolit ovat jalostuneet kohtalokkuuden asteelle.
Aleksi Holkko tekee upean roolityön, Tiina Weckströmin roolit ovat jalostuneet kohtalokkuuden asteelle. KUVA: NOORA GEAGEA / KOM

Tiina Weckströmin näyttelemää asianajajaa voisi pitää esimerkkinä ”sukupuolisokeasta” roolittamisesta. Kiristäjäksi ajautuvan loukatun hahmon voi samalla ajatella edustavan mitä tahansa sukupuolta, mikäli määrittelyn edes kokee tarpeelliseksi.

ROIHA on ohjaajana saanut huomiota erityisesti tavastaan antaa näyttelijöiden rikkoa rajojaan. Epätyypilliset näyttelijävalinnat ovat samalla luoneet uutta särmää esimerkiksi vahvojen suomalaisten naisdramaatikkojen teoksiin.

Kom-teatterin Nukkekodin ihmiskuvasta voi löytää jännittäviä heijastuksia vaikkapa Maria Jotunin näytelmien henkilöistä.

Roihan ohjauksessa yhteiskunnalliset lainalaisuudet määräävät ihmisten toimia välillä hyvinkin tarkkaviivaisesti kuvattuina.

Holkko suorastaan viilettää viivana pitkin näyttämötilaa ilmentäessään Aronin selviytymistaistelua.

Niko Saarela piirtää aviomiehenä osuvan kuvan suuresta periaatteen ihmisestä, joka omasta mielestään on aina oikeassa, vaikka hänen ratkaisunsa ovat johtaneet useampaankin umpikujaan.

Markus Riutun esittämä pariskunnan ystävä on oman järkeilynsä halvaannuttama surullisen hahmon ritari, joka avautuessaankin tuntuu vain törmäävän tuulimyllyihin.

Vilma Melasniemi tekee uutta elämää aloittelevana Aronin ystävättärenä esityksen tarkimman piirroksen siitä, minkälaista kaupankäyntiä elämä pohjimmiltaan on, ja miten siinä ei turha hötkyily auta.

Tiina Weckströmin roolit ilmeettömänä asianajajana ja kävelykeppinsä kanssa vaeltavana mykkänä ovat jalostuneet kohtalokkuuden asteelle.

ROIHAN tyylikkään tehokkaasti visualisoiman esityksen linjakkaisiin ratkaisuihin kuuluvat myös musiikkivalinnat. Erityisesti Bernard Herrmannin sävellykset Alfred Hitchcockin elokuvaan Vertigo.

Vertigon ääniraidan viipyilevistä jousista muodostuu eräänlainen teema näytelmän aviomiehelle ja tämän jännitteiselle elämälle harhakuvien keskellä. Samasta lähteestä löytyy myös painajaismainen säestys Aronin tanssimaan villiin tarantellaan, jolla on aivan keskeinen asema draaman kaaressa.

Lavastus ja valot Mikko Roiha, äänet Jani Rapo, puvut Riitta Röpelinen, maskeeraus Leila Mäkynen. Rooleissa Aleksi Holkko, Niko Saarela, Markus Riuttu, Vilma Melasniemi, Tiina Weckström.

Combat is fun yet difficult, and the story is interesting; a beautiful nod to the dark souls genre, with elements of many from software games like Sekiro, Bloodborne and dark souls. Would definitely recommend to any from soft veteran, as it may not be quite the same, its certainly an interesting plate cleanse from the open world feel of Elden ring.

Good game, I can strongly recommend it; that said, it's pretty short relative to what I'm used to. I've beaten the whole thing in under 20 hours and I feel like I took my time, meanwhile it took me 70+ hours to beat Elden Ring my first time through.

Lies of P is definitely harder than Elden Ring however, the game doesn't seem to have any comically overpowered options available to abuse and is less forgiving than games like Bloodborne or Sekiro when it comes to dodging and parrying/deflecting. To be clear, this game doesn't actually have a proper parry, it has a "perfect guard" mechanic which does feel a bit different from what I'm used to.

I like this game as about as much as I do something like Nioh 2, I would probably take most of Fromsoft's output over this, but it's an extremely strong first showing and I'm more excited to see what these developers do next.

I do have a couple complaints though:
- boss runs are dumb, there's a reason Fromsoft has been moving away from them
- it feels like in most souls-likes I can eyeball a lot of attacks when it comes to parrying, I could not do this with perfect guard; I have to get beaten down and just learn the patterns and timings
- it took a long time to get a weapon I liked
- there is a specific side objective you can lock yourself out of because you don't opt to make a boss weapon much earlier in the run, just why?
- most of the areas are arguably too short, but the final area is comically long and well outstays it's welcome while simultaneously being the most visually uninteresting overall
- the game has a lot of ambushes to the point where I felt a little fatigued, but it's probably not actually more than what's typical in the genre and just exacerbated by a lot of areas being short
- there are roided dudes bursting through brick walls, but the rooms they were in had no doors or any way to get in; who the hell is just sealing these guys in walls and why are they okay with it?

I couldn't finish DS3 or Elden Ring (even though I've invested more hours in the latter than in Lies of P) because I was just too bored to remember specific enemy patterns and unable to choose a different build due to the difficulty of respeccing. This game, however, gives you the freedom to play how you want, not just based on the weapons you choose but also in terms of mechanics.

It has everything you need: dodging, parrying, blocking, and items that you actually use, avoiding the issue of them sitting in your inventory forever. I never felt stuck on a boss or a game segment because I was doing something wrong. I always had the option to try something different.

Yes, learning attack patterns can be frustrating, and the game is far from easy, but it's no less satisfying to finally beat the challenge by using your entire arsenal. The last time I had so much fun playing a game was when I played Sekiro, and this game is Top1 for me. I hope there's a DLC coming, and I would recommend this game to everyone.

And last but DEFINITELY not least is the soundtrack...... This is a robbery that I as a customer had to only pay 50 or so euros for the game with such soundtracks. It's that good.

Truly excellent game. Has my favourite combat system out of any Souls game "including" the OG games. having to use a mix of defensive options rather then just spamming the "best" one and actually using my weapons full move-set gives a sense of engagement and satisfaction I've never personally felt with any other souls-like game. So combat wise this is my favourite game in the genre.
Level design isn't as open as i personally prefer although the levels themselves are excellently made, with lots of shortcuts and inter-connectivity within the individual levels.
It just lacks the openness and freedom that i personally prefer. If they ever make that sequel they hinted at i'm hoping for a more Dark souls one style map then Lies of P's more DS3 style map. though if they don't I'd still play it.
Slow heavy weapons are a little under powered and need something to help them out since hyper armour is weirdly spread out amongst the various move sets and generally under powered. Id say if a weapon has a slow swing speed then they need guaranteed hyper armour for the actual attack frames but i'm open to the devs fixing slow weapons in other ways if they can find some. Faster weapons are in a fine place though and don't need much if any adjustment.
Boss design is incredible. Just remember when fighting the bosses to not get to attached to blocking, dodging or parrying to the point your only doing one exclusively. 9 times out of 10 if I was struggling with a boss it was because I was just doing one and ignoring the others.
As long as someone comes into the game understanding that this game is a soul-LIKE and not an actual souls game they should have an excellent time.
Just don't try to Unga bunga with the heaviest weapon you find it probably wont work.
Edit: as of the recent patch Heavy weapons are great again Hazzah!

This game is pretty excellent.  I have looked at the criticism and almost feel that the "souls-like" tag has hurt the player experience of the game.  That, however, is really not the developers fault.  This game iterates on the souls-like combat pretty heavily similar to games like Sekiro or Nioh.  I am disappointed to see people try to fit it into a Dark Souls box and then decry it for not encouraging Dark Souls playstyles.

This game is hard and expects a lot of you.  The game is made significantly easier for the player who experiments and tries to use all different tools to fight.  For instance, the game encourages you to use dodges and perfect blocks together, not just one or the other.  The combat paradigm is excellent and the bosses always feel fair while also feeling like they are actually trying to kill you.  The balance between those priorities is something that Dark Souls and souls-like games have always struggled with.  There are definitely things to fine-tune and the developers have done a good amount of work to do that.  Points of pain that the developers have been working on are good health pools on enemies (on this count I hope the developers don't nerf enemies too much), the weight of different equipment, and the scarcity of upgrade materials for weapons.

The story is extremely intriguing and incredibly unique.  I appreciate the passion that went into adapting the Pinocchio story.  This story, for me, far surpasses any souls-like story that comes to mind (I am almost certainly forgetting one).  Bloodborne is close perhaps.  The attention to detail and love put into the levels is quite enjoyable.  This is not an open world game, this is a linear story-driven souls experience with minimal backtracking so don't go in expecting the common souls-like open world.

Overall, the game is not perfect but the passion put into the story and the clear work put into the tools and bosses, making the combat feel complete, makes this a good recommend to anyone looking for a very difficult, heavily story-driven, souls-like game.  But please don't go into this game expecting to be good at it because you are good at dark souls or for it to play like dark souls.  Good job developers.  If you are picking it up, enjoy!

My time with Lies of P was exactly the intense and gratifying experience I hoped for. As one who holds Bloodborne in the highest regard as one of From Software’s finest achievements, I was absolutely enamored with Round 8 Studio’s unique, clever take on the formula. 

While the game broadly functions similarly to the best the souls-like genre has to offer, Lies of P‘s tweaks and refinements are so masterfully planned out and implemented that they make every moment of gameplay a pleasure. From the dopamine hits provided by exploring the labyrinthine level layouts, to the extreme delight of finally besting a challenging boss, there’s nary a moment of Lies of P‘s meaty campaign that feels wasted or unsatisfactory. With a post-credits teaser hinting at a second incredible twist on another literary classic lying in wait, the future looks bright for this new addition to the genre.

Lies of P, welcome to the top!

I honestly love the game. It is one of the few games that understands multiple play styles in souls-like games; don’t like parrying, dodge; don’t like dodging, parry. The game even has equipment which enables different play styles… I really enjoyed the boss fights too, some human bosses are difficult to read so they can be a bit frustrating… (Looking at you, R and L), but the game is beautifully made by people who really enjoy and love souls games, and it shows…

My only gripe is that NG+s are not very rewarding. You don’t get anything different except a some +1 amulets and higher ergo chunks… the fact that you can have multiple of the same weapon and amulets take multiple slots is also a small thing that bugs me… 

Overall, a beautiful game… must play and a worthy GotY nominee for me…

Lies of P is an amazing game that is not only better than any other Souls-like you've seen, but then also in many ways outperform FromSoft's own games.
Just technically the game looks great while also running amazingly well, almost never dropping any frames during all of my time playing the game. A constant and stable 144fps even on the highest possible graphic options. Which is something we will probably never see happen in a FromSoft game.

Aesthetically it's obviously inspired from Bloodborne, however the combat is more of a combination of Sekiro and Dark Souls 3, allowing decently fast movement and doging, along with a deflection mechanic that is similar to the parrying you can do in Sekiro. However the difference is that Lies of P deflection is much more precise and punishing, with a window so small, you basically have to press the block button a milisecond before the enemy's attack land on you. At first this will probably frustrate you quite a bit, but if you take the time to learn the timing of the attacks, the deflection system will become increadibly rewarding and leave you feeling like a god when you successfully pull them off.  
A small tip is that you can basically deflect anything in the game, including projectiles, the only exception being grab attacks. But if you are unsure whether you can deflect something, just try it and see what happens, you might get pleasantly surprised. 

Here are a few pros and cons with the game.
Pros:
- Good amount of enemy variety, all the way up to the end of the game. 
- Almost all of the bosses have amazing designs, while also being increadibly fun fights thanks to well animated and telegraphed attacks with a good variety of them.
- A weapon assembly system that gives huge amounts of customizability.
- Tons of QoL imporvements, such as allowing you to teleport from and to any stargazer you've found, right from the start of the game. Or showing you a red circle to indicate where to stand when performing a fatal attack on a staggered boss or enemy, avoiding the jankyness that can often be found in a FromSoft Souls title. 
- The music is fantastic. Especially the musical records that you can find troughout the game. 

Cons:
- The game is extremely linear. If you live for the exploration in FromSoft's games, you will unfortunately find very litte of that in this game. With there basically only being one substantial optional area that you can find and explore. Probably my biggest gripe with the game.
- The translation and voice acting isn't the best. There are a bunch of lines that have weird grammar or just straight up spelling mistakes. And the voice acting from certain characters absolutely lack proper direction, leading to awkward or stiff voice work. 
- The Lie system isn't the most fleshed out. It's nice that you can get different endings depending on your choices, but it would've been better with more direct consequences and more interesting dialogue. 

To round it all off. Lies of P is not only a great Souls-like, but also just a fantastic game in general that I implore you to check out if you've ever had any interest in these types of games. These developers certainly did their homework and should be supported.

After multiple playthroughs and obtaining all achievements I have to say... this game is a must play if you have any interest in souls-likes. Even if you've never played one I would still recommend this as a starting point. I absolutely love everything about this game from combat, to bosses, to world design, to music, literally every piece of this game is a work of art and executed flawlessly. Although it is very challenging in the first playthrough, the sense of progressing your skill as a player is stronger than even any Fromsoft game that I have played (aside from Sekiro). There is no cheesing your way through the game, there is no getting lucky to progress, you really need to just continue to learn and get better and should you decide to give new game plus a try it will be clear how much better you have become as you blow past the early game bosses that gave you such a hard time in the past. This game has become my comfort food and although I have done all there is to do I will continue to come back for new playthroughs for a long time, I truly cannot get enough of it. Huge congratulations to the developers and a huge thank you for pouring your heart into this masterpiece, it really shows. This very well be my favorite game I have ever played and I cannot wait to see what the DLC and sequel will bring us.

Very good Soulslike, others have gone into better detail than I could already. It plays well, looks great, sounds great, frustrates me endlessly but in a healthy way, fun exploration and worthwhile rewards, multiple endings, cool weapons, really cool and interesting enemies and bosses, extremely challenging (don't be afraid to use specters), a level up woman, memorable NPCs and sidequests (they're easy to follow in this one!), glowing creatures that drop weapon upgrade material, and some poison swamp type areas.

Despite all of these being characteristics this game shares with other soulslike game, this one is quite special and brings a different and unique experience that I'd recommend to anyone.

This is a unique and fun souls-like with a great environment and exciting gameplay. Easily the best souls-like I've played that wasn't made by fromsoft.

Its a good game, it really improves on a lot of simple QOL things that other soulslikes doesnt have and that is a huge win. In saying that it also uses new mechanics that are quite interesting and fun to work around with combat and area traversal.
The bosses are really good, the way that the design of some bosses has a lot of visual story-telling and lore information is really cool.
The fighting is fun and have great music as well as a uniqueness to every boss (that I've fought thus far) to make the combat shine.

Granted there are some things that I wouldn't consider perfect.... 
There are some VERY minor graphical errors (such as: when holding the starter greatsword, the blade clips through the character models head after finishing a block animation,
 like the whole blade noclips through all the cogs and gears in P's head). There has only been one audio clip missing of a massive safe smashing through the floor which was dead quiet in the game.

AFTER I FINISHED THE GAME:
I really enjoy how the challenges put in the New Game+ stage of the game really keep the game feeling fresh and very enjoyable!
All in all I highly recommend this game if you're up for a challenge.

They so blatantly tried to copy Bloodborne I think it merits being compared directly TO Bloodborne and that is a very bad thing for this game.

The fact they do NOT explain very well that using certain crystals for extra "souls" for leveling that drop from bosses will lock you out from being able to get their boss weapons is a JOKE.  You literally don't meet the guy that sells you their weapons until after the 4th or 5th boss and as all of us who play Souls games know by default IN souls games you use the dropped gems for leveling points.  But not in this stupidly designed game.  Nope.  When you kill a boss a gem drops that has nothing that distinguishes it at all from the other ones.  So you use it for extra souls and guess what?  You then don't have the gem to buy the damn weapon.  Patch this crap out.  The boss gems SHOULD NOT BE ABLE TO BE USED TO LEVELING POINTS.  

Seriously, this is a joke.  And guess what?  You can't play the bosses again.  That's right.  You have to either restart the entire game or you have to finish and get them in New Game+.

Take your negative review for that.

Knockdown.  STOP PUTTING THIS IN GAMES JUST TO FRUSTRATE THE PLAYER.  You will spend half the game getting knocked down.  The absolute best thing in the world is getting "stun-knocked" when an enemy does 4 knockdowns in a row and you literally cannot recover because you are locked into the stupid getting off the ground animation.  That is bad game design.  That is designed only to frustrate.  Bloodborne didn't have ANY of that crap.  It was about pure skill.

As for the game, it's OKAY.  It's not great and it should NEVER be mentioned in the same breath as Bloodborne.  Ever.  EVER.  It's not even close.  It has a dark gothic atmosphere.  That's it.

The enemy attacks are laughably unpredictable and my god the bosses.  The attacks are utterly ABSURD with unlimited stamina and attacks that can't be parried just spammed over and over.  

They rely HEAVILY on parry in this game.  That's not good because the parry system is TRASH.  The timing for it is utterly terrible.  It's just not fun to use this mechanic and before any idiot tells me to git gud - I have completed almost every souls game along with a Platinum in Bloodborne.  I'm not new to this.

Technically it's perfect.  ZERO crashes, ZERO issues.  Runs flawlessly.  This was a breath of fresh air.

While there isn't anything directly woke shoved down your throat the male protagonist who literally has a female face is enough to put this in the weird and completely unnecessary category.  Grow up devs.

This is a DECENT somewhat lengthy game that tried to copy Bloodborne.  Buy it on sale.

So up front: I bought this specifically after seeing review videos calling its difficulty "broken" due to "badly designed" dodge and parry mechanics—not because I'm a masochist, but because said videos showed footage of the videomakers playing poorly in ways entirely unrelated to their complaints. Poor positioning leading to getting mobbed, for example, would not be saved by having a few extra iframes on the dodge or a wider parry window. So I had to see for myself if it was as broken as they claimed.

Having played through it entirely twice and partially a third time, and racking up 100% achievement completion in around 40 hours, I really don't understand why anyone made such a fuss about this game's difficulty. It just...feels like a good Soulsborne game. An excellent one, in fact.

(With only a couple of exceptions. Looking at you, Jester Bot.)

The only explanation I can think of is too many people kept trying to play it "wrong." Trying to perfect guard everything like it's Sekiro is possible, but it's doing things the hard way. Trying to do Souls-style hit and run is fine, but makes things take a lot longer and is hard to do safely for the most part, so that's also doing things the hard way.

Lies of P definitely has its own rhythm, and if you try to play it like it's a different game, you're probably going to have a Bad Time. But that's to be expected. Playing Sekiro like it's Bloodborne will get you killed, and vice versa. Try not to carry preconceived notions of how the game "should" play going into it and approach it on its own terms.

That said: it's still very much a game for the Soulsborne crowd. If you haven't enjoyed those kinds of games before, this one isn't going to change your mind.

I highly recommend this game. This is the best souls-like game I have ever played; it has a very satisfying combat system and amazing bosses that you really need to learn in order to beat. Lots of great ideas in there too, such as the ability to combine weapon hilts and blades in order to make the perfect weapon for your play-style. Another great idea is with the healing item: as soon as you run out, it will begin to recharge by doing damage. This way, it never feels like you're out of the fight just because you healed one too many times, there is always room for a comeback.
